headline: Week in Pictures for Nov. 30
abstract: Subjects include sewage problems following Hurricane Sandy; residents returning to Ortley Beach, N.J.; and camels enjoying the Manhattan streets.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include sewage problems following Hurricane Sandy; residents returning to Ortley Beach, N.J.; and camels enjoying the Manhattan streets.

headline: Which Turkey is Healthiest?
abstract: Is it dangerous for Turkey to bring religion back, or is it necessary as it seeks to become a leader of the Muslim world? Will making the country’s leadership more reflective of the public risk the freedoms for women, artists and gays?
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — This is a mind bendingly beautiful city. It is poised between Europe and Asia, between the Western and Muslim worlds. It throbs with the fusion fashion, the beaty music, the oversized watches, the way-too-pricey cars that have become the telltale signs of an emerging economy in our globalizing era.

headline: Study Shows Possible Brain Damage Caused by Subconcussive Blows
abstract: A hockey concussion study published Friday in the journal Neurosurgical Focus includes in its findings an intriguing element – possible radiological evidence of brain trauma caused by subconcussive blows.
lead_paragraph: A hockey concussion study published Friday in the journal Neurosurgical Focus includes in its findings an intriguing element – possible radiological evidence of brain trauma caused by subconcussive blows.

headline: Iranian Channel Reports Bomb Outside Its Office in Damascus
abstract: Press TV says a bomb destroyed six vehicles, including a satellite news truck near the broadcaster’s office in Damascus.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s state-owned satellite channel Press TV reports that a bomb destroyed six vehicles, including a satellite news truck near the broadcaster’s office in Damascus early on Friday.

headline: On Our Radar: Ice Melt Accelerates in Arctic and Antarctic
abstract: A sampling of environmental news for Friday, November 30.
lead_paragraph: A new study shows that the ice sheets covering the land in Greenland and Antarctica are melting at three times the rate they were in the 1990s. A Fox Business News host, Stuart Varney, who previously called the science of climate change a “scientific conspiracy,” called the new evidence “hard and authoritative.” [NASA/Jet Propulsion Laboratory] [Media Matters]

headline: Apple Rolls Out a Cleaner iTunes
abstract: Apple has introduced the free iTunes 11 for download. It’s still the front end for music, videos and iGadgets, and its features and personality are much the same. But the design has been overhauled — deeply, controversially, but, in general, successfully.
lead_paragraph: Well, it finally happened: Apple got around to fixing iTunes.

headline: The Monster of Monticello
abstract: The ugly truth about our slave-owning third president.
lead_paragraph: Durham, N.C.

headline: Chrysler Museum Is Shutting Down
abstract: The museum’s collection will be purchased by the Chrysler Group.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler said it would close the museum located in its headquarters in Auburn Hills, Mich., at the end of the year.

headline: Notes on Epistemic Closure
abstract: What they didn’t know hurt them.
lead_paragraph: I gather that philosophers are upset over the use of the term “epistemic closure” to refer to the closing of the movement conservative mind – that’s not what they mean by the term. Never mind: that’s the term everyone is using. And recent reports are a reminder of just how closed that mind really is.

headline: Perot Museum of Nature and Science
abstract: The museum, with 180,000 square feet of space and 11 exhibition halls, opens in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: The museum, with 180,000 square feet of space and 11 exhibition halls, opens in Dallas.

headline: Ford Recalling 73,000 Escapes and 15,800 Fusions
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker cites a fire hazard in its 1.6-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engines.
lead_paragraph: For the third time this year, Ford is recalling vehicles with its 1.6-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engines, citing a fire hazard.

headline: Bursting With Science, Some of It Unsettling
abstract: The Perot Museum of Nature and Science, with 180,000 square feet of space and 11 exhibition halls, is opening in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — When you approach the new $185 million Perot Museum of Nature and Science, which opens here on Saturday, it is clear that you are not being led into a serene temple, where a harmonious cosmic order is going to be revealed. The building is alluring but unsettling. Is the museum’s 10-story concrete cube splitting apart or being pieced together? Is it being held intact by an enormous brace — a transparent protrusion on the cube’s side containing a 54-foot-long escalator — or is that a destabilizing gash that pierces the building’s body?

headline: House Votes to Ease Visa Limits for Some Foreign Workers
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas']
abstract: A measure that passed with mostly Republican support — many Democrats found it too narrow — previewed a fight over how far Congress should go in changing immigration laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided House of Representatives voted Friday to ease visa restrictions for a limited pool of foreign workers, previewing a fight over how far Congress should go in changing the country’s immigration laws.

headline: Friday Night Music: Decemberists
abstract: Less is more.
lead_paragraph: On paper I should be a big Decemberists fan; lists of “if you like this (Arcade Fire, etc.) you should like that” always point me to their stuff. Somehow, however, their music never grabbed me — not an active dislike, just not clicking for some reason.

headline: A Calling Card in Shards of Glass
abstract: Six burglaries in the West Village last month have been attributed to the same person, the police said, some involving smashed windows and an improvised key.
lead_paragraph: A waiter at Moustache, a popular Middle Eastern restaurant on Bedford Street, pointed at a spot on the floor and said: “It was there. The police took it.”

headline: When Counterculture of 1971 Got Its Hands on Video
abstract: An exhibition from the archives of Electronic Arts Intermix, now at at Dia:Beacon in Beacon, N.Y., showcases an era when both the politics and the medium were radical.
lead_paragraph: BEACON, N.Y. — Nineteen seventy-one was an eventful year in this country: Half a million people marched on Washington to protest the Vietnam War; riots broke out at Attica prison in upstate New York; the Supreme Court ruled unanimously in favor of busing to achieve racial desegregation in schools; and The New York Times started publishing the Pentagon Papers, detailing a history of American political and military involvement in Vietnam. It is also the year Electronic Arts Intermix (EAI) was founded in New York to support “moving-image” art, which, as shown by the 23 films and single-channel videos in “Circa 1971: Early Video and Film from the EAI Archive” at Dia:Beacon in Beacon, N.Y., was closely aligned with the politics and ethos of that moment.

headline: Moves of a New Breed, in a Habitat of Its Own
abstract: Deborah Hay’s “As Holy Sites Go/duet,” part of the Danspace Judson Now series, was performed at St. Mark’s Church on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: To watch the two dancers of Deborah Hay’s “As Holy Sites Go/duet” at St. Mark’s Church is like observing members of a new species, with plenty of animal characteristics. Much of what Jeanine Durning and Ros Warby do is odd, idiosyncratic and private, but they’re so motivated and strangely coherent that the realm they make onstage is large and satisfying. We watch like anthropologists, anxious not to disturb.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Piecework
abstract: On the Street: The dash of black leather sleeves mixed with a cloth coat or jacket is a new fashion expression.
lead_paragraph: On the Street: The dash of black leather sleeves mixed with a cloth coat or jacket is a new fashion expression.

headline: Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs
abstract: Winners of the three-day event in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The winners of the three-day Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs here on Thursday evening were John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla., and Brian Platnick of Evanston, Ill. They finished less than a quarter of a board ahead of Eric Greco of Wynnewood, Pa., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas. Those two pairs, with Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas and Brad Moss of Denver, won the 2010 Rosenblum Cup world team title and Spingold Knockout Teams.

headline: Lopez’s Right Foot Is Not Hurt Badly. Really.
abstract: The Nets insist that, this time, the injury to Brook Lopez’s right foot truly is minor.
lead_paragraph: Brook Lopez’s right foot has become a source of endless stress and curiosity for anyone following the Nets and, for that matter, anyone employed by them. Their entire season could hinge on the health of his fifth metatarsal — the bone that fractured last December and knocked him out for nearly the entire 2011-12 season.

headline: College Football Matchups
abstract: Only a handful of college football games are left before bowl season begins, including several conference championships. But one towers above them all.
lead_paragraph: Boy, that went fast, didn’t it? The college football regular season is all but over, with just a handful of games left before bowl season begins, including several conference championships. One towers above them all.

headline: State Secret Revealed: Mitterrand as a Doting Father
abstract: Mazarine Pingeot, the daughter of François Mitterrand and Anne Pingeot, his longtime mistress, has written a diary that includes her memories of Mr. Mitterrand as an attentive and doting father.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — SHE would sneak into the Élysée Palace to see her father, the president of France, through a back door that led directly to his private apartments. On winter days, they dined together in the library, by the fireplace.

headline: New View from Inside Fukushima: Chaos and Uncertainty
abstract: While the plant owner made calm statements, videotapes of calls between the plant and company headquarters show a more dire picture.
lead_paragraph: Even in the early days of the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in March of last year, as the reactors spiraled out of control, the terse statements issued by the operator felt like an exercise in denial. Radiation readings were “higher than the ordinary level” (about 100 times higher), and a “loud noise and white smoke” had hit the No. 4 reactor (a possible hydrogen explosion).

headline: On Religion: A Search for God Through Bluegrass and Klezmer
abstract: Andy Statman, considered a musical visionary for his ability to traverse genres and defy rules, has been able to square his circle of religion and music by tracing klezmer back to Hasidic melodies.
lead_paragraph: Andy Statman stood in the narrow basement of an Orthodox synagogue improbably wedged among the boîtes and boutiques of Greenwich Village. He wore a plain blue suit and white shirt, and from his waist hung tzitzit, the fringes meant to remind an observant Jew of the 613 commandments. Twisting together the pieces of his clarinet, he ran through a glissando that seemed to corkscrew through the air.

headline: Traditional Flavors of Havana Made New
abstract: At the Cuban Restaurant and Bar in Hoboken, the walls radiate a flattering glow and the menu features the chef’s updated versions of the dishes on which he was raised.
lead_paragraph: The Colada Cuban, one of a dozen cocktails served at the Cuban Restaurant and Bar, sets the tone for the entire evening: it’s sweet, rich, vibrant and a little intoxicating — a real party. It and other cocktails (a classic basic mojito is only $5 on Mondays) introduce the traditional Cuban dishes that follow. Alexis Lahens, the chef, takes these old dishes and makes them seem new. Wait until you try his rice and beans.

headline: Beckham Wrapping Up American Mission With M.L.S.
abstract: As David Beckham prepares to play what he has said will be his last game for the L.A. Galaxy in the M.L.S. Cup on Saturday, his footprints are visible all over soccer in the United States.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — When David Beckham signed with Major League Soccer in 2007, he did not want merely to win titles or sell Los Angeles Galaxy jerseys: he wanted to sell soccer to the United States.

headline: Strike Shuts Down Los Angeles and Long Beach Ports
abstract: A strike dragged into its fourth day as 600 clerical workers walked off the job and colleagues from the International Longshore and Warehouse Union refused to cross picket lines.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The nation’s busiest port complex remained largely shut down here on Friday as a port workers’ strike dragged into its fourth day, raising fears that the work stoppage could hurt the region’s economy.

headline: Statue of Liberty Was Unscathed by Hurricane, but Its Home Took a Beating
abstract: Water covered most of Liberty Island during Hurricane Sandy, but never reached the Statue of Liberty’s base. Even so, it could be months before the site reopens.
lead_paragraph: Add the following to the long list of items that took a beating when Hurricane Sandy blasted by: a dock that was refashioned in the twisting, turning shape of a water slide; a sea wall that started to pull away from the shoreline; and a fence that took on a gaptoothed look when long sections were extracted.

headline: Clip: ‘Only the Young’
abstract: A scene from the documentary "Only the Young," from Jason Tippet and Elizabeth Mims.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary "Only the Young," from Jason Tippet and Elizabeth Mims.

headline: Solar Industry Borrows a Page, and a Party, From Tupperware
abstract: Solar parties, like Tupperware parties, are being used by solar companies to sell their products to neighbors of homeowners who have installed the arrays.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — The neighbors had gathered on the patio of a sun-baked ranch here, eager to hear the party’s hosts talk about their products and how they could enhance their lives. But in place of the timeworn arrangement of plastic storage containers or cosmetics on the coffee table, the couple was showing off an array of a different sort: the 32 solar panels on the roof.

headline: Battle Between Argentine Media Empire and President Heats Up Over a Law
abstract: A law championed by President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner will force Clarín to divest most of its lucrative cable operations starting in December.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — In her battle with Argentina’s largest media empire, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner has raided its headquarters with 200 tax agents. Her supporters have accused the conglomerate’s largest shareholder of adopting two children thought to have been abducted from women killed during Argentina’s “dirty war.” Her vice president has disparaged its chief executive, Héctor Magnetto, as a “Mafioso.”

headline: Simpler Taxes Now, Growth Later
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Economists say the talk in Washington of raising additional tax revenue and cutting spending would most likely depress growth in the short term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers consider rolling back many of the $1 trillion a year in tax breaks now doled out to businesses and individuals, some are promising that streamlining the tax code will not only raise revenue, but also spur economic growth.

headline: After Lowest Point, Murray Nears Peak
abstract: Georgia quarterback Aaron Murray rebounded from a crushing loss and news of his father’s cancer to lead the Bulldogs to the SEC title game against Alabama on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The first weekend of October was rather grim for Georgia quarterback Aaron Murray. The Bulldogs lost to a division rival in a crucial game, fans held him responsible for the defeat in a very personal way, and then he found out his father was seriously ill.

headline: Aid Changes Raise Issue of Diversity at Colleges
abstract: Wesleyan and other highly selective colleges are changing their financial aid formulas, raising concerns about how campus diversity — both economic and racial — might be affected.
lead_paragraph: College and university endowments have recovered most of the losses they sustained during the recession, now that the economy has begun to grow. Yet as this year’s high school seniors begin to fill out applications and aid forms, a number of prestigious smaller colleges are straining to meet students’ financial needs. To bridge the gap, some colleges have begun revising their financial aid formulas, raising concerns about how campus diversity — both economic and racial — might be affected.

headline: A Salute to the Southwest
abstract: The first impression of Truck, a restaurant in Bedford, left much to be desired (fumbling servers, bad timing and lukewarm food), but a return trip was a successful attempt at redemption.
lead_paragraph: AS customers leave Truck, a New Mexican-themed restaurant in what was once a truck stop on Route 22 in Bedford, they are invited to put suggestions into a big tin can nailed to the wall near the front door. On a recent, raucous Saturday night, after four of us had survived a dinner that could only be characterized as a fiasco, we grumbled that the oversize tin could not begin to hold our sentiments.

headline: Chairman of Utility Under Fire Resigns
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Howard E. Steinberg’s exit is the latest in an exodus from the Long Island Power Authority, which has faced harsh criticism for its response to Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Long Island Power Authority resigned on Friday, continuing an exodus from the troubled agency, which has received harsh criticism from customers and elected officials for its response to Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Wright Stays a Met, for Better or Worse
abstract: David Wright and the Mets agreed to a new deal Friday, but now a struggling team that has been forced to downsize needs to find a way to build around him.
lead_paragraph: It is a quirk of team history, or maybe just the natural cycle of baseball, that almost every significant Mets player before this era had at least one shot at the World Series. From 1969 to 1973 to 1986 to 2000, the Mets spaced their pennants rather nicely, so when you picture almost any Met of consequence, you can remember him playing on the ultimate stage.

headline: Surprising Pleasures, With Simple Titles
abstract: The chef-owner of the Chelsea restaurant, which opened in mid-July, said he strives to offer “food that’s a little bit edgy.”
lead_paragraph: MY major regret about the Chelsea, a new restaurant in Fairfield, is that it’s not closer to my home. It’s the kind of informal neighborhood place that you’d love to stop by before or after the movies, or any time in between. I can’t think of many things more gratifying than sitting in one of the summery lime green chairs in the “Greenhouse” room, even in the cold of winter, and devouring one of the generous, well-made dishes on the menu, as sunshine danced through the windows.

headline: The Season for Shellfish
abstract: Scallops, clams and oysters are the stars of the Greenport Shellabration and restaurant walk on Dec. 8 and 9, but beer and wine will also be on hand.
lead_paragraph: Local corn and tomatoes are only a memory at this time of year, but a different kind of Long Island bounty — scallops, clams and oysters — is in season for the Greenport Shellabration and restaurant walk on Dec. 8 and 9.

headline: New U.N. Status for Palestinians Could Open Door for Claims of Israeli War Crimes
keywords: ['International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Working with the International Criminal Court could also make Palestinians vulnerable to Israeli counterclaims, experts say.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Palestinian Authority has tried to have its accusations of Israeli war crimes investigated by the International Criminal Court, only to see its request go nowhere because the Palestinian territories were not recognized as a state.

headline: Small Employers Weigh Impact of Providing Health Insurance
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Businesses like restaurants and hotels that rely heavily on low-income workers are trying to decide how to change their business models for the new health care law.
lead_paragraph: Like many franchisees, Robert U. Mayfield, who owns five Dairy Queens in and around Austin, Tex., is always eager to expand and — no surprise — has had his eyes on opening a sixth DQ. But he said concerns about the new federal health care law had persuaded him to hold off.

headline: Spurs Fined $250,000 for Resting 4 Regulars
abstract: Tim Duncan, Tony Parker, Manu Ginobili and Danny Green did not go with the Spurs to Miami for a nationally televised game Thursday. On Friday, Commissioner David Stern showed his displeasure with the move.
lead_paragraph: When the San Antonio Spurs held out four regulars Thursday night, Coach Gregg Popovich framed it as an investment in the future: Resting Tim Duncan, Tony Parker, Manu Ginobili and Danny Green now will presumably pay dividends next spring.

headline: ‘Last Best Hope’
abstract: As a speech, Lincoln’s second Annual Message to Congress contained glimpses of what was to come at Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 1, 1862, Abraham Lincoln submitted his second Annual Message to Congress, in fulfillment of his duties, as spelled out in Article II, section 3 of the Constitution. (“He shall from time to time give to Congress information of the State of the Union and recommend to their Consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient.”) From that line comes the modern phrase “State of the Union,” to describe a ritual now performed, more publicly, in January. At the time, the message was a written effort, though it was read aloud by the secretary of the Senate. You can see a copy of it here.

headline: Striking Setting for Food of Uzbekistan
abstract: Kazan Authentic Central Asian Cuisine, a beautiful storefront restaurant in Port Washington, offers a menu that also has elements of Russian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: THE restaurant Kazan Authentic Central Asian Cuisine, which opened in Port Washington in October, is not your run-of-the-mill suburban spot. As one of my fellow diners put it: “Wow, I’ve never had Uzbek food before.”

headline: Isner Drops Coach
abstract: John Isner, who at No. 14 is the top-ranked American, has parted ways which Craig Boynton, who had served as his coach since March 2009.
lead_paragraph: John Isner, who at No. 14 is the top-ranked American, has parted ways which Craig Boynton, who had served as his coach since March 2009. Isner’s ranking peaked at a career-high No. 9 in April, but had slipped by the end of the season after first-week losses at the last three Grand Slam events.

headline: U.S. to Pay $3.8 Billion for Next Lot of F-35 Jets
abstract: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle for 32 of the jets after a year of tense negotiations to lower costs.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle on Friday on the price of a fifth batch of F-35 fighter jets after a year of tense negotiations over how to lower costs.

headline: Ultimate Culpability for a Mine Disaster
abstract: Federal prosecutors are wise to pursue the path of corporate responsibility in their investigation of the West Virginia mine disaster.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have signaled a bold new move up the corporate ladder in their investigation of the Upper Big Branch mine disaster that killed 29 West Virginia coal miners in 2010. A former executive of Massey Energy, which ran the mine but has since been acquired by another company, has been accused of criminal conspiracy in hiding lethal safety violations at Massey mines and tipping off mine supervisors to spot inspections.

headline: Wizards Try to Put Worst Start, and Jokes, Behind Them
abstract: As the Knicks worked to extend their unbeaten streak Friday, the Wizards tried to improve their 1-12 record heading into the game.
lead_paragraph: The first month of the N.B.A. season has been so miserable for the Washington Wizards that guard A. J. Price has been forced to alter his television viewing habits.

headline: Liberty Island Remains Battered After Storm
abstract: A lot of work has been done to clean up Liberty Island since it was flooded during Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: A lot of work has been done to clean up Liberty Island since it was flooded during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: In Latest Campaign, Obama Takes Deficit Battle to the Public
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Visiting a toy factory in Hatfield, Pa., President Obama used a campaign tactic to turn up the heat on Republicans as he promotes his tax plan.
lead_paragraph: HATFIELD, Pa. — The blue “Forward.” signs with the lonely period were gone. But U2’s “City of Blinding Lights” once again blared over the loudspeakers, and some in the audience broke into a chant of “fired up, ready to go!”

headline: Deserving or Not, Rutgers Emerges as a Winner
abstract: The Scarlet Knights are ending on a dim note, but brighter days — at least financially — await the Big Ten.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — On Rutgers’s first play from scrimmage Thursday night, receiver Brandon Coleman streaked down the sideline, away from Louisville’s pursuit, and might have run all the way to Columbus, Ohio, had the end zone not been compensatory enough for the moment.

headline: Rating a Mayor of New York
abstract: Books on former Mayor David N. Dinkins, biking in the boroughs and the evolution of mass transit in the city.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have an uncanny knack for electing the right mayoral candidate at the right time. In the racially charged urban climate agitated by a bombastic Edward I. Koch, the balm-throwing David N. Dinkins presented himself in 1989 as an ideal alternative: a black politician campaigning for conciliation.

headline: What’s Missing in the Latest Greek Bailout
abstract: The deal offers temporary debt relief, but no way forward for a shrinking economy.
lead_paragraph: The new Greek bailout deal agreed to Tuesday by euro zone finance ministers and the International Monetary Fund is a clear improvement over earlier deals. It recognizes that Greece’s current and projected ratios of debt to output are unsustainable. It prescribes useful steps to lower that ratio, including lower interest rates on loans from Greece’s European partners, longer bond maturities and a plan for Athens to buy back and retire some of its heavily discounted bonds.

headline: Push to Prosecute Drowsy Driving May Hinge on Its Definition
keywords: ['Fatigue', 'Sleep', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Buses']
abstract: The trial of a bus driver accused of being too sleepy to drive when his bus crashed, killing 15 people, is among an increasing number of cases being pursued against sleepy drivers involved in crashes.
lead_paragraph: Roadside signs around the country have long warned drivers not to doze off behind the wheel with gentle catchphrases like “You Snooze, You Lose” and “Drive Alert, Arrive Alive.”

headline: Health Insurers Will Be Charged to Use New Exchanges
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Obama administration said Friday that it would charge insurance companies for selling health insurance to millions of Americans in new online markets run by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would charge insurance companies for the privilege of selling health insurance to millions of Americans in new online markets run by the federal government.

headline: In South Africa, Lethal Battles for Even Smallest of Political Posts
abstract: Dozens of officials, including ward councilors, party leaders and mayors, have been killed in what has become a desperate, deadly struggle for power and its spoils.
lead_paragraph: OSHABENI, South Africa — It was, by all accounts, an ordinary small-town political meeting. The leaders of the local branch of the African National Congress gathered in September at a convent here to discuss candidates for a newly vacated seat on the ward council, the lowest-level elected position in South Africa.

headline: Retail Frenzy: Prices on the Web Change Hourly
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Retail price wars online have entered a new era of speed and precision, creating a confusing landscape for shoppers in which prices leap and plummet on short notice.
lead_paragraph: The day before Thanksgiving, Amazon was offering a discounted price of $49.96 on a popular Xbox game, the same price as Walmart and 3 cents lower than Target.

headline: Model Convicted of Killing His Lover
abstract: Visiting from Portugal, Renato Seabra, 23, killed his companion, the journalist Carlos Castro, in a Times Square hotel room in 2011.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Friday convicted a former Portuguese model of murdering his journalist lover in a Times Square hotel last year, just after the victim had ended their relationship.

headline: Shotgun Report at Center of Florida Shooting Case
abstract: Michael Dunn, who is accused of fatally shooting a Jacksonville teenager, says a shotgun was pointed at him, but the police have not found such a weapon.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The case against Michael Dunn, a software developer charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of a 17-year-old Jacksonville student at a convenience store, hinges on a shotgun.

headline: Young Men Finding Their Way
abstract: Over the course of the 2012-13 Neediest Cases campaign, The New York Times is catching up on some of the people who were profiled in recent campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of the 2012-13 Neediest Cases campaign, The New York Times is catching up on some of the people who were profiled in recent campaigns.

headline: Seeing Threat, British Press Hails Cameron as Defender
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Britain’s squabbling newspapers have found common ground: praise for Prime Minister David Cameron’s opposition to a  proposal for a new system of parliamentary-backed regulation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is hard to find much common ground among Britain’s squabbling, competing newspapers. Not only do they naturally mistrust one another, but they also tend to divide along party lines, so that The Daily Telegraph, for instance, is generally pro-Tory, while The Guardian is generally pro-Labour. (The papers owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation support whomever Mr. Murdoch supports.)

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 1, 2012.
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Dec. 1, 2012.
lead_paragraph: People are not going to hug the president right now. They are waiting for him to take

headline: The Ice Queen of Rock Center
abstract: Rikki Samuels, who teaches amateurs and a Rockette or two the moves to master Rockefeller Center’s ice-skating rink, loves the ice so much she even got married there.
lead_paragraph: Rikki Samuels sat on a hard bench in the cramped skate house at the  Rink at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan and pulled on her well-worn ice skates.

headline: Mayor Says Rebuilt Boardwalk in Rockaways Won’t Be Wooden
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that the Rockaway Boardwalk will be rebuilt, although it may not be done before next summer, and concrete will be used instead of hardwood.
lead_paragraph: The decree was unsentimental, no apologies to first kisses, bike rides or any other summer snapshot. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the Boardwalk in the Rockaways would be rebuilt — but without hardwood, and perhaps not before next summer.

headline: Basketball Players’ Night Off Makes a Stand for Sitting Out
abstract: Commissioner David Stern fined the Spurs $250,000 for sending home four of their starters before a game in Miami, raising a significant question for bosses everywhere: when is it unreasonable to give someone the day off?
lead_paragraph: And to think what would have happened if they were given a three-day weekend.

headline: The Bad Luck of Winning
abstract: Two lucky ticket-holders struck it rich this week in the Powerball. Why do so many lottery winners wind up broke?
lead_paragraph: “We’re normal human beings,” said Cindy Hill on Friday, moments after she and her husband, Mark, posed with an oversized check for $293,750,000. “We’re common,” she added. “We just have more money.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Cuomo Plans Trip to Washington to Press for Disaster Aid
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is planning to travel to Capitol Hill on Monday to seek nearly $33 billion to pay for storm cleanup and billions more to prepare for future storms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to build support for billions of dollars in federal aid to help New York recover from Hurricane Sandy’s devastation, is planning to travel to Washington on Monday, according to administration officials.

headline: For Syria’s Rebel Movement, Skype Is a Useful and Increasingly Dangerous Tool
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Computers and the Internet']

abstract: When the war against Al Qaeda winds down, the responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of the group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies.

abstract: On Fifth Avenue, department stores and boutiques sparkle through the holidays with extravagant window displays.

Augustus Saint-Gaudens’s gilded statue of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman leads the charge downtown from the park’s Grand Army Plaza to the avenue’s department stores and boutiques, which sparkle through the holidays with extravagant window displays. Like so much in this neighborhood, the tradition dates to the golden days of the early 20th century.

headline: To Save Congo, Let It Fall Apart
abstract: Congo isn’t too big to fail; it’s too big to succeed. Rather than striving to hold it together, we should let it break up.
lead_paragraph: THE Democratic Republic of Congo, which erupted in violence again earlier this month, ought to be one of the richest countries in the world. Its immense mineral reserves are currently valued by some estimates at more than $24 trillion and include 30 percent of the world’s diamond reserves; vast amounts of cobalt, copper and gold; and 70 percent of the world’s coltan, which is used in electronic devices. Yet the most recent edition of the United Nations Development Program’s Human Development Index ranked Congo last among the 187 countries and territories included in the survey.

headline: Half of the Nets’ Core Four Provide Enough for a Win
abstract: While Brook Lopez nursed an ankle injury and Deron Williams had a subpar game, another Nets pair led them to victory over the Magic on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Gerald Wallace stayed behind to put up some extra shots after the shootaround on Friday morning, and Joe Johnson continued to work himself into form. The work paid off Friday night. With plenty of open looks from behind the 3-point arc, Wallace and Johnson combined for seven 3-pointers and 42 points as the Nets rode the quieter half of their so-called Core Four to a 98-86 victory over the Magic.

headline: ‘Mayor of Strange Places’
abstract: Paul Hoffman, chief executive of the Liberty Science Center, takes off on explorations on the weekends, winning back mayorships on the mobile check-in service Foursquare along the way.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take a science expert to figure out that Sundays are good for walking around and eating, but if it did, Paul Hoffman might be the man for the job. Mr. Hoffman, 56, who last fall became the president and chief executive of the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, has run Discover magazine and published 11 books; he is also a partner in the restaurant Rucola, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and an investor in several food start-ups. He lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, sometimes with his son, Alex, 15.

abstract: It is necessary to look for ways to raise the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad and encourage a stable postwar Syria without arming the rebels.
lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels are making headway against President Bashar al-Assad. In recent weeks, they have seized several military bases and shot down military aircraft, reportedly with shoulder-fired missiles, but there is no end in sight to the war. More than 40,000 Syrians have been killed, 2.5 million are now displaced and more than 600,000 are refugees in Turkey, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon.

Mike Ramsey won an N.C.A.A. championship with the Gophers in 1979 and an Olympic gold medal in 1980, both under Coach Herb Brooks, before embarking on a lengthy career as an N.H.L. defenseman and assistant coach. Phil Kessel, the Toronto Maple Leafs star, used one season at Minnesota in 2005-6 as the jumping-off point for his N.H.L. career.

lead_paragraph: FROM his earliest days as a graduate student, Sudhir Venkatesh did things differently. He came to sociology by way of math, not by the social sciences. He was an Indian-American Deadhead from Southern California who wore a ponytail and tie-dyed shirts. He stuck out.

headline: Storm Charity: 15% of What?
abstract: In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, businesses have gone into overdrive on “cause marketing,” tapping charitable impulses while advancing their own interests, occasionally to unseemly effect.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, Jerry Welsh, an executive vice president at American Express, observed from his Lower Manhattan office that the Statue of Liberty was undergoing a major renovation. Within a short time, the company inaugurated an advertising campaign promoting its interest in the project: For every new credit card application, American Express would donate one dollar to the statue’s restoration; for every transaction, it would contribute one penny. Eventually, the effort raised $1.7 million. As Mara Einstein, a professor of marketing at Queens College, explains in her recent book, “Compassion Inc: How Corporate America Blurs the Lines Between What We Buy, Who We Are and Those We Help,” this was essentially the beginning of what is known as cause marketing.

headline: Help for a Troubled Steel Plant in Italy
keywords: ['Steel and Iron', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The government approved an emergency measure to allow the Ilva plant to continue its operations, provided the company invests about $3.9 billion to modernize the plant to meet environmental standards.
lead_paragraph: The government approved an emergency measure on Friday to allow the Ilva steel plant in the southern city of Taranto to continue its operations, provided the company invests about $3.9 billion to modernize the plant to meet environmental standards. The case, which pits health concerns against the need to protect 20,000 jobs in heavy industry, has tested the government of Prime Minister Mario Monti, which estimated that the economy would suffer losses of $10.4 billion a year if the plant closed. Mr. Monti, above, said the government needed to safeguard both public health and jobs as the plant carried out its cleanup. On Monday a court ordered the seizure of parts of the plant as a criminal investigation looked into claims of environmental damages caused by the plant’s emissions. Some studies have found that cancer rates around the steel plant, Europe’s largest, are significantly higher than elsewhere in Italy. Ilva had said that the investigation would force it to close the plant. An independent monitor will supervise Ilva’s plan to improve its technology.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) PROJECT X (2012) After Thomas (Thomas Mann), an unpopular high school student, is left unsupervised for the weekend, his friend Costa (Oliver Cooper, above left, with Mr. Mann, center, and Jonathan Danile Brown) sees it as an opportunity to give an over-the-top birthday party that will inaugurate them and their pal J. B. (Mr. Brown) into the realm of the cool kids. The result is pure chaos. “Nima Nourizadeh, the director, puts three relative unknowns in the central roles, and it pays off, especially with Oliver Cooper, who gives Costa a mischievous likability that anchors the enterprise,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Also smart: the boys bring along a video geek (Dax Flame) to film the whole thing, which gives Mr. Nourizadeh a lot of viewpoint options. He also has assorted cameras in the midst of the party, a funny script and some skilled editors cutting it all together. The ‘Animal House’ of the iPhone generation? Could be. Pretty enjoyable for parents too.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 1
abstract: News, arts and sports from today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS For much of her youth, Mazarine Pingeot, daughter of the late French president François Mitterrand and his mistress, was a state secret. She would sneak into the Élysée Palace through a back door that led directly to Mr. Mitterand’s private apartments; when she got a bicycle, bodyguards followed her on bicycles, too. Now 37, Ms. Pingeot, an author and philosophy professor, has published “Bon Petit Soldat” (Good Little Soldier), a diary that includes memories of that unusual childhood. “Being unable to share a secret makes this secret very heavy,” she tells Maïa de la Baume. “You protect it rather than protecting yourself.”

headline: Against Willful Denseness, The Gods Themselves Contend In Vain
abstract: What is it about zero that you don’t understand?
lead_paragraph: From the very beginning of the Lesser Depression, the central principle for understanding macroeconomic policy has been that everything is different when you’re in a liquidity trap. In particular, the whole case for fiscal stimulus and against austerity rests on the proposition that with interest rates up against the zero lower bound, the central bank can neither achieve full employment on its own nor offset the contractionary effect of spending cuts or tax hikes.

headline: Young Filmmakers, Young Subjects
abstract: The young documentarians behind “Only the Young” and “Tchoupitoulas” tell the tales of others, as well as their own.
lead_paragraph: IT all started at a skate park in Santa Clarita, Calif., in the summer of 2010. The spot was just a few miles from the California Institute of the Arts, from which the filmmakers Jason Tippet and Elizabeth Mims had recently graduated, and mere blocks from where Mr. Tippet had grown up, a regular knockabout at the park just a few years earlier. Up skated 17-year-old Garrison Saenz and 16-year-old Kevin Conway, asking questions and bickering as if no one were watching, a teenage comic duo in the flesh.

headline: With Help, Afghan Survivor of ‘Honor Killing’ Inches Back
abstract: The story of Gul Meena, who was accused of adultery and struck by an ax 15 times, is also the story of a society struggling with shifting attitudes about women.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — It is doubly miraculous that the young woman named Gul Meena is alive. After she was struck by an ax 15 times, slashing her head and face so deeply that it exposed her brain, she held on long enough to reach medical care and then, despite the limitations of what the doctors could do, clung to life.

headline: Morris Turns Heads That Griffin III Hasn’t

As McCray paused, wide receiver Aldrick Robinson slipped behind him and Griffin, the Redskins’ Heisman-winning first-round draft choice, stepped back into the pocket and flipped the ball 60 yards. headline: Poor Women and Children Faced With Fiscal Threat

abstract: Cuts to nondiscretionary public spending, whether bargained for or automatic, will disproportionately affect women and children living in poverty.
lead_paragraph: As negotiating and posturing over the looming “fiscal cliff” continues, one phrase we hear less often than we should is “nondefense discretionary spending.” A boring string of words if ever there was one, it’s a category of spending that will play a role whether we go off the cliff or if we avoid it with a grand bargain, since it stands to see drastic cuts either way. Those abstract, boring words represent very concrete assistance to women and children living in poverty. A significant reduction in governmental spending in that opaquely named category will disproportionately affect programs they rely on.

headline: ‘Twilight’ and ‘Lincoln’ Thrive at Box Office
abstract: But “Killing Them Softly,” a drama starring Brad Pitt and released by the Weinstein Company, struggled in its opening weekend at theaters.
lead_paragraph: Post-Thanksgiving audiences dined on cinematic leftovers over the weekend. “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 2” (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie at North American theaters, taking in an estimated $17.4 million, for a three-week total of about $254.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. “Skyfall” (Sony) was a close second, taking in $17 million, for a four-week total of about $246 million. Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln” (Disney) placed third, with ticket sales of $13.51 million; “Lincoln,” a leading Oscar contender, is turning into a runaway hit, at least as far as serious historical dramas go these days, taking in about $83.7 million over four weeks. DreamWorks Animation’s struggling “Rise of the Guardians” (Paramount) was a whisker behind, taking in an estimated $13 million, for a two-week total of $48.9 million. Another Oscar contender, Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi” (20th Century Fox), was fifth, selling about $12 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $48.4 million. The weekend included one notable flop: “Killing Them Softly,” a drama starring Brad Pitt and released by the Weinstein Company (with financing from the Oracle heiress Megan Ellison), arrived in seventh place, taking in about $7 million.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) BABY PEGGY, THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM (2012) Peggy-Jean Montgomery, left, a daughter of a professional cowboy turned stuntman who moved his family to Hollywood, was 19 months old when she captured the attention of the director Fred Fishbach. Impressed by her plucky demeanor and good behavior, he cast her in some of Century Studios’ comedy shorts, sometimes opposite Brownie the Wonder Dog. As the third great child star of the silent era, after Baby Marie and Jackie Coogan, Peggy made about 150 shorts in all, working eight-hour days, six days a week, and performing stunts like being held underwater and escaping a burning building. In 1923 she earned the nickname Million-Dollar Baby when Universal lured her away from Century with the chance to make feature films for $1.5 million annually. But soon her father and the producer Sol Lesser argued about her salary, and Lesser not only fired her but also blackballed her in Hollywood. By the age of 11 Baby Peggy was a has-been. When she reached adulthood, she discovered that her family had spent her earnings — more than $2 million. Calling herself Diana Serra Cary, Peggy became an author and film historian as well as an advocate for laws protecting child actors. This tribute begins with Vera Iwerebor’s documentary, filmed shortly before the actress’s 90th birthday in 2008. It is followed by “Captain January” (1924), a silent feature about a lighthouse keeper (Hobart Bosworth) who raises a child found washed ashore in a ship’s wreckage, at 9; and three of her few remaining shorts: “Carmen, Jr.” (1923), a spoof on Bizet’s “Carmen” and the tango, at 10:15; “Such Is Life” (1924), loosely based on Hans Christian Andersen’s “Little Match Girl,” at 10:30; and “Peg o’ the Mounted” (1924), about a pint-size Mountie who hunts down a gang of moonshiners, led by a giant of a man played by Jack Earle, who stood roughly 7 feet 7 inches.
