headline: Memo From Miami | Richard Prince, Soda Maker
abstract: At Art Basel Miami this week, Prince, in conjunction with the soft-drink maker Arizona, will introduce his very own beverage.
lead_paragraph: It’s not the first time Richard Prince has lent imagery to an outside brand — he collaborated with Louis Vuitton for its spring 2008 collection — but his latest partnership is decidedly more affordable. At Art Basel Miami this week, Prince, in conjunction with the soft-drink maker Arizona, will introduce his very own beverage: “Richard Prince Lemon Fizz.” The tall boy cans retail for 99 cents to $1.25 and feature photographs of him by Sante D’Orazio and Sebastian Piras, as well as career highlights like a nurse painting, a cowboy photograph and the odd joke (all shown in gold frames). “The graphics on the can reminded me of a baseball card,” Prince said. “I started looking at it as memorabilia. I thought I could do something with my own history where the final result would be pretty far away from art.” For the uninitiated, it’s worth noting that Prince has used plastic six-pack holders as source material in various sculptural work since the 1990s. In terms of outside inspiration, he cites a variety of precedents, from the golf legend Arnold Palmer to the artists Hannah Wilke and Piero Manzoni, who once tinned his own excrement. Let’s hope this stuff tastes better.

headline: The Frenchwoman  Fraud: C’est Fini, Fifi
abstract: In Paris for the first time in years, I am surprised to see  that the French are no longer as skinny as they used to be, and they have given up style for comfort.
lead_paragraph: I went to Paris recently and as it had been years since I had been there, I was very much interested in seeing what the Frenchwomen were up to these days. When I lived there, 25 years ago, they were indeed a slim and elegant bunch, able to do things with a scarf that could make you weep. And the number of books published about them since suggested they had reached even more celestial heights — they never slept alone, they were brilliant mothers, they ate what they wanted yet never got fat.

headline: Could You Run a Business With a Former Spouse?
abstract: What happens when mom and pop divorce and neither wants to leave the business?

They got married in 1998, and soon after, Ms. Calistro took a more active role in running the company’s operations. Together, they built the business into what is now a 50-person operation with an emphasis on civil litigation. It became their baby.

headline: Coaches Can’t Resist Call of the SEC
abstract: Wisconsin’s Bret Bielema had frequently criticized the Southeastern Conference. On Tuesday he took the Arkansas job.
lead_paragraph: O.K., let’s see if we’ve got this straight: Bret Bielema spends much of his six-season tenure as Wisconsin’s football coach bashing the Southeastern Conference for being slimy and unfair and just plain mean. He does this to try to make his dwindling Big Ten neighborhood look more spiffy by comparison, to gloss over the fact that Jim Delany’s kingdom would love to crack the slimy, underhanded market. He does this to win over the Wisconsin faithful, who will never forgive him for not being Barry Alvarez, no matter how many Big Ten titles he wins. And despite all of that, two minutes after Arkansas backs up an armored truck to his house, he bolts the whole scene to coach an SEC also-ran, best known as the site of Bobby Petrino’s motorcycle accident.

headline: India Is Not a Secular Republic
abstract: On Dec. 6, 1992, the destruction of the Babri Masjid mosque by Hindu extremists killed hundreds of Hindus and Muslims. In a truly secular nation, what happened next would have been different.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — “Twenty” is somehow a newsworthy round number and it is inevitable that the 20th anniversary of an event that shook India will be observed by the nation with deeper introspection than usual on this Dec. 6. On this date in 1992, a mob of Hindu demonstrators tore down the Babri Masjid, a mosque more than 450 years old that they claimed was built over a Hindu temple. Hundreds of Muslims and Hindus died. Using the anniversary of this tragedy as the peg, my latest column questions India’s constitutional claim and aspiration that it is a secular republic.

headline: An Evening of Dance for Wendy Whelan and More at Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival
abstract: Ms. Whelan will dance four duets with a different male partner, each of whom created the steps for their number.
lead_paragraph: One ballerina, four dance-making partners. A new work inspired and performed by Wendy Whelan, the New York City Ballet principal dancer, called “Restless Creature” will be unveiled this summer at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, organizers said on Wednesday. Ms. Whelan will dance four duets with a different male partner, each of whom choreographed their number. The partners are Kyle Abraham, Joshua Beamish, Brian Brooks and Alejandro Cerrudo. Performances run Aug. 14 to 18. Jacob’s Pillow also said in announcing part of its lineup that the recently resurrected Dance Theater of Harlem would open the season with a run from June 19 to 23. Repertory includes George Balanchine’s “Agon,” Alvin Ailey’s “Lark Ascending” and John Alleyne’s “Far but Close.”

headline: 36 Hours in Steamboat Springs, Colo.
abstract: If you only know this ski town for its dude ranches and cowboy culture, it’s time to take another look.
lead_paragraph: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS evokes an era when cattle ranchers roamed its streets and locals preferred Stetsons to ski vests. But in recent years, Steamboat has sought to shed a bit of its family-friendly image as a cowboy theme park and embrace its inner Breckenridge. The town, nestled along the Yampa River in northwest Colorado, has installed an array of new après-ski bars, haute cuisine restaurants and late-night haunts, as well as upscale lodgings, like One Steamboat Place, that can rival anything at Vail or Aspen. The centerpiece of Steamboat’s face-lift, which coincides with the resort’s 50th anniversary, is a redeveloped promenade at the base of its gondola, with a heated walkway, a musical stage and a three-tiered ice castle. Families still flock to Steamboat for its dude ranches and hot springs. But after the children are put to bed, its downtown comes alive with an impressive night life and innovative culinary scene. “It’s still a cowboy ski town,” said Gerry Verdoner, bar manager of Sweetwater Grill. “But now there’s more balance.”

headline: Six Performers Moving Through a Labyrinth of Perceptions
abstract: Miguel Gutierrez’s “And lose the name of action” is a complex study of disconnection, examining the role perception plays in reality.
lead_paragraph: Miguel Gutierrez’s “And lose the name of action” seeks to demonstrate facets of a mind that has come apart. The title phrase concludes the “To be, or not to be” soliloquy in “Hamlet”; a long program note by Mr. Gutierrez begins with that speech’s final five lines and tells us of neurological problems afflicting his father, which in turn led Mr. Gutierrez to investigate the connections of body and mind. His note also variously addresses neurology, philosophy and somatics, and examines the role perception plays in reality. Mr. Gutierrez goes on to hope that his work may be a bridge connecting these various fields of inquiry.

The men, who still have individual practices, met about 10 years at the Princeton Jewish Center, where both are members. lead_paragraph: In 1865, a nearly penniless Frenchman fleeing his debts opened Café Royal in London. The club’s heyday lasted more than a century, as celebrities swirled through its sumptuous precincts. (Max Beerbohm described “fumes of tobacco ever rising to the painted and pagan ceiling” of the Domino Room.) But in 2008, the building was sold, and its lavish appointments — cut-glass chandeliers, heavily varnished oil paintings, even a boxing ring — were auctioned off.

The other eye, the one closest to the camera, can connect with the lens. The camera “will not miss anything,” he said, “including the bad. So you have to watch it.”

headline: Eva Zeisel’s Designs Shine On

She first created versions five years ago for a friend of her granddaughter who was designing a coffee shop. “Eva was adamant about keeping the shape exactly the way it was” said Josie Anthony, Leucos USA’s president. “And she only wanted to do it in white.” (Leucos had to persuade her to make a honey-colored model.) The lamps — Summer (single curve, shown); Spring (double) — display her signature undulations. Available starting Friday at Gracious Home, from $345 for a Spring sconce to $735 for a Summer suspension lamp: (800) 338-7809 or gracioushome.com.

headline: South Dakota: Tribes Raise Money for Sacred Land

lead_paragraph: Indian tribes that consider a high mountain prairie in the Black Hills of South Dakota to be sacred have raised enough money to purchase the land so that it can be preserved for religious ceremonies, the tribes announced. Three Sioux tribes — the Rosebud and Crow Creek in South Dakota and the Shakopee Mdewakanton in Minnesota — made contributions toward the $9 million cost of the 1.942-acre parcel, which is known as Pe’ Sla. The Sioux believe that Pe’ Sla was the scene of an ancient fight in which evil was vanquished.

Three others have already pleaded guilty and await sentencing in the death of James C. Anderson, who was assaulted in June 2011. William Montgomery, 23, confessed in Federal District Court in Jackson on Tuesday to assaulting Mr. Anderson but said he did not participate in running him over. Another suspect, Jonathan Gaskamp, 20, also pleaded guilty to hate crimes charges in assaults against other blacks.

headline: Bad News on Capitol Hill for Last Coal-Fired Ferry
abstract: The Badger, the last coal-fired ferry in the United States, will have to sink or sail on its own.
lead_paragraph: The Badger, the last coal-fired ferry in the United States, will have to sink or sail on its own. A provision in a little-noticed Coast Guard bill in the House would have allowed the ship to continue plying Lake Michigan — and dumping tons of coal ash into the lake each year. But the provision was taken out of the bill this week in negotiations with the Senate. It passed by voice vote in the House on Wednesday and was sent to the Senate. The Badger’s owners will have to hope that the Environmental Protection Agency gives the ferry a reprieve before its permit expires on Dec. 19. Otherwise, they will have to put the ferry into dry dock or switch to some other power source at considerable cost.

keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Witnesses', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Editorials']
abstract: An Oregon Supreme Court ruling shifts the burden of proof to prosecutors to show that eyewitness identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon Supreme Court in a unanimous decision last week upended how eyewitness identification is to be used in criminal trials. The landmark ruling shifts the burden of proof to prosecutors to show that such identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial. Misidentification is the country’s leading cause of wrongful convictions. By altering the legal standard, Oregon has set an example that other states and the federal courts would be wise to follow.

An investigation by The Times found that state and local governments are giving out $80 billion a year in tax breaks and other subsidies in a foolhardy, shortsighted race to attract companies. That money could go a long way to improving education, transportation and other public services that would have a far better shot at promoting real economic growth.

headline: After Fleeing Belize, Software Pioneer Seeks Asylum  in Guatemala
abstract: John McAfee, who disappeared from his home last month after the police there called him a “person of interest” in their investigation into the murder of his neighbor, has resurfaced in Guatemala City.
lead_paragraph: John McAfee, the software antivirus pioneer who disappeared from his home in Belize last month after the police there called him a “person of interest” in their investigation into the murder of his neighbor, has resurfaced in Guatemala City. He has hired a former attorney general and prominent defense lawyer, Telésforo Guerra, to seek political asylum in Guatemala. Mr. Guerra told local reporters that Mr. McAfee, 67, above, is being persecuted because he has refused to give the authorities in Belize any more money. Mr. McAfee had been blogging and sending Twitter messages while on the run, saying he fled because he feared for his life. Prime Minister Dean Barrow of Belize has called Mr. McAfee “bonkers.”

lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 6
abstract: News, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Rescuers sought to reach isolated villages Wednesday after a typhoon struck the Philippines, killing at least 325 people and leaving thousands homeless. Floyd Whaley reports from Manila.

headline: Stalemate and Rancor Stage Rally in N.H.L.
abstract: Just as the three-month N.H.L. lockout appeared to be headed to a conclusion, the league rejected the players union’s latest proposal.
lead_paragraph: Donald Fehr, the executive director of the players union, had just finished a news conference Thursday in which he described the union’s latest offer to end the N.H.L. lockout, and how he believed it provided a “clear outline” for ending the dispute. Players like Sidney Crosby and Brad Richards were expressing guarded optimism to reporters about returning to the ice.

headline: Morsi Defends Wide Authority as Turmoil Rises in Egypt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: President Mohamed Morsi vowed to proceed with a vote on an Islamist-backed constitution that has set off deadly battles between his supporters and opponents.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt descended deeper into political turmoil on Thursday as the embattled president, Mohamed Morsi, blamed an outbreak of violence on a “fifth column” and vowed to proceed with a referendum on an Islamist-backed constitution that has prompted deadly street battles between his supporters and their opponents.

headline: Minorities Report
abstract: In Pakistan, Ahmadis are becoming prime targets of both violence and widespread discrimination.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Monday, a dozen masked gunmen said to be affiliated with the ­Taliban and Lashkar-e-Taiba broke into a graveyard in an elite neighborhood of Lahore, the historic capital of Punjab Province. They tied up the guard, a caretaker and about 20 visitors, and then vandalized 120 gravestones.

headline: Barclays Increases Stake in Absa Group in $2.1 Billion Deal
abstract: Barclays has increased its stake in its South African subsidiary, the Absa Group, in a deal worth $2.1 billion as it moves to consolidate its operations across Africa.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British bank Barclays agreed on Thursday to increase its stake in its South African subsidiary, the Absa Group, as it moved to consolidate its operations across Africa.

headline: Standard Chartered to Pay $330 Million to Settle Iran Money Transfer Claims
abstract: The British bank’s expected settlement with American authorities comes on top of a $340 million settlement it agreed to pay the top New York State banking regulator in August.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – The British bank Standard Chartered said on Thursday that it expected to pay $330 million to settle claims by United States government agencies that it had moved hundreds of billions of dollars on behalf of Iran.

headline: U.N. Envoy Is Seeking a Deal to Oust Assad From Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: A meeting involving Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia comes amid reports of heightened activity at Syria’s chemical weapons sites.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — With the support of the United States, the United Nations special envoy on Syria is mounting a diplomatic push for a brokered agreement that would lead to the ouster of the country’s president, Bashar al-Assad, and the installation of a transitional government.

headline: In Gujarat’s Gir Forest, India’s Most Privileged Voter
abstract: A polling station for one voter in Banej, Gujarat.
lead_paragraph: BANEJ, Gujarat — Nestled in the heart of Gir forest, home to the rare Asiatic lion, in Gujarat (where the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party rules), is a hamlet called Banej.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: Pregame Events
abstract: A dispatch from the first hours of the art-world gathering: air kisses, oysters and a Bill Viola video. Are you at Art Basel Miami Beach? What have you seen? What have you liked, or not?
lead_paragraph: “Few events at Art Basel Miami Beach start before 11 a.m., so that everyone can recover from the previous evening’s partying,” Patricia Cohen reports from the fair on our sister blog ArtsBeat.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 6, 2012
abstract: Can you find the word pair that completes the sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Nascent Rivalry for the Fans, Too.”

headline: Jay-Z, Meet Ellen Grossman
abstract: Where did the rapper Jay-Z meet Ellen Grossman, a 67-year-old woman who did not know who he was?
lead_paragraph: In “When My Friend Ellen Grossman Met Jay-Z,” Tanzina Vega writes about the woman in the video posted above.

headline: Lynchings in the West, Erased From History and Photos
abstract: Seeking to underscore a seemingly absent history, Ken Gonzales-Day altered 19th and 20th century postcards of lynchings in the American West, removing the bodies from the original scenes.
lead_paragraph: At first, “Disguised Bandit” — a life-size reproduction of a century-old postcard by Ken Gonzales-Day — does not suggest anything out of the ordinary. A sparse tree cuts the center of the photograph. A group of white American soldiers flanks the tree. One man grins. The others stare passively into the camera.

headline: The Real Fiscal Risks in the United States
abstract: The biggest danger of the looming “fiscal cliff” is that the government will do too little to address underlying problems in the economy, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management.

headline: Is It Wrong for a Newspaper to Publish a Front-Page Photo of a Man About to Die?
abstract: A New York City newspaper caused a stir by publishing a photograph of a man trapped on a subway platform seconds before an oncoming train killed him. What do you think about their choice?
lead_paragraph: Note: This Student Opinion question refers to a photograph that teachers may or may not wish to show to students. We have purposely not republished the photograph here, although we are providing a link to The Times City Room column, which published a photo of the New York Post front page and asked its readers a similar question.

headline: Week 14 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Sanchez Mistake
abstract: Teams often cling to quarterbacks for longer than they should. The Jets should have been looking for an upgrade at quarterback two years ago.
lead_paragraph: With Mark Sanchez’s benching last Sunday, it’s time to see how his 2012 production compares with his previous seasons. To be fair, Sanchez is not surrounded with as much talent as he has been in previous years. However, the nature of the quarterback position is such that truly skilled quarterbacks are able to transcend the limitations of the players around them. Just this season, we’ve seen rookies like Russell Wilson, Robert Griffin III and Andrew Luck instantly and significantly improve their offenses despite having about the same or less supporting talent than their teams had a year before.

headline: Tip of the Week: Bookmarks on the Home Screen
abstract: Making Web-site bookmarks that live on your phone’s home screen can save time when browsing on the go.
lead_paragraph: Google’s Android operating system and Apple’s iOS software both include a Web browser that lets you save bookmarks. For sites you visit frequently, however, it is often faster to get to your favorite page with the mobile equivalent of a desktop shortcut — an icon on the phone’s home screen — instead of fiddling around with the browser’s bookmark menu.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader Seeks to Ease Concerns About Mainland China’s Influence
abstract: Leung Chun-ying, Hong Kong’s chief executive, called for closer relations with the mainland but also emphasized his willingness to impose limits on visitors and investors.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Seeking to address a local backlash against mainland Chinese control, the chief executive of Hong Kong called Thursday for closer relations with the mainland but also emphasized his willingness to impose limits on mainland visitors and investors.

headline: Part 4: College Students Answer Reader Questions on Admissions and Campus Life
abstract: Two college students who wrote for our student-led series “The Envelope, Please” are answering questions about going to college. Part 4.
lead_paragraph: The Choice has invited two of our former student bloggers of “The Envelope, Please” series to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer reader questions about the admissions process and what college life is like after you’ve made your choice.

headline: Five Americans Who Could Leave M.L.S. and Head Abroad This Winter
abstract: A quick look at five M.L.S. players who might be ready for a move to Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Major League Soccer season is over, and December has already seen several players move from one M.L.S. team to another.

headline: The Early Word: Togetherness
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:

headline: Enhancing Classics With Old-Car Style and Modern Mechanicals
abstract: Some companies are trying to make viable businesses out of making everything old new again in classic cars.
lead_paragraph: Once shunned by purists, older collector cars and lookalikes fitted with modern engines, transmissions, brakes, electronic controls and sound systems are gaining new respect. Broadly known as restomods, cars that have been updated under the skin are as easy to drive, and often as safe and reliable, as a new model. And after modernization, these sought-after vehicles are unlikely to be garage queens, gathering dust.

headline: New eBay Product Aims to Harness User Data to Aid Auto Marketers
abstract: The company will pair its own information about shopping habits with other data about car and truck shoppers to help marketers direct their ads more precisely.
lead_paragraph: EBay is joining the growing hordes of companies that are offering even more data to advertisers to help them better reach intended customers, in this instance companies that sell cars, trucks, motorcycles and R.V.’s and run digital ads on ebay.com.

headline: A Conversation With: Author William Dalrymple
abstract: In Afghanistan, history is repeating itself in an extraordinary way, author’s new book says.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish historian and travel writer William Dalrymple’s new book “Return of a King: The Battle for Afghanistan 1839-1842” is an eloquent, animated account of the first Anglo-Afghan war, long regarded as Britain’s most disastrous imperial adventure. He spoke with India Ink about writing narrative history; the parallels between the first Anglo-Afghan war and the war on terror; and what the West could learn from his book.

headline: Aid Group Hit by Car Bomb in Damascus
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The explosion killed one person and damaged the headquarters of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent relief organization, state media reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As fighting raged in the Damascus suburbs, a car bomb exploded in the southern Zahraa district on Thursday, killing one person and damaging the headquarters of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent relief organization, state news media reported.

headline: How the ‘Death With Dignity’ Initiative Failed in Massachusetts
abstract: Massachusetts voters seemed poised to pass a “Death With Dignity” law in November. Then came the opposition, with large spending and ads that took aim at certain provisions of the law and how they were worded.
lead_paragraph: On election night, Jim Carberry and others who had worked to put a “Death With Dignity” law on the Massachusetts ballot gathered in the back room of a Waltham restaurant and watched their effort go down to narrow defeat.

headline: Shipping Horses Is Risky, but Hong Kong Race Is Enticing
abstract: Horses from around the world, and the people who own and look after them, are getting the red carpet treatment as they arrive for the annual Group 1 races at the Sha Tin course on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Horses from around the world, and the people who own and look after them, have been traveling over the past week to take part in the Hong Kong International Races, four Group 1 contests at Sha Tin Racecourse on Sunday. Once they land, they get red-carpet treatment that the owners and trainers will probably be talking about for years.

headline: Billionaire Sells Stake in Topshop for $805 Million
abstract: The British billionaire Philip Green sold a 25 percent stake in the Topshop retail chain to the American private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners, which co-owns the J. Crew brand.
lead_paragraph: The British billionaire Philip Green sold a 25 percent stake in the Topshop retail chain to the American private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners, which co-owns the J. Crew brand, for about $805 million.

headline: Daimler Sells Half Its Stake in EADS for $2.2 Billion
abstract: The German carmaker Daimler sold half of its stake in European Aeronautic Defense and Space on Thursday as part of a realignment of the ownership structure of the aerospace company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The German carmaker Daimler sold half of its stake in the aerospace giant European Aeronautic Defense and Space on Thursday in deal worth 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion).

headline: Eggnog the Hard Way
abstract: You could buy eggnog at the store. But it’s better to make your own.
lead_paragraph: Around this time last year, I advocated forgoing eggnog in favor of glogg, the Scandinavian mulled wine. I’m not here to issue a mea culpa, but I’m also not proud when it comes to holiday drinks and certainly not above a little backpedaling.

headline: How to Tame a Wild Pork Chop
abstract: If you’re Jesse Griffiths, you bury it under a mess of gravy.
lead_paragraph: Here, then, were two young people climbing through a canyon in morning half-light, Central Texas, stalking hogs. They were private chefs enjoying a morning free of clients, smelling faintly of the Angora sweater one of the chefs wore and also of last night’s red wine. They were headachy, and trying not to stumble in the scree that tumbled off the canyon’s walls as pigs above them rooted amid low oak and thickets of juniper. They had one rifle between them, and they walked slowly, heel to toe, so as not to make noise.

headline: A Social Business Strikes a Deal With Big Tobacco
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Small Business', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Consumers can create a collection location at no cost by signing up a home or business on our Web site. We pay the shipping, and for each pound of cigarette waste collected, we donate $1 to Keep America Beautiful.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I wrote a blog post about TerraCycle’s intention to create a national recycling program for all waste, even including cigarette butts. As our programs have grown, we have had frequent internal debates about what kinds of companies we want to partner with to help them make their waste recyclable (which in turn makes their products greener).

headline: Afghan Spy Chief Is Wounded in Attack, Officials Say
abstract: The chief of Afghanistan’s intelligence service, Asadullah Khalid, survived an attack by a suicide bomber in Kabul on Thursday, Afghan officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber tried to assassinate the influential new chief of Afghanistan’s intelligence service at an agency guesthouse in Kabul on Thursday, officials said, in a brazen attack that left him seriously wounded and underscored the insurgency’s ability to go after those at the highest levels of the government.

headline: Morsi and the Balance of Power
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Egypt erupted in violent clashes after President Morsi seized temporary powers beyond the review of any court.
lead_paragraph: Egypt erupted in violent clashes after President Morsi seized temporary powers beyond the review of any court.

headline: View From Boston on Sanchez: Thanks, Rex
abstract: Some Jets fans may not agree with the decision to start Mark Sanchez, but the feeling is more supportive among Patriots fans.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it’s the holiday spirit, but Patriots fans and Jets management seem to be in rare agreement these days.  Any rancor in an intense rivalry has been replaced by thanks, deep thanks. The Jets want Mark Sanchez to be the starting quarterback. And so, it turns out, do Patriots fans.

headline: Deutsche Bank Says Report That It Hid Losses Lacks Merit
abstract: Deutsche Bank, the big German lender, said claims made by whistle-blowers that it had hidden $12 billion in losses during the financial crisis had been investigated previously and found to be without merit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The big German lender Deutsche Bank on Thursday denied a report that it had hidden $12 billion in losses during the financial crisis. The bank said charges made by whistle-blowers had been investigated previously and found to be without merit.

headline: Thai Ex-Premier Charged With Murder Over Crackdown in 2010
abstract: The former prime minister of Thailand, Abhisit Vejjajiva, was charged with murder on Thursday for his role in a military crackdown on antigovernment protesters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The former prime minister of Thailand, Abhisit Vejjajiva, was charged with murder on Thursday in connection with his role in a military crackdown on antigovernment protesters in Bangkok two and a half years ago.

headline: Congo Peace Talks Set to Open in Uganda
abstract: Congolese rebels and government officials prepared on Thursday for their first face-to-face encounter since the rebels relinquished Goma, one of Congo’s principal cities.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Congolese rebels and government officials prepared on Thursday for direct peace talks in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, their first face-to-face encounter since the rebels relinquished Goma, one of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s principal cities, after capturing it last month.

headline: On Dwindling Savannas, Lions at Risk
abstract: Of the 67 lion areas identified in Africa by a research team, only 10 support lion populations that are large, stable and protected enough to persist into the foreseeable future.
lead_paragraph: When armchair travelers think of the African savanna, they may conjure images of vast expanses of untouched wilderness.

headline: Pressure Grows on Swiss Banks to Expose Tax Cheats’ Billions
abstract: In search of every dollar and euro, strapped governments in the United States and Europe are stepping up the war on tax evaders by persuading the Swiss to close loopholes. Switzerland is cooperating — to an extent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Spare a thought for wealthy tax cheats.

headline: European Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
abstract: The bank’s move is a reversal from previous optimism that the euro zone economy would start to recover next year.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Acknowledging that the economy is likely to remain weak well into next year, the European Central Bank sharply reduced its growth forecast for the euro zone Thursday, and left its main interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.75 percent.

headline: Kissing Cousins: One Is President
abstract: Bill Murray portrays Franklin D. Roosevelt in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” which depicts a dalliance with his cousin Daisy Suckley.
lead_paragraph: Peering into famous bedrooms is a pastime of biographers and filmmakers alike, and this season offers several opportunities for the nosily inclined. Alfred Hitchcock, as well as Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, have all recently received the keyhole treatment; even Abraham Lincoln helps loosen Mary’s corset in the otherwise buttoned-up “Lincoln.” And in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” filmgoers can watch some presidential pleasuring, courtesy of Franklin Delano Roosevelt (Bill Murray) and his obliging cousin, Daisy Suckley (Laura Linney).

abstract: The Jets’ Mark Sanchez deserved to be benched after his second interception in the opening quarter against Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Andy Benoit takes a closer look at some Week 13 matchups, with the benefit of film analysis.

keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Some analysts are hopeful that the move by a big, innovative company like Apple could inspire a broader renaissance in American manufacturing, but a number of experts remain skeptical.
lead_paragraph: Apple plans to join a small but growing number of companies that are bringing some manufacturing jobs back to the United States, drawn by the growing economic and political advantages of producing in their home market.

headline: Recurring Name in Insider Trading Inquiry: SAC
abstract: In a long-running investigation of insider trading, SAC Capital Advisors has continued to surface. | Standard Chartered says it expects to pay $330 million to settle money laundering charges. | Citigroup’s plan to cut 11,000 jobs worldwide continues a trend. | Brazil is increasing efforts to promote technology growth.
lead_paragraph: In the government’s long-running investigation into insider trading, one hedge fund has continued to surface: SAC Capital Advisors, the $14 billion firm run by Steven A. Cohen. With federal prosecutors now going after a former SAC portfolio manager, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports that the trail to SAC “has emerged out of a cluster of cases, many of them connected to the prosecution of the fallen titan Raj Rajaratnam. Investigators heard SAC traders on incriminating wiretaps; in other instances, cooperators and informants accused the fund of misconduct.”

headline: Toronto-Dominion to Buy Epoch for $668 Million
abstract: The Canadian lender Toronto-Dominion Bank agreed on Thursday to buy the parent company of Epoch Investment Partners for $668 million, as it moved to bolster its asset management operations in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian lender Toronto-Dominion Bank agreed on Thursday to buy the parent company of Epoch Investment Partners for $668 million, as it moved to bolster its asset management operations in the United States.

headline: Diamondback to Close After Investors Withdraw $520 Million
abstract: Diamondback Capital Management, one of several hedge funds to be ensnared in the government’s insider-trading investigations, will close down after investors asked to withdraw $520 million in capital.
lead_paragraph: Diamondback Capital Management, one of several hedge funds ensnared in the government’s insider-trading investigations, will close down after investors asked to withdraw $520 million in capital, the firm wrote in a letter to investors on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Apple to Bring Some Manufacturing to U.S.
abstract: For the first time in years, Apple will manufacture computers in the United States, the chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, said in interviews with NBC and Bloomberg Businessweek. As an icon of American technology success and innovation, Apple has been criticized in recent years for outsourcing jobs abroad.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in years, Apple will manufacture computers in the United States, the chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, said in interviews with NBC and Bloomberg Businessweek.

headline: A Note for the Transit Chief: Beware the Endorsement From Giuliani
abstract: The Day: Joseph J. Lhota, eyeing a run for mayor, is getting enthusiastic support from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Though when it comes to choosing sides in major elections, Mr. Giuliani has the Midas touch in reverse.
lead_paragraph: If the mass-transit chief, Joseph J. Lhota, is serious about running for mayor next year, he ought to start worrying about the enthusiastic support he is getting from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. As Mr. Lhota surely knows — he was Mr. Giuliani’s deputy at City Hall, after all — a blessing from his old boss is a political version of the kiss of death.

headline: The Brotherhood of Combat
abstract: Whether they’ve fought on beaches in the Pacific islands, the mountains of Afghanistan or the many other places our military has traveled over the last century, all veterans have felt the connection of war.
lead_paragraph: Marine Corps boot camp inundated us with footage from Iwo Jima, images from Chosin Reservoir and stories of Khe Sanh. As I deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan I pondered what it is during the horrors of combat that drives us on, and if the experiences of war are the same across generations.

headline: Viva la Villa | Vampires in Volterra
abstract: A writer’s search for the perfect Italian home brought her to a 19th-century farmhouse, located near a newly famous town.
lead_paragraph: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

abstract: The American private equity firm General Atlantic has agreed to invest $200 million for a minority stake in the Brazilian financial services firm XP Investimentos.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The American private equity firm General Atlantic has agreed to invest $200 million for a minority stake in the Brazilian financial services firm XP Investimentos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: British Newspapers’ Regulation Plan; and Brubeck, Jazz Popularizer
abstract: A voluntary plan from British newspapers would give independence and greater authority to a press regulator; the Grammy award nominations are announced; Dave Brubeck dies at 92; and Nickelodeon remakes the “Peter Rabbit” books as an animated series.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s main national newspapers on Wednesday agreed to the establishment of an independent newspaper regulator with far greater powers than the current, much-criticized regulation system, John F. Burns reports. The agreement came after pressure from Prime Minister David Cameron, who has agreed with the publishers that any change in regulation should be voluntary, and not be written into law, as was recommended by the Leveson inquiry, which investigated press abuses in Britain. Mr. Burns writes:

headline: Trust Women Conference: A Delegate’s Reflections
abstract: The Trust Women conference in London confronted difficult subjects like modern-day slavery, the role of women in the Arab Spring, child marriage, corruption and development.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The first Trust Women conference, hosted by Thomson Reuters Foundation and the International Herald Tribune in London this week, boasted an impressive line up of speakers — from Melanne Verveer, the U.S. ambassador-at-large for global women’s issues to Christy Turlington Burns of Every Mother Counts to Queen Noor of Jordan, to name a few.

abstract: Hugo Lindgren talks with Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Gus Van Sant about "Promised Land."
lead_paragraph: Hugo Lindgren talks with Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Gus Van Sant about "Promised Land."

abstract: Hearing the words Oakland Raiders and playoffs in the same sentence is only going to happen if it’s related to fantasy football, as Week 14 marks the start of the fake postseason for many fantasy owners.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

lead_paragraph: NPR: The dairy cliff: milk producers, who have no safety net, would be hit hard if Congress does not pass a new farm bill. — Maria Newman

headline: Sorry, ‘Lincoln,’ That Wasn’t Your Day
abstract: The National Board of Review snubbed “Lincoln” in its honors, but as a predictor of the Oscars, the board’s choices signify little.
lead_paragraph: The National Board of Review had its say on Wednesday, and it was a good day for everyone except the more than 100 actors (not to mention the hundreds of crew members, dozens of producers and one very important writer and celebrated director) in “Lincoln.”

headline: Starbucks Offers to Pay More British Tax Than Required
abstract: In a concession, the American coffee chain said it would refrain from claiming certain deductions so that it pays some taxes regardless of whether it makes a profit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Starbucks offered on Wednesday to pay about £10 million ($16.05 million) a year in corporate taxes in Britain — or £10 million more than it paid last year — in an effort to defuse protests against its lack of contributions to public coffers at a time when ordinary taxpayers are feeling the effects of government spending cuts.

headline: A Fresh Look at the Not-So-Dark Side of Earth
abstract: A NASA satellite takes a fresh look at the spreading nighttime signs of human civilization.
lead_paragraph: Fresh imagery showing the increasingly illuminated night side of Earth has been produced by NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This is one of the clearest visible signs of the Anthropocene — an era in which one species, us, is becoming a planet-scale influence. The imagery also shows big dark gaps in populous places — reflecting the reality that some 1.3 billion people still lack access to electricity.

headline: Searching for Latinos in Children’s Literature: A Reading List
abstract: Given the dearth of books with Latino characters that are aimed at school-age children, City Room asked the owner of a Latino bookstore for a children’s reading list. What other books should it include?
lead_paragraph: Where are all the Latinos? That’s the question raised in an article published Wednesday in The Times that focused on the dearth of books with Latino characters that are aimed at school-age children. (No disrespect meant to the hugely popular Dora the Explorer or her cousin Diego, who started as cartoons.) This is an especially relevant issue given the increasing number of the country’s public school seats occupied by Latinos.

headline: An Age-Old Question: Readers Debate Science and Theology
abstract: An essay last week by Nicholas Wade prompted dozens of letters. Here are some of them, followed by a response from Mr. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s essay, “Between Rock of Ages and a Hard Place,” by Nicholas Wade, on a comment by Senator Marco Rubio of Florida that the age of the earth was “one of the great mysteries,” prompted dozens of letters. Here are some of them, followed by a response from Mr. Wade.

headline: Partners’ Stake in Goldman Sachs Rises
abstract: In a regulatory filing, Goldman disclosed that its 407 partners own 12.7 percent of the the investment, up from 11.4 percent in late October.

headline: A Money Saving Phone Service Is Revived
abstract: Validas, a site that analyzed consumer phone bills then suggested lower-priced plans, had shut down but is back as Vera.
lead_paragraph: In past years I have advised people looking to lower their phone bills to try the Web site Validas. It let them electronically enter their phone bills, which it analyzed, then suggested lower-priced plans that still gave them the same service or better.

headline: Mayor Pledges to Rebuild and Fortify Coast
abstract: With Al Gore in attendance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave his first major address on what New York City should do in a post-hurricane world.
lead_paragraph: New York City, still reeling from the impact of Hurricane Sandy, will expand its evacuation zones, tighten building codes and look for ways to fortify critical infrastructure like transportation and electrical networks from future natural disasters, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday.

headline: Carnegie Hall Dream Comes True for Medgar Evers’s Widow
abstract: Myrlie Evers-Williams, who studied classical piano, will join Pink Martini onstage Dec. 14 and 15.
lead_paragraph: Myrlie Evers-Williams, the widow of the slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, has long shared the dream of many an aspiring musician: playing Carnegie Hall. Now, at age 79, Ms. Evers-Williams will get that chance, thanks to the persuasive power of the pop orchestra Pink Martini.

headline: Up in the Air
abstract: The new airport that was supposed to be the city’s gateway to the world has turned into a symbol of its provincialism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It’s the city’s biggest construction project since the Berlin Wall. But 20 years after it was first conceived and almost $4 billion dollars later, Berlin’s new airport is a hulking empty terminal with no planes and no passengers.

headline: Ian McEwan: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Atonement” and, most recently, “Sweet Tooth,” believes the greatest reading pleasure has “an element of self-annihilation.”

headline: How Should New York Rebuild?
abstract: Should the city retreat from low-lying shorelines, or seek to restore ruined neighborhoods? Four experts weighed in at a New York University forum.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, New York University’s Institute for Public Knowledge sponsored a public forum on the recent superstorm‘s implications for New York City, where many low-lying areas face a long and painful recovery — if full recovery is indeed the goal. Moderated by Chelsea Clinton, now a special correspondent for NBC News, the forum included four panelists from the fields of earth science, climate science, philosophy and sociology who reflected on how the likelihood of more frequent storm surges might be woven into the city’s urban planning.

headline: Hollywood’s Year of Heroine Worship
abstract: In 2012, the traditional Hollywood hierarchy was overturned. Women ruled.
lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, the unemployment of a film critic would be the very definition of a dog-bites-man story, but the circumstances that separated Michael Calleri from his job at The Niagara Falls Reporter, a small weekly newspaper in upstate New York, were sufficiently peculiar — and also sufficiently resonant — to go a bit viral, stirring up a minor storm on the Internet and attracting the attention of a network morning-news show. This was a man-bites-man story that also turned out to be a man-freaks-out-about-women story. In a long narrative uploaded in November by Roger Ebert on The Chicago Sun-Times’s Web site, Calleri quoted an e-mail from his boss, Frank Parlato (curiously unnamed in the article), who had recently taken over as editor and publisher of The Reporter. Parlato was not, to put it mildly, a fan of Calleri’s movie reviews, but his real problem was with the movies themselves. “I don’t want to publish reviews of films where women are alpha and men are beta,” he wrote. “Where women are heroes and villains and men are just lesser versions or shadows of females.”

abstract: If food does not seem to taste as good as it used to, the problem may be that you are losing your sense of smell as you get older.
lead_paragraph: They are a ghastly orange color when they tumble out of their crinkly package with its flamelike logo, and salt mines and chemical plants may come to mind when you eat the first one, but, man, those tortilla chips are tasty. Or maybe it’s just that you can actually taste them. Because sorry, Charlie: as we get older, there may come a time when we find ourselves drawn not to food with good taste or food that tastes good but simply to food that has any flavor at all.

headline: Love Unleashed on the London Stage
abstract: Love may or may not make the world go round, but it’s certainly doing its bit for the London theater, from “Twelfth Night” and “Kiss Me Kate” to “Boy Meets Boy” and “The Effect,” the galvanic new play by Lucy Prebble.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—Love may or may not make the world go round, but it’s certainly doing its bit for the London theater. On stages large and small, across new plays and revivals and musicals, too, the vagaries of passion are fueling one show after another. “Cantiamo D’Amore” – “we sing of love” – or so announces a number in “Kiss Me, Kate,” the Cole Porter musical that has been newly revived in a Trevor Nunn-directed production at the Old Vic that, truth be told, is a mixed bag.

headline: Why Breaking Up H.P. Makes Sense

Its chief executive, Meg Whitman, and its board, not to mention investors, won’t stick around for an arduous and risky five-year turnaround project. Breaking the company into good bits and selling bad ones must be on the agenda for 2013.

headline: The Meaning of Kobe Bryant at 30,000
abstract: Kobe Bryant is the youngest player to score 30,000 points, and at 34, he is not only leading the N.B.A. in scoring this season, he’s also enjoying the most efficient scoring season of his career.
lead_paragraph: If you read the headlines, you know that Kobe Bryant became the youngest N.B.A. player to score 30,000 points after dropping 29 Wednesday night in a victory over the New Orleans Hornets. Only four other players — Michael Jordan, Karl Malone, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Wilt Chamberlain — hit that mark, so it is a meaningful accomplishment.

headline: Wider Chaos Feared as Syrian Rebels Clash With Kurds
abstract: Kurdish militias have joined the fighting in Syria and are seeking autonomy, raising fears of balkanization if the government of President Bashar al-Assad falls.
lead_paragraph: CEYLANPINAR, Turkey — In plain view of the patrons at an outdoor cafe here in this border town, the convoy of gun trucks waving the flag of the Syrian rebels whizzed through the Syrian village of Ras al-Ain. They had not come to fight their primary enemy, the soldiers of Bashar al-Assad’s government. They had rushed in to battle the ethnic Kurds.

headline: Living Under Great Expectations
abstract: “Great Expectations: The Sons and Daughters of Charles Dickens” explores the lives of the writer’s offspring before and after his death.
lead_paragraph: In “Great Expectations” the illustrious book editor Robert Gottlieb examines the long shadow cast by Charles Dickens over the lives of his children. This sketchy group biography could not have a better title, but Mr. Gottlieb takes an oddly equivocal position toward his material. On the one hand, the famously unhappy union between Dickens and Catherine Hogarth — who was cast off bitterly by her husband after she bore 10 children and experienced several miscarriages, all in a period of 15 years — makes him think of his own parents’ marriage. On the other, he is a father who identifies with Dickens and can “sympathize to a certain extent with his frustrations.”

headline: Visit to West Bank by King Gives Palestinians a Lift
abstract: The arrival of  King Abdullah II, coming three weeks after violent protests in Jordan over gas price increases, signaled an effort to maintain balance and stability in a region in turmoil.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — King Abdullah II of Jordan on Thursday became the first head of state to visit the West Bank since last week’s vote by the United Nations General Assembly upgraded the status of the Palestinians to nonmember observer state. It was a gesture of support that also underlined the importance of the vote to Jordan, analysts said.

headline: A Liberal Take on Family and Opportunity
abstract: Lane Kenworthy on the link between family structure and economic mobility.
lead_paragraph: In the latest Foreign Affairs, Lane Kenworthy has an essay on opportunity in America that brings a liberal perspective to bear on themes that will be familiar to my readers — in particular, the link between marriage and social mobility, and the ways in which family structure rather than race or gender is emerging as the biggest cleavage in 21st century America. The essay is well worth reading in full, both for its analysis and its policy prescriptions: Kenworthy ranges across marriage promotion, the child tax credit, education costs, mass incarceration, and class-based affirmative action, offering a more left-of-center (that is, somewhat more goverment-centric and free-spending) alternative to the pro-family, “Party of Sam’s Club” populism that certain writers have been urging on the Republican Party unsuccessfully for some time.

headline: Dramatic Nuggets With a Certain Glow
abstract: Four shows that recently opened in New York — “Golden Age,” “Golden Boy,” “Golden Child” and “The Golden Land” — have similar titles but little else in common.

headline: A Coming-Out Story Starring the Filipino Clint Eastwood
abstract: Talking with the director of “Bwakaw,” the Filipino entry for best foreign-language Oscar.
lead_paragraph: The story is one familiar to filmgoers: a gay man afraid to come out of the closet because his Roman Catholic guilt won’t let him acknowledge his true sexuality. But the setting of “Bwakaw,” the Philippines’ submission for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, is hardly typical: a quiet village in the tropics of Southeast Asia. Not only that, but also, the main character’s co-star, for whom the film is named, is a stray dog.

lead_paragraph: If you’re like me, you love the eggy, spicy flavor of chilled eggnog, which I write about in this month’s Drink column, but sometimes nothing but a warm drink will do on a cold winter’s night. That’s what makes the Tom & Jerry an excellent alternative (though some might bristle at the notion that it’s an alternative to anything — it stands on its own merits just fine).

headline: The Fiscal Ignoramus Factor

lead_paragraph: Some of us had fun with the Business Insider poll finding that by a large margin, people who thought they knew something about the fiscal cliff believed that it would increase, not reduce, the deficit. Ha ha ha — although I actually have a lot of sympathy for ordinary voters, who don’t follow these things closely but know that everyone important has been warning for years that the budget deficit is Worse than H!lter or something. How are they supposed to know that those very same people are now screaming that the deficit is coming down too fast?

abstract: A United States proposal to keep the Internet in the hands of the private sector is being resisted by some delegates, including those from Russia and some African and Middle Eastern nations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly a week into a global conference to draft a treaty on the future of international telecommunications, delegates remain divided on a fundamental question: should the Internet feature in the discussions?

headline: To Elf or Not to Elf
abstract: We’ve never had, and don’t plan to acquire, an “Elf on the Shelf”.
lead_paragraph: The “Elf on the Shelf” first entered my consciousness a few years ago, when my oldest daughter came home from a clearly hip-and-ahead-of-the-curve friend’s house after Thanksgiving and declared that the family had an elf.

headline: In Obama’s Plan to Tax Rich, $250,000 Figure May Mislead
abstract: A large majority of families making up to $300,000 — as well as hundreds of thousands of families with even greater incomes — would not pay taxes at a higher marginal rate.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s insistence that marginal tax rates rise for families making more than $250,000 has convinced millions of affluent Americans that they are likely to be writing larger checks to the government next year.

headline: Memo From Miami | Valentino’s Pop Pois Party at the Webster
abstract: A cheerful resort capsule collection based on the house’s beloved polka dot scarf made its debut last night.

headline: The Price on 25 Years Of Friendship
abstract: What to do about friends who charge for business services, a psychiatrist who interrupts, a smelly son and people who want to borrow cookie recipes.
lead_paragraph: For 25 years, we’ve been friends with a self-employed real estate broker. We socialize, and my doctor husband has never charged her family for office visits. Recently, we asked her to prepare a commercial lease. She did, and we thanked her with a gift card. But we were stunned to learn that she included her customary $100 monthly management fee. We signed it and have been paying, but not happily. Was I unreasonable to expect her services to be gratis? Anonymous

headline: Gas Tanker Completes Arctic Sea Journey
abstract: Accompanied by two Russian icebreakers, the vessel took nine days to complete the trip.
lead_paragraph: A bit of news about the melting of the Arctic waterways associated with climate change:

headline: A New Airport App in Time for Holiday Travel
abstract: TravelNerd’s new Airport Guide helps with navigating airports.
lead_paragraph: The Web site Nerdwallet, which earlier this year introduced a tool to help consumers compare airline fees, has added a new feature to its travel site in time for the holidays, to help save time and money at airports.

headline: Dogs Behind the Wheel? Bad News for Cats
abstract: A branch of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in New Zealand says it has taught three shelter dogs to drive.
lead_paragraph: News out of New Zealand this week that dogs there are being taught to drive is discombobulating on so many levels that it’s difficult to know how to process it. A branch of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals there, as a stunt to show that dogs awaiting adoption are smart and have all sorts of potential, has apparently taught three shelter dogs to drive and will showcase their skills behind the wheel of a Mini Countryman in a television broadcast on Monday.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Monopoly, the Zapped Edition
abstract: Here’s the first entry in the first week of the first year of a new feature: David Pogue’s 12 Gadgets of Christmas. Today’s entry: Monopoly Zapped, a version of the game that lets an iPad or iPhone count the money.
lead_paragraph: Ho-ho-ho, people! Time to rack your brains to come up with cool gifts for the tech nuts in your life.

headline: ‘Inventing Abstraction’ at MoMA, Collaboration With WQXR
abstract: Music, poetry and dance will play a role in the Museum of Modern Art’s “Inventing Abstraction, 1910-1925,” which opens Dec. 23.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that you leave a major museum exhibition with strains of Schoenberg or Webern or Debussy running through your head. It is even less often that you can listen to these and other compositions created around the same time both at the show and on a playlist, which is available on Q2, WQXR’s online contemporary classical station.

headline: At Random House, Employees Will Enjoy 5,000 Shades of Green
abstract: Markus Dohle, the chief executive of Random House, promised employees — from top editors to warehouse workers — a $5,000 annual bonus to celebrate a very profitable year, led to by “Fifty Shades of Grey.”
lead_paragraph: Random House had its corporate Christmas party on Wednesday night in New York, and word is that Santa likes bondage. A lot.

headline: Scene City: Art Basel Heads to the Beach
abstract: Chanel, ASAP Rocky and Silencio (and Demi Moore) made a splash on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Chanel, ASAP Rocky and Silencio (and Demi Moore) made a splash on Wednesday night.

abstract: TimesCast Politics: Senator Bernard Sanders of Vermont pushes for no cuts to entitlements. | Possible 2016 contenders meet with donors. | Clinton discusses Syria with Russian counterpart.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast Politics: Senator Bernard Sanders of Vermont pushes for no cuts to entitlements. | Possible 2016 contenders meet with donors. | Clinton discusses Syria with Russian counterpart.

headline: Romney’s Chief Strategist Dissects Campaign
abstract: The first postcampaign book has yet to hit shelves, but Stuart Stevens, the chief strategist of Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential bid, offered his take on the race on “The Charlie Rose Show.”
lead_paragraph: The first postcampaign book has yet to hit shelves, but on Wednesday, Stuart Stevens, the chief strategist of Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential bid, offered his own take on the race on “The Charlie Rose Show.” In an extended and wide-ranging interview, Mr. Stevens was by turns defiant, humble, philosophical and revisionist.

headline: Tips on Enjoying the Holidays More Simply
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Gifts', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Kristin van Ogtrop, managing editor of Real Simple, will answer your questions about how to simplify life this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Answers on this subject can be seen here. ] This week Ask the Expert features Kristin van Ogtrop, who will be answering questions about ways to simplify your life this holiday season. Ms. van Ogtrop, who has spent her career at magazines, has been managing editor of Real Simple since 2003 and oversees Adventures in Chaos, a blog where she writes about life as a working mother. She is author of “Just Let Me Lie Down: Necessary Terms for the Half-Insane Working Mom,” published by Little Brown in 2010.

headline: Fighting the Calm After the Storm
abstract: Across from South Street Seaport, the vintner Marco Pasanella has gotten his shop up and running for the holidays, but his neighborhood was emptied by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: “How can you have a corner store with no one on your block?”

headline: Obama Calls for Day of Service to Kick Off Inaugural Festivities
abstract: The president is relying on longtime supporters and aides to run the inaugural committee: Jim Messina, his campaign manager, will oversee preparations for the parade, while Julianna Smoot, a former White House Social Secretary, will run the inaugural balls and receptions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, following a tradition he began four years ago, announced Thursday that he would begin his inaugural festivities with a National Day of Service, and has asked Americans to organize and participate in community service projects on Jan. 19, the day before he is sworn into office for his second term.

headline: Damning Review of Gas Study Prompts a Shakeup at the University of Texas
abstract: A damning review of a shale gas study prompts big changes at the University of Texas Energy Institute.
lead_paragraph: The University of Texas said today that it has accepted the findings of a damning independent review of the preparation of a report on potential impacts of shale gas drilling by the school’s Energy Institute. The school said it will undertake six recommended actions, the most significant being the withdrawal of papers from the Energy Institute’s Web site related to the report until they are submitted for fresh expert review.

headline: Lhota Boasts in Washington of M.T.A. Success but Is Quiet on Any Political Dreams
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the head of the transit agency, told lawmakers about the need for federal aid for post-hurricane rebuilding costs, but reports of his possible mayoral bid followed him on his trip.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As enthusiasm builds in certain political quarters for a mayoral bid by Joseph J. Lhota, no one seems more eager to highlight his achievements as head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority than Mr. Lhota himself.

headline: Pentagon’s Top Lawyer to Resign
abstract: Jeh C. Johnson has been a central player in legal debates over drone strikes and the detention and trial of terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: Jeh C. Johnson, the Obama administration’s top lawyer at the Pentagon, will step down at the end of December, the military said on Thursday. Over the course of President Obama’s first term, Mr. Johnson was a central player in some of the most important legal policy deliberations of the administration.

headline: Frederick Neumann, Actor, Director and Interpreter of Beckett, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Neumann was an early member of the New York experimental troupe Mabou Mines which, by 1990, had produced eight works by his friend Samuel Beckett.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Neumann, an actor and director whose affinity for Samuel Beckett’s works and his friendship with the man himself helped forge the distinguished New York experimental troupe Mabou Mines, died on Nov. 27 at his home in Kingston, N.J. He was 86.

headline: Freedom of the Press for Posterity
abstract: Lawmakers should support, not stifle, freedom of the press in the UK.
lead_paragraph: Political panic often leads to bad laws and regulations, especially where basic liberties are involved, such as freedom of the press. That seems to be happening in Britain right now as politicians and editors scramble to appease public fury over the lawless behavior of sensationalist tabloids, such as The Sun and The News of The World (which stopped publishing in 2011).

headline: BMW 4 Series Goes Long and Low
abstract: The new model is the beginning of a new and possibly more confusing numerical nomenclature for BMW models.
lead_paragraph: BMW models have been growing lower, longer and softer, as if they were being heated up, then gently tugged from each end. The new Concept Four released in advance of its appearance during press days at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit in January is longer, lower and less angular than the current 3 Series coupe, whose successor it seems to be.

headline: There Will Always Be a Fantasy England
abstract: Donald Rice’s film “Cheerful Weather for the Wedding” resembles “Downton Abbey,” complete with Elizabeth McGovern, but also with a difference.
lead_paragraph: Starring Elizabeth McGovern as Hetty Thatcham, the widowed matriarch of a well-heeled British clan, “Cheerful Weather for the Wedding” may look like an offshoot of “Downton Abbey.” But the sour, dispirited characters, who convene at a mansion in Devon in December 1932 for the nuptials of Dolly (Felicity Jones), the elder and prettier of Hetty’s two daughters, have none of the spunk of the aristocrats on “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Oscar Niemeyer: In Memoriam
abstract: The Brazilian architect “designed some of the most audacious, sublimely poetic and occasionally goofy buildings of the 20th century.”

headline: A 56-Game N.H.L. Schedule Is a Possibility
abstract: With so many games canceled because of the N.H.L. lockout, 56 games may be the best the league can do.
lead_paragraph: With the nearly three-month N.H.L. lockout lurching uncertainly toward a conclusion, fans can start to consider how much of the season can be saved. With the schedule through Dec. 14 canceled, and more games likely to be canceled later this week, the best hope may be for a 56-game schedule.

headline: Kanzaburo Nakamura, Stalwart of Kabuki, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Kanzaburo, whose career spanned five decades, initially immersed himself in the Kabuki classics before forging his own path both in Japan and worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Kanzaburo Nakamura XVIII, a star of Japan’s Kabuki theater who broke from tradition to bring that stylized art form to younger generations and audiences overseas, died on Wednesday in Tokyo. He was 57.

headline: Holiday Balls of Fun
abstract: A bounty of Christmas ornaments at shops in New York could mean that you need more than one tree.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years ago, I spent an exorbitant $6 on a tiny Santa in a basket tied to a wooden red and white hot air balloon. I was newly in love, and it was our first Christmas together. When my partner died of AIDS, I vowed to keep our ornament collection going. And that’s the only reason my new partner (17 years new), who is Jewish, agrees to cohabit each December with an elaborately decorated Christmas tree. Or rather trees. My sizable collection now requires a second tree, for dog ornaments only. Every year I vow not to buy any more ornaments, and every year I encounter irresistible offerings all over New York.

headline: Spotify Event Tries to Bury the Old Feuds Between Artists and Napster
abstract: On Thursday, Lars Ulrich of Metallica embraced Sean Parker, an investor in Spotify and a co-founder of the file-sharing site Napster. Back in 2000, Metallica sued Napster, accusing it of copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: Could a single bro-hug symbolize healing for the music industry after a decade of digital strife?

headline: A Kaleidoscopic Cave Pulsing With Energy
abstract: Onstage at Terminal 5, Animal Collective’s songs — most of them from “Centipede Hz” — got back some physicality.
lead_paragraph: Animal Collective perches itself between irritating and exhilarating — an unstable position that demands frequent readjustments. At Terminal 5 on Wednesday night, it found one euphoric balance.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: What does a couple do when guests do not donate to a suggested cash fund or charity? And does a cash-strapped wedding attendant have to give a gift?
lead_paragraph: Thank-You Notes for Cash Gifts

headline: No Tax Increase for Many ‘Wealthy’ Families
abstract: President Obama says he wants married couples to pay higher taxes on income above $250,000. But his plan actually excludes most joint filers making less than $300,000 — and many who make more.
lead_paragraph: President Obama says he wants married couples to pay higher taxes on income above $250,000. But his plan actually excludes most joint filers making less than $300,000 — and many who make more.

headline: The Alchemy of Debris Forged Into Passion
abstract: “Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt: Tender Love Among the Junk,” a retrospective at MoMA PS1, assembles discardable elements into sexual and religious works.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt makes luminous art out of trash: candy wrappers, cling wrap, reflective plastics, aluminum foil, plastic bottles, beer cans and too many other kinds of cheap refuse to list. In and of itself, this is unremarkable; artists make work out of all kinds of stuff. What is impressive is how Mr. Lanigan-Schmidt’s dedication to his materials and hobbylike processes has yielded an oeuvre of transcending beauty, eroticized religiosity and poignant autobiography.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Our choice of the 10 Best Books of 2012 reflects an unusually strong year.
lead_paragraph: Our choice of the 10 Best Books of 2012 reflects an unusually strong year, one in which, to cite a single example, the graphic novel achieved new heights of mastery in Chris Ware’s “Building Stories.” This year’s list also includes more traditional works, but they too range beyond the familiar. Katherine Boo’s “Behind the Beautiful Forevers” explores, with the author’s matchless empathy, the netherworld of Mumbai. Saudi Arabia is both visited and reimagined in Dave Eggers’s “Hologram for the King.” In “The Yellow Birds,” Kevin Powers brings home the Iraq war in uncannily evocative prose. And Jim Holt’s pursuit of the most fundamental of philosophical questions, in “Why Does the World Exist?,” leads him across time zones and intellectual disciplines.

headline: Evans Could Return Friday; Lopez Still Out
abstract: Reggie Evans of the Nets is expected to play Friday against the Warriors. Brook Lopez will miss at least one more game.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Evans is expected to return to the rotation Friday when the Nets host the Golden State Warriors. Brook Lopez, however, will miss his fourth straight game.

headline: The Familiar Shares the Stage With a Debut
abstract: The New York Philharmonic took care of some business before featuring a debut by the conductor Juraj Valcuha and yet another performance by the pianist André Watts.
lead_paragraph: The unexpected sight of an arts organization’s chief executive taking the stage to make an announcement before a performance is usually cause for concern. Did the star soloist break a nail? Was the conductor stuck in rush-hour traffic? Was some other awkward intrigue afoot?

headline: And the Award for Most Flops Goes To …
abstract: Gerald Wallace and Reggie Evans of the Nets have been cited for two flopping violations each. The rest of the N.B.A. has been cited five times.
lead_paragraph: The Nets are chasing the Knicks and the Miami Heat for supremacy in the Eastern Conference, but they do lead the N.B.A. in one unfortunate category: flops.

headline: Oysters and Sparkling Wines
abstract: For holiday entertaining, giving oysters a quick broil is easier on the host.
lead_paragraph: I recently realized that the combination of oysters and Champagne is one of my comfort foods. And it has become more readily available since I learned how to open oysters (much more difficult than clams) and acquired a really sturdy, proper knife for the task. Open a bottle of bubbly? That’s a walk in the park in comparison.

headline: Drinks, Live Music and That Head-Nodding Thing Dads Do
abstract: Birdland offers an early showtime, 90 minutes of music, at a cost of a $25 ticket with a $10 cover.
lead_paragraph: A quiet drink does not mean a silent one. Conversation is usually in order. Music is, too; a thoughtful playlist is almost always a requisite. Live? That works.

headline: Deft Hands Behind the Bubbles
abstract: Think it’s easy to make a good sparkling wine? Many American winemakers try, but few can produce anything that can come close to competing with Champagne.
lead_paragraph: YOU’RE going to be looking for sparkling wine, you want specific suggestions and the wine panel is here to help you.

headline: The Giving Spree | Yvette Van Boven
abstract: The Dutch chef shares what she’s giving for the holidays – and what she’s hoping to get.
lead_paragraph: Who: The Dutch chef Yvette van Boven, author of the cookbooks “Home Made” and “Home Made Winter,” who was photographed in her Amsterdam apartment by The Selby for “Dutch Oven,” which ran in T’s winter fashion issue.

headline: YouTube Tries to Become More Like TV
abstract: YouTube introduced a redesigned site that it hopes will encourage casual users to visit when they have spare time to see what their favorite video creators have posted, as opposed to visiting only when they receive a link or want to search.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the day, many of us flop on the couch and turn on the TV to channel surf. But if YouTube has its way, more of us will be channel surfing the online video service instead.

headline: Black and Jewish Music, Kentucky Cabinets, Magician Posters
abstract: Sheet music by black and Jewish composers goes on display in Harlem; a museum buys an 18th-century Kentucky dresser; an auction features early-1900s posters promoting magicians.
lead_paragraph: Framed sheet music has been hung throughout the Harlem restaurant Settepani, and the song titles and graphics at times caricature African-Americans.

headline: Sorting Out a Chinese Puzzle in Auditing
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS']
abstract: American and Canadian regulators who try to scrutinize Chinese corporations generally face a huge task getting cooperation from Chinese authorities.
lead_paragraph: Imagine for a moment that you were auditing a company whose principal asset was trees that it would eventually cut down to sell the timber. Would you bother to verify whether the company actually owned the trees? Would you make sure that the trees the company showed to your auditors were the same trees it claimed to own?

headline: TimesCast Politics: The Debate Over Cuts to Entitlements
abstract: Senator Bernard Sanders is fighting to avoid entitlement cuts, posing a left-leaning obstacle in the fiscal negotiations. Also, the 2016 money race and the latest on Syria.
lead_paragraph: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press

headline: Ann Hamilton’s ‘event of a thread’
abstract: Scenes from the artist's installation at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the artist's installation at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: To Love — or Not — ‘Les Miz’
abstract: The critics are starting to weigh in on “Les Misérables,” some not kindly, but it certainly has its fans.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert is proceeding to nerd out with his Hobbit Week; here at the Bagger, we’ve getting our Semaine des Misérables on (Les Miz Week for the uninitiated). Stay tuned for more from star Eddie Redmayne, who told us about the utter terror of performing in the Tom Hooper movie adaptation. In the meantime, get a load of what Bagger pal Sasha Stone, over at Awards Daily, calls two “Oscartastic” new TV spots for the film.

headline: Totems That Tell About the Past and the Future
abstract: Huma Bhabha’s sculptures and drawings bookend the history of figurative sculpture, from ancient fertility icons to what could be the last vestiges of the human race.
lead_paragraph: In “Huma Bhabha: Unnatural Histories,” at MoMA PS1, long-enduring forms from the ancient world lend some gravity to the throwaway materials that are now commonplace in contemporary sculpture. You could also say that the precariousness of recent assemblage and installation art haunts Ms. Bhabha’s monstrous, totemic figures, which are typically made of Styrofoam, clay, rubber, wood scraps and wire mesh; either way, the juxtaposition is arresting.

headline: Mark Kirk Is Returning to Senate
abstract: Mr. Kirk, an Illinois Republican, will come back to the Capitol nearly a year after having a stroke.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mark Kirk will return to the Senate on Jan. 3, nearly a year after having a stroke.

headline: A Sun’s Influence on a Galaxy of Stars
abstract: “Dancing Around the Bride,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, looks at how Cage, Cunningham, Johns and Rauschenberg developed their resistance movement from the art of Marcel Duchamp.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Just under the wire, I’ve found a top candidate for favorite museum show of the year in a sparkling piece of curatorial choreography called “Dancing Around the Bride: Cage, Cunningham, Johns, Rauschenberg and Duchamp,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. An ensemble performance entirely of stars, with an elusive sun, Marcel Duchamp, at the center, it focuses on a transformative moment in American Modernism when a heroic view of art ended, and another view, cool, wry and brainy, began.

headline: City Settles With Disabled People Fraudulently Adopted in ’90s and Abused
keywords: ['Abuse of the Disabled', 'Foster Care', 'Welfare (US)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The plaintiffs were fraudulently adopted by a Judith Leekin of Queens over 15 years ago and subjected to years of mistreatment.
lead_paragraph: In a 1990s-era case that has been seen as a colossal breakdown in the city’s foster care system, New York City will pay $9.7 million to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of 10 disabled people who were fraudulently adopted as children by a Queens woman more than 15 years ago and were subjected to years of abuse.
