lead_paragraph: European data protection officials are drafting plans to censure Google over its online privacy policy if the company does not meet the demands of regulators to revise it.

headline: Banks Agree to Sell Back Some Greek Bonds
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The buyback, which aims to trim about 20 billion euros, or nearly $26 billion, from Greece’s staggering 323 billion euro debt, could be announced early next week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greece moved a step closer to completing a complex debt-reduction deal on Friday when the country’s largest banks said they had agreed to sell their discounted bonds back to the government.

headline: It’s Beginning to Feel a Lot Like . . . the End of the World
abstract: The Mayan long year and a passage from “Gringos,” the 1971 novel by Charles Portis about expat cranks and goofballs hanging out in the Yucatan.
lead_paragraph: It’s getting to be that time of year again — the Mayan long year, I mean. The 13th and current baktun comes to an end in a matter of weeks, on the winter solstice. (Those 144,000 days just flew by, didn’t they.) Maybe you have kids of a certain age (or apocalyptic bent) who’ve brought it up? They seem to be joking about it in school lately. Or maybe you recall a passing mention in the magazine last month. (“The Vivos Group, which sells luxury bunkers, until recently had a clock on its Web site that was ticking down to Dec. 21, 2012 — a date that, thanks to the Mayan calendar, some believe will usher in the end times.”)

headline: Pompidou Center Reaches Across Atlantic for a Curator
abstract: The French museum is expanding its acquisitions of American art.
lead_paragraph: French museums like the Louvre and the Pompidou Center seem to like all things American. The Louvre commissioned Cy Twombly to create a 3,750-square-foot ceiling for its Salle des Bronzes, which was unveiled two years ago next door to a ceiling triptych created more than half a century before by Georges Braque.

headline: Freeport Deals Too Cozy for Comfort
abstract: For the top executives involved — but not shareholders so far — Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold’s acquisitions to get into the energy business appear very attractive, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold’s foray into energy keeps getting cozier for the top executives involved. The mining company’s market value has plunged by $6 billion following news of its planned purchase of Plains Exploration and Production and McMoRan Exploration. Yet Jim Bob Moffett, Freeport’s chairman, and James Flores, chief executive of Plains, will come out ahead.

headline: On Our Radar: A Plant Stress Index
abstract: Satellite monitoring of plant temperatures and evaporation offered an early indication that this year’s severe drought was in the making.
lead_paragraph: Government satellites’ measurements of “plant stress” anticipated the arrival of this year’s severe drought in the United States a month before the nation’s drought monitor did. [The Atlantic]

headline: A Party Swirling Nonstop, Safely
abstract: Kyle Abraham’s first Alvin Ailey production, “Another Night,” had its premiere at City Center, continuing an upswing in his career.
lead_paragraph: The grants, gigs, residencies and commissions have been coming fast and furious for the 35-year-old choreographer Kyle Abraham.

headline: Buzzed
abstract: Designers began showing collections for prefall 2013 this week in New York, and the looks were strong enough to give you a little buzz.
lead_paragraph: Designers began showing collections for prefall 2013 this week in New York, and the looks were strong enough to give you a little buzz. While the season’s preview collections will go on through January, there is already a hint of the look to come, with a focus on sleek leather coats at Michael Kors and Alexander Wang, for example. And one coincidence that came up was the appearance of shearling that had been shaved so close to the skin in the collections of both Francisco Costa at Calvin Klein and Reed Krakoff that it looked like velvet.

headline: Advice for Avoiding Bad Investment Decisions
abstract: Bucks readers recount their own bad investment decisions and discuss what they have learned from the experience.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, uses the fourth anniversary of the collapse of a string of investor frauds (including the biggest, the one involving Bernard L. Madoff) to offer some advice on avoiding similar frauds.

headline: Justices to Hear Two Challenges on Gay Marriage

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would enter the national debate over same-sex marriage, agreeing to hear a pair of cases challenging state and federal laws that define marriage to include only unions of a man and a woman.

abstract: When strangers ask “What do you want Santa to bring you?” the Jewish child has to find an answer.
lead_paragraph: My social butterfly of a son waved at the woman standing in line at a local Starbucks. Simon was intrigued that the 20-something woman wore Army fatigues. She was curious about my 4-year-old’s holiday plans.

headline: Land of Light Taxes and Heavy Shopping
abstract: A robust commercial area has helped to keep taxes low in this Morris County township.
lead_paragraph: EAST HANOVER wasn’t spared much misery when the hurricane struck in late October. Trees were downed and power was out as long as two weeks. Then, once lights and heating came back on, Lisa Beck recalled, an electrical surge almost immediately sparked a fire at her neighbor’s house.

headline: Cellos Frame Sculptures in Stop-and-Go Motion
abstract: Russell Maliphant’s dancers took to the Joyce’s stage on Wednesday night to pay homage to Rodin’s watercolors and sculptures with an overwhelming set and straining muscles.
lead_paragraph: When a choreographer takes inspiration from a French master like Auguste Rodin, alarm bells go off. Doesn’t it sound like a school assignment? In “The Rodin Project,”  performed at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday evening, the effect is more aimless and impressionistic than didactic.

headline: Pay Wall Push: Why Newspapers Are Hopping Over the Picket Fence
abstract: Charging for content, long the scourge of the Internet, has become almost sexy. What’s ahead in the fight for paid readers.
lead_paragraph: When The Wall Street Journal broke the news that The Washington Post was likely to start charging for online content sometime next year, it should not have come as a surprise, but it did.

headline: An Appeal to President Obama’s Better Side
abstract: Pushing for greater transparency in the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: This is a blog post about excessive secrecy, unsanctioned killing and an administration that abuses power to block court actions aimed at imposing accountability and review on its policy making.

headline: Off the Charts: Is the Banking Crisis Over?
abstract: Since the European Central Bank took steps to assure the banks could borrow money, and it became clear that Germany was not willing to allow the euro zone to break up, euro zone bank stocks have been among the best investments around.

headline: A Bypassed Bellini Gets Its Due
abstract: The Collegiate Chorale’s performance of “Beatrice di Tenda” offered a chance to see how some gifted artists coming into their maturity are faring, especially the soprano Angela Meade.
lead_paragraph: The impressive and busy Collegiate Chorale regularly provides New York opera buffs a service by presenting concert performances of rarities at Carnegie Hall. It did so again on Wednesday, when James Bagwell, the chorus’s music director, conducted Bellini’s seldom-heard “Beatrice di Tenda” with a strong cast and the American Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Fables’ Spinoff Starring Sleeping Beauty
abstract: The first volume of “Fairest” hits the paperback list at No. 5.
lead_paragraph: The writer Bill Willingham and “Fables,” the series he created, are no strangers to our graphic books best-seller lists. Now the first volume of that book’s spinoff, “Fairest,” has joined in, landing at No. 5 on our paperback list this week. Featuring intricate artwork by Phil Jimenez, the story follows Sleeping Beauty after she is woken by Ali Baba, the prince of thieves, who does not have the purest of intentions for the heroine.

headline: Sweet or Savory, a Bite at a Time
abstract: Making pâte à choux, the classic French pastry used for cream puffs and éclairs, is not as difficult as you’d think.
lead_paragraph: IN my very first restaurant job, I learned to make pâte à choux, the classic French pastry that is used for cream puffs and éclairs. I had to learn in a hurry, too, because my boss had just decided to make me the pastry chef, a position for which I was not remotely qualified. Yes, I knew how to bake bread, and I had experimented with pies, but I had no clue about producing fancy pastries for a “Continental” restaurant. No problem, the chef said, as he handed me recipes for the desserts I would be required to make daily: cream puffs, floating island, baked alaska and cheesecake.

headline: Newly Delayed Bike Share Program Is Now to Begin in May
abstract: Equipment damage from Hurricane Sandy forced the latest postponement, and New York City will start with 5,500 bicycles, fewer than originally planned.
lead_paragraph: First it was the software. Now it is the surge.

headline: Campaign Postscript Offers a Peek at Debates on Security and Spending
abstract: An unseen player in closing stages of the race: the Secret Service.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Kan. – President Obama resisted the blue goose.

headline: Consumer Reports Questions Ford’s Fuel Economy Ratings
abstract: Ford says, “Early C-Max Hybrid and Fusion Hybrid customers praise the vehicles and report a range of economy figures, including some reports above 47 m.p.g.”
lead_paragraph: Consumer Reports said on Thursday that its tests showed the 2013 Ford Fusion Hybrid and C-Max Hybrid fall short of the estimated fuel economy numbers assigned by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: The Grooves That Have Pulsed Before
abstract: A quartet led by the jazz drummer Reggie Quinerly, invoking rhythms of earlier days, played sets featuring songs from his debut album Wednesday night at Smoke.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard to pick up on historical echoes in the music of Reggie Quinerly. A conscientious jazz drummer with a nimble and approachable style, Mr. Quinerly can naturally call a handful of his precursors to mind, especially the steady-humming engines of hard bop’s heyday, like Art Taylor, Louis Hayes and Jimmy Cobb.

headline: European Banks Thriving as Investor Fears Ease
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: There is a growing confidence that institutions in countries like Germany will succeed in their efforts to support the euro.
lead_paragraph: THE European bank crisis was one of the major worries of 2012. There were forecasts that the euro zone would break up, that various countries would default on their debts and that undercapitalized banks would fail because national governments could not afford to keep them alive.

headline: Romance, From Tristan and Isolde to Today
abstract: David Lang’s vocal work “love fail” is being performed by Anonymous 4, a female vocal quartet, at the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: In its first moments, the composer David Lang’s new vocal work “love fail” establishes the subdued and mystical mood it will sustain for more than an hour.

headline: Techniques to Up Your Holiday Baking
abstract: You, too, can make a light pâte à choux, and learn how to handle a pastry bag.
lead_paragraph: The holiday party season approaches, bringing all manner of baked goods in its wake. Two of my favorite bite-sized treatsfrom the oven are classic cheese puffs and cream puffs, both featured in this week’s City Kitchen column. The dough, which in French is called pâte à choux, is pretty easy to put together, once you learn the technique.

headline: Aston Martin, With New Cash, Moves to Next Step
abstract: A Milan investment firm agreed on Friday to pump $241 million of new capital into Aston Martin.
lead_paragraph: A high-stakes battle for the heart and soul, if not control, of the sports car maker Aston Martin has been settled in favor of the Italian private equity firm Investindustrial.

headline: Parlor Coffee: Espresso and a Cut
abstract: The Scoop app adds another coffee spot.
lead_paragraph: Parlor Coffee might be New York City’s smallest espresso bar. It opened recently in the back of the Persons of Interest barbershop in Williamsburg. Dillon Edwards, the barista, operates his one-group Speedster espresso machine in a tiny back room that he shares with a display of hair tonics and creams. Mr. Edwards worked for Stumptown Coffee Roasters and Blue Bottle Coffee before setting up shop, and he pulls shots of espresso with beans he roasts himself and sources from the noted importer Coffee Shrub.

headline: Facebook Likely to End Experiment With Democracy
abstract: Facebook’s brief experiment with direct user democracy — introduced after a major privacy imbroglio — is apparently at an end. It was a policy that never amounted to much in the first place.
lead_paragraph: A half-million Facebook users have told the social network they do not want the company to change its privacy policy. Sounds impressive, right? Well, the only way that crowd will get its way and the status quo remain intact is if an additional 300 million people vote thumbs down before Monday. Odds of that happening? About zero.

He’s having a career year as a shooter, which would suggest that the Knicks are using him correctly.

headline: ‘Clear Errors’ About the Death Penalty
abstract: The Kentucky Supreme Court upholds an unconstitutional death penalty sentence.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976, it said that the penalty could never be mandatory. Even if a jury finds a defendant guilty of a brutal murder, it still must weigh evidence about how to sentence him. Aggravating evidence concerns why a jury should impose a death sentence. Mitigating, or moderating, evidence concerns why it should not. That is the law of the land.

headline: Lumière | France’s Trouble With Money
abstract: French antipathy toward capitalism and the profit-making rich is a sentiment that echoes back through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Arnault, the richest man in France and one of the richest men in the world, is a master of emotional concealment. But there he was, in a television interview in 2007, pouring his heart out about feeling unappreciated in his own country. He boasted that his company, LVMH, is a “beautiful” enterprise dedicated to producing made-in-France luxury goods and to spreading French creativity and culture throughout the world. In other countries, he said, corporate heads are highly respected; in France, they are not. “France has a problem with a market economy,” he said. “The influence of Marxism still exists.”

headline: Not Quite Headed for the Coffee Table
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Rock Music']
abstract: There are some great books on the history of punk, but now there’s a history of Punk, the loudmouthed, comic-stripped magazine that helped define the scene in New York in the mid-1970s.
lead_paragraph: There are some great books on the history of punk, like Jon Savage’s “England’s Dreaming,” but now there’s a history of Punk, the loudmouthed, comic-stripped magazine that helped define the scene in New York in the mid-1970s, when everything was fun and filthy and the city was trying to avoid bankruptcy. Debbie Harry and Chris Stein, in a foreword to “The Best of Punk Magazine,” write that they assumed Punk was a really obvious, junky name, “but no, it was a periodical.”

Eventually, he wore her down. On Thursday evening at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, the Sokolow Theater/Dance Ensemble, led by its artistic director Jim May, performed the 1953 dance in its entirety as part of its “Sounds of Sokolow” series.

Still, it’s worth examining why the United States might be a more attractive place to locate your plant today than in the past.

We asked the two perennial rivals-slash-cooking buddies (they wrote a book together) to come up with a menu of gift-worthy treats, and asked readers to pick which one they preferred. Slightly more readers chose Ms. Severson’s Southern-inspired sweet spiced pecans, cheese straws and hot fudge sauce. When they appeared on the “Today” show on Wednesday, the host, Willie Geist, picked Ms. Moskin’s menu. “All I can say is that the readers of The New York Times are among the smartest people on earth,” Ms. Severson said upon hearing the news of her victory.

headline: Hollywood Heroines: Behind the Scenes
abstract: Tierny Gearon was the perfect photographer to bring out the superhero in the actresses featured in the magazine’s annual Hollywood Issue.

In 2010, our performers riffed on film archetypes (the femme fatale, the man on the run); in 2011, they played villains (the mad scientist, the gun moll). This year, once we realized, in consultation with the paper’s movie critic, A.O. Scott, that 2012 was a “pretty good year for female heroism,” we greenlighted the concept of an all-female cast, with a super power for each. That’s how we ended up with a snake charmer, a rainmaker, a light-bringer, superheroes and transformers (the personal kind, not the Michael Bay, mechanical kind).

headline: ‘Fangio & Mercedes-Benz: Alliance of the Best’
abstract: An excerpt from “Fangio & Mercedes-Benz: Alliance of the Best.”
lead_paragraph: Fangio was indisputably the leading racing personality of his time.  When Mercedes-Benz provided him with a brilliant and virtually indestructible vehicle for their spectacular postwar comeback, it proved an almost unbeatable combination.  But it also saw the coming together of two very different characters, and every now and then a little ripple would appear on the otherwise smooth surface of this partnership.

headline: ‘Porsche — Origin of the Species’
abstract: An excerpt from “Porsche — Origin of the Species”
lead_paragraph: Through 1943 and the early months of 1944 Allied bombers roamed more and more freely above Germany’s industrial centers. The spring of 1943 marked sharp intensification of the bombing. The eleventh attack on Stuttgart came on September 6, 1943, when the U.S. Army Air Force made its first daytime bombing run over the industrial center, location of the Daimler-Benz aircraft-engine factory. Nevertheless the home base of the Porsche team remained at Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen — even though many other firms with important wartime missions had already been dispersed, either underground or to strategically less important regions.

headline: ‘History’s Greatest Automotive Mysteries, Myths and Rumors Revealed’
abstract: An excerpt from “History’s Greatest Automotive Mysteries, Myths and Rumors Revealed”
lead_paragraph: The more automobile design has changed, the more it has remained the same. A century after the Model T Ford debuted, the vast majority of the cars on the road still feature steel bodies, chassis suspended on four wheels and four-stroke internal combustion engines. Not that would-be revolutionaries haven’t tried to “improve” the automobile with a host of innovations: Bodies made of carbon-fiber. Bodies fitted with wings. Bodies that float on water. Three-wheelers. Six-wheelers. Steam engines. Jet turbines. For a while, there was even talk of nuclear power.

headline: ‘Fast Girl’
abstract: An excerpt from “Fast Girl: Don’t Brake Until You See the Face of God”
lead_paragraph: Enter the racetrack. It’s not exactly yoga, my friends, and it’s not a day at the spa. It’s very, very loud. It’s stinky. The gear is uncomfortable. The helmet is heavy and restrictive and looks stupid. The seat belts are uncomfortably tight. The gloves are hot. If I’m not sweating like a pig while marinating on the hot tarmac then I’m freezing my [expletive] off. And above all else, screaming down a straight at 135 miles per hour is not relaxing. Adrenaline is having a house party in my nervous system. My heart is thudding. My brain is calculating wildly as my sensory input approaches maximum overload. My palms are sweating. Every nerve in my body is thrumming with the effort of keeping up, and the lizard part of my brain is just repeating and repeating: You’re gonna die, you’re gonna die, you’re gonna die. And yet I find this mental activity to be so therapeutic, so beneficial, so seductively desirable that I go back again and again for the brain fix. Why?

headline: ‘Corvette Sixty Years’
abstract: An excerpt from “Corvette Sixty Years”
lead_paragraph: Born in 1910 to Russian-Jewish parents, Zachary (Zora) Arkuss grew up in St. Petersburg, where he witnessed the February 1917 Bolshevik revolution. Eventually his parents divorced and Zora’s mother Rachel remarried a man named Josef Duntov. In the early 1920s, they relocated to Germany. Enthralled with cars, racing, and high performance, he became a friend of Alfred Neubauer, head of Mercedes- Benz racing.

headline: A Big Business in Getting High
abstract: Pop stars like Rihanna and Lady Gaga might be joining a marijuana-culture tradition that formerly embraced men like Jerry Garcia and Willie Nelson, but these women are integrating it into their endorsement deals.
lead_paragraph: THE artwork for Rihanna’s hit single “Diamonds” features a black-and-white image of the singer’s manicured hands rolling a joint made of diamonds. For the song’s music video, she takes a bedazzled puff.

headline: Prank Call Seeking Royal Family Secrets Takes Horrifying Turn
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Royal Family', 'Hospitals', 'Hoaxes', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Radio']
abstract: A nurse tricked by Australian D.J.’s who called posing as Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles to get information about Kate Middleton’s pregnancy was found dead on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As pranks go, this one appeared outrageous and obnoxious rather than malicious: after convincing a hospital nurse who answered the phone this week that they were Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles, two Australian radio hosts then tricked another nurse into disclosing medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, who had been admitted with acute morning sickness.

headline: An Art World Gathering, Divided by Money
abstract: Art Basel Miami Beach is under way this weekend, and even before it opened, some critics said it was an example of something wrong in the art world.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Mera Rubell was taking time out from greeting the hundreds of visitors at her family’s sprawling contemporary art center here to vent.

headline: Rice in Limbo as Nomination Remains Uncertain
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: President Obama has strongly defended Susan E. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, but it is not yet clear if he will nominate her for secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It did not take long for Susan E. Rice and her champions at the White House to realize that the Republican furor over the Benghazi attack was not going away after the presidential campaign ended.

headline: Justices to Take Up Generic Drug Case
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: The case involves a decade-long battle over whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would decide whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor millions of dollars to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.

headline: ‘Joe’s Junk Yard’
abstract: An excerpt from “Joe’s Junk Yard”
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in Southeastern Pennsylvania, my father ran an automotive junkyard, and my mother ran a series of small antique shops. I was surrounded by junk. My mom routinely dragged us out of bed at sunrise to go to the flea markets and yard sales, in search of treasure – a painting by a famous artist, a valuable piece of pottery, or an important document or cash stowed in the backing of a frame. My dad helped run the family business, and started a motorcycle department to tap into his other interest besides cars: Harley Davidsons. He built one of his bikes from the ground up, using parts he acquired in the business. I was shaped by the idea that one man’s trash is another man’s treasure.

headline: Automotive Diversions of the Non-Driving Kind
abstract: A brief review of “Joe’s Junk Yard” by Lisa Kereszi.
lead_paragraph: This weekend’s Automobiles section offers six brief reviews of recent books that readers may want to consider as holiday gifts or as additions to their own bookshelves. Covering a broad range of interests – pop culture, famous racers and marque histories are among the selections – they are evidence of a healthy ecosystem in the realm of automotive literature.

headline: A Lifetime of Work Destroyed at Westbeth
abstract: The largest federally subsidized artist’s colony in the country suffered the fate of many in Lower Manhattan when flood waters from Hurricane Sandy surged into the West Village building and ruined decades of art.
lead_paragraph: Al Cooke, 81, had a few hours on Friday to save what remained of his life’s work. A metal sculptor, he slowly carried heavy sheets of aluminum up to his studio’s loft. Walking back down the stairs, however, the pain shooting through his knees made him hesitate with every step.

headline: Storm Sirens’ Last Wail
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: A decision to dismantle tsunami sirens on the Oregon coast has some residents concerned that the new warning system — texts and phone calls — will not reach everyone.
lead_paragraph: TILLAMOOK, Ore. — The tsunami sirens of Tillamook County, posted along the rocky beachfront on this stretch of the earthquake-prone Pacific coast, are a reassuring presence to many residents and visitors. The 30-odd pole-mounted speakers, simple and dated in their 1960s technology of transistors and circuit boards, carry an echo of cold war civil defense, suggesting that people have a kind of handle on responding to the earth’s potential violence from a killer wave.

headline: Pacquiao, Like All Boxers, Is in Fight Against Time
abstract: As he faces Juan Manuel Marquez on Saturday for the fourth time, Manny Pacquiao, 33, may be on the cusp of a moment all boxers experience — the realization that it’s no longer wise to keep going.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When Manny Pacquiao climbs inside the ring Saturday to face his longtime nemesis Juan Manuel Marquez for the fourth time, his every movement will be scrutinized, analyzed, picked apart for signs of decline. His legs. His reflexes. His willingness to attack.

headline: Whipping Up Confections, With Expert Help
abstract: Cooking studios and bakeries in New Jersey offer courses in which cooks of all ages and skill levels can come together and, hours later, walk out with holiday treats.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J. — Jonell Copeland, one of the 16 students in a holiday cookie class at the Sur La Table store here last Sunday, had carefully considered reasons for spending two hours learning to make gingerbread and sugar cookies, lemon-thyme wreaths and other treats.

headline: Pornography Curbs Ordered
keywords: ['Pornography', 'Sexual Harassment', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Air Force has ordered inspections of its facilities for public displays of pornographic or misogynistic materials after complaints from female personnel.
lead_paragraph: The Air Force has ordered inspections of its facilities for public displays of pornographic or misogynistic materials after complaints from female personnel. The order from the Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mark Welsh, follows a report in The New York Times about the case of a technical sergeant, Jennifer Smith, who has served in the Air Force for 17 years. She filed a complaint with the service saying that she had been the victim of sexual assault and harassment, and that she had also been forced to endure a hostile work environment because of widespread and open displays of graphic materials that were demeaning toward women.

headline: All That Sparkles
abstract: A sampler of first-rate sparkling wines, eminently suitable for holiday parties and meals.
lead_paragraph: When Louisa and Alex Hargrave pioneered the Hargrave Vineyard (now Castello di Borghese) in Cutchogue in 1973, they made only still wines. First-rate sparkling wines from East End producers lay years in the future.

headline: The Best Gift Ideas for the Best-Dressed Global Traveler
abstract: From office style that goes beyond office drab to the most practical yet stylish travel gear, the I.H.T.’s fashion special report tells you what you need to wear — or give.
lead_paragraph: Times are harder than they used to be for pretty much everybody. But that doesn’t change the professional imperative to look good or the personal desire to travel well. Indeed, in tougher economic times standing taller than the rest can be even more crucial at the office. And that means looking good, as the I.H.T. explains in our fashion special report:

headline: Rebel Groups in Syria Make Framework for Military
abstract: After three days of intensive talks, military commanders of the main Free Syrian Army units from all over Syria agreed Friday to a unified command structure.
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — Military commanders of the main Free Syrian Army units from all over Syria agreed Friday to a unified command structure, bowing to intense pressure from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, who the fighters said promised more advanced weapons once a central military council was in place.

headline: A Killer Ends Half-Told Tale of His Crimes With Suicide
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Sex Crimes', 'Kidnapping', 'Serial Murders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Bank Robberies']
abstract: Investigators are now trying desperately to illuminate the dark shadows left by Israel Keyes, the admitted killer in Anchorage who took his own life last weekend.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — In a conversation with homicide investigators before his suicide in jail this week, Israel Keyes said he had lived much of his life thinking that people only pretended to be nice. But then, Mr. Keyes told one of the interrogators, he realized that perhaps it was only him.

headline: Safety Agency Proposing Mandatory Event Data Recorders
abstract: Approximately 96 percent of model year 2013 cars and light-duty vehicles already have E.D.R. capability, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Friday that it was proposing a new standard that would require light passenger vehicles built on or after Sept. 1, 2014, to have event data recorders, or E.D.R.’s, an earthbound and much less complex version of the “black boxes” long seen in airplanes. The rule will not apply to vehicles weighing more than 8,500 pounds.

headline: Corporate Money Allowed for Inaugural Donations
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Campaign Finance', 'Inaugurations']
abstract: President Obama’s 2013 inauguration will be low-key, compared with 2009’s festivities, but this year corporate donations, with some exceptions, will be welcome.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will accept unlimited donations from corporations — but no money from lobbyists or political action committees — to finance his 2013 inaugural festivities, a spokeswoman for his inaugural committee said Friday.

headline: Aiming Beyond the Diner Décor
abstract: Fancy Lee Asian Bistro ’n’ Sushi in Babylon defies its dinerlike looks by offering a menu of Pan-Asian dishes with great flair and variety.
lead_paragraph: It is safe to say no one is coming to Fancy Lee Asian Bistro ’n’ Sushi for the décor. The restaurant, which opened early last year in Babylon, resembles neither a sedate traditional-style Japanese restaurant nor an ornate Pan-Asian palace. Instead, it looks like the diner that the building once was.

headline: Japanese Quake Stirs On-Air Alarm, but No Damage to Nuclear Plants Is Reported
keywords: ['Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Earthquakes']
abstract: After a 7.3-magnitude earthquake hit near the same area affected by last year’s earthquake and tsunami, a television broadcaster urged people to “flee now to save your life!”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was perhaps the surest sign that Japan remains unnerved by last year’s devastating earthquake and tsunami. After a large quake on Friday hit near the same area stricken last year, broadcasters on the public television network NHK threw aside their usual reserve to repeatedly issue worried warnings about tsunamis, with one host frantically urging people to “flee now to save your life!”

headline: Jobs Report Becomes Fodder in Fiscal Debate
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans seized on November’s job numbers to press for a compromise on a deficit deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats and Republicans seized on November’s job numbers on Friday to press for a compromise on a deficit deal, as Speaker John A. Boehner opened the door slightly to tax rate increases as part of a broad fiscal package.

headline: Tacos Every Which Way, and Beer From the Can
abstract: Even though Bartaco restaurant in West Hartford cultivates an atmosphere of convivial machismo, it serves up dainty tacos that can fall apart in your hands.
lead_paragraph: The newest of three tequilacentric restaurants, offshoots of the popular Barcelona tapas bars based in Fairfield County, Bartaco occupies a prime slot in West Hartford Center. The place has a brash and sunny feel, with high ceilings, whitewashed barn-wood walls, gleaming oak booths and a central three-sided bar where silver citrus juicers stand sentinel at every corner. The walls display colossal photos of tropical beaches, bikini-clad goddesses and bearded outdoorsmen conquering Alpine peaks.

headline: Hoping to Wake Up Against Saints, Giants Revisit a Nightmare
abstract: To motivate the Giants’ defense before Sunday’s game against the Saints, the team watched film of the 49-24 thumping by New Orleans last season in which the Saints amassed 577 yards.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ season-long quest to return to the defensive heights that carried them to last season’s Super Bowl triumph may revolve around motivation drawn from watching one of the worst performances in their 88-year history.

headline: An Enemy of Brussels, and Not Afraid to Say So
abstract: A political party, and its irascible leader, Nigel Farage, has gained on the strength of one idea: Britain needs to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG, France

lead_paragraph: On the Street: The male fashion peacock is out of the cage.

headline: A Pizza for Dessert? Naturally. With S’mores.
abstract: Härth, a new spot in the Hilton Westchester, has a farm-to-table sensibility and offers enticing combinations of flavors and textures in entrees like rib-eye steak served with lobster mac.
lead_paragraph: IT has been years since going to a restaurant in a hotel typically meant suffering through mediocre fare designed mainly for the convenience of those staying there. Still, I cringed a little upon entering the Hilton Westchester in Rye Brook to go to its new restaurant, Härth, despite an attractive renovation that has opened up the space and made it more inviting. I smelled the chlorine of the indoor pool, saw the hotel’s generic welcome desk and thought, this isn’t promising.

headline: Holiday Boxes on Stoops Bring Reports of Thefts
keywords: ['Gifts', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'E-Commerce', 'Delivery Services']
abstract: As more consumers order gifts online, they are being advised to be proactive against thefts, by tracking packages and requiring signatures upon delivery.
lead_paragraph: A pair of brown leather boots was snatched last week from a doorstep in the suburbs of Chicago. A computer disappeared from a front porch in Fort Worth last month, and an iPad case was stolen outside a Long Island home this week.

headline: Strapped District Plans to Add Online Classes
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'E-Learning', 'Charter Schools', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)']

lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Budget cuts have eliminated about 95 full-time teachers from the school district here over the past year, swelling class sizes and prompting parents to cry foul.

headline: Harlem to Say Goodbye to an Art Deco Haven of Jazz
abstract: The Lenox Lounge, which opened in 1942, will close on Dec. 31 and will reopen next year under a new owner, worrying regulars who feel it will lose its appeal.
lead_paragraph: The Lenox Lounge, where Billie Holiday had a table, Dizzy Gillespie played his trumpet, and James Baldwin soaked up the scene, where the burgundy leather couches, Art Deco light fixtures and zebra-print wallpaper stir up memories of other eras, and where, even now, everybody knows everybody, will close on Dec. 31.

headline: A True Story of Hate and Redemption
abstract: “The Best of Enemies,” at the George Street Playhouse, recounts the unlikely friendship between Claiborne Paul Ellis, a Klansman, and Ann Atwater, a civil rights activist.
lead_paragraph: I buy the idea of “Driving Miss Daisy”: A grouchy Southern Jewish white widow and her soft-spoken black chauffeur defy tradition and become close friends as the civil rights movement changes the world around them. But a Ku Klux Klan leader and an African-American woman who become pals? In the 1970s?

headline: Twenty and Counting
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: So there are going to be more women in Congress. But what does that mean?
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that there are going to be 20 women in the Senate next year. I’ve been trying to figure out what that means.

headline: Canada Clears $15 Billion Chinese Takeover of an Energy Company
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The takeover would give China some footholds in the Gulf of of Mexico and the Canadian oil sands in the North Sea.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Canada on Friday allowed a Chinese state-run oil giant to move forward with $15 billion takeover of a domestic energy company, but the government indicated that such deals might not pass muster in the future.

headline: Cheaper Money
abstract: Converting from paper dollar bills to the dollar coin would be a reasonable way for Washington to save money.
lead_paragraph: America’s money is too expensive. That’s essentially what the Government Accountability Office stressed last week to a House subcommittee examining possible changes in America’s currency. Paper dollar bills wear out after four or five years, and replacing them with a sturdier coin could save $4.4 billion over the next 30 years. Pennies were not mentioned, but they, too, should get some reconsideration, on cost grounds alone: a single penny costs the government two pennies to make.

headline: Some Thieves at City’s Jails Lurk Outside
abstract: Two women who were visiting inmates at the Rikers Island corrections complex on a Sunday in October had property stolen from their cars.
lead_paragraph: From a thief’s point of view, the place had a lot of potential.

headline: Bid to Write New Rules for Funds Gains Ally
keywords: ['Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A member of the S.E.C. who had been opposed to a proposal to overhaul the money market fund industry has had a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: A type of mutual fund could lose its trademark stable value of $1 a share after a crucial government official voiced his support for controversial efforts to overhaul the $2.6 trillion money market fund industry.

headline: Mavericks Succeeding Without Their Coach
abstract: The Minnesota State Mavericks have reached the national Division II semifinals without their coach, Todd Hoffner, who  missed the season because of legal charges that have now been dismissed.
lead_paragraph: MANKATO, Minn. — Football practice ended early, in the twilight, at Minnesota State University on Wednesday. As has been the case since mid-August, the Mavericks crossed Stadium Road to their locker room, cleats clacking on the asphalt. As they have all season, they made the walk without their coach.

headline: In WikiLeaks Case, Defense Puts the Jailers on Trial
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Torture', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: While Pfc. Bradley Manning faces a life sentence if convicted, his lawyer is demanding answers about his treatment at the Marine base where he was kept.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — In a half-empty courtroom here, with a crew of fervent supporters in attendance, Pfc. Bradley Manning and his lawyer have spent the last two weeks turning the tables on the government.

headline: It’s Hard to Be a Hero
abstract: What would you do if you saw someone pushed onto the subway tracks?
lead_paragraph: On a crisp January day in 2007, a 50-year-old construction worker named Wesley Autrey became a New York hero when he rescued a man who had fallen onto the subway tracks.

headline: Certified Safe, a Factory in Karachi Still Quickly Burned
keywords: ['Series', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Retail giants have helped create and champion numerous factory inspection systems, but industry-backed auditing was no protection for at least 262 Pakistanis who died in a September blaze.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The century-old Central Jail here, a gritty repository of criminals, jihadists and sectarian killers, has a reputation for overcrowding and prisoner riots. But for Arshad and Shahid Bhaila, the industrialist brothers whose factory burned to the ground in September, killing at least 262 workers, there are some comforts.

headline: Scrooge. The Grinch. Congress.
abstract: Extending federal jobless benefits is the least the lawmakers should do before they leave town for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy didn’t suppress job growth in November by as much as economists had expected. But the jobs report, released on Friday, offers plenty of bad signs, and no reason to believe the picture will improve unless Congress starts dealing with high unemployment and the needs of those already out of work for months.

headline: Beyond the Fiscal Cliff
abstract: As Congress waits for negotiators to resolve the budget standoff, there is business in political ethics that could be accomplished.
lead_paragraph: As Congress waits for negotiators to resolve the budget standoff, there is other worthy business that could be accomplished, particularly in political ethics.

headline: After Stroke, Living in a Home Filled With Bickering, and Love
abstract: Despite a stroke left her partially paralyzed, Marianela Toro has kept her spirits high, with the help of a sister and a nephew.
lead_paragraph: A conversation between two roommates, Marianela Toro and Ana Ventura, on a recent afternoon consisted of disparaging comments soaked in sarcasm and exasperated sighs that were soon chased with laughter. There was even a weapon brandished: Ms. Ventura, 43, threatened Ms. Toro, 46, with a pillow.

headline: Next Civil Rights Landmark
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The battle over marriage equality finally lands on the Supreme Court’s docket.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-eight years after it banned discrimination in public education, the Supreme Court has set the stage for the defining civil rights decision of this era — agreeing to hear two cases challenging laws that define marriage to exclude couples of the same sex. To us, and a growing number of Americans, the right course seems clear: that the justices continue the march toward real equality.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for Dec. 7, 2012 for New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.

headline: Ytterbium’s Atomic Number
abstract: Barry C. Silk is back with a satisfying Saturday that’s on the easier side.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — SEVENTY. The answer is SEVENTY.

headline: Dinosaurs and Denial
keywords: ['Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio created quite a stir with comments about the age of Earth, but his answer was in line with the consensus of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Finally, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida — a Tea Party darling and possible 2016 presidential candidate — admits that dinosaurs and humans didn’t co-exist.

headline: Bill on Russia Trade Ties Sets Off New Acrimony
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Jackson-Vanik Amendment']
abstract: Officials in Moscow are angry over the financial and travel restrictions on human rights violators that were attached to the bill making Russia a full trading partner with the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In theory, the action by Congress this week to make Russia a full trading partner — finally doing away with a 38-year ban that once punished the Soviet Union over its restrictive emigration rules — could have begun a new era of happier ties between former cold war rivals.

headline: Jon Kest, Advocate for Low-Wage Workers in New York, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Kest, who organized a strike last month by New York City’s fast-food employees, was a founder of the Working Families Party.
lead_paragraph: Jon Kest, a founder of the Working Families Party and a longtime community advocate in New York, who organized the recent strike by the city’s fast-food workers, among many other initiatives, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 57.

headline: Jets’ Focus Returns to Ground Game
abstract: The Jets have returned to Rex Ryan’s philosophy of a running game identity by averaging 140 yards rushing in the past three games.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — All of the attention paid to Mark Sanchez this week overlooks a simple point: the quarterback is not supposed to be the focal point of the Jets’ offense.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 8, 2012
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Dec. 8, 2012.
lead_paragraph: If we see any rockets and missiles, it will probably be the ones fired at us.

headline: Subverting the Standard Survey
abstract: “Artists in America,” an exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art, covers 300 years but disrupts the flow of linear history to show new connections.
lead_paragraph: An impressive selection of 79 artworks dating from the 1700s to the present makes up “Artists in America: Highlights of the Collection From the New Britain Museum of American Art” at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. But while the museum’s Web site says the exhibition “surveys 300 years of great American painting,” the show isn’t arranged as a historical survey at all. Instead, it reflects recent curatorial trends, which lean toward mash-up or collage aesthetics, with paintings hung in pairs or groupings that consciously disrupt the flow of linear history.

headline: Marty Reisman, 82, a Wizard of Table Tennis, Dies
abstract: Mr. Reisman won national championships, won and lost fortunes on wagers and moved crowds to laughter as an opening act for the Harlem Globetrotters.
lead_paragraph: Marty Reisman, a wizard at table tennis, the sport in which he captured national championships, won and lost fortunes on wagers and moved crowds to laughter — sometimes using a frying pan as a paddle — as an opening act for the Harlem Globetrotters, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Point Guards Past and Present Send Nets to Third Straight Loss
abstract: Stephen Curry, the guard being groomed by Coach Mark Jackson, who starred on his high school team in Brooklyn, scored 21 points in the second half to lift the Warriors over the Nets.
lead_paragraph: As the Warriors’ bus pulled up to Barclays Center on Friday, Coach Mark Jackson imagined for a moment what effect the glittery new arena and the rebranded Nets franchise would have on young point guards in New York.

headline: Small-Scale Works That Surprise at Every Turn
abstract: It’s been nearly 40 years since an American museum mounted a major show devoted to the work of Anthony Caro, and there’s much to catch up with.
lead_paragraph: Steel that bends like a palm frond. Porcelain that mimics paper. And paper that flows like a river. The famed British sculptor Anthony Caro, still at work at 88, is a kind of alchemist, transmuting a range of materials and playing with our perceptions. These tricks of his can be contemplated at intimate range in the strong, lively small-scale works — most from private collections — that make up “Caro: Close Up,” at the Yale Center for British Art.

headline: Russia: Prosecutors Investigate After Exhibition Draws Complaints
abstract: Prosecutors in St. Petersburg are investigating an exhibition at the State Hermitage Museum by the British artists Jake and Dinos Chapman for possible violations of a law on inciting religious hatred.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in St. Petersburg are investigating an exhibition at the State Hermitage Museum by the British artists Jake and Dinos Chapman for possible violations of a law on inciting religious hatred. The exhibition, which opened in October, is called “The End of Fun” and addresses themes of violence and fascism in a series of installations resembling a chamber of horrors. A statement posted Friday on the Web site of the St. Petersburg prosecutor’s office said that “numerous citizens” had complained that the exhibition “offends the feelings of Orthodox believers and contains actions directed at degrading the dignity of citizens who profess Christianity.” The installations include a figure of the McDonald’s clown mascot, Ronald McDonald. crucified on a cross. Mikhail Piotrovsky, the Hermitage’s director, said the investigation of the exhibition was a sign of “the cultural degradation of our society,” according to the Interfax news agency. Members of the band Pussy Riot were tried and convicted in a similar case this year.

headline: In This Show, the Abstract Is Here and Now
abstract: An exhibition of 40 paintings and prints at the Rye Arts Center aims to enlighten gallerygoers about what abstract art is.
lead_paragraph: RYE, N.Y. — Abstraction is often defined as what it is not: it is not representational, not objective, not figurative, not realistic, not narrative. “From Where I Stand: 12 Contemporary Abstract Artists,” an exhibition of 40 paintings and prints at the Rye Arts Center, aims to enlighten gallerygoers about what abstract art is and to present an assortment of methods and aesthetics at play in the genre.

headline: Congo: Peace Talks Delayed
abstract: Peace talks between rebels and the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Uganda were delayed Friday as negotiators failed to arrive on schedule.
lead_paragraph: Peace talks between rebels and the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Uganda were delayed Friday as negotiators failed to arrive on schedule, Congolese and rebel officials said.

headline: Quinn Backs Expansion of Campaign Spending
abstract: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, supports a bid to change the city’s campaign finance rules that the Campaign Finance Board says would create gaping loopholes in the city’s regulations.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and an expected candidate for mayor next year, is supporting a change to New York City’s campaign finance rules that would significantly expand the ability of unions, corporations and advocacy groups to spend money on behalf of local candidates.

headline: Hot Chocolate Under Stuffed Moose
abstract: Reko Moreno, 30, and Kat Castaneda, 28, actors from Studio City, Calif., celebrated their engagement at the Hudson Lodge, which cultivates a kitschy urban ski lodge ambience.
lead_paragraph: The big stuffed moose peers down in amusement at the midweek crowd gathered on the Hudson Hotel’s terrace, newly tented in for the winter. Other assorted taxidermy, twinkling lights, sleds, skis, wooden tables and couches draped in fur throw rugs create the full-on incongruity of an urban ski lodge on West 58th Street. In lieu of expensive lift tickets, customers at the Hudson Lodge open their wallets for spiked and steaming drinks and gooey foodstuffs like fondue, cookies and s’more grilled cheese sandwiches. Manufactured snow shoots into the air nightly after 8, drawing tequila-induced squeals and melting into soap suds on the pates of prematurely balding men in suits. As D.J. tunes bounce in the 1,500-square-foot tent, spillovers from holiday parties mingle with couples on second dates cozying on benches, enjoying the marshmallow ambience after a hard day on the office slopes.

headline: Convictions in ’95 Killing of Cabdriver to Be Vacated
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Five people, found guilty in 1997, had been imprisoned for more than 17 years in the fatal shooting of a livery cabdriver.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx district attorney said Friday that the murder convictions of five people found guilty in the 1995 shooting of a livery-cab driver must be thrown out.

headline: Women on the Margins
abstract: Charles N. Crittenton, a wealthy New York City druggist, opened his first home for prostitutes and unmarried pregnant girls in the city in 1883.
lead_paragraph: Q. There used to be a group of institutions for pregnant girls called Florence Crittenton Homes. Who was Florence Crittenton?

headline: Daring to Take the Long Way Home
abstract: Some New York City apps encourage the wanderlust in users instead of directing them to the shortest route between two points.
lead_paragraph: The point of a mapping app is to move you efficiently from one place to another. But Wanderous, a free iPhone app released this fall, turns that idea on its head. A user enters start and end points, and the app comes up with a meandering path to travel between them. Exploring the city has always been a popular subject for New York-based  apps,  and Wanderous is one of several that aim to make strolling around the city feel like a game.

headline: Knicks Are Bombarding Their Opponents With 3-Pointers

During training camp and after practice, many members of the Knicks did not lift weights or head to the treadmill. Instead, they looked for a ball and the 3-point line.

headline: Dance Is Never Far From His Mind
abstract: Robert Battle, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, indulges in the coffee, culture and cuisine the city has to offer, when he’s not thinking about rehearsals.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Robert Battle became the third person to head the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater since the company was founded in 1958. During the troupe’s season in New York, which runs through Dec. 30 at City Center, Mr. Battle attends both the matinee and evening performances. At other times, the day is more relaxing (though he also can’t seem to stay away from Ailey’s Midtown studios). Mr. Battle, 40, has for the past 14 years shared his Upper West Side apartment with Nina Miller, a voice teacher, who he says has become “like family.”

headline: The Maestro of Flushing
abstract: Maurice Peress, 82, may head a student orchestra at Queens College, but he runs it like a big-time Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: “You’re eating up my energy,” roared Maurice Peress, 82, as he rushed around his Manhattan apartment on Wednesday evening. He was preparing for a rehearsal but kept getting sidetracked by questions about his 60 years as an orchestra conductor, the last 30 at the Queens College Aaron Copland School of Music.

headline: Eyes of the Soccer World Turn to Manchester
abstract: The rivalry between Manchester City and Manchester United, the top teams in the Premier League, will be on display when the teams clash Sunday.
lead_paragraph: With just one swish of his right foot, Sergio Aguero changed the landscape of English soccer forever. His stoppage-time goal against Queens Park Rangers on the final day of the Premier League season in May clinched Manchester City’s first league title in 44 years and confirmed Manchester United was no longer the only soccer superpower in the northwest of England.

headline: Are the Knicks This Good?
abstract: The Knicks are atop the Eastern Conference with a 14-4 record. They were expected to be competitive, but can they keep up this pace? A cast of die-hard basketball fans offer an outlook.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks stand atop the Eastern Conference with a 14-4 record and have already demolished the Miami Heat on two occasions, including a 112-92 rout Thursday night in which Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks’ best player, did not suit up. The Knicks were expected to be a competitive team this season, but no one can really say he saw this kind of basketball coming.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) WAR HORSE (2011) Steven Spielberg’s sweeping adaptation of the popular stage spectacle follows Joey, a fleet-footed headstrong half-thoroughbred who has formed an unbreakable bond with a strapping lad, Albert (Jeremy Irvine, above), on his parents’ tenant farm in England. Across the English Channel, on the battlefields and in the trenches of Flanders and France, Joey and Albert endure parallel experiences, including harrowing escapes, the loss of friends, terror and deprivation. Peter Mullan and Emily Watson play Albert’s parents, and David Thewlis is their landlord in this story written by Lee Hall and Richard Curtis, based on the novel by Michael Morpurgo. “Like most movies with an antiwar message, ‘War Horse’ cannot help but be enthralled by the epic scale and transformative power of military conflict,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “  ‘The war has taken everything from everyone’ — the truth of this reckoning, uttered more than once by characters on screen, is self-evident, but it is complicated by the visceral charge and cathartic relief that an effective war movie gives to its audience.” Still, “The extreme violence of the slaughter in World War I is implied rather than graphically depicted,” he added. “Mr. Spielberg steps back from the bloody, chaotic naturalism of ‘Saving Private Ryan’ — this is an animal fable for children, after all, with echoes of ‘E. T.’ and Carroll Ballard’s ‘Black Stallion’ — but his ability to infuse action sequences with emotional gravity has hardly diminished.”

They had just received a radio assignment from an instructor: 911 had taken a complaint about an “E.D.P.” — an emotionally disturbed person — in their sector. They were told to report to the location and advise.

headline: The Great Divide, Now in the Toy Aisle
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Children and Childhood', 'Income Inequality', 'Toys']
abstract: Parents who can afford to shop only at mass-market retailers won’t find the kinds of playthings, like games of logic or sequence, that can help their children advance.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, at the 109th Annual American International Toy Fair, held at the Javits Convention Center as one of the culture’s most convincing cases for childlessness, a former investment banker named Jill Todd displayed “The Tuneables,” an interactive DVD series she had created through her company, the Music Intelligence Project. The daughter of two musicologists, Ms. Todd developed the project in conjunction with her parents as an instructional system in melody, rhythm and tone — the fundamentals of music leveraged as a means to enhance cognitive function. Nearby, but easily obscured by the acres of primary-color plastic, was a booth for a company called Fat Brain Toys, whose games and puzzles in logic and sequencing came with an impressive lineage, some of them designed by the celebrated inventor Ivan Moscovich, a Holocaust survivor.

headline: Haiti’s Silenced Victims

The message came from a Haitian researcher in our group, an enthusiastic and talented graduate student whom we’ll call Wendy. She had been walking alone a few blocks from our hotel when she was forced into a house and brutally raped.

headline: An Unexpected Journey: Hobbits in the Heartland
abstract: A long-ago journey across barren prairies led to the chamber holding that precious hoard from Middle-earth.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years and 300 leagues separate me from that wintry day and place, yet how well I remember. Wearing a blue goose-down jerkin over my doublet, and boots, I descended the stairs to a library chamber and beheld with my own eyes the grave and thrilling history of Middle-earth, in its earliest form — page after page of the words, runes and drawings of J. R. R. Tolkien, the original texts, with corrections and annotations in his own spidery hand. How long I tarried there I do not know, yet even a scant minute would have justified my long journey across barren prairies to the city of men beside the Great Lake where the precious hoard had come to rest.

lead_paragraph: Menzie Chinn has some fun pointing out that if the doctrine Heritage was pushing to oppose fiscal stimulus were true — namely, that government borrowing always crowds out an equal amount of private spending — then the fiscal cliff could not be a problem. Hey, the government is going to borrow less, which will automatically and necessarily lead to an equal rise in private borrowing, so total demand can’t be affected, right?

abstract: Negotiations between the president and Congressional Republicans hinge on a concept outlined in a book called “Getting to Yes.”

Knowing your true Batna — and your adversary’s — is critical in bargaining. A vivid example from the entertainment world illustrates the concept and offers some useful hints about how the current fiscal negotiations in Washington are likely to unfold.

A novelist turned right-wing firebrand, he has long held celebrity status on the political margins, where he was known for dramatic flourish. He once signed a pact in blood to oppose diplomatic ties with China because of its communist government, and he published a book at the height of Japan’s economic power that lectured his countrymen on the need to end what he considered its postwar servility to the United States.

Three divisions have been settled and two more could be this weekend, but the playoff picture is still spectacularly scintillating. Colts-Broncos in the Peyton Bowl? Sign us up. But subplots — and no shortage of firings, benchings and questionable decisions — abound to tide us over until January. Put down the holiday catalogs and keep this guide handy.

Aidner of Los Angeles, was married Saturday evening to Micah Levy Brill, the son of Ralph Brill of North Adams, Mass., and the late Gail J. Koff, who lived in New York. Rabbi Jordan Millstein officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street, an event space in New York.

headline: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay

lead_paragraph: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay were married Saturday at the Acqualina Resort and Spa in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. The Rev. Milan R. Kralik, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Erin Nicole Moughon and David Paul Smith were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Gary Wiley, an evangelical minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

headline: Kerry Nordling, David Mayurnik
abstract: The bride works in book publishing, the groom in radio news.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Catherine Nordling and David Paul Mayurnik were married Saturday evening at Meadow Wood Manor, an event space in Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Carroll J. Mrowicki, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, performed the ceremony.

headline: Sonya Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz
abstract: The bride is a White House staff photographer in Washington; the groom is a partner in Godwin Lewis, a law firm in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Sonya Natasha Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz are to be married Sunday at the Carnegie Institute for Science in Washington. Rabbi Stan Levin is to officiate.

headline: Pacquiao Stunned in Sixth Round
abstract: Juan Manuel Marquez knocked out Manny Pacquiao at the end of the sixth round of their nontitle welterweight bout, beating him for the first time in his fourth attempt.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Manny Pacquiao never saw it coming. He never saw the punch that snapped his head back Saturday and dropped him to the canvas and left him sprawled there momentarily, face down, while his wife sobbed uncontrollably and the packed crowd at MGM’s Grand Garden Arena rose to its feet in shock.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: An article in Open magazine titled “The Villain Nobody Knows” looks at the beginnings of the Babri Masjid controversy. “The idea that eventually changed the politics of India emerged for the first time among three friends,” write the authors, who trace its origins to Maharaja Pateshwari Prasad Singh, head of the princely state of Balrampur, Mahant Digvijai Nath, politician and religious leader, and KKK Nair, an Indian Civil Service officer, whose friendship was formed over a shared interest in Hindu communalism (and tennis).

headline: Like the Band They Follow, Stones Fans Are Grayer but Still Spry
abstract: Judging by the crowds streaming into Barclays Center in Brooklyn for the first Rolling Stones concert in the city since 2006, many of their fans are aging as gracefully as the band.
lead_paragraph: After 50 years in the rock music business, the Rolling Stones have an average age of 68, higher than the average age of the justices on the United States Supreme Court. By all accounts, they are aging well, as have their songs.

headline: Reindeer Games in Hong Kong
abstract: A new Christmas video by CBRE in Hong Kong addresses one of the critical problems in Santa’s supply chain.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong has one of the most expensive and crowded property markets in the world, and CBRE, the commercial real estate services firm with offices here, can be highly imaginative when illustrating that point.

headline: Well-Worn Sound, With Unrelenting Swagger
abstract: What is a Rolling Stones show in 2012? At the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Saturday it was slapping guitar from Keith Richards and irrepressible stamina from Mick Jagger.
lead_paragraph: In a filmed montage of celebrity adoration before the start of the Rolling Stones show on Saturday night at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Iggy Pop had a good line. He was remembering seeing the band play in the late ’60s, and he said, approvingly, that hearing Keith Richards’s guitar sound back then felt like being hit with a dead mackerel.

headline: Ignoring Planetary Peril, a Profound ‘Disconnect’ Between Science and Doha
keywords: ['Kyoto Protocol', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Despite impassioned pleas — and only after 24 hours of overtime — the already largely ineffective Kyoto Protocol was extended until 2020 when a more global emission reduction agreement, currently under negotiation, is to take effect.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most poignant moments of the Doha climate talks, the Philippine climate change commissioner, Naderev M. Sano, appealed to his fellow negotiators at a session deciding the contours of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.

headline: Afghan and Coalition Forces Rescue American Doctor Who Was Kidnapped by Taliban
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At least six people were killed, including a Navy SEAL member, in the rescue of Dr. Dilip Joseph, who was abducted Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American doctor kidnapped by the Taliban was rescued Sunday by Afghan and coalition forces in eastern Afghanistan, officials said. At least six people were killed, including a member of a U.S. special forces Navy SEAL team. Two Taliban leaders were arrested during the rescue.

headline: All He Wants for Hanukkah Are In-App Purchases
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Hanukkah', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Parenting']
abstract: Is there any down-side to in-app game purchases that let kids short cut the “hard work” of the game?
lead_paragraph: “In-app purchases,” my son said when I asked him what he wanted for Hanukkah. I was dismayed. He wanted to buy the $0.99 and up shortcuts that let him level up in his iPod games. It’s a cash cow for video game developers, a freemium business strategy that allows you to download apps for free but which hits you up for cash later in exchange for slogging through hours of gameplay and unlocking content fast.

lead_paragraph: Robin van Persie is unlikely to forget his first Manchester derby.

headline: Disruptions: How My Smartphone Emptied My Pockets
abstract: People’s wallets used to expand with each passing year. Now, the opposite is happening: many of the wallet’s contents have been siphoned out by the smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I noticed that something happened to my father as he aged: his wallet expanded with each passing year.

headline: Tom Wolfe Would Hardly Recognize The Bronx Today
abstract: Twenty-five years after the publication of Tom Wolfe’s “The Bonfire of the Vanities” the South Bronx depicted in the book has changed.
lead_paragraph: Two white people, one of them a young woman decked out in a royal-blue Avenue Foch jacket with shoulders out to here . . . enough matched luggage in the back seat for a trip to China . . . a $48,000 Mercedes roadster . . . in the middle of the South Bronx . . .Miraculous!

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Romanians went to the polls on Sunday in parliamentary elections that have threatened to push the country further into political upheaval and acrimony.

headline: On Our Radar: The Doha Denouement

headline: Mortgage Crisis Presents a New Reckoning to Banks
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A torrent of lawsuits could add significantly to billions of dollars of settlements in mortgage securities cases.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks are facing a fresh torrent of lawsuits asserting that they sold shoddy mortgage securities that imploded during the financial crisis, potentially adding significantly to the tens of billions of dollars the banks have already paid to settle other cases.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (ABC) CHRISTMAS WITH HOLLY (2012) Mark Nagle (Sean Faris) is the uncle and guardian, along with his two brothers, of 6-year-old Holly (Lucy and Josie Gallina), who hasn’t spoken a word since her mother died unexpectedly. He also owns a coffee shop in Friday Harbor, Wash., where Maggie Conway (Eloise Mumford, above with Mr. Faris) has moved after her fiancé left her at the altar. Maggie’s dream, quickly fulfilled: to open a toy store in this town, where she spent her summers as a girl. During the holiday retail crunch, she can’t help but be drawn to Holly each time she comes in. Alex Paxton-Beesley plays Mark’s girlfriend, who may or may not be what keeps Mark and Maggie from getting to know each other in this “Hallmark Hall of Fame” production.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: After it was rejected by the national regulator, the combination of 3 Austria and Orange Austria appears headed for approval after the intervention of the E.U. competition commissioner.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For nearly a decade, financial analysts have expected a wave of mergers and acquisitions to sweep Europe’s fragmented telecommunications sector, consolidating the region’s 102 mobile operators and creating a more efficient market.

headline: James Bond Won’t Die at the Box Office Either
abstract: “Skyfall” climbed back to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend after more than a month in release. It took in an estimated $11 million between Friday and Sunday, lifting its domestic total to $261.6 million.
lead_paragraph: “Skyfall” climbed back to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend after more than a month in release — an extremely difficult box-office stunt to pull off, even for James Bond. “Skyfall” took in an estimated $11 million between Friday and Sunday, lifting its domestic total to $261.6 million and putting a $1 billion global gross within reach for Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

headline: Obama and Boehner Talk Deficits at the White House
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama and Speaker John Boehner met privately at the White House as a top Republican senator suggested that his party should perhaps accede to Mr. Obama’s demand to raise the top tax rates so that the attention can shift to making serious cuts in benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With just three weeks left for lawmakers to avert a fiscal crisis, President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner met privately at the White House on Sunday as a top Republican senator suggested that his party should perhaps accede to Mr. Obama’s demand to raise the top tax rates so that the attention can shift to making serious cuts in benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION While on patrol in Iraq in February 2007, Staff Sgt. Shilo Harris received burns to more than 40 percent of his body after an roadside bomb struck the truck that he was traveling in. But he refused medical treatment until he had been assured that his troops were safe. During the months of surgeries that followed, Mr. Harris and his wife, Kathreyn (above, with their children), found their calling: to help those undergoing the same anguished ordeal. Mr. Harris became a motivational speaker, and Ms. Harris started working for the Army Wounded Warrior Project. In this two-hour episode Ty Pennington and his crew renovate their home in Smithville, Tex., with the help of the actor J. R. Martinez and the country singer Lee Greenwood.

lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A senior commander for Al Qaeda has been killed in an American drone strike in North Waziristan, the restive tribal area along the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani security officials said Sunday.

headline: A Day for the Reds in the Manchester Derby
abstract: It was a tumultuous soccer match in Manchester on Sunday, settled by a winning goal in stoppage time that gave United a 3-2 victory on City's turf.
lead_paragraph: Manchester’s derby, City versus United, has grown into a game for all nations. The players now come from all over the world, and Sunday’s version was broadcast live to 212 countries. It was a tumultuous affair, settled by a winning goal in stoppage time that gave United a 3-2 victory on City’s turf.

From Damascus
abstract: Through decades of repression, Syria’s capital held on to an atmosphere of tranquility, but the proximity of recent clashes has left residents afraid to leave their neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Business has been terrible for Abu Tareq, a taxi driver, so last week, without telling his wife, he agreed to drive a man to the Damascus airport for 10 times the usual rate. But, he said later, he will not be doing that again.
