headline: Broadway on the Elbe
abstract: “Tarzan,” “The Lion King” and now “Rocky” are turning Hamburg, Germany, into a profitable city for big, splashy musicals.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — An eight-hour production of Goethe’s “Faust” may be the highbrow hit of the fall at the grand Thalia state theater here, but it is an altogether different blockbuster — the Disney musical “Tarzan” — that exemplifies why modern Hamburg has become that rare thing in the theater world: a reliable profit center for producers outside of their two biggest markets, New York and London.

headline: Nets’ Evans, Knowing Focus Is on Him, Tries to Stay on His Feet
abstract: A top rebounder, Reggie Evans is also viewed as one of the most shameless floppers. It’s a reputation he somewhat embraces, even as he tries to evade scrutiny in this new era of flopping prohibition.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Evans is a brawny, feisty rebounding machine who loves a good collision. It takes a lot to make him cringe. A brief exchange with Commissioner David Stern might have done it.

headline: Opponents of Egypt’s Leader Call for Boycott of Charter Vote
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Constitutions']
abstract: The Egyptian opposition signaled that it had given up hope of defeating the draft constitution at the polls and would opt instead to try to undermine the referendum’s legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The political crisis over Egypt’s draft constitution hardened on both sides on Sunday, as President Mohamed Morsi prepared to deploy the army to safeguard balloting in a planned referendum on the new charter and his opponents called for more protests and a boycott to undermine the vote.

headline: Next Act in Italian Drama: Exit Monti the Technocrat, Enter Monti the Politician?
abstract: Mario Monti’s announcement that he would step down as prime minister, raised the the possibility that he might run as a candidate.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For months, he had flirted with the idea of staying out of politics, but in the end former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi just could not resist. His statement on Saturday that he would seek office again out of a sense of “responsibility” for Italy effectively ended the mandate of Prime Minister Mario Monti, who said he would step down after Parliament passes a budget bill this month.

headline: Protest of Peace Prize for E.U. Turns Local
abstract: At a time when joining the European Union is an unpopular idea among Norwegians, giving the union the Nobel Peace Prize brought out the protesters.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — After braving a blizzard of denunciation from China from afar over its decision two years ago to honor a jailed Chinese dissident, the Norwegian Nobel Committee faced anger in its own backyard Sunday on the eve of a ceremony awarding this year’s Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union.

headline: The Lure of the Writer’s Cabin
abstract: From Heidegger’s hut to the Unabomber’s shack, we are drawn to the spaces in which writers create their work. But what do we hope to find?
lead_paragraph: Much has been written about the writer’s cabin. Among the most notable recent books on the topic are “Heidegger’s Hut” by Adam Sharr and “A Place of My Own: The Architecture of Daydreams,” Michael Pollan’s account of  imagining and then actually constructing his own writing space. A standard Internet search can quickly yield images of the writing rooms (cabins, huts, sheds) of legendary scriveners: Dylan Thomas, Virginia Woolf, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Roald Dahl, Carl Jung, Henry Thoreau and — a writer of a markedly different sort —Ted Kaczynski, to name a few. And Jill Krementz’s 1999 collection of photographs “The Writer’s Desk” gives us tantalizing glimpses of writers sitting at their desks. But why the interest? Have these places somehow become secular sites of the sacred?

headline: As Jets Stand by Sanchez, They Run Past Jaguars
abstract: A week after pulling him from a game, Rex Ryan gave the ball to Mark Sanchez, but installed a safe, protect-the-ball-first plan that focused on the run.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — It may not look like it sometimes, but the Jets want to win. Honest, they do. That desire to win consumes their lives, week after week after week, and guides their decisions — decisions like their call to start Mark Sanchez on Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, a week after he was removed with a bruised ego.

headline: Channeling Bach, With Intensity and Dexterity as Tools
abstract: Piotr Anderszewski’s Bach recital at Carnegie Hall included his own melody-driven personal touches.
lead_paragraph: Piotr Anderszewski hurried onto the stage of Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening with the awkward impatience of a stagehand who had left behind a tool and now had to retrieve it in front of an auditorium packed with expectant faces. Without a glance at the audience he sat down at the piano, lightly hunched his shoulders and began to play the first notes of Bach’s French Suite No. 5 in G.

headline: Fall Nationals in San Francisco
abstract: Quick — when you are nonvulnerable, which scores more: six spades redoubled and made with an overtrick, or seven spades doubled and made? What if you are vulnerable?

headline: Awakenings in a Kooky Wonderland
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s “Nutcracker,” from American Ballet Theater, is a human tale woven together by magic to pinpoint the strange, awkward time when a boy and a girl take their first tentative steps toward adulthood.
lead_paragraph: It begins with a little white mouse. The opening of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Nutcracker,” performed by American Ballet Theater, is flawless: Hiding under a table in the bustling Stahlbaum kitchen is an adorably droll rodent with twiggy legs and bony knees. After devouring a piece of cheese, he gives his beer belly a pat and waves off a couple of horrified maids. Was “The Nutcracker” missing a rogue all along?

headline: Top-of-the Lungs Welcome for Young Top-40 Favorites
abstract: Young British bands joined Taylor Swift and Justin Bieber at the annual Z-100 Jungle Ball showcase at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The Z-100 Jingle Ball 2012 was not the apotheosis of the sublime or the terrifying, but only the massive — as in British slang, as in, “Massive thank you to Z-100!,” a phrase the audience became accustomed to.

headline: Florida May Reduce Tuition for Select Majors

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Rick Scott, businessman turned politician, campaigned for governor in 2010 with promises to run Florida like a successful business — more efficiency, lower costs, less hand-wringing and measurable results.

headline: Messi’s Mark Leaves a Goal Yet to Achieve

lead_paragraph: If Lionel Messi had been born three hours from Barcelona, rather than from Buenos Aires, there would be little doubt today about his place in soccer history.

headline: In Girl’s Last Hope, Altered Immune Cells Beat Leukemia

headline: Time Passes, but a Song’s Time Doesn’t
abstract: “The Holy or the Broken” tells the story of “Hallelujah,” Leonard Cohen’s 1984 song whose popularity seems only to solidify.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen spent years struggling with his song “Hallelujah.” He recalls being in a New York hotel room in his underwear, “banging my head on the floor and saying, ‘I can’t finish this song.’ ” He wrote perhaps as many as 80 verses before paring the song down and recording it on the 1984 album “Various Positions.” Then his label, CBS Records, refused to release “Various Positions,” not realizing that “Hallelujah” would become one of the most haunting, mutable and oft-performed songs in American musical history.

headline: Patrick Moore, Eccentric Astronomer and TV Host, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Moore, who hosted BBC’s “The Sky at Night” astronomy program, was known for both his outsize personality and his scientific work.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Moore, an eccentric and accomplished astronomer, television show host and author of popular science books who once wrote an astronomy book with the guitarist from the band Queen, died on Sunday at his home in Selsey, England. He was 89.

headline: Humor at High Altitudes
abstract: The troupe Circus Oz, from Melbourne, Australia, blends comedy, music, acrobatics, trapeze and spectacle at the New Victory Theater.
lead_paragraph: There are no clowns and no lions (or any live animals for that matter). So unless you’re afraid of daring Australians who fly through the air — or men in tutus sprinkling fairy dust — you have no reason to fear Circus Oz. This Melbourne group’s fast and furious show “From the Ground Up” is the New Victory Theater’s holiday offering, and it’s a good one: a little naughty, a little nice, a little death defying.

lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1985 the World Music Institute has enriched New York’s cultural ecosphere with events featuring accomplished practitioners of classical and folkloric traditions from around the globe. Global Salon, a new series in the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space, is meant to illuminate its participants’ creative paths, mixing music and conversation in an intimate, stripped-down setting.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Wins a Video Game Honor

abstract: “The Walking Dead: The Game” was selected as the game of the year at the 10th annual Spike Video Game Awards on Friday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: The undying popularity of Robert Kirkman’s zombie property, “The Walking Dead,” continues to spread — first from comic books, then to television and now to video games. “The Walking Dead: The Game” (above) was selected as the game of the year at the 10th annual Spike Video Game Awards on Friday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Developed by Telltale Games, this downloadable game was released in five parts, reflecting the episodic nature of the comic book and the television series. Other winners included “Borderlands 2” (Gearbox Software) for best shooter and multiplayer game and “Journey” (thatgamecompany) for best independent game.

Masseuse/stylists (let’s call them “masstylists”) apply gentle fingertip pressure on both sides of your nose to clear sinuses. headline: Technology and Wages, the Analytics (Wonkish)

headline: As One-Acts, Operas Find Solidarity
abstract: The adventuresome Juilliard Opera fashioned a fascinating double bill from two disparate English operas that proved complementary in less than obvious ways.
lead_paragraph: One-act operas can seem to exist via reputation and recordings only, with staged presentations few and far between. Even the very best works in the genre tend to languish, often for the most prosaic reason: if an opera is too short to sustain a full program, what can it be paired with, profitably and sympathetically? The Italian red-sauce tandem “Pagliacci” and “Cavalleria Rusticana” is an example of an unusually successful coupling, bonded by blood and big tunes.

headline: A Stamp on the Outside, Intimacy on the Inside

In another letter he sadly observed, “We seem attached to each other by some stiff piece of wire, so that each time one moves, the other moves in another direction.”

lead_paragraph: “Méditation,” the interlude for solo violin from Massenet’s opera “Thaïs,” has developed a life of its own on the concert stage, but the opera itself is not often performed. Marked Andante religioso, the “Méditation” is played as the title character ponders giving up her life as a courtesan to enter a convent. Her night of soul-searching is heralded by remarkably sensual, passionate music, fit for a hedonist converted by a lustful monk.

headline: Nikolai V. Zlobin: Selected Quotations
abstract: The political analyst Nikolai V. Zlobin documents meticulously everyday American life for an uncomprehending Russian readership.
lead_paragraph: The political analyst Nikolai V. Zlobin documents meticulously everyday American life for an uncomprehending Russian readership. It seems strange that ordinary Russians would still be hungry for details about how ordinary Americans eat, pay mortgages and hire teenage baby sitters. But to Mr. Zlobin’s surprise, his book — published this year and marketed as a guide to Russians considering a move abroad — is already in its fifth print run, and his publisher has commissioned a second volume. The following are selected quotes from his 400-page book, “America — What a Life!”

headline: Can You Be Creative in Berlin?
abstract: Our Riff on the challenges of being a productive artist in Berlin motivated several readers to write in with their own Berlin success stories.
lead_paragraph: In his Riff in the magazine’s Nov. 25 issue, Robert F. Coleman writes about his stint as a musician in Berlin. Instead of flourishing in a city many consider a “creative mecca,” he became one of the many people who flock to Berlin to pursue their art, only to realize months later that they haven’t produced a single piece of work. This motivated several of our readers to respond in disagreement, saying that it is possible to be a productive artist in Berlin and avoid all the partying — and laziness — associated with so-called “creative tourists.”

headline: A Hunger for Tales of Life in the American Cul-de-Sac

Zlobin recently found himself trying to explain, for an uncomprehending Russian readership, the American phenomenon of the teenage baby sitter.

He raised lambs with the local 4-H club and sheared them for elderly German farmers. His office is lined with paintings of sheep and a plaque honoring him for “promoting culinary excellence” in lambs.

headline: A Compelling Salute to Posterity
abstract: In her finale after more than 30 years of professional dancing, Renee Robinson was still a compelling image of style.
lead_paragraph: Renee Robinson gave the farewell performance every dancer would love to give at City Center Theater on Sunday evening. After more than 30 years of professional dancing, she was still a compelling image of style, moving with verve and élan at the heart of two of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s classic works. Any dancer in any company could learn from her about focus, projection and ardor; she danced as if she had not only the equipment to carry on much longer but the hunger for it too.

Memories probably aren’t that short. And once Big Boi’s solo career got moving — his 2010 album, “Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty,” was delayed by record-company conflicts — it was clear that he was keeping what made Outkast so memorable: fast-talking rhymes alongside full-fledged tunes that might draw on funk, new wave, club beats or hip-hop. headline: California: 25 Arrested Off Coast in Suspected Smuggling Case

lead_paragraph: Kathleen McCartney, the dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education, will be the next president of Smith College, effective July 1. Dr. McCartney, an expert in early childhood education, has degrees from Yale and Tufts, where she is a trustee, and is the Harvard representative on the founding board of edX, an online consortium. Under her leadership, the Harvard education school began a doctoral program in education leadership, a three-year tuition-free program designed in collaboration with the faculty from the Harvard Business School and the Harvard Kennedy School. She will succeed Carol T. Christ, who has led Smith since 2002.

In a league that is often teeming with undeserved bravado — the Jets come to mind — there is also an overwhelming amount of self-flagellation. headline: Delay Sought for Visa Cases That Involve Same-Sex Spouses
keywords: ['Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Americans are seeking legal residency visas for their foreign-born spouses of the same sex want their immigration cases delayed until the Supreme Court issues a ruling on same-sex marriage next year.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to the White House on Monday, more than 50 gay rights and immigrant advocacy groups asked President Obama to delay immigration cases involving Americans who are seeking legal residency visas, known as green cards, for their foreign-born spouses of the same sex until the Supreme Court issues a ruling on same-sex marriage next year. Under the federal Defense of Marriage Act, a same-sex marriage cannot be a valid basis for federal benefits, including immigration documents. Administration officials have been denying applications for green cards for foreign-born same-sex spouses of American citizens. On Friday, the Supreme Court agreed to hear two cases involving same-sex marriages, including a direct challenge to the federal law. The groups are asking the administration to postpone decisions on green card applications from gay couples until the court rules.

headline: Montana: Wolf Hunts Are Banned in Areas Bordering Yellowstone

abstract: Montana wildlife commissioners on Monday shut down all wolf hunts and prohibited trapping in areas of the state that border the northwest corner of Yellowstone National Park.
lead_paragraph: Montana wildlife commissioners on Monday shut down all wolf hunts and prohibited trapping in areas of the state that border the northwest corner of Yellowstone National Park. The decision was made after the eighth Yellowstone wolf wearing a tracking collar for research was killed this season. Bob Ream, the chairman of the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Commission, said the scientific study played a role in the decision. “We recognize they put a lot of time and money and effort into collaring wolves, and we want to see that research continue,” he said. Doug Smith, a senior wildlife biologist for the park, praised the decision as a “moderate” one that “addresses some of the issues as far as the science.”

headline: El Salvador: Court Orders Investigation of 1981 Massacre
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Inter-American Court of Human Rights has ruled that a 20-year-old amnesty law does not cover war crimes committed during El Salvador’s long civil war.
lead_paragraph: The Inter-American Court of Human Rights has ruled that a 20-year-old amnesty law does not cover war crimes committed during El Salvador’s long civil war. The ruling, which was announced Monday, ordered the government to investigate the massacre in the region of El Mozote 31 years ago and to prosecute and punish those hold responsible. More than 800 civilians, many of them children, were killed by the military in the worst massacre of the war, which began in 1979 and ended in 1992. But Salvadoran courts have refused to investigate the killings, citing a 1993 amnesty law. The regional court’s ruling means that “El Salvador will have to secure truth and justice for the crimes committed during this massacre,” said Viviana Krsticevic, executive director for the Center for Justice and International Law in Washington, which joined with the human rights office of the San Salvador archdiocese to take the case to the regional court.

Those who vowed never to forget her were matched by those who said: “Jenni who?” The short version is that she was a superstar in the border-straddling world of Mexican regional music, an immigrant’s daughter from a musical dynasty who sold millions of albums, became a TV celebrity and led a personal life straight out of a telenovela.

headline: Chinese Leader Offers Policy Hints
abstract: The state news media confirmed Monday that Xi Jinping, the new Communist Party chief, visited Guangdong Province over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The state news media confirmed Monday that Xi Jinping, the new Communist Party chief, visited Guangdong Province over the weekend, a trip first reported by Hong Kong news organizations. Mr. Xi chose Guangdong and the special economic zone of Shenzhen for his first tour outside of Beijing as party chief, signaling that he might favor more market-oriented economic policies. Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Monday that Mr. Xi met with business executives in Guangzhou and talked about tax reform, support for exports, aid for small businesses and land use. “We need both a firm confidence in victory and a stronger sense of peril,” he said, and added that officials should carry out “deeper reform,” improve the mechanisms of the market economic system and strengthen the “rule of law.”

headline: Welcome to Saudi Albany?
abstract: Fracking isn’t just going to change the energy business; it could change every business. And that’s pretty scary.

Once the icon of American manufacturing, the company became shorthand for the country’s industrial decline. For decades, it ignored innovation and was undercut by cheaper Asian producers and outflanked by U.S. start-ups. Its brief glory in the mid-2000s turned out to be fueled by housing-bubble excess; and its stock price has dropped nearly 90 percent since late 2008. A few months ago, John P. Surma, the company’s chairman and C.E.O., addressed a Steel Hall of Fame event at which all the inductees were either long dead or retired. He noted that, given the business climate, his own generation of steel C.E.O.’s might have trouble getting the big prize themselves.

headline: Bleeding Europe
abstract: Austerity, still not working.
lead_paragraph: Europe has surprised me with its political resilience — the willingness of debtor nations to endure seemingly endless pain, the ability of the ECB to do just enough, at the very last minute, to calm markets when the financial situation seems ready to explode. But the economics of austerity have played out exactly according to script — the Keynesian script, that is, not the austerian script. Again and again, “responsible” technocrats induce their nations to accept the bitter austerity medicine; again and again, they fail to deliver results. The latest case in point is Italy, where Mario Monti — a good guy, deeply sincere — is leaving early, ultimately because his policies are delivering Italy into depression. (And yes, for the record, this means that Italy won’t get the full Monti.)

headline: A Regional Oddball, Resurrected for Chilliest of Days
abstract: More common in the Midwest, the Tom and Jerry is a drink that arrives at New York bars typically in the coldest weeks.
lead_paragraph: DICKENSIAN trappings like wassail, flaming punch or mulled wine didn’t figure at all in the Christmases of my Wisconsin childhood. But at some point during the day, the adults would all hoist a hot mug of Anglo-American nostalgia: a Tom and Jerry.

headline: Melee at the Opera: Catcalls for Paris ‘Médée’
abstract: Audiences fed up with a radical director’s take on an opera usually save their rage till the final curtain calls. At a performance Monday night of Cherubini’s “Médée” at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées, the audience didn’t wait.
lead_paragraph: Audiences fed up with a radical director’s take on an opera usually save their rage till the final curtain calls. Monday night at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées, in the first of four performances of Cherubini’s “Médée,” the audience couldn’t wait and interrupted the performance. There are limits, it would seem, on just how far a director can go, and for many those limits were breached.

headline: In New Brand of Philanthropy, Nonprofits Invest in For-Profits
abstract: Deeming the pool of philanthropic assets too small to make a dent in the biggest social problems, an increasing number of philanthropists are enlisting capitalists.
lead_paragraph: When the W. K. Kellogg Foundation set aside $100 million in 2007 to invest in companies that could produce both social and financial benefits, it was considered revolutionary. Historically, major foundations had used mainly stocks, bonds, real estate and other traditional asset classes to build their endowments.

headline: That’s Demi, Not Semi
abstract: Whether it was hanging out with her rumored boy toy, the 26-year-old art dealer Vito Schnabel, or partying with Lenny Kravitz, Demi Moore provided plenty of material for anyone with access to a Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: EVER since her split with the much-younger Ashton Kutcher (and reports that she is distressed over his new relationship with Mila Kunis), Demi Moore has been keeping a relatively low profile. That all changed last week, with the actress’s here-there-and-everywhere appearances at Art Basel Miami Beach. Whether it was hanging out with her rumored boy toy, the 26-year-old art dealer Vito Schnabel (who reportedly broke up with her by week’s end), or partying with Lenny Kravitz and Stacy Keibler, or bringing a stray kitten as her date to a Chanel-hosted dinner party, Ms. Moore provided plenty of material for anyone with access to Twitter.

Kennedy and his interest in American history, the Columbia University Libraries announced on Tuesday. lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The German steel maker ThyssenKrupp, battered by slow economic growth and a series of corruption scandals, reported the biggest loss in its history late Monday and confirmed that three top executives would leave the company.

abstract: Ms. Vishnevskaya was a soprano of the postwar Soviet Union and later one of its most prominent political dissidents.
lead_paragraph: Galina Vishnevskaya, an electrifying soprano who endured repression and exile as one of the postwar Soviet Union’s most prominent political dissidents, died on Tuesday in Moscow. She was 86.

headline: Corcoran Gallery of Art Will Stay Put
abstract: After the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington alarmed fans of its spectacular Beaux-Arts home near the White House by announcing this summer that it was considering a relocation, the board of trustees said on Monday that its members have decided against a move.
lead_paragraph: After the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington alarmed fans of its spectacular Beaux-Arts home near the White House by announcing this summer that it was considering a relocation, the board said on Monday that its members had decided against a move. According to a news release, the board voted on Dec. 5 to “now focus only on approaches that keep the museum in the building,” including the possibility of a collaboration with another “like-minded institution.”

headline: Reshaping the Future of Cocoa in Africa
abstract: Strains on West Africa’s cocoa production have led to innovative partnerships for developing hardier trees and protecting the environment.
lead_paragraph: Seventy percent of the world’s cocoa now comes from West Africa, where family-run farms have proliferated across the landscape in recent decades. Yet in a paradox, the spread of these nonnative cocoa trees often contributes to deforestation. Rather than planting cacao trees under a forest canopy that shades them, which is the traditional method in Latin America, farmers in Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Ghana often clear forest so they can plant more trees and achieve higher yields.

abstract: Detectives on two coasts scoured for evidence and a motive after Brandon Lincoln Woodard, a law student from Los Angeles, was stalked and killed in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A single bullet. A nickel-plated gun. Two suspects, lying in wait in the light drizzle of a Monday afternoon in Midtown, stalking their victim for nearly 30 minutes.

headline: Why Everyone Is So Certain About Hillary 2016
abstract: All the talk today about the 2016 election — a veritable thousand lifetimes away in politics — is a little crazy. But not to know the latest on Clinton could prove embarrassing, not to say unforgivable.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The Hillary-in-2016 buzz has hit overdrive, and the political speculation game has gone viral. By ten o’clock Monday, I’d watched a variety of commentators on three cable news programs speculate, guess, opine and bet on the real and imaginary future of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Water Pollution and the Farm Economy
abstract: By exempting farmers from restricting fertilizer-laden runoff from their fields, the United States is making no headway on the water pollution front, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: As many people know, the astounding increase in agricultural output that marked the latter half of the 20th century came at a high environmental price. Agriculture is a major contributor to global warming, and runoff from farm fields helps pollute rivers and streams.

headline: New York Areas Offer $10 Lift Tickets, for a Day
abstract: More than 20 resorts across New York State are offering the deal for Jan. 10.
lead_paragraph: Ski resorts have in recent years been selling multiresort passes that promise so many potential slopes that their names alone (Epic, Mountain Collective, Yeti) get your adrenaline pumping. New York State ski areas haven’t come up with a catchy name yet but they do have a catchy promotion: $10 a lift ticket on Jan. 10.

headline: Judge Keeps Curbs on Travel for Defendant in Martin Case

headline: Zosia Mamet’s Winter Plans: On ‘Girls’ and Off Broadway
abstract: Ms. Mamet will star in Paul Downs Colaizzo’s “Really Really,” a drama about sexual politics and culture clashes among college students.
lead_paragraph: The actress Zosia Mamet will be playing two characters this winter who, apart from being lovelorn, could not be more different temperamentally. Just as she is returning to the HBO series “Girls” in January as the bubbly naïf Shoshanna Shapiro, Ms. Mamet will also make her Off Broadway debut as the downbeat, enigmatic Leigh in Paul Downs Colaizzo’s “Really Really,” a drama about sexual politics and culture clashes among college students. The MCC Theater production will be staged by David Cromer, the Obie-winning director of the recent Off Broadway productions “Our Town” and “Tribes.”

lead_paragraph: 5:09 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from Google.

headline: Messi’s Brilliance Transcends His Numbers
abstract: Lionel Messi, an Argentine forward who plays soccer for Barcelona, must be appreciated in the moment, not melted down to statistics, fans and teammates say.
lead_paragraph: It was Pep Guardiola, the former manager of Barcelona, who once suggested that Lionel Messi should be observed instead of dissected. He is, after all, widely considered the world’s greatest soccer player, not a biology project.

headline: Feeling For | Cole Haan and Fragment Design’s LunarGrand Loafer
abstract: A subtle change to an iconic shoe turns preppy into street-savvy.
lead_paragraph: Cole Haan’s partnership with Nike last year, when the former incorporated the latter’s Lunarlon foam cushioning into the soles of its shoes, resulted in LunarGrand, a collection of sportier wingtips and chukka boots that Cole Haan then expanded upon in a collaboration with Fragment Design‘s Hiroshi Fujiwara. That partnership’s pop-preppy shoes were an instant hit, achieving cult status among dandy-cool fashion folk — a pair of the spectator wingtips with neon pink soles are currently on eBay for almost four times their original retail price. Which is precisely why the latest shoe from this collaboration — a loafer with a white Lunarlon sole — is so exciting. “We wanted to explore a modern yet authentic reimagination of this iconic style,” says Gareth Lewis, Cole Haan’s men’s footwear design director. Completing this new series, which will be available tomorrow, are two spectator-like wingtips in brown and white with a neon orange sole or black and white with black sole. “It’s a subtle but bold reinterpretation of a timeless classic,” Lewis adds.

headline: Kidd Finds a Home Beyond the Arc
abstract: Jason Kidd was once known as a defensive wizard and passing virtuoso with a suspect jumper. Now he is one of the N.B.A.’s best 3-point shooters.
lead_paragraph: When the Nets play the Knicks on Tuesday night, they will have their hands full keeping the Knicks from scoring. The Knicks have had the N.B.A.’s second-best offense for most of the season, as measured by offensive efficiency.

headline: Beauty Spots
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Skin']
abstract: Metal found in pennies has been added to products seeking to maintain firm and radiant skin.
lead_paragraph: In a glittering season, copper is the beauty industry’s latest salvo against aging. The metal, best known for its presence in pennies, also has been mentioned in claims that it helps prevent collagen loss, for firmer and more radiant skin. But forget the pennies: the new products featuring it aren’t exactly cheap.

headline: Deconstructing Dodd-Frank
abstract: Since the law was passed in 2010, banks and other financial institutions have sought to tone down the most onerous aspects, fearful of the threat to their businesses and their bottom line.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has found a common enemy: the Dodd-Frank Act. After the industry’s aggressive risk-taking nearly toppled the financial system and the broader economy, Congress ushered in Dodd-Frank, the most significant regulatory overhaul since the Great Depression. Since the law was passed in 2010, banks and other financial institutions have sought to tone down the most onerous aspects of the law, fearful of the threat to their businesses and their bottom line.

headline: Slow Gains in Justice for Afghan Women
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Women and Girls', 'Domestic Violence', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Female victims of violence in Afghanistan are often afraid to report abuses to government authorities and rarely see their cases taken to trial, according to a United Nations report.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Women who are victims of violence in Afghanistan are often afraid to report abuses to government authorities and rarely see their cases taken to trial, though prosecutors regularly obtain convictions when cases do go forward, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations office here.

headline: Plenty of Footage (and Headaches) on the ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Shoot
abstract: “Zero Dark Thirty” wasn’t an easy production — locations changed and cameras got stuck in customs, as one of the producers recalls.
lead_paragraph: The Bagger’s pals over at Vulture have a lengthy examination of how Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal came to make “Zero Dark Thirty,” from Mr. Boal’s abandonment of his original script, which he spent two years on (about the failed hunt for Osama bin Laden in Tora Bora) to the tough working conditions on their six-month shoot in India and Jordan. Not that it put a dent in Ms. Bigelow’s directorial vision: she shot two million feet of footage. “The average is probably half of that,” Megan Ellison, a producer of the film, told the Bagger at a recent lunch at the 21 Club.

headline: Shia LaBeouf to Star Opposite Alec Baldwin in ‘Orphans’ on Broadway
abstract: Mr. LaBeouf will make his Broadway debut as a petty thief who kidnaps a mobster, to be played by Mr. Baldwin, in the revival of Lyle Kessler’s 1983 drama.
lead_paragraph: Shia LaBeouf is better known for performing high intensity heroics (the “Transformers” movies, the last Indiana Jones picture) than limning cold fury, but his new career move will give him a chance to play a bad boy – a very bad boy.

abstract: The move came after Azerbaijan asked for a steep increase in rent for the Gabala station, which can detect missile launchings throughout the Middle East.

headline: Tagliabue Lifts Suspensions but Not Blame in Bounty Case

headline: Molding Himself to the Moment
abstract: Bruno Mars’s new album, “Unorthodox Jukebox,” emphasizes a particular style or influence on each of its 10 tracks, offering energy-infused but profoundly cosseted songs.
lead_paragraph: If the Brill Building were still the songwriting hub it once was, Bruno Mars would be both guarding the entrance and occupying the penthouse suite. Not only is he probably the best pop-oriented traditionalist songwriter of the past five years, but he’s also the one who’s been most successful at preserving that practice in the mainstream. Others are more daring, their songs taking unanticipated left turns or staying in the high-minded conceptual clouds. But no one brings it home quite like Mr. Mars, a model of concision who always knows where the trigger is, and always, always pulls it.

headline: Storm-Tested Menorah, Off to the White House
abstract: A menorah housed in a Long Island temple ravaged by Hurricane Sandy will serve as a symbol of resilience at a White House Hanukkah celebration.

headline: The Fighting Irish Brigade
abstract: One of the Civil War’s most renowned immigrant-majority units was also among its most battle-scarred.
lead_paragraph: When the Civil War broke out, thousands of Irish-born men in both the North and the South volunteered for military service. Some 140,000 served in the Union Army, and they dominated at least 20 regiments. The most famous belonged to Thomas F. Meagher’s Irish Brigade. Meagher (pronounced “Mar”) was an Irish native whom the British had banished to Tasmania after he became involved in Ireland’s 1848 uprising. After escaping from the island, he made his way to America, where he became a popular lecturer on Irish independence.

headline: Bookshelf | The White Review
abstract: A sumptuous, cream-colored journal features interviews, essays, fiction and artwork by up-and-coming writers and artists.
lead_paragraph: London’s better-known literary publications tend to look after their own. Not unwisely, the London Review of Books et al repeatedly turn to a well-worn roster of credential-heavy big hitters for contributions — a default position that suits authors like Colm Tóibín, Jenny Diski and John Lanchester but which leaves emerging talent somewhat out in the literary cold. Small titles with lofty ambitions to break the trend have come and gone in Britain, but The White Review, a sumptuous, cream-colored journal that mixes interviews, essays, fiction and artwork by up-and-coming writers and artists, might just contain the youthful wherewithal to stick it out.

headline: Delusions of Wisdom

In said piece they talk to various Very Serious People, and divine the insider consensus on What Must Be Done — which mainly seems to involve, naturally, cutting Social Security and Medicare while reducing corporate tax rates.

headline: Thomas Hart Benton Masterwork Goes to Met
abstract: “America Today,” which depicts life just before the Great Depression, will go on display when the Met takes over the Whitney’s Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Day 1931, a new and radically different building opened amid the town houses of West 12th Street: Joseph Urban’s International-Style New School for Social Research, with one room in particular as a star attraction. Thomas Hart Benton, the American realist painter, had lined the third-floor boardroom with nine panels of what would be a 10-panel mural, “America Today,” depicting a panoply of pre-Depression American types, from flappers to farmers, steel workers to stock market tycoons. Lloyd Goodrich, a prominent art historian, pronounced it a breakthrough that heralded a new approach to mural painting, “of actually taking reality and making mural art directly out of it.”

lead_paragraph: A new kit allows you to make your own bathtub gin — without the bathtub or the moonshine. Start with good vodka, and use the kit’s juniper, mixed spices and botanicals to create a gin tinged with amber and perfumed with juniper and lavender; there are also spice, sandalwood and green cardamom notes in the flavor. That makes it better served on the rocks with a spritz of fresh lime or in a French 75 with Champagne than in a classic martini, which demands the clean, persistent whisper of juniper. The kit also contains two empty bottles, a fine-mesh strainer and a funnel. It’s a fitting gift for an amateur mixologist.

And so in Townshend, Vt., Lucas Farrell and Louisa Conrad, who produce cave-aged goat cheese, have begun turning the rich milk from their herd into hand-wrapped caramels. The candies are simple and irresistible, with only a chai flavor and long caramel sticks straying from the theme.

headline: A New Generation of Italian Cheeses
abstract: Renato Brancaleoni has taken the aging techniques learned from his father in different directions.
lead_paragraph: Renato Brancaleoni learned the craft of aging cheese from his father, who started in Italy in 1937, but he has taken the techniques in new directions. Mr. Brancaleoni (at right) is from Roncofreddo, in the Emilia-Romagna region. He buys young cheeses, often pecorino, and carefully ages them in caves or in huge terra cotta containers. But instead of sticking only to cheeses made nearby, as tradition dictates, he brings them in from elsewhere, often the high Dolomites. They may be coated with olive oil and ashes or wrapped in walnut leaves. Or he might enclose them in hay, chestnut leaves or even crushed blackberries or beeswax. Each of his cheeses has a different aroma, flavor and texture but offers a balance of richness and acidity. A new one, a majestic cylinder wrapped in hay, leaves and mushrooms and called Merlino, was an experiment that has made him very happy.

headline: ‘Solo, Piano — N.Y.C.’
abstract: A short documentary chronicles the interactions of passers-by with an abandoned piano as it awaits its fate.
lead_paragraph: Making this film was pure serendipity. After a January snowstorm in New York City, I decided to do some work on another film, in my home in Washington Heights. But as I approached my desk, I thought I heard a piano plinking. I looked out the window and saw a piano on the curb below. I was mesmerized by the pattern that emerged. Passers-by would slow, stop and play. Some played well. All day long they collected and dispersed, and into the night they measured, shoved and deliberated the piano’s fate. (If it stayed on the sidewalk, the city could have issued a fine.) I was riveted. Pianos have histories. No one who stopped seemed eager to leave it behind. Their thoughts were obvious: Can we take it? Who abandons a piano? Is it worth anything?

headline: British Plan for Gay Marriage Would Exclude Anglican Church

abstract: The government’s plan to legalize same-sex marriages  took an unexpected turn on Tuesday with an announcement that the Church of England will be forbidden from marrying same-sex partners.
lead_paragraph: The government’s plan to legalize same-sex marriages before a general election in 2015 took an unexpected turn on Tuesday with an announcement that the Church of England, England’s most populous faith, will be forbidden by the new law from marrying same-sex partners, while other religious groups that favor the change, including Quakers, Unitarians and liberal Jews, will be allowed to “opt in” to the practice. By specifically excluding Anglicans, the government of Prime Minister David Cameron appeared to have taken a major step back from a change that gay and lesbian groups have hailed as a watershed. Maria Miller, the culture minister, said the aim was to guarantee the Anglican churches that they could not be forced to hold same-sex marriages if litigants went to British and European courts demanding the rights that members of other faiths would enjoy. That possibility helped opponents of the change muster support from a substantial bloc of Conservative lawmakers.

headline: Taking On Cancer Again, This Time With the Wisdom of Age
abstract: My first encounter with testicular cancer in my 20s turned me into someone I did not wish to revisit.
lead_paragraph: After I finished eight months of treatment for testicular cancer in my mid-20s, my psychologist said, “Well, that was like having five years of therapy all at once.” What he meant was that you learn a lot about yourself in weekly talk sessions, but during a life-threatening illness, the “issues” come at you nonstop. I relished the slow unfolding of myself in the first, but I resented — no, hated — every step of the second. Nearly two decades later, when confronted with the same diagnosis, I finally understood the benefits of that earlier trial by fire, much as I did the wisdom of Ralph Waldo Emerson when he wrote, “The years teach much which the days never knew.”

headline: A Win for Small Businesses in a Bank Fraud Case

headline: Secrets, Stories and Soul Baring
abstract: Among the year’s best recordings are those by Tim Berne, the Vijay Iyer Trio, Kurt Rosenwinkel, Frank Ocean and Kendrick Lamar.
lead_paragraph: 1. TIM BERNE “Snakeoil” (ECM) A gorgeous, brooding statement from an alto saxophonist and composer of granite conviction, unveiling a deftly chamberlike quartet with Oscar Noriega on clarinets, Matt Mitchell on piano and Ches Smith on drums. Recorded with haunting clarity, this is an album that encourages full immersion while refusing to give up its secrets.

headline: Rap or Rock or Folk-Jazz, They’ve Got Soul
abstract: From Frank Ocean to Bettye LaVette, the best music of 2012.
lead_paragraph: 1. FRANK OCEAN “Channel Orange” (Def Jam) The moody introspection of a soul-ballad man fuses with the metaphor-making skills of a rapper in the sparse, aching songs that fill Frank Ocean’s official debut album. Even with some resemblances to Prince and R. Kelly, he’s an unusual character for R&B: estranged but observant, admitting an attraction to a man, finding emptiness where others find material or emotional comfort. And in their sound as well as their lyrics, his songs create hollow spaces that they can only sometimes fill. As the tracks make eerie, restless dissolves between instruments and electronics, the songs melt down and recast themselves, again and again.

headline: Asking Questions and Raising Stakes
abstract: Among the best albums of 2012 are works from Ravi Coltrane, Frank Ocean, Off! and Anita Wilson.

Intuitive and original, it’s equally of the American experimental jazz tradition, Afro-Cuban religious culture and modern nonjazz composition. It’s got nerve and soul and memory.

headline: Bright Colors, Grown-Up Concerns and Bruises

headline: Moving Forward in Tough Times
abstract: A look at more than 30 social initiatives covered in Fixes this year shows that working to improve and save lives is still a growth industry.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the second annual Fixes holiday season retrospective! Almost every week, over the past two years, we’ve covered a response to a social problem that’s noteworthy, usually because it’s producing better than expected results. We highlight these “positive deviants” because 1) they’re under-reported; 2) they show society not just what’s going wrong but how it might improve; and 3) they’re inherently interesting, like a good puzzle or whodunit. Because we get more leads than we can cover, we typically focus on initiatives that have a track record, evidence of effectiveness and potential for broader impact.

headline: The “Yes, Minister” Theory of the Medicare Age
abstract: The logic of bad policy.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Carroll can’t believe that we’re still talking about raising the age for Medicare eligibility; his disbelief is easy to understand. It is, after all, a truly terrible idea, for reasons he details in the linked post; it would inflict vast hardship on the most vulnerable, while saving the federal government remarkably little money, and would actually raise overall health spending, basically because private insurers have much higher administrative costs and much less bargaining power than Medicare, so shifting seniors out of the program ends up costing a lot of money.

It’s a fountain of a sort, and behind its soft gurgle stretches Dorado Beach, a $342 million hotel built along three miles of toasty Caribbean sand. At the center of the resort, which opened Wednesday, guests will find a labyrinthine infinity pool with a “bubble bed” in its center, a four-bedroom villa that rents for $30,000 a night and a spa composed of 22 buildings that sprawl across five acres and includes treatment platforms built into treetops.

headline: In London, a Sanctum for Single Malts
abstract: The new Soho Whisky Club offers privacy, free monthly tastings and rare reserves.
lead_paragraph: Signature cocktails need to go. And no one seems to feel this sentiment as acutely as the whiskey aficionados and connoisseurs who belong to London’s new Soho Whisky Club. Besides its fabulous whiskey, the club’s finest quality is its semisecret location in a lofty annex above one of London’s oldest and finest single-malt retailers, the Vintage House on Old Compton Street. This downstairs shop carries over 1,800 pours and is the envy of single-malt collectors, offering hard-to-find tipples like a 70-year-old Mortlach (just $30,400). The attitude of the upstairs whiskey club seems to be along the lines of: Why read a description of our whiskies when you can have them in a glass? And for a $320 annual membership fee, members enjoy privacy, free monthly tastings and a choice from over 300 single malts, from the delightfully drinkable to the rare reserves. Among the special 2012 bottles the club currently recommends are the Port Ellen 32 year old ($956), a peppery pour with an almost muddy coal finish, and Auchroisk 30 year ($367), which tastes of banana, charred fruitcake and orange peel.

lead_paragraph: An Athens court on Wednesday ordered the seizure of assets belonging to Lavrentis Lavrentiadis, a Greek oligarch whom the authorities have charged with fraud and embezzlement, and 29 of his former associates, the latest legal maneuver in a case that has underscored concerns over corruption and crony capitalism in Greece.

headline: It's Game On for Super Bowl Ads
abstract: The Times’s Stuart Elliott talks about how Super Bowl advertisers, spurred by the marketing opportunities created by social media, are starting their campaigns earlier than ever before.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Stuart Elliott talks about how Super Bowl advertisers, spurred by the marketing opportunities created by social media, are starting their campaigns earlier than ever before.

headline: The Best Tablets for Children
abstract: TimesCast Media+Tech: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. | Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast Media+Tech: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. | Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: The Best Tablets for Children
abstract: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.

headline: The Giving Spree | Stephen Burks
abstract: The Readymade Projects designer shares what he’s giving, and what he’s hoping to get, this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Who: The Readymade Projects designer Stephen Burks, who appeared with the poufs he made out of Manila rope and Dedar fabric trimmings in T’s Design and Living issue.

headline: A Filmmaker Comes to Terms With a Modern Medea
abstract: The director Joachim Lafosse talks about the choices he made for the psychological drama “Our Children,” about a mother who kills her four offspring.
lead_paragraph: What is it about Belgian filmmakers and their fascination with children in peril? The Dardenne brothers have built an entire career out of sympathetic portrayals of them, most recently with “The Kid With a Bike,” and last year Michael Roskam won a nomination for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film for “Bullhead,” a portrait of a severely damaged little boy who grows into a fearsome beast of a man.

headline: Scene City: Celebs Pile Up at “Django Unchained”
abstract: Quentin Tarantino fetes his latest movie at a star-filled screening.
lead_paragraph: Quentin Tarantino fetes his latest movie at a star-filled screening.

headline: When Wall Street Investors Favor Performance Over Ethics
abstract: Another former employee of SAC Capital Advisors has been accused of insider trading, but the author says investors don’t seem to mind, as they continue to put new money into the hedge fund in search of great returns.
lead_paragraph: To have one employee tied to insider trading may be regarded as a misfortune. But, with apologies to Oscar Wilde, to have six looks like carelessness.

headline: Father and Son Drive 423 Miles on One Charge in Tesla Model S
abstract: David Metcalf said in an interview that he averaged 25 or 26 miles an hour, with a top speed around 37 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Tesla Motors speculated in a blog post that “it could even be possible” to drive a Model S more than 400 miles on a single charge and offered an unspecified prize for the first person to do so. Last weekend, the challenge was met by a father-and-son team in Florida.

headline: Keeping Score: For Warriors, Defense Is the Difference
abstract: Golden State’s early success is due in large part to their improvement on the defensive end of the floor, which has been a point of emphasis for Coach Mark Jackson.
lead_paragraph: Economist Arthur Okun invented the misery index in the 1960s as a quick and dirty way to measure the economic climate for a given economy, with higher scores being associated with more “miserable” economies.

headline: Eric Schmidt: How We Outrace the Robots
abstract: The executive chairman of Google says that the three great economic trends of our time are globalization, demography and automation, and together they will create a worldwide crisis in employment. The solution for the United States, he says, is to see this as a “Sputnik moment” and create a revolution in creating lifelong analytic learners.
lead_paragraph: At the DealBook conference today in Manhattan, I asked the executive chairman of Google, Eric Schmidt, where in the world the jobs for a great many people will be. His advice: We have to learn how to “outrace the robots.”

headline: European Officials Agree to Central Oversight of Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The deal would put more than 100 large banks in Europe under the supervision of the central bank, leaving thousands of smaller banks primarily overseen by national regulators.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Finance ministers agreed early on Thursday to place banks in the euro area under a single supervisor, a step enabling European Union leaders to deliver a show of unity at their year-end summit that starts later in the day.

headline: Photo Replay: December 12
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including club soccer and a man-versus-horse race.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including club soccer and a man-versus-horse race.

headline: Earlier Kickoff for Super Bowl Advertising Campaigns
abstract: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist of The New York Times, discusses how the rise of social media has changed thinking among Super Bowl advertisers.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist of The New York Times, discusses with David Gillen, a deputy business editor, a recent change in thinking among Super Bowl advertisers. Once, the content of the ads was a closely guarded secret, often first shown during the game itself; this year, many companies are teasing what is in their ads, hoping to stoke interest on social media.

headline: Be Wary of Video Games’ Educational Promises
abstract: Parents looking for educational apps and games to justify a big electronic gift will find little to guide them.
lead_paragraph: With electronic toys from Leap Pads to Wii U consoles topping many a holiday gift list, one way many parents justify the purchases, particularly with younger children, is to focus on their educational possibilities. Every platform offers games and apps that come with promises about everything from promoting social or spatial abilities to developing literacy.

headline: A Son Comes Out, Needing More Than His Family
abstract: In “Oddly Normal,” John Schwartz details his family’s efforts to help his son Joseph as he declared his homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Schwartz has sophisticated, loving parents. When they noticed their son’s aversion to sports and attraction to dolls, they didn’t assume Joseph was gay; they just knew he was different. When Joseph referred to Saladin, the well-dressed 12th-century Sultan of Egypt and Syria, as “the fabulous Muslim leader,” they simply embraced their son’s panache. When his father, John, discovered pictures of naked men in Joseph’s Internet history — well, at that point Joseph’s parents did assume he was gay. Still, John Schwartz and his wife, Jeanne Mixon, wisely waited for their son to come out on his own terms, which he eventually did, at the age of 12.

headline: In Brooklyn, Minus the Buzz
abstract: At the lower end of the basketball food chain in Brooklyn, high school players often play road games to which students from the visiting school are not permitted.
lead_paragraph: Here came the Patriots of Lafayette Educational Campus, crossing Benson Avenue in front of their school, on the way to another road game and traveling, as usual, with train fare, not fanfare.

headline: Fancy Pants
abstract: Amid all the formal dresses, pants can make for a standout look.
lead_paragraph: “IT’S feminine without being obvious,” said Phillip Lim, explaining why he is attracted to the notion of a woman in evening pants. Frocks may still be the go-to choice for holiday celebrations, but this season’s chic new party pants can hold their own, sleek eye-catchers in a room otherwise crowded with conventional cocktail dresses and trailing gowns. Irreverent but considered, these scene-stealers — cigarette-slim and shown in extravagant brocades, cool jacquards and slippery jewel-tone silk blends — seem destined to be the life of the party.

headline: For Knicks and Lakers, a Reunion and a Rivalry
abstract: Mike D’Antoni, the former Knicks coach who is now with the Lakers, will face off against the Knicks’ Mike Woodson, his assistant last season.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers, trending in opposite directions, will cross paths for the first time this season Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. In what is usually a marquee game for the league, the Knicks will see a familiar face at the Garden in Lakers Coach Mike D’Antoni.

headline: Latino Groups Warn Congress to Fix Immigration, or Else
abstract: The nation’s largest Latino organizations said they will keep a report card during the immigration debate next year, with plans to mobilize their voters against lawmakers who do not support a comprehensive immigration bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s largest Latino organizations warned Congress on Wednesday that they will keep a report card during the immigration debate next year, with plans to mobilize their voters against lawmakers who do not support a comprehensive immigration bill.

headline: Hunt for Midtown Killer Focuses on Queens After Getaway Car, a Rental, Is Found
abstract: By Wednesday evening, police detectives were questioning someone in connection with the shooting of Brandon Lincoln Woodard, which occurred on West 58th Street.
lead_paragraph: The search for the gunman who carried out the brazen murder of a man in Midtown Manhattan has intensified in Queens, where investigators found the getaway car, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Wednesday.

headline: This Tarantino Premiere Killed
abstract: A screening of “Django Unchained” brings profanity, gore and lots of stars enjoying them.
lead_paragraph: AH, Christmas. Movies are rushed out this time of year, either as Oscar contenders or for the holiday box office.

headline: Rick Snyder on ‘Right to Work’
abstract: He suggested the law will make unions stronger.
lead_paragraph: Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder explained on Morning Joe today that his state’s new “right to work” law is actually good for workers and unions; it makes unions stronger by requiring them to “present a good value proposition” to workers that will inspire them to join up.

headline: Caro on Johnson Tops Historians’ Poll, but Seward Book Is Close Behind
abstract: Voters on the History News Network call “The Passage of Power” the year’s best work.
lead_paragraph: To perhaps no one’s surprise, “The Passage of Power,” the latest installment of Robert Caro’s acclaimed biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, has topped the History News Network’s online poll to choose the best history book of 2012.

headline: Warren Is Nominated for Senate Banking Committee
abstract: Elizabeth Warren, a noted consumer advocate, had harsh words for Wall Street throughout her campaign for Senate, and she is expected to support tougher controls on the industry.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor who won a Senate seat in November, is officially on track to join the Senate Banking Committee, after the Democratic Steering Committee approved her assignment on Wednesday. The appointment is subject to approval by the full Democratic caucus and a resolution by the full Senate after it convenes in January.

headline: The New York Times Names a New Business Editor
abstract: Dean Murphy, a deputy in the department, will become the new editor, replacing Larry Ingrassia, who will take on a larger role at the paper, according to a memo from the newspaper’s executive editor, Jill Abramson.
lead_paragraph: Dean E. Murphy, a reporter and editor with The New York Times for the last 12 years, has been named the next editor of the business section of The Times. The announcement was made on Wednesday afternoon in a memo from Jill Abramson, the executive editor.

headline: Israeli Minister Vents Anger at Europe
abstract: Now effectively the prime minister’s No. 2, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman invoked the Nazi era in castigating European leaders over support for the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s blunt-talking foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, gave vent on Wednesday to the government’s anger over recent diplomatic gains by the Palestinians paired with international rebukes for Israel, comparing Israel’s situation to that of Czechoslovakia in 1938 before the Nazi invasion.

headline: Christie Tells Barbara Walters He Isn’t Too Heavy to Be President
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, who is featured in an ABC special tonight, said it was “ridiculous” for people to think his weight should disqualify him for the job.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie said it was “ridiculous” for people to question whether he was too heavy to be president of the United States during a television interview scheduled to be broadcast on Wednesday night.

headline: Ground Rules for a Shopper
abstract: Here are some shopping tips from fashion insiders.
lead_paragraph: Many things may be within your price range if you know how to scout for a deal. In the piece, Follow the Bargain Hounds, fashion insiders tell us how to search for a good bargain. Here are some of their tips:

headline: On 12-12-12, Songs in Reply to a Storm
abstract: New Jersey rock stars like Bruce Springsteen shared a stage with their British counterparts, comedians and others in a benefit concert for Hurricane Sandy’s victims. Jon Pareles live blogged from Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles live blogged the 12-12-12 benefit concert for victims of Hurricane Sandy from Madison Square Garden. Read his complete review here. A slide show of images from the concert by Damon Winter is here.

headline: Follow the Bargain Hounds
abstract: It takes a cool head and a keen fashion compass to navigate the winter sales. Here are some tips from the experts.
lead_paragraph: IT takes a cool head and a keen fashion compass to navigate the winter sales. But Tammy Eckenswiller, a style executive for an Internet fashion retailer, has scoped that terrain long enough to know that patience pays. Even now, weeks deep into the discount season, she has unearthed deals, among them a handful of items she sighted when they first bowed on the runways last spring.

headline: In a Farewell Speech, Lieberman Reflects on His Political Journey
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Joseph I. Lieberman, the retiring Connecticut senator, appearing before a small audience, noted the momentous changes in the world and at home during his four terms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nearly a quarter-century, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has been an unmistakable presence in a legislative body filled with colorful personalities and large egos.

headline: 2012 Hack Day Coverage
abstract: Here’s a quick roundup of articles and tweets about the TimesOpen Hack Day we held this past weekend.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a quick roundup of articles and tweets about the TimesOpen Hack Day we held this past weekend:

headline: Wheelies: The Here, There, Everywhere Edition
abstract: The Cadillac ATS, the Ford Fusion and the Honda Accord have been selected as the finalists for the 2013 North American Car of the Year.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Google’s Coolest Project? Broadband
abstract: According to the executive chairman of Google, the company’s efforts to increase nearly gigabit-speed Internet into Kansas City has compelled local start-ups to move into suburban tracts when the service lights up. More lasting, he said, is the effect on videoconferencing.
lead_paragraph: According to Eric Schmidt, Google‘s executive chairman, the most interesting project going on at the search giant is its high-speed broadband trials in Kansas City. (Missouri and Kansas versions)

headline: A Quirky Little Bookshop in Cyberspace
abstract: A new online store offers limited-run, hard-to-find print publications that are perfect for the coffee table.

headline: Guilty Plea for One of Julian Robertson’s ‘Tiger Cub’ Funds
abstract: Bill Hwang, once a star at Tiger Management, entered a guilty plea on behalf of his fund, Tiger Asia, admitting to wire fraud by the firm.
lead_paragraph: Bill Hwang was once a star at Tiger Management, the gilded hedge fund empire run by the billionaire investor Julian Robertson.

headline: Characters Who Take Up More Than Their Share of Room in the Family
abstract: Jami Attenberg, author of the novel “The Middlesteins,” and Samuel D. Hunter, whose play “The Whale” is at Playwrights Horizons, talk about why they created protagonists who are obese.
lead_paragraph: Diabetic and more than 300 pounds, Edie Middlestein, the feisty matriarch in Jami Attenberg’s new novel, “The Middlesteins,” is facing surgery and a family in disarray. At 600 pounds, Charlie, the housebound writing teacher in Samuel D. Hunter’s play “The Whale” (at Playwrights Horizons through Saturday) has congestive heart failure and a daughter he hasn’t seen in years. We asked Ms. Attenberg and Mr. Hunter to take in each other’s works and discuss what led them, coincidentally, to characters who are literally larger than life. These are excerpts from their e-mail exchange.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Egypt, Greece and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Egypt, Greece and North Korea.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Foxconn’s Robot Troubles, and Google’s Broadband
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a plan to save schools money by reducing the need to buy new PCs, a New York official trying to extend the benefits of technology to more workers and two takes on the year in review.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: No Celebrity-Filled Concert on the Mall for Obama’s 2nd Inaugural
abstract: The only official concert will be a children’s concert, similar to one that was held in 2009, according to the planners.
lead_paragraph: There will be no big star-studded concert on the National Mall to celebrate President Obama’s second inauguration next month, several of his inaugural planners said Wednesday.

headline: A Story of AIDS, From the Beginning
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Movies', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The documentary by David France charts the journey of the disease from the first days.
lead_paragraph: LAST Wednesday night, David France, the director of the documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” made his way to the Open Society Institute in Columbus Circle for a question-and-answer session and a screening of his film, which is about the early years of the AIDS epidemic. Afterward, he was mobbed by well-wishers and advice-seekers.

headline: L’Wren Scott, The Sweet Smell
abstract: The fashion designer and romantic partner of Mick Jagger has introduced a fragrance.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer and romantic partner of Mick Jagger has introduced a fragrance.

headline: L’Wren Scott: Fashion, Mick Jagger and Now a Fragrance
abstract: Fame, fortune, fragrances, diamonds or men — however they come, and in what order, has little to do with luck.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE she was a fashion designer whose clothes can be found in the closets of Nicole Kidman and Michelle Obama, and before she was famous for a decade-plus romance with Mick Jagger, L’Wren Scott was one of the most successful stylists working in Los Angeles. One of her assignments, in the early 1990s, was an advertising campaign for Elizabeth Taylor’s White Diamonds, which would become the best-selling celebrity fragrance in the world.

headline: Suspect in Patz Murder Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: After court, a defense lawyer said Pedro Hernandez, as a result of mental illness and other issues, had given authorities a false confession that led to his indictment in the 1979 killing of Etan Patz, a 6-year-old.
lead_paragraph: The man indicted in the killing of Etan Patz in 1979 loudly pleaded “not guilty” Wednesday to murdering the 6-year-old boy.

headline: Russell Libby, Organic Farming Advocate, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Libby’s lifelong passion for growing food began when his fourth-grade teacher in Maine handed out packets of vegetable seeds to the class.
lead_paragraph: Russell Libby, one of the nation’s leading advocates for organic farming, died on Sunday at his farm in Mount Vernon, Me. He was 56.

headline: To Extend a Device’s Battery Life, Get to Know It Better
abstract: A number of apps can help a user extend the battery life of a mobile device, in part by providing information about its other apps and functions.
lead_paragraph: As you jet off on a winter vacation or a holiday season trip to see family, chances are you’ll face a 21st-century problem: mobile device battery angst. It’s a never-ending itch at the back of your thoughts. Though we all love to use our smartphones to stave off boredom, or to navigate a new city, every moment of use eats precious battery time. And, particularly during a journey, you never know when you will find power next.

headline: Steps, Back and Forth, Into a New Comfort Zone
abstract: The choreographer Molissa Fenley and her colleagues ventured outside their comfort zones in approaching one another for the collaboration “Cross Bridge.”
lead_paragraph: For the collaboration “Cross Bridge” the choreographer Molissa Fenley and her colleagues ventured outside their comfort zones in approaching one another. Dancers spoke. An actress danced. But the work, which had its debut last weekend at the Club at La MaMa, began and ended with proven strengths.

headline: Kevin Arpino Plays to a Silent Audience
abstract: He just unveiled another new collection, which he does usually twice a year, of mannequins whose prices start at $1,300.
lead_paragraph: TALL and tan with a wrist full of jangly silver bracelets, Kevin Arpino shouted into his cellphone in a room full of fashion models.

headline: Spirituality Follows Its Cycles to ‘Grace’
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s performance on Tuesday included works by Robert Battle, its new artistic director; Ulysses Dove; and Ronald K. Brown.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Battle became artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater last year, he gave up a dance company named after himself and his works, and his principal job changed from making his own art to tending a repertory filled with the creations of others. Finding the right place for his choreography in his new home loomed as a challenge.

headline: Woman Declares Louis Armstrong Was Her Father
abstract: A Florida woman is selling letters to her mother from Louis Armstrong, who she says was her father; she is also releasing a memoir.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday a batch of letters that Louis Armstrong wrote to a girlfriend will go on sale at an auction house in Los Angeles. That in itself is not surprising: Armstrong wrote thousands of letters in his lifetime, and he was known to be a lothario.

headline: Senator Demands F.A.A. Relax Electronics Rules
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri sent a letter to the Federal Aviation Administration urging the agency to allow the use of electronics during the full duration of a flight. She threatened to push for legislation if the agency took too long.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration could be on the receiving end of legislation if it does not change its stance on the use of electronics during takeoff and landing.
