keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Various discounts at holiday pop-up stores, a new boot from Timberland and Supreme, the Opening Ceremony sale and more shopping events.
lead_paragraph: POP-UPS

headline: Q Train, 11:05 A.M.
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Subways', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: N.Y. See: A honeymoon begins on the Q train.

headline: Tooker Alley
abstract: In an unmistakable sign that Prospect Heights has arrived on the Brooklyn scene, the neighborhood now claims not one, but at least two artisanal cocktail bars.
lead_paragraph: IN an unmistakable sign that Prospect Heights has arrived on the Brooklyn scene, the neighborhood now claims not one, but at least two artisanal cocktail bars. The latest even has a retro-sounding name, Tooker Alley, which, it turns out, is named after the Chicago street that led to the Dil Pickle Club, a famed freethinker’s hangout.

headline: News Roundup: In Afghanistan, Reporting on Progress and Recalling the Soviet Invasion
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan the same week the Pentagon released a bleak report finding that Afghan forces still need assistance.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan on Wednesday to push forward proposals for future troop levels, Thom Shanker reports.

headline: Young Venezuelans Exude Confidence to Go With Their Passion
abstract: The young performers in the Bolívar Orchestra radiate confidence, but that is only one of the facets of their appeal.
lead_paragraph: It is typical for orchestras of well-trained young musicians to convey exuberance. The players of the Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, under their charismatic music director Gustavo Dudamel, were afire with exuberance during two sold-out programs at Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday nights.

headline: Energy Dept. to Underwrite 7 Wind Projects
abstract: Federal money will flow toward engineering and design for the ventures, with three of them eventually receiving money for construction as well.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is stepping up its efforts to kick-start the offshore wind industry by awarding $28 million in grants to seven projects that are developing varying kinds of power-generation technology.

headline: The Moods of Messiaen, Interpreted in 20 Ways
abstract: The pianist Christopher Taylor performed Messiaen’s “Vingt Regards sur l’Enfant-Jésus,” a two-hour piece, in its entirety and from memory.
lead_paragraph: Messiaen would surely have been delighted at the setting for a concert featuring his “Vingt Regards sur l’Enfant-Jésus.” The piano was placed next to the crèche under the huge Christmas tree in the Medieval Sculpture Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. En route to the space guests passed through a room featuring ornate Christian paintings and iconography.

headline: SolarCity Slashes I.P.O. Share Price
abstract: The solar panel installation company had expected to raise up to $151 million with shares priced at $13 to $15, but on Wednesday the company lowered its sights.
lead_paragraph: SolarCity, which installs solar panels for homeowners, has priced its initial public offering at $8 a share, well below its earlier estimates, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Holiday Reading, Some Homework Required
abstract: Books to read before hitting the holiday parties for D.I.Y. types.
lead_paragraph: “BurdaStyle Sewing Vintage Modern: Mastering Iconic Looks from the 1920s to 1980s,” by Nora Abousteit with Jamie Lau. Potter Craft. 216 pp. $29.99

headline: George Bailey Touches a Few More Lives
abstract: The Irish Repertory Theater’s stage adaptation of the classic Christmas movie “It’s a Wonderful Life,” set in a 1940s radio station, is a small triumph.
lead_paragraph: The Irish Repertory Theater’s “It’s a Wonderful Life: The 1946 Live Radio Play” can’t help frustrating fans of Frank Capra’s 1946 holiday perennial about a small-town family man contemplating suicide who learns how worthwhile his life has been. After all, the conceit of the play — which condenses more than two hours into 70 brisk minutes, with 25 characters inhabited by 6 actors (and one sound-effects man) — requires the excision of treasured passages. But this feather-light show is a small triumph anyway.

headline: The Fed vs. the Fiscal Cuts: Not a Fair Fight
abstract: Fiscal tightening is now a much bigger negative for the economy than monetary easing is a positive.
lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis began, the Federal Reserve has taken the lead on stimulating the economy. It starting easing long before the Recovery Act was even a twinkle in Congress’s eye, and it has continued its stimulus efforts in the last couple of years to counteract fiscal tightening while the Recovery Act was petering out. As Mervyn A. King, the governor of the Bank of England, explained this week, central banks around the world have pursued monetary easing to offset fiscal tightening.

headline: A Crowded Red Carpet for Women After Oscar
abstract: With four of the five spots for the best-actress Oscar category considered already sewn up, veteran performers, and a few newcomers, are working the circuit to secure the one in play.
lead_paragraph: Keira Knightley was in the unlovely upper lobby of a Chelsea movie theater, chewing gum, waiting to discuss “Anna Karenina.” She was on a tight schedule promoting her star turn in the director Joe Wright’s film adaptation of that Tolstoy novel, and there was little time to waste. Spoiler: We started with the death.

headline: Flickr Has the Opportunity to Become the Next Flickr
abstract: Yahoo on Wednesday announced a long-awaited update to Flickr’s mobile experience. So what’s next for one of the first photo-sharing services?
lead_paragraph: It’s quite amazing to think that Flickr, once one of the best photocentric social sites, was purchased by Yahoo in 2005 for, wait for this, around $30 million. (No, that’s not a typo, people used to buy start-ups for million of dollars, not billions.)

headline: A Trove of Tablets for Young Hands
abstract: Children take their tablets as seriously as they do their bikes. So if you are going to buy one that is just for them, you should involve them in the process.
lead_paragraph: Parents take note. For approximately the price of a child’s bicycle — about $200 — you can purchase what may be the 21st-century equivalent: a tablet computer.

headline: Gold Cup Semifinals and Final in England
abstract: The premier event on the British bridge calendar is the Gold Cup.
lead_paragraph: The premier event on the British bridge calendar is the Gold Cup. The semifinals and final, played at the West Midlands Bridge Club in Solihull, England, last weekend, featured two close matches.

headline: Perchance to Make You Look Rested
abstract: A new procedure injects hyaluronic acid into those half-moons that may help under-eye shadows.
lead_paragraph: BAGS. Puffiness. Dark shadows. Circles.

headline: Consignment Shopping, With Confidence, on the Web
abstract: A crop of new Web sites is helping to remove the uncertainty when buying resold clothes and luxury goods.
lead_paragraph: RUMMAGE through your closet. Amass your no-longer-desirable designer clothes. Carry them to a consignment store or upload jpegs to eBay and wait for someone to deem your castoffs worthy of purchase. Or if you are on the buying end: pray the designer pieces you bought online are genuine.

headline: During the Regency’s Renovations, the Power Breakfast Takes a Pause
abstract: The Regency is about to close for what Jonathan M. Tisch, the chairman of Loews Hotels, described as 10 months of top-to-bottom renovations. So on Wednesday, the hotel invited Regency regulars to what it promoted as the final power breakfast. But it was not a goodbye: Mr. Tisch and his cousin James S. Tisch, the president and chief executive of Loews Corporation, want the power-breakfast crowd to move to a temporary home, a restaurant at 100 East 63rd Street.
lead_paragraph: When the next history book about New York City is written, the chapter on people and power will almost certainly require a section covering something that began in 1975 and ended on Wednesday: The modern Manhattan power breakfast.

headline: At Interfaith Luncheon, an Appeal for a Miracle
abstract: The leader of a mosque in Harlem whose congregation is being priced out of its home asks rabbis for help.
lead_paragraph: Hanukkah is the Jewish holiday of miracles, commemorating how one day’s worth of oil left in a Jerusalem candelabra more than 2,000 years ago somehow lasted for eight days. Imam Souleimane Konate, the head of Masjid Aqsa, a mosque in Harlem, is hoping that bodes well for his cause.

headline: Trying on a Look? You Can Ask an App for Help
abstract: Apps from cosmetics companies and dermatologists offer advice on everything from makeup to skin cancer.
lead_paragraph: CAN an iPhone make you more beautiful?

headline: Antiwar ‘Grannies’ Briefly Make Toys ‘R’ Us Store Their Battlefield
abstract: Members of two groups demonstrated inside the Times Square store to protest what they said was the prevalence of violence in children’s games and toys.
lead_paragraph: Clamors for peace inside the mammoth Toys “R” Us emporium in Times Square might not be unusual coming from parents and directed at their toddlers demanding yet another Barbie doll or another ride on the store’s Ferris wheel.

headline: An Artist’s Obscure Object of Desire
abstract: Nacho Carbonell on “Unknown Shell,” his contribution to “KAMA, Sex and Design” at the Triennale Design Museum in Milan.
lead_paragraph: If you’d like to spice up your cultural life, you might want to visit the “KAMA, Sex and Design” show, which opened this month at the Triennale Design Museum in Milan. There are some 300 exhibits, from historic to contemporary, including “Unknown Shell,” an installation by Nacho Carbonell, a 32-year-old Spanish-born artist in the Netherlands, who does free-form fantasy furnishings and whose work has been collected by celebrities like Brad Pitt.

headline: Seating That Demands Your Best Behavior
abstract: Scott Newkirk designs a furniture collection based on church pews.
lead_paragraph: Scott Newkirk started his design career in the visual display department at Barneys three decades ago. He went on to a career as a fashion stylist, with a few years spent as the proprietor of a now-defunct shop called Kudzu in Sullivan County. Now he’s a furniture designer. Last month, he introduced the Newkirk collection, which consists of a bench, a desk and two versions of an oversize chair, all made of solid oak and inspired by the church seating of his Mississippi youth. He said his daybed design is like a modernist pew, while his oversize, seemingly Donald Judd-inspired chairs (called Sculpted Seating No. 1 and No. 2) were conceived as mismatched twin sofas. “The black one wraps around you and is mysterious and sensual, while the white one is soothing in a different way. Sitting in the white one seems to clear your mind.” Prices from $7,500 to $15,000. Information: newkirkny.com.

headline: A Work of Art Where You Can Rest in Peace
abstract: The Final Turn, a funerary urn by Tom Kundig, is about the size and weight of a cannonball.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle-based architect Tom Kundig designs houses that fit serenely into the landscape, often with generous quantities of concrete and steel and splashes of mechanical wizardry (roofs and wall-size shutters may crank open with a hand-turned wheel). Recently, Greg Lundgren, an artist and impresario who founded Lundgren Monuments, a Seattle company that produces memorials, approached Mr. Kundig to design a funerary urn as handsome as those homes.

headline: ‘The Collier Campbell Archive: 50 Years of Passion in Pattern’
abstract: The book documents textile patterns by sisters Sarah Campbell and Susan Collier.
lead_paragraph: For half a century, Sarah Campbell and her older sister, Susan Collier, created textile patterns that found their way onto wallpaper, bedding, furnishings, clothing, even the carpets in Gatwick Airport. The British design team’s colorful body of work has been collected in “The Collier Campbell Archive: 50 Years of Passion in Pattern” ($75; Ilex), a brick of a book that contains seemingly everything they ever produced.

headline: Storage That Mimics the Skyline
abstract: The shelves represent designer Victor Vasilev’s zest for urban life.
lead_paragraph: It felt like a million-to-one-shot, but Victor Vasilev tried anyway. Mr. Vasilev, the Milan-based architect, sent the design of a shelf he wanted to produce to the Italian company Boffi — via a general e-mail address listed on the Web site. “It’s like sending a drawing to Chanel and expecting them to call back,” he said. “But they called me after two hours.”

headline: Of Many Woes, One Man’s Illness Threatens Venezuela’s Revolution

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The bottlenecks at a major port were so bad this year that Christmas trees from Canada were delayed for weeks, and when they did show up they cost hundreds of dollars. A government-run ice cream factory opened with great fanfare, only to shut down a day later because of a shortage of basic ingredients. Foreign currency is so hard to come by that automakers cannot get parts and new cars are almost impossible to buy.

abstract: By ignoring risks in loans it insured in 2009 and 2010, the study says, the Federal Housing Administration is imperiling borrowers and taxpayers who stand behind the agency.

headline: Census Officials, Citing Increasing Diversity, Say U.S. Will Be a ‘Plurality Nation’
abstract: By the end of the decade, no single racial or ethnic group will constitute a majority of children under 18, census officials say.

And in about three decades, no single group will constitute a majority of the country as a whole.

headline: California: Governor Being Treated for Prostate Cancer
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown’s office said that the cancer was caught in its early stages and that Mr. Brown, 74, would continue to work a full schedule.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is undergoing treatment for localized prostate cancer caught in its early stages, his office announced on Wednesday. Dr. Eric Small, Mr. Brown’s oncologist, said that the cancer would be treated with a short course of conventional radiotherapy. “The prognosis is excellent, and there are not expected to be any significant side effects,” he said in a statement released by Mr. Brown’s office. The treatment is expected to be completed by the first week of next year, the statement said. Mr. Brown’s office said the governor, who is 74, would continue to work a full schedule.

headline: Massachusetts: Mistrial in Treasurer’s Corruption Case
abstract: The trial of a former treasurer, Timothy P. Cahill, ended in a mistrial on Wednesday, after the jury announced a deadlock.
lead_paragraph: The corruption trial of a former Massachusetts treasurer, Timothy P. Cahill, ended in a mistrial on Wednesday, after the jury announced a deadlock. In April, the state’s attorney general, Martha Coakley, charged Mr. Cahill with public corruption, fraud and conspiracy. Ms. Coakley alleged that Mr. Cahill ran TV and radio advertisements in support of the state lottery, which, as the state treasurer, he oversaw, to bolster his independent run for governor in 2010. The jury acquitted his co-defendant, Scott Campbell, on Tuesday.

For the 40-something virgin whose father has just died, shrouding herself in singlehood has almost become a comfort, like a big puffy coat. lead_paragraph: The Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against a firearm classifieds Web site on Wednesday, apparently the first time legal action was taken against online gun sales. The lawsuit, in Chicago against Armslist.com, contends that the Web site facilitated the illegal purchase of a handgun used to kill Jitka Vesel in Illinois last year. “It should be harder to buy a semiautomatic handgun than a used sofa on Craigslist,” said Jonathan E. Lowy, director of the legal action project at the Brady Center. Richard A. Pearson, executive director of the Illinois State Rifle Association, called the lawsuit “ridiculous” because the site requires users to agree not to use its listings for unlawful purposes.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Weapons Inspectors Visit Iran
abstract: The visit did not resolve a dispute over inspectors’ repeated requests to examine Parchin, a military site where they suspect atomic weapons trigger testing may have been conducted.
lead_paragraph: Nuclear inspectors visited Iran for their first meeting since August, but they appeared to be no closer to resolving a dispute over their repeated requests to examine Parchin, a military site that the inspectors suspect was used for atomic weapons trigger tests. The head of the inspector delegation, Herman Nackaerts, deputy director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna, told reporters as the group left for Tehran that the purpose of the visit was to devise a way to satisfy the agency’s concerns over the Iranian program’s “possible military dimensions.” He also said his delegation still hoped the Iranians would allow a visit to Parchin. Some members of his group were seen carrying equipment that could be used for testing at Parchin.

He has a closetful of suits by Thom Browne and Lanvin that don’t have shoulders that slant like a roof. This one was a blip of misjudgment. headline: Acropolis Now
abstract: The Museum of the Stoa of Attalos offers an array of Greek gods and Roman nobles in statue against a dense backdrop of olive trees.
lead_paragraph: Say what you will about the state of the Greek economy, but Athens remains a triumph. As politicians left and right try to hammer out a plan to keep the country afloat, the Parthenon still crowns the Acropolis like, in the words of an ancient Turkish traveler, “some impregnable fortress not made by human agency.” And if there is more commotion in Syntagma Square than usual, overall Athens is noisily going about being Athens — cafes are full, night life is roaring and at a recent concert by the singer Anna Vissi fans were flinging 10-euro trays of carnations at the star by the hundreds. Best of all, those undeterred by fiscal follies can probably get more value for their euro here than in any other big European city right now. Consider that a room at the posh New Hotel, by Syntagma Square, is going for slightly more than 100 euros a night, and includes the kind of gourmet breakfast that draws local dealmakers and diplomats alike. That kind of value, along with refreshingly drama-free winter weather, turns the idea of visiting into an imperative.

headline: 36 Hours in Sarasota, Fla.
abstract: Whether you’re seeking flowers or flamenco, paintings or powdery sand, you can find it in this city on the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: WHERE else can one spend the morning reveling in the beauty of works by Peter Paul Rubens, Frans Hals and Botticelli and the afternoon lolling on a powdery white sand beach? That is the lure of Sarasota, the city perched on the Gulf of Mexico where John and Mable Ringling, the circus impresario and his wife, set the stage for a vibrant cultural life after buying land there in 1911. Not only did John Ringling create the old-master-filled John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art, but he brought the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus to winter in Sarasota. His elephants even hauled timber for the John Ringling Causeway, which links the mainland to Lido Key. Nature, which initially attracted the Ringlings and other wealthy Midwesterners, provides its own set of pleasures beyond the beaches: whether it’s fishing, watching manatees and sea turtles or strolling past orchids and mangroves in an expansive botanical garden. For more civilized diversions, there is a plethora of restaurants and shops, and even an opera and orchestra.

lead_paragraph: While looking into the history of Barneys for my article in Sunday’s magazine, I came across the amazing windows that the artist Lynn Hershman Leeson did for Bonwit Teller in the fall of 1976. Bonwit’s was located on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street, where Trump Tower is today. After two years of negotiation with store management, Hershman Leeson brought her art and social commentary to 25 windows. “I wanted to put art in the context of everyday life,” Hershman Leeson, whose work includes photography, video, film and installations, said this week. She had already done a project in a prison. “I thought, Well, if I’m going to do something in New York City, I should do stores.”

headline: Simplifying the Fiscal Cliff Debate
abstract: Why the inevitability of an $800 billion tax hike makes a bigger compromise unlikely.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of potential moving parts in the fiscal cliff negotiations, and thus a lot of potential ways that matters could be negotiated and settled, postponed or left half-resolved. But sometimes simplification helps, and the best place to start when thinking about how things are likely to play out is with the following brute fact: No matter what Congressional Republicans offer the president and what they’re willing to concede, taxes on the wealthiest Americans are going to rise by at least $800 billion over the next decade. This is not a possibility, not a likely scenario, not a maybe or a might be; it’s just reality, conceded even by the notorious RINO Jim DeMint. Which means that it’s useful for analytic purposes to treat that $800 billion as a baseline, rather than as a live point of give and take in the negotiations, and recognize that any bigger deal John Boehner and Barack Obama are able to cut should be judged as much on how it balances spending cuts and tax increases beyond that baseline as on what it looks like overall.

keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Leading a post-hurricane task force, the nation’s housing secretary says the vast majority of communities can be rebuilt safely, however.
lead_paragraph: Visiting New York City, Shaun Donovan,  the nation’s housing secretary and President Obama’s appointee  to oversee the post-Hurricane Sandy federal recovery effort, said on Thursday that he expected most of the damaged areas along the East Coast to be rebuilt but not necessarily as they were before.

headline: Film Forum
abstract: The avid, idiosyncratic movie critic David Thomson traces a path through more than a century of movie history, from Eadweard Muybridge to Martin Scorsese.
lead_paragraph: Seen in fast forward, the career of David Thomson — the avid, idiosyncratic movie critic — looks more like a klatch session than a formal lesson in the history of film. Where many writers’ work suggests a dutiful progression, Thomson chases his subjects with free-associative license: Nicole Kidman to Alfred Hitchcock (with a hefty reference work in between), the big picture to the picayune. And where a lot of critics aim for impartial assessment, he has unapologetically privileged his private passions. Today, Thomson is best known for his “New Biographical Dictionary of Film,” but his strength is less taxonomy than transition, the almost cinematic way his mind cuts among its intellectual frames.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Sound Oasis Sound Therapy Pillow
abstract: A pillow with speakers inside — just what Santa ordered. Day 6 in Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets.
lead_paragraph: You better not pout, you better not cry — today is Day 6 in Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets! A tech-gift goodie daily, under $100.

headline: Small Utilities Credits Are Just the First Step, a Commission Says
abstract: A state commission plans to conduct its own investigation into how utilities prepared for Hurricane Sandy and responded to the damage it caused.
lead_paragraph: Would a credit of $3 or $6 appease utility customers who are still steaming about how long they went without power or heat after Hurricane Sandy?

headline: Kanye’s Kilt
abstract: Kanye West’s leather skirt stole the show during a concert for Sandy relief.
lead_paragraph: Kanye wore what? Based on the emphatic reactions on Twitter, Kanye West stole the show at last night’s  “12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief” – or rather, his leather skirt did.  “Was it Kim Kardashian’s,” more than one smart aleck joked. No, it appears to be from Givenchy’s fall 2012 men’s wear collection.  And now it has its own Twitter account  @KanyesSkirt.

headline: Newly Minted New-Music Experts Leap Over a Cascading Niagara
abstract: Axiom, a new-music ensemble of Juilliard students, plays John Adams and Toru Takemitsu at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: John Adams’s “Grand Pianola Music” has baffled and infuriated critics since its first performance in 1982. Scored for two pianos, three wordless singers, wind instruments and percussion, it’s an everything-but-the-kitchen-sink concerto that gleefully tosses out notions of stylistic purity for the sake of big effects and a lingering ironic aftertaste.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Short Life of ‘Evita’
abstract: The new revival illustrates the problem with importing English productions, and depending on celebrity casting, for Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Are many tears being shed among Broadway lovers for the comparatively brief run of “Evita,” which announced a January closing on Tuesday? Probably not. The only people crying at the closing of this generally ill-received production are likely to be Ricky Martin fans who never made it to New York to catch the swivel-hipped Latin pop star on Broadway.

headline: Copa Chaos in Brazil
abstract: The second leg of the Copa Sudamericana finals Wednesday night in Brazil descended into chaos amid threats and counter accusations.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you know something is going to happen.

abstract: Innovation is necessary, but for an event of this kind, questions are raised about journalistic distance.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot happening at the inaugural DealBook conference on Wednesday — and much of it was undeniably impressive.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence and the Role That Keeps Revealing Itself
abstract: Ms. Lawrence said that she continues to learn about her character in “Silver Linings Playbook,” the role for which she received a Golden Globes nomination.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper was home, luxuriating in bed, when he got the news of his Globes nomination, and Jennifer Lawrence, his co-star in “Silver Linings Playbook,” was in Hawaii. Tough life.

headline: A Room to Herself for a Vermeer Girl
abstract: “Girl With a Pearl Earring” is one of 15 paintings going to the Frick for “Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals.”
lead_paragraph: Paintings that have achieved superstar status need superstar treatment. That’s what Colin Bailey, chief curator at the Frick Collection, realized on a recent trip to Tokyo when, at an exhibition, he saw the crowds jostling to get a glimpse of Vermeer’s beloved “Girl With a Pearl Earring.”

headline: Nissan Battery Plant Begins Operations in Tennessee
abstract: The first batteries, which Nissan began producing in Smyrna in October, have gone through the required aging process, which takes several weeks; and now they are ready to receive a charge, a Nissan spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Nissan announced on Wednesday that its new lithium-ion battery plant in Smyrna, Tenn., is operating and will be ready with the batteries for the all-electric 2013 Nissan Leaf when production begins at the vehicle assembly plant next door early next year.

headline: Out of Its Shell and Onto Your Plate
abstract: Whelks, a type of sea snail that inhabits the Atlantic Ocean, are making news on cutting-edge menus.
lead_paragraph: CALL the creatures scungilli, and you have an ingredient that Italian-Americans have long used in a seafood salad for the Feast of the Seven Fishes on Christmas Eve. But call them by their English name — whelks — and you have an item that is suddenly making news on cutting-edge menus.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running short to work out a deal to avert a year-end fiscal crisis, President Obama called Speaker John A. Boehner to the White House on Thursday evening to try to move talks forward even as pessimism mounted that a broad deal could be struck that bridges the substantial gap between the parties on taxes and entitlements like Medicare.

headline: Woodson Reveals That He Challenged His Stars

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Shortly after Mike Woodson was named the Knicks’ interim coach in March, he brought his three best players, Carmelo Anthony, Amar’e Stoudemire and Tyson Chandler, into a room. He shut the door and told them to have a seat.

lead_paragraph: NABLUS, West Bank — Hundreds of men and boys sporting the signature green of the militant Hamas faction marched through the narrow alleys of the old city here on Thursday afternoon, calling for Palestinian unity but also renewed attacks on Israeli cities, in the first public demonstration by the Islamist party allowed in the West Bank in years.

headline: The Senate Does Something Right
abstract: Disabled veterans won a big, unexpected victory today.
lead_paragraph: Disabled veterans won a big, unexpected victory today: the Senate passed Senator Patty Murray’s bill to expand fertility services, including in-vitro fertilization, at the Veterans Affairs Department. Ms. Murray, the Washington Democrat and chairwoman of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee, sponsored the bill, S.3313, to help service members whose war wounds have left them unable to have children. She said infertility was a particular problem for service members coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan, where improvised bombs frequently cause severe pelvic injuries.

abstract: Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman said he saw no reason to resign after prosecutors announced that he would be formally charged only with breach of trust instead of fraud and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Avigdor Lieberman, Israel’s blunt-talking and polarizing foreign minister, will be charged with breach of trust but not with fraud and money laundering, prosecutors announced Thursday, ending an investigation lasting years and throwing a curve into Israel’s coming elections.

abstract: “Foiled: Tinsel Painting in America,” at the American Folk Art Museum, tells the story of this popular Victorian art form.

headline: Borders and Epochs, Dissolving at His Keyboard
abstract: The pianist and bandleader Eddie Palmieri has been influenced by Latin music, jazz, African rhythms and classical composers and has, in turn, affected Latin music and jazz.
lead_paragraph: EARLY in his career, beginning in the 1950s, the pianist and bandleader Eddie Palmieri used to play mambo shows at the Palladium Ballroom, on Broadway at 53rd Street. The Ed Sullivan Theater was just across the street but seemed to belong to a different, distant world: while Sullivan’s popular Sunday night TV show was happy to book the likes of Señor Wences, the Spanish ventriloquist, the frenetically danceable Latin music that Mr. Palmieri played was thought to lack mainstream appeal.

headline: Ahead of Their Times, but Resolved to Love
abstract: In “Any Day Now,” directed by Travis Fine, Alan Cumming plays a drag queen in 1979 who struggles to adopt an abandoned teenager with Down syndrome.
lead_paragraph: When Alan Cumming turns on his beaming grin in “Any Day Now,” Travis Fine’s militant tear-jerker, he conveys such intense, unguarded emotion you almost want to avert your eyes. That smile, and the blazing performance it distills, conveys so ferocious a mixture of desire, hurt, defiance, courage, neediness and reckless abandon that it makes everyone else seem cowardly. You consider the real meaning of the Jerry Herman anthem, “I Am What I Am,” from “La Cage aux Folles,” as it is lived out in extremis by one flamboyantly gay man.

lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Angels’ best player said it all in three letters: “Wow.” That was the reaction, via Twitter, of the Angels’ do-everything outfielder, Mike Trout, to the news Thursday that his team had signed Josh Hamilton from the rival Texas Rangers.

headline: Down the Shore, the Lost and the Found
abstract: A tour of favorite spots along the Jersey Shore a month after Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc finds a region slowly starting to recover.
lead_paragraph: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — I’m riding down Kingsley, looking for a place to park. With the crowds at Convention Hall, the Stone Pony and the Wonder Bar, there are no spots left on this oceanfront stretch. I’m here to see the roller-derby championship, three weeks after Hurricane Sandy ripped through and devoured the boardwalk. It’s night, and a waxing moon barely lights the culprit — the churning Atlantic, which both gives this place its life and threatens its existence.

headline: The Drinks Are Expensive but the View Is Priceless
abstract: At Salon de Ning, the rooftop bar at the Peninsula Hotel on Fifth Avenue, bring plenty of cash and be prepared to put up with spotty service. But the setting is grand.
lead_paragraph: The bar at Má Pêche in the Chambers Hotel was closed for a private party, so it would be a night without seven-spice sours and steamed pork buns. The King Cole Bar at the St. Regis was so packed with souls — almost all of them merry, fittingly enough — that there wasn’t even room to stand.

headline: Russian State Role Seen in Death of Poisoned Spy
abstract: Testimony at a London hearing on the 2006 poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer, also suggested that he had been a paid agent of British intelligence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — New testimony that emerged Thursday deepened the intrigue surrounding the death of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, offering “prima facie” evidence of Russian state involvement and indicating that he had been a paid agent of the British Secret Intelligence Service, MI6, lawyers at a preliminary inquest hearing said.

headline: Where Opposites Attract
abstract: The Yale University Art Gallery, always a respected museum, is now a must-see one since its renovation and expansion.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — In a museum era dominated by the vying forces of bad economics and compulsive building, it’s a miracle when something comes out right, which makes the opening of the splendidly renovated and expanded Yale University Art Gallery here a happy event. The angels of art, design and budgetary planning were on duty. Everything worked. The country’s oldest university art museum has arrived at a kind of institutional ideal of opposites in balance.

headline: Bodies in Motion
abstract: Tonight at La Mama: Netta Yerushalmy’s “Devouring Devouring” explores the relationships between identifiable human gestures and the more intangible qualities of dance.
lead_paragraph: Netta Yerushalmy, a lifelong dancer who first performed at just 3 years old, will present a new work, “Devouring Devouring,” tonight at the storied Off Off Broadway theater La Mama. The title may conjure images of gluttony, and Yerushalmy doesn’t shy away from the food metaphor, describing the piece she has choreographed as a “feast” of offerings for the audience’s eyes and minds.

headline: Top Sichuan Official Removed in Corruption Inquiry
abstract: The move against the official, Li Chuncheng, may hint of a wider crackdown on graft.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A high-ranking Communist Party leader who was the second most powerful official in China’s southwest Sichuan Province was removed from his posts on Thursday amid corruption allegations that may hint of a wider crackdown on graft.

headline: Leak of Climate Panel Drafts Speaks to Need for New Process
abstract: A leaked report raises questions about the merits of closed deliberations over climate science in an era of enforced transparency.
lead_paragraph: Dec. 14, 11:00 a.m. | Updates below |A WikiLeaks-style Web dump of drafts of the 2013 report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change provides fresh evidence that the organization’s policies and procedures are a terrible fit for an era in which transparency will increasingly be enforced on organizations working on consequential energy and environmental issues.

headline: Opening the Doors to the Life of Pi
abstract: The goal of the new Museum of Mathematics, its founders say, is to show that math is fun, engaging, exciting. And despite its flaws, it is exhilarating to see math so exuberantly celebrated.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who have been intoxicated by the powers and possibilities of mathematics, the mystery isn’t why that fascination developed but why it isn’t universal. How can students not be entranced? So profound are the effects of math for those who have felt them, that you never really become a former mathematician (or ex-mathematics student) but one who has “lapsed,” as if it were an apostasy.

headline: In Gangster State of Mind: Aging? Fuhgeddaboutit
abstract: “Stand Up Guys” features veteran gangsters on a last rampage; you might describe the movie as a bad-boy “Bucket List.”
lead_paragraph: The three geezers who run riot in “Stand Up Guys” aren’t just grumpy old men acting up. They’re veteran gangsters whose final rampage before they surrender to the dying of the light is a triumphant affirmation of vitality that the movie milks for two parts comedy to one part pathos.

headline: Few Echoes in a Voice With Mettle
abstract: Solange’s presence felt huge on stage, though she was content to be much smaller with her songs on Tuesday night at the Bowery Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: At the end of her show at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night, Solange was in the crowd, dancing, one reveler of many, set apart only by the fact that she had just been onstage, that it was her song moving the room, that her sister is Beyoncé — but really, by none of that.

headline: Audience Participates; Kneepads Recommended
abstract: “The Shining,” Yvonne Meier’s dance-theater work, requires 12 audience members who are brave enough to be pulled, touched and turned along dark passageways constructed from large cardboard boxes.
lead_paragraph: Imagine for the purposes of this review that you have a ticket for Yvonne Meier’s dance-theater work “The Shining.” Not many do; only 12 people may attend each performance. First, in the foyer of New York Live Arts, you must sign a liability waiver. Then a naked woman greets you, sings to you and ushers you into a van that transports you to a location outside Manhattan. (Though its Web site announces that performances of “The Shining” are happening there, I’ll preserve its mystery, as requested.)

headline: No Reading Between the Lines
abstract: “Saul Steinberg: A Biography,” by Deirdre Bair, is  much less lively than one of Steinberg’s illustrations.
lead_paragraph: What does it say about a biography when the author’s description of her working methods is more revealing than her text is. That’s the situation with “Saul Steinberg,” a studious, bone-dry book that is packed with information yet utterly inert. Its author, Deirdre Bair, has done far better work before, including her book on Simone de Beauvoir and her National Book Award-winning biography of Samuel Beckett. But when it comes to Steinberg she is hopelessly constrained by the circumstances in which she did her research and writing.

headline: A Daughter Stumbling in Her Father’s Footsteps
abstract: In “The Girl” a woman follows her father’s career path and decides to start smuggling people into the United States on her own, with less success.
lead_paragraph: It takes a stupid crime and an avoidable tragedy to realize that the title of the American independent movie “The Girl” refers to two people. The first is Ashley (Abbie Cornish), a solitary, thorny rose of Texas who lives in a trailer park and punches a clock at a dead-end job. Her manager favors the Latina workers, or so she believes; worse, her young son, Georgie (Austin Wayne West), has been taken away from her. She visits him soon after the story opens, dropping by the foster home where he lives and that, with its tidy lawn and swing set, looks pretty as a picture. It’s a snapshot of the American dream that seems out of her reach and that will bring her and the second girl trouble.

headline: Iran: U.S. Expands Anti-Nuclear Sanctions
abstract: The seven blacklisted companies cannot do business with any American businesses or citizens and any assets they may have in the United States will be frozen.
lead_paragraph: The United States expanded anti-nuclear sanctions against Iran on Thursday, blacklisting seven Iranian companies and five individuals including Fereydoon Abbasi, Iran’s top nuclear official and the target of a failed assassination attempt in Tehran two years ago, which Iran said was the work of Israeli operatives. The Treasury Department said the sanctions were intended to deter the procurement operations of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, which is led by Dr. Abbasi; the Iran Centrifuge Technology Company; and Iran’s uranium enrichment program. Companies and people on the blacklist cannot do business with any American businesses or citizens, and any assets they may have in the United States will be frozen. The new sanctions, which came as a team of inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency was visiting Iran, were likely to anger Iranian officials, who have repeatedly rejected Western and Israeli accusations that their nuclear program is a cover to develop the ability to make atomic weapons.

headline: Egypt’s Flawed Constitutional Vote

lead_paragraph: On Saturday, voters will begin casting their ballots in Egypt on their new constitution. Mr. Morsi should have postponed the referendum, reconvened a constitutional assembly that was less dominated by his Muslim Brotherhood allies and charged its members with writing an amended charter that would respond to the concerns that his more liberal, secular opponents have with the current draft.

lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox reached an agreement on a two-year, $26.5 million contract with the right-hander Ryan Dempster, adding a veteran starter to a thin rotation. The agreement was confirmed by a baseball official. The deal will not be announced until Dempster, 35, passes a physical. He was 12-8 with a 3.34 earned run average last season for the Chicago Cubs and the Texas Rangers. Dempster is the fifth player, but the first pitcher, to reach a two- or three-year contract agreement with the Red Sox this off-season. Burned in past years by long-term commitments, the Red Sox have been thriftier this time, signing Dempster, Jonny Gomes, Mike Napoli, David Ross and Shane Victorino to short-term deals. Napoli’s contract has not been finalized.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Sundance) RESTLESS In the conclusion of this two-part drama written by William Boyd, Ruth Gilmartin (Michelle Dockery), a Cambridge graduate student in 1970s England, continues to uncover the past of her mother, Sally (Charlotte Rampling, above), who she has recently discovered is actually Eva Delectorskaya (Hayley Atwell plays the young Eva), a Russian exile who worked as a British spy during World War II. Now the former spy thinks someone is out to kill her, which is why she’s buying a rifle and ammunition strong enough to take down a charging elephant. “We all have secrets,” she admonishes her disbelieving daughter. “No one even knows half the truth about someone else.” Rufus Sewell and Michael Gambon share the role of Lucas Romer, a spymaster and Sally’s former lover, who may be the only one who can save her. “Devout fans of the British espionage thriller or the British cozy mystery may find themselves perfectly happy with ‘Restless,’ ” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Boyd’s understated script is free of hackneyed dialogue or florid emotion (no surprise), and there are niceties of language — strategically repeated phrases, Ruth’s wavering forms of address to her mother — that you don’t expect in a mini-series. And Ms. Dockery and Ms. Rampling, in their relatively short screen time together, have an astringent rapport that brings to life the complicated relationship of Ruth and Eva, as well as Mr. Boyd’s themes of the forging and cracking of identity under pressure, in a way that goes beyond words on a page.”

headline: Ending a Life, and a Part of Yourself, for the First Time

lead_paragraph: Two hundred meters was all that separated me from an insurgent carrying an AK-47. I sat in a dilapidated brown leather chair, recessed in the shadows of a second-story room in the government complex of Falluja, Iraq. My sights were perfectly centered as I perched my elbows on the desk in front of me. The clear tip traced the center of his chest. He crept around a corner of a mud wall and slowly moved toward our position. Fear built inside me. I hesitantly began to pull the trigger of my M-16.

He quickly seduced the city’s frequently Francophile establishment, and, more important, tutored them in Gallic gastronomy like a stern but conditionally charming headmaster. For almost 40 years, Bec Fin was considered the best restaurant in Philadelphia, and one of the finest French tables in the United States.

headline: At the Panel’s Edge
abstract: In “Marbles,” Ellen Forney documents her struggles with bipolar disorder and her wobbly progress toward stability.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Forney’s greatest strength as a cartoonist is her gift for explanation — getting information across with vigor, wit and visual inventiveness. That inspiration may have come at an awful cost, she suggests in MARBLES: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me (Gotham, paper, $20), a memoir of her long tango, or wrestling match, with bipolar disorder. As she explains, her frantic, volatile high moods seemed to fuel her art; her crushing lows made it nearly impossible for her to make it, or do anything else; and the desperately inexact science of medication, she once feared, might rob her of the creativity she cherished. The bulk of “Marbles” documents her wobbly progress toward stability, with interpolated drawings from her journals and occasional side trips into the history of “crazy artists.” It’s not exactly focused, but it’s mostly delightful: Forney switches up the style and layout of her artwork every page or two, and she’s got enough perspective on herself to find some kind of comedy even in painful experiences.

abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SASHA AND EMMA: The Anarchist Odyssey of Alexander Berkman and Emma Goldman,  by Paul Avrich and Karen Avrich. (Belknap/Harvard University, $35.) Even when their affair ended, their comradeship lasted for the rest of their remarkable lives.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: [SIC]: A Memoir,  by Joshua Cody. (Norton, $15.95.) This sprightly, manic cancer memoir sidesteps sentimentality by mocking it, in prose our reviewer, Gregory Cowles, called “bright and jazzy and meandering.” Drawing from journals he kept during his treatment, Cody, a young composer in New York, combines the story of his illness — and his attempts to find refuge in sex and drugs — with meditations on family and the relationship between art and life.

headline: Sweeping Torture Under the Rug
abstract: On Thursday the Senate Intelligence Committee finally approved a 6,000-page report on C.I.A. detention and interrogation—but it remains classified.
lead_paragraph: In Strasbourg, France, a 17-judge panel of the European Court of Human Rights ruled unanimously on Thursday that U.S. intelligence did in fact kidnap a German citizen in Macedonia. The court said he was locked in a hotel room for 23 days, then handed over to a C.I.A. rendition team at an airport, where he was “severely beaten, sodomized, shackled and hooded.” Later he was sent to Afghanistan and illegally detained for months. The German citizen, Khaled el-Masri, had no connection to terrorism, unless you count the fact that U.S. officials were seeking an Al Qaeda operative with a similar name. The court ordered Macedonia to pay Mr. Masri $78,000 in damages.

headline: Empresses of Fantasy
abstract: How Diana Vreeland, Grace Coddington and Anna Wintour have made the world of fashion hum.
lead_paragraph: As the lowly assistant crouched on the floor, arranging purple snakeskin shoes for a photo shoot, the imperious editor swept into the room, flinging her Mainbocher coat at the young woman. Without thinking, the assistant “chucked it right back.” Was the underling fired for insubordination? No. Did she turn her experience into a blockbuster movie? Yes. But not in the way you might suppose, and not when you might suppose. That assistant wasn’t Lauren Weisberger, who parlayed her first job — answering the phones for Anna Wintour, editor of the American edition of Vogue — into the roman à clef, and then film, “The Devil Wears Prada” (a “disgracefully disloyal” thing to do, Vogue’s creative director, the amusingly blunt Grace Coddington, remarks in her understatedly dishy memoir, “Grace”). Far from it: the office dogsbody was the future film star Ali MacGraw, then an assistant to Wintour’s legendary predecessor, Diana Vreeland.

headline: Death of an Author
abstract: In Alberto Manguel’s novel, a journalist traces the life of an elusive South American writer.
lead_paragraph: For over 30 years, the Argentine expatriate Alberto Manguel has championed the cause of literature and reading in his polyhistoric anthologies and essays. His latest novel, “All Men Are Liars,” translated by Miranda France, advances this concern under the guise of a cross-­continental literary mystery.

headline: Outside the Ring
abstract: Eduardo Halfon’s narrator tries to discover the truth about his grandfather’s past.
lead_paragraph: Eduardo Halfon is the author of 11 books, but “The Polish Boxer” is his first to be translated into English, by, as it happens, five translators. This seems less a testament to the difficulty of the novel than a playful nod to one of its central preoccupations: how translation is a form of writing and writing is a form of translation. It is the sort of concern that can easily become ponderous in the wrong hands; in Halfon’s, it is funny and revelatory.

headline: Rocking the Cradle
abstract: The work of the composer Marc Blitzstein was often ignored because of his left-wing politics and openly gay sexuality.
lead_paragraph: Although in the same league with George Gershwin and Aaron Copland, subjects of two earlier biographies by Howard Pollack, Marc Blitzstein is relatively unfamiliar for a variety of reasons, among them his leftist politics and his openly gay sexuality in an era when both were disdained. Three years after Blitzstein’s death from what was evidently a gay-­bashing in Martinique in 1964, Cop­land said, “It is disheartening to realize how little the present generation knows who he was or what he accomplished,” and Leonard Bernstein expressed dismay in 1976 at “the rapidity with which his name’s been forgotten,” calling him “the greatest master of the setting of the American language to music.”

headline: Bookworms and Apples
abstract: In this novel, traditional researchers and digital experts join forces to solve a mystery.
lead_paragraph: In life and fiction, technology obsolesces the moment we acquire it. In Stieg Larsson’s novel “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” Lisbeth Salander is a hacker. Her superpower is an ability to uncover anything about anyone using her Powerbook, a laptop produced by Apple from 1991 to 2006. When Larsson wrote the novel, Powerbooks were advanced. Today, they are relics. Larsson spends an inordinate amount of time detailing hardware specifications, but this information doesn’t have the desired effect. Our smartphones have more computing power than Salander’s Powerbook. The way to write about technology does not reside in exhaustive technical description.

headline: The Trial
abstract: A former Khmer Rouge prisoner meets his captor.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, François Bizot, a French ethnologist studying Buddhism in Cambodia, was captured and held for three months in a Khmer Rouge detention camp, where he was interrogated (though apparently not physically tortured) by Kaing Guek Eav, a young revolutionary better known as Duch. Captor and captive developed a rapport, and ultimately, Bizot became the only Westerner to be released from Khmer Rouge captivity. Duch, meanwhile, went on to oversee the torture and murder of thousands of Cambodians at the notorious Tuol Sleng prison and in 2010 was the first person convicted by Cambodia’s war crimes tribunal. Bizot returned to Cambodia to testify at the trial. “Facing the Torturer” is his attempt to come to terms with this part of his ordeal (a previous account, “The Gate,” published in the United States in 2003, chronicled his earlier experiences in Cambodia).

headline: Nation Reels After Gunman Massacres 20 Children at School in Connecticut
abstract: A man with no apparent motive, armed with semiautomatic pistols and a semiautomatic rifle, fatally shot 26 people inside a Newtown elementary school before taking his own life.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year-old man wearing combat gear and armed with semiautomatic pistols and a semiautomatic rifle killed 26 people — 20 of them children — in an attack in an elementary school in central Connecticut on Friday. Witnesses and officials described a horrific scene as the gunman, with brutal efficiency, chose his victims in two classrooms while other students dove under desks and hid in closets.

headline: This Means War
abstract: Two picture books with an international perspective take a look at how conflicts start.
lead_paragraph: It was a rainy afternoon. Two 4-year-old girls played on the kitchen floor, coloring either end of a long accordion of paper. Glorious pastels and autumn tones materialized on the adjoining rectangles until they came together in the middle. The two girls held up their joint creation with glee. Until, that is, one mother arrived to pick up her daughter, who refused to budge without her half of the book. She asked for scissors, but her host, who happens to be my daughter, shook her head no and crawled under the kitchen table. One wailed for her half; the other wailed to keep the whole book.

headline: Midnight Caller
abstract: A 15-year-old creates an alter ego to woo his dream girl.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, most Americans still had rotary phones. CB radios were a new craze. Students learned math using slide rules. Mark Zuckerberg had not yet arrived on the planet, and teen­agers didn’t obsessively fashion aspirational online identities.

headline: In His Own Time
abstract: Karen Cushman’s young hero comes of age in the 16th century.
lead_paragraph: “Will Sparrow was a liar and a thief, and hungry” begins Karen Cushman’s latest novel. One of her recurring themes is that with enough pluck and mulishness, children will play through the bad hand fate deals them — once they’ve glimpsed a reason to do so. “I care for no one but myself,” the boy starts out saying, “and nothing but my belly!” while stealing a cold rabbit pie. By the end of “Will Sparrow’s Road,” when the boy’s conscience blossoms as he envisions a different life, we will have traveled with him through a lively and amusing parade of the late 16th century and through the hero’s own personal journey.

headline: The World Below
abstract: A basement passage leads a lonely girl into another realm.
lead_paragraph: No matter how fervently children cling to the belief that fairies yet linger in the backyard, fireflies are really fallen stars and stuffed animals can talk, absolutely, the adult world (with its tedium, stresses and need for matched socks) will slowly encroach on theirs. But the stubborn and lucky few who refuse ever to believe they are “too old” for imagination are also those who wisely come to understand that “sometimes there was great truth in made-up stories.”

headline: Dec. 14 Updates on Connecticut School Shooting
abstract: Multiple people, mostly children, were shot in Newtown, Conn., at the Sandy Hook Elementary School.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, hundreds of people turned out for prayer vigils and services in Newtown, Conn. and across the country in the aftermath of one of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history. As our colleagues report a gunman killed 26 people, including 20 children, then killed himself at the Sandy Hook Elementary School. The gunman’s 54-year-old mother was found dead at the home they shared in Newtown. Read all related coverage on the Lede »

headline: Generator of Dreams
abstract: Margaret Talbot writes about her father, the actor Lyle Talbot, in “The Entertainer,” and Richard Lingeman writes about paranoia and insecurity in Hollywood and elsewhere in “The Noir Forties.”
lead_paragraph: First, let me dispel the curse of the two-book review. These ambitious works of cultural history are in no way a forced pairing. Both “The Entertainer” and “The Noir Forties” examine political and sociological shifts in America at large, viewing Hollywood as a generator of dreams that at once mirrors and shapes the collective unconscious — as well as a company town run by despotic bosses.

headline: Caroline Sylvester and Charles Maddock
abstract: Introduced by a mutual friend, the couple grew increasingly attached after a first date that was nearly canceled.
lead_paragraph: ON the surface, Charles Maddock could be seen as one of those privileged young men who develops a sense of noblesse oblige as he dances between the raindrops while everyone else gets wet.

headline: Pin Your Best Recipes for Holiday Sweets

lead_paragraph: What is your foolproof holiday dessert recipe, the secret weapon in your December arsenal, the dazzler at the party or the beauty at the end of the meal? Or, if you’re trying something new this year, what is the recipe you’re most enticed by?

headline: 25 Favorites From a Year When 10 Aren’t Enough
abstract: Despite the year’s critical cries of despair over the declining fortunes of cinema, the film industry responded with a resounding “So what?”
lead_paragraph: IF you spent a lot of time this year reading and writing about movies — as opposed to watching them, which is more fun — you might have detected recurrent notes of anxiety, trepidation, even dread. Television is better than movies; audience levels are in a state of permanent decline; the Hollywood studios have given up on grown-ups; and digital, a force so powerful that it is both adjective and noun, is destroying cinema as we know it. These are among the tenets of a pessimistic conventional wisdom.

headline: Your ‘Homeland’ Questions Answered

lead_paragraph: The second season of the Showtime thriller “Homeland” has been as suspenseful as its acclaimed first run but somewhat more polarizing. With the finale coming up on Sunday, the creators of “Homeland” — Alex Gansa, the show runner and executive producer, and Howard Gordon, an executive producer — agreed to answer questions from Times readers about the show.

headline: Nothing Staid About Royal Academy’s Art Gift to the Queen
abstract: To commemorate Queen Elizabeth II’s diamond jubilee, the Royal Academy of Arts gives her some interesting artworks.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II’s art collection just got a little bigger and – at least by the work represented – a lot more adventurous. To commemorate the queen’s diamond jubilee marking the 60th anniversary of her ascension to the throne, the Royal Academy of Arts has given her 97 works on paper by some of Britain’s most esteemed and also most polarizing artists.

headline: A Proliferation of Ways to Use a Tax Break as Its End Nears
keywords: ['Gifts', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Time is running out on a generous exemption from gift taxes, but tax advisers have no shortage of ways to get in under the deadline.
lead_paragraph: HOLIDAY shoppers and tax filers are known for procrastinating. This year, they’re joined by the wealthy who have still not decided whether to make a gift under a generous gift tax exemption that may soon disappear.

headline: Safety First, Then Mistletoe, Is Byword for the Holidays
abstract: Holiday hosts naturally think of festive décor and delicious food, but they should first ensure their home is in good repair and safe for guests.
lead_paragraph: LAST Thanksgiving, I learned a valuable safety tip: be careful when using a foil roasting pan. It can puncture and fat can drip in the oven, resulting in a fire.

headline: Against the Odds, Smart Films Thrive at the Box Office
abstract: This has been a bumper year for movies big and small, imported and domestic, some made for hundreds of millions of dollars and others made for about the price of a grande soy latte.
lead_paragraph: SEEN any good movies lately? How could you not? This has been a bumper year for movies big and small, imported and domestic, some made for hundreds of millions of dollars and others made for about the price of a grande soy latte. As has been the case in recent years, the top box office movies in America were mostly formulaic corporate entertainments, including the superhero comic-book fantasies like “Marvel’s The Avengers” that make some critics despair. Even amid the usual selection of big-screen cartoons and testosterone, though, it was nice to see female-driven stories like “The Hunger Games” — and all the female viewers its box office represents — muscling into the mix.

headline: Thank You for the Tissue Graft
abstract: How do you show gratitude to the family of someone who’s given you a posthumous gift of life?
lead_paragraph: FOR weeks I had been reading the sample thank-you letter I got from the hospital. In June I underwent A.C.L. replacement surgery, which means that one of the major ligaments in my knee — the one that holds the knee in place — was removed, and in its place doctors screwed in an anonymous cadaver’s Achilles’ tendon. Along with the tendon, I got a folder filled with recovery instructions for taking a shower and protecting the stitches and a piece of paper on how to write a thank-you note to the family of the donor. Every few days I’d pick up the paper and my eyes would fill with tears as I was reminded that my gain was someone else’s heartbreaking loss.

headline: Week 15 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
abstract: The fantasy football playoffs are starting to feel like the Twilight Zone–just ask owners of Patriots running back Stevan Ridley.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Perpetual Motion
abstract: What to glean from the fall precollections? A shift to longer lengths, volume in shoulders and sleeves, and widened lapels, for starters.
lead_paragraph: THE fall 2013 fashion season begins on the worn-down heels of fall ’12. Stores are marking down the stuff they couldn’t sell as designers present their new duds. There is no time to mourn in fashion, and apparently no room for a guilty conscience about the glut of clothes, since it keeps right on growing like a berserk house plant.

headline: Hard-Line Israeli Foreign Minister Resigns
abstract: Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman resigned on Friday after being charged with fraud and breach of trust, in a move that could have repercussions for next month’s elections.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Facing indictment for breach of trust and fraud, Israel’s foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, resigned his post Friday afternoon amid mounting political pressure, upending the campaign landscape five weeks before national elections.

headline: Ristretto | Books for the Coffee Lover
abstract: The best of this year’s coffee books, according to our caffeinated columnist, take a deeper look into the history of the drink, in America and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The annual annual avalanche of cookbooks, food memoirs and single-ingredient investigations has largely passed by coffee. For some reason, the publishing industry hasn’t been that interested in what you drink every morning.

headline: The Year of the Body Vulnerable
abstract: The body — not exalted, but in its weaknesses — gets focus in many significant films of 2012, including “Amour,” “The Sessions” and “Rust and Bone.”
lead_paragraph: SO many of the year’s best films have broken ground in their depiction of the realities of war, disability, aging, illness and death that I would call 2012 the year of the body. Not the body beautiful, which Hollywood has exalted for decades, but the body vulnerable. Even the male strippers in “Magic Mike,” Steven Soderbergh’s unsexy beefcake parade, are tarnished deities with feet of clay.

headline: Educating Students From Cultures That See Work as Exploitation
abstract: A new community college tackles the preconceptions of students from backgrounds where work is seen not as an outgrowth of one’s passions, but as something negative or scarce.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Traveling through this city’s warren of subways, you see them everywhere: advertisements promoting community colleges — and in so many cases, emphasizing their flexibility as a principal selling point.

headline: E.P.A. Sets a Lower Limit for Soot Particles in the Air
abstract: Acting under a court deadline, the agency will seek a standard that will force industry, utilities and local governments to find ways to reduce emissions of particles by 2020.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency announced a new standard for soot pollution on Friday that will force industry, utilities and local governments to find ways to reduce emissions of particles that are linked to thousands of cases of disease and death each year.

headline: “I Was A Teenage Cyclist, Part 2: The Scourge of the Lethal Ghost Riders”
abstract: On the heels of “The Bike Lane Cancer,” the latest anti-bike screed which was published in The New York Post, we catalog the growing lexicon of the burgeoning anti-bike genre.
lead_paragraph: Back in March 2011, John Cassidy of The New Yorker wrote a much-discussed and highly instructive blog post in which he made a case against bike lanes in New York — much-discussed in that many people disagreed with him (including me) and instructive insofar as it conveniently collected nearly all the tropes of the burgeoning anti-bike genre.

headline: Journalists Punched by Israeli Officers After Fatal Shooting at West Bank Checkpoint
abstract: Two Palestinian journalists working for Reuters were punched by Israeli soldiers as they tried to reach the scene of a fatal shooting at a West Bank checkpoint this week.
lead_paragraph: Two Palestinian journalists working for Reuters were punched, hit with rifle butts and forced to strip by Israeli soldiers on Wednesday as they tried to reach the scene of a fatal shooting at a West Bank checkpoint, the news agency reports. The soldiers then confiscated the crew’s camera and gas masks before letting off a tear-gas canister which forced one of the men to seek medical treatment.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss their pop music top-ten album lists of 2012.
