abstract: After Susan E. Rice pulled her name from the race for secretary of state, The Times looks at her record and other possible nominees for the position.
lead_paragraph: After Susan E. Rice pulled her name from the race for secretary of state, The Times looks at her record and other possible nominees for the position.

headline: Lopez Hopes to Play Friday Night
abstract: Brook Lopez of the Nets, who has missed the last seven games, is listed as probable for Friday night’s game against the Pistons.
lead_paragraph: Nets center Brook Lopez said he is hopeful to return from a sprained right foot on Friday against Detroit, after missing the last seven games.

headline: The 12.2.12 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: SUPERHERO OF THE SEA

headline: Why I Keep the Dearly Departed in My Address Book
abstract: Even though I know that they won’t call back.
lead_paragraph: Heading into my golden years, I have one bad knee, two good daughters and 836 names in my iPhone address book. Of the latter, 246 are people I have not seen or spoken to in at least 10 years. Thirty-nine are a total mystery to me — I have no idea who they are.

headline: Willie Nelson, the Silver-Headed Stranger
abstract: The singer and author of “Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die” on calming the rage and fighting bumblebees.
lead_paragraph: In your new book, “Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die,” you write about enjoying bumblebee fights in Texas as a child. What is that exactly?  Abbott, where I grew up, is a small farm town, and you knew all the farmers. They would come in on weekends to do their shopping and talk about bumblebees’ nests that they had run into while they were out plowing their fields. They would tell us kids where the bumblebees were, and we’d go out on Sunday afternoons and fight bumblebees.

headline: Cat Custody
abstract: And the cat came back.
lead_paragraph: A neighbor recently posted on a neighborhood forum that after several years, her lost cat returned home. The cat was a kitten when it went astray. Naturally, the neighbors did the usual things you do when you lose a cat; searched endlessly, put food out and posted on community boards, electronic and otherwise. The family was naturally relieved when the cat returned. However, someone has clearly cared for the cat. It is healthy and has been neutered. But there’s no indication of ownership. My neighbor’s dilemma is a question of obligation to the “temporary” family and whether she can take ownership of the cat. CRAIG FIELD, AUSTIN, TEX.

headline: Let My Tebow Go
abstract: The best argument to let Tim Tebow play has nothing to do with football. It has to do with Kierkegaard, Sartre’s existential nausea and a quest to embrace the absurd.
lead_paragraph: What will Tim Tebow be doing by the time you read this? Will he be leading the Jets to an improbable victory, perhaps even a miraculous playoff berth? Will he be publicly demanding a trade to somewhere like Jacksonville? Or will he be exactly where he was when we last saw him — injured and wasting away on the Jets’ bench, weathering nasty cheap shots from teammates, like the one who sneered to The Daily News: “We’re depending on miracles? You can’t play that way”?

headline: Feast in a Day
abstract: Mark Bittman and Sam Sifton show you how to cook an unforgettable holiday dinner in eight hours — and make the process itself a celebration.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Sam Sifton and I took up the job of cooking for 15 people at a friend’s home in Brooklyn. The idea was to feed and impress friends, family members and colleagues without driving ourselves nuts. It’s possible. And to do so, we decided not to spend more than eight hours obsessing over, shopping for and preparing the meal. We bought all our ingredients in the morning and then cooked through the afternoon. Dinner was called for 6 p.m.

headline: Who Made Those 3-D Glasses?
abstract: The beginnings of a fad that won’t die.
lead_paragraph: One morning in 1915, curiosity-seekers filed into the Astor Theater in New York for a new cinematic spectacle. As two film projectors rattled to life, the audience was immersed in a wonderland. “Hills, valleys, houses, the figures on a country road,” wrote Lynde Denig, a reporter who attended the screening, “the effect is marvelously real.”

headline: The Sweet Spot | Music Sharing
abstract: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the various ways we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes — like “Gangnam Style.”
lead_paragraph: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the various ways we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes — like “Gangnam Style.”

headline: Examining the Hazards of Older Parenthood
abstract: To dial back the age at which we have children for not just some, but most adults, we’re going to have to change the way Western societies approach family policy. Should we?
lead_paragraph: Older parenthood, proposes Judith Shulevitz in The New Republic, will “upend American society.” Parenthood over the last century “has undergone a change so simple yet so profound we are only beginning to grasp the enormity of its implications,” she writes. In short, we have our children much later than we used to.

headline: Salutes to the Pros, From a Winded Amateur
abstract: A reporter bestows awards on some musical events that made this a memorable year.
lead_paragraph: OH, how the arts love awards! Here at Classical Music World News Headquarters we issue our own at the end of random years. We do not give them cute anthropomorphic names (Bessie, Emmy, Tony); they have no monetary value, no statuette and, in fact, no real importance. But here they are anyway, a means of recalling some of the year’s highs and lows.

headline: Risk Creeps Up in Long-Term Bonds
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: If rates rise, bondholders’ old bonds will lose value. If rates fall, their old bonds may be redeemed by the company, depriving the bondholders of yield.
lead_paragraph: THE Federal Reserve Board’s Open Market Committee this week gave the first hint of what would cause it to allow interest rates to rise. It promised to maintain low rates until the unemployment rate — at 7.7 percent last month — fell to 6.5 percent, so long as inflation also remained quiet.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 14
abstract: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about ways in which we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes — like “Gangnam Style.”
lead_paragraph: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the more modern ways in which we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes — like “Gangnam Style.”

headline: How to Cook a Feast in 8 Hours or Less
abstract: A timeline in photos.
lead_paragraph: A timeline in photos.

headline: This Look Won’t Insult Her
abstract: Lisa Lampanelli, the insult comic, finds that it’s much easier to dress after recent weight loss.
lead_paragraph: LISA LAMPANELLI, 51, a former journalist, is best known for the insult comedy that has earned her the nickname the Queen of Mean. Ms. Lampanelli, who was born in Trumbull, Conn., now lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with her husband, Jimmy (Canno) Cannizzaro, her road manager. She is scheduled to perform at the Apollo Theater on Jan. 30.

headline: Denise and Jeff Austin, Blessed With Enthusiasm
abstract: Married 29 years, the fitness guru and the big brother of the tennis star Tracy Austin keep it together with positive attitudes and a determination not to take anything for granted.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Travel Is Educational In a Year of the Move
abstract: Dance performances in their styles’ Indian and Southeastern contexts were among the most indelible moments of 2012.
lead_paragraph: THE links among dance, geography and social anthropology are complex and profound. Sooner or later much — by no means all — of the world’s best dance comes to New York; some of it even blooms brighter here. Yet dance grows in meaning when we see it within its culture. Two trips I made this year opened my eyes and mind in life-enhancing ways.

headline: Sights in New York Like No Others
abstract: Douglas Dunn, Justin Peck and Sally Silvers offered singular visions in 2012.
lead_paragraph: IN her terrific new book, “A Choreographic Mind,” Susan Rethorst discusses the difficulties of sticking to your artistic guns in the face of forces like the market, the feedback of colleagues and the ever-changing fashions of the field. “How on earth,” she asks, “do you keep your compass?”

headline: Russia Opens New Inquiry Targeting an Activist
abstract: The activist and street protest leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, is already being questioned in two other cases and the new charges became public a day before a planned opposition rally.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The police opened a new criminal investigation on Friday against Aleksei Navalny, the street protest leader and anticorruption activist, who is already being questioned in two other cases.

headline: Quirks of the Game: Should the N.F.L. Kill the Kickoff?
abstract: Tampa Bay Coach Greg Schiano has proposed doing away with kickoffs to make the game safer. The idea has yet to gain much support.
lead_paragraph: Talk about bad timing.

headline: Making the Most Of Their Moments
abstract: Hee Seo, Nicole Mannarino and Thibault Lac are among several dancers with standout moments this past year.
lead_paragraph: THIS was the year of the dancer. Ingrained in my memory is a treasure chest of afterimages: the most vivid are Hee Seo, Nicole Mannarino and Thibault Lac. Ms. Seo, a newly promoted principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, is a dramatic ballerina of profound depth, as she proved with her savagely beautiful Tatiana in “Onegin” at the Metropolitan Opera. Ms. Mannarino’s spellbinding performances in Sarah Michelson’s dances at both the Whitney Biennial and at the Museum of Modern Art have cemented her as a cherished muse and, in turn, transported an experimental choreographer’s work to a new level. And Mr. Lac, a contemporary dancer based in Europe, moves like a slippery piece of silk. One of the great pleasures of this past year has been watching his lanky frame navigate the places where voguing meets postmodern dance in Trajal Harrell’s excellent series “Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church.”

headline: Karl Rove’s ‘Social Welfare’ Organization
abstract: In 2010 Crossroads GPS applied to the IRS for tax-exempt status. ProPublica obtained the document.
lead_paragraph: From June 2010 until Dec. 2011, leading up to the presidential election season, Karl Rove’s Crossroads GPS spent $64.7 million, according to ProPublica. Of that money, a grand total of $1.4 million, or 2 percent, was spent on what Crossroads identified as “research.”

headline: The Angel of Marye’s Heights
abstract: Did the Confederate soldier Richard Kirkland really bring water to wounded Union men during the Battle of Fredericksburg?
lead_paragraph: All through the night of Dec. 13, 1862, the ambulance corps of the Union’s Army of the Potomac labored to remove their wounded brethren from the killing grounds at Fredericksburg. Compared with earlier battles – especially the twin debacles at Bull Run – the stretcher-bearers and hospital stewards did an exemplary job.

headline: Curtain Falls, But Operas Reverberate
abstract: “Einstein on the Beach,” by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson, and “Dog Days,” by David T. Little and Royce Vavrek, cast long shadows.
lead_paragraph: AS I look back over the concerts, productions and developments that made an impact in 2012, two operas loom largest in my estimation. One, “Einstein on the Beach,” by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson, must have felt like the death and rebirth of the art form when it first appeared in 1976. (Hard for me to say, not having been there.) The other, “Dog Days,” by David T. Little and Royce Vavrek, received its premiere this year. Compared with “Einstein” it was defiantly traditional.

headline: Worth Hearing And Rehearing
abstract: String quartets, solo violinists and monodramas were among the memorable musical programs of the year for Vivien Schweitzer.
lead_paragraph: HERE are the performances that have stuck with me through the year:

headline: Fat Dad: Hanukkah With My Grandmothers
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Families and Family Life', 'Hanukkah', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Recipes']
abstract: Between my father’s constant dieting and my mother’s odd eating habits, I was always hungry. But all that changed when I was with my grandmothers during the Jewish holidays.
lead_paragraph: When I lived in Chicago, Jewish holidays were spent either at my Grandma Beauty’s house or my Bubbe Mary’s house. My two grandmothers lived near each other on the North Side of Chicago. However, I saw my grandmother Beauty every weekend, but I would only see my grandmother Bubbe Mary, my father’s mother, on occasional holidays. While my two grandmothers had a lot in common — they were both amazing cooks — they were also very different.

headline: Ancient Roots, Twisting Together in Easy Harmony
abstract: Highlights of the year included performances by Lo Còr de la Plana, Yousif Sheronick and Eden MacAdam-Somer in New York.
lead_paragraph: WE spent a good part of 2012 celebrating the bridge builders in music: institutions like Georg Solti’s World Orchestra for Peace and Daniel Barenboim’s West-Eastern Divan, which bring together players from different cultures, or the Venezuelan Sistema, which narrows the gap between low income and high art. All worthy and good. But what drew my attention was the archaeological work of musicians who quietly reveal the common foundations and tangled roots among cultures that have been there all along.

headline: Titans Outpaced by Little Guys
abstract: In 2012 there were more downloadable games than ever, and they were more consistently excellent than the output of the industry’s major studios.
lead_paragraph: THE six years leading up to this one were blessed with an extraordinary bounty of video games. Every year brought new creations that expanded our sense of the medium’s possibilities. Among them — and I could go with a score of different titles — were BioShock, Grand Theft Auto IV, Portal, Red Dead Redemption and Rock Band. The run of games since the release of the Xbox 360 in late 2005 (followed the next year by the PlayStation 3 and Nintendo Wii) has been so remarkable that sometimes it feels as if 2012 has broken the streak, that well-turned games like Borderlands 2, Dishonored and XCOM: Enemy Unknown don’t quite belong in the same genre-expanding class as their predecessors.

headline: Moments Taut, Tawdry or Unscripted
abstract: The New York Times’s chief television critic weighs in on TV series and events that delivered the goods this year. Or didn’t.
lead_paragraph: THE lure of the unexpected drew mass television audiences to the London Olympics and the presidential debates. But what keeps viewers returning to regular shows week after week (or hour after hour on an iPad) is a more delicate blend of familiarity and surprise. It’s a balance that is easily upset by overblown expectations. And even some of the best shows of the year battled the weight of excessive appreciation:

headline: Pleasures of Unexpected Programming
abstract: The pianists David Greilsammer, Andras Schiff, Jeremy Denk and Mitsuko Uchida provided some of the year’s more exciting classical concerts.
lead_paragraph: ADVENTUROUS programming has proved one of the most effective tools artists have to shake classical music out of its staid concert protocols. The Israeli pianist David Greilsammer has been particularly innovative at devising programs that juxtapose old and new works in dynamic ways. He showed this vividly in a solo recital at the Mostly Mozart Festival in August at the Kaplan Penthouse, part of the popular Little Night Music series of late-night programs. If the ambience was informal, the music making was exhilarating.

headline: Still Going Strong: Detectives, Killers and Bill Moyers
abstract: Among the top offerings on television this year: “Sherlock,” “Southland,” “Louie,” “The Killing” and HBO’s documentaries.
lead_paragraph: 1. SHERLOCK (PBS) We get only three episodes of this BBC series a year, but each one packs an amazing amount of intelligence, mystery, action, brittle emotion and sheer entertainment into its 90 minutes. Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman, as the contemporary Holmes and Watson, give very different but perfectly complementary performances, and each is wonderful.

headline: Violinist With Flag, Film With Diva, Allegory of Aging
abstract: Hahn-Bin, Paul Lewis and — mainstream surprise! — the New York Philharmonic deliver highlights of the year.
lead_paragraph: HERE, in chronological order, are the 10 performances that excited me most this year:

headline: Popcast: The Best Albums of 2012
abstract: The New York Times critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss their pop music top-ten album lists of 2012.
lead_paragraph: This week, the critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff emerge from seclusion, deliberation and rigorous inventory to discuss their pop music top-ten album lists of 2012.

headline: Dubious Ideas, and Hybrids That Got Away
abstract: A sampler of oddities, stray thoughts and ephemera from TV 2012 illustrates just how head-spinning the medium can be.
lead_paragraph: MOST year-end lists involving the arts try to impose order on an impossibly unwieldy subject or theme: the Most Memorable Broadway Performances among hundreds; the Best Indie Films That Nobody Saw among a countless number of indie films that nobody saw. But in the case of television this insistence on tidy systematization runs counter to what the medium has become; namely, the very definition of chaotic.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Recalling 5,800 Vehicles for Fuel Leak
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker said it began looking into a problem last August when it saw warranty claims for fuel filters had increased.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz is recalling about 5,800 vehicles because of a possible fuel leak, the automaker has told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Wild Horses Are Running Out of Room, On and Off Range
abstract: The question of what to do with horses who roam the rural West has confounded the federal government for decades.
lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo. — The herd of wild horses clopped cautiously toward the strangers in their pen. A chestnut mustang leaned in for a closer look, sniffing and snorting curiously. Another inched backward, her black eyes flashing with fear.

headline: Dempster’s Deal With Red Sox Should Interest Dickey
abstract: If Ryan Dempster is worth $26.5 million over two years to the Red Sox, how much should R.A. Dickey, the National League Cy Young Award winner, be worth to the Mets?
lead_paragraph: Just how much is R.A. Dickey, the Mets’ 38-year-old Cy Young Award-winning knuckleballer, worth?

headline: A. O. Scott’s Top Film Picks
abstract: Images from the critic’s top picks from the year.
lead_paragraph: Images from the critic’s top picks from the year.

headline: Dec. 16 — 22
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: WHEN “THE CLOCK” — Christian Marclay’s universally adored video installation — was playing at Lincoln Center this past summer, 18,000 people came to see it. But those who missed it have another chance. From Friday through Jan. 21 it will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art. The 24-hour montage of clips from the last hundred years of movies and television that depict particular minutes in the day, synchronized with the moment they are shown, has become one of those classics that movie buffs relish seeing over and over again.

headline: A Sleepy Cosette and a Hungover Fantine
abstract: At a luncheon for “Les Miz,” the 10-year-old actress who plays young Cosette confessed to falling asleep at the film’s New York premiere — but it’s not what you think.
lead_paragraph: Musical interludes have been a big theme this week, as studios and consultants pull out all the stops before the cutoff date for razzle-dazzling voters, on Jan. 10, when the Oscar nominees are revealed.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names New Regional Chiefs for Mergers Unit
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Morgan Stanley named new heads of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas and for Europe on Friday after a management reshuffling brought on by the impending departure of the senior deal maker Paul Taubman.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley named new heads of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas and for Europe on Friday after a management reshuffling brought on by the impending departure of a senior deal maker, Paul Taubman.

headline: On Our Radar: Atlantic Panel Limits Catch of Crucial Fish
abstract: The harvesting of the menhaden will be reduced by 20 percent. Some environmental groups had sought a reduction of as much as 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: In a compromise, a regulatory panel approves a 20 percent cut in the annual harvest of the menhaden, a vital fish in the mid-Atlantic food chain. [The Baltimore Sun]

headline: ESPN Suspends Commentator Over Racial Comments About Quarterback
abstract: ESPN announced that it had suspended Rob Parker, a commentator on the network’s program “First Take,” because of his racially oriented comments about Robert Griffin III, the rookie quarterback for the Washington Redskins.
lead_paragraph: ESPN announced on Friday that it had suspended Rob Parker, a commentator on the network’s program “First Take,” because of his racially oriented comments about the rookie quarterback for the Washington Redskins, Robert Griffin III.

headline: This Duck Doesn’t Need a Label on It
abstract: At its best, braising is an art, not a frugal attempt to concoct a meal with a few scraps of meat and a lot of gravy.
lead_paragraph: IF the word “stew” conjures up less-than-positive memories, perhaps you should consider saying “braise” instead. It is really just a question of semantics, but your dining companions may react differently if you tell them there are red-wine braised duck legs on the menu, rather than calling the dish duck stew.

headline: Murder Charges Upgraded in Florida Killing of Youth
abstract: The man accused of fatally shooting a 17-year-old in Jacksonville after an argument over loud music is now being charged with first-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of shooting and killing a Jacksonville, Fla., youth after an argument over loud music is now being charged with first-degree murder.

headline: The Giving Spree | Olivier Theyskens
abstract: The designer shares what he’s giving, and what he’s hoping to get, this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Who: The designer for Theory and Theyskens’ Theory, Olivier Theyskens, who turned the city of New York into our signature initial for T’s spring men’s issue.

headline: Mining ‘Scandal’ for Ratings
abstract: Propelled by a cliffhanger a la “Who Shot J.R.?,” the ABC drama “Scandal” has soared in the ratings.
lead_paragraph: On the ABC drama “Scandal,” Kerry Washington plays Olivia Pope, the best consultant in Washington, but even that character would have to be impressed with the marketing savvy that is pushing the series to new heights in the ratings.

headline: Rialto Bridge in Venice to Be Restored With Corporate Money
abstract: The city of Venice announced Friday that the fashion entrepreneur Renzo Rosso, the founder of the OTB holding company – whose brands include Diesel, Viktor & Rolf and Martin Margiela – had donated 5 million euros (about $6.5 million) through the company to restore the city’s famed Rialto Bridge.
lead_paragraph: ROME – The city of Venice announced Friday that the fashion entrepreneur Renzo Rosso, the founder of the OTB holding company – whose brands include Diesel, Viktor & Rolf and Martin Margiela – had donated 5 million euros (about $6.5 million) through the company to restore the Rialto Bridge in the city.

headline: The Debt Ceiling, Then and Now
abstract: The Times’s Annie Lowrey reports on how the 2011 debt ceiling negotiations have informed the current back-and-forth.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Annie Lowrey reports on how the 2011 debt ceiling negotiations have informed the current back-and-forth.

headline: The Slaughter of Schoolchildren
abstract: A gunman slaughters schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: It is a sad reflection of the human capacity for violence that Wikipedia has a sub-category, under “rampage killers,” for “rampage killers: school massacres.” David Brooks’ July column on rampage killings and a related piece by the psychiatrist David Archer in Psychology Today, provide valuable data and insights on such killings, if little comfort on a very dark day.

headline: For Student Borrowers, Relief Now May Mean a Big Tax Bill Later
abstract: Two federal loan programs that include loan forgiveness can result in a huge tax bill years later when the remaining balance is forgiven.
lead_paragraph: Those breathing a sigh of relief that their student loan payments are now in line with their income may want to re-examine the rules that set the payment in the first place. There could be a tax time bomb looming, slowly ticking away. And defusing it is not a big part of the policy discussion in Washington at the moment.

headline: Should You Have to Pay Taxes on Forgiven Student Loan Debt?
abstract: Bucks readers weigh in on whether forgiven student loan debt should come with a fat tax bill from the Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: I generally try to stay away from policy debates in my work, but this weekend’s Your Money column begs a tax policy question that will probably affect millions of people someday: If you’re enrolled in the income-based repayment program, where any remaining federal student loan debt gets forgiven after a certain number of years, should you have to pay income taxes on the loan balance that the government dismisses?

headline: Spurs Mystery: Where Is Matt Bonner?
abstract: The odd man out for San Antonio this season has been Matt Bonner, which is curious because he seems to complement Spurs players so well.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the San Antonio Spurs and Coach Gregg Popovich decided to go all-in on a fast-tempo offense that emphasizes the 3-pointer, the offense has hummed along at incredible efficiency. The one clinking noise ratting around in the otherwise smooth offensive machine has been the dilemma of what to do with the second front court spot. That is, the one not occupied by future hall of famer Tim Duncan.

headline: Q&A: Moving Playlists to the iPod in iTunes 11
abstract: Apple’s new iTunes 11 program may look different from previous versions, but you still have several ways to add playlists and other content to a connected iPod.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Trading Up Can Be Hard to Do
abstract: A two-bedroom in the $1.4 million to $3 million range can be difficult to come by in the Manhattan market.
lead_paragraph: EVEN with a hefty down payment, a perfect credit score and a top-notch broker, many New Yorkers who want to move to bigger and better apartments are having no luck. Stymied by a scarcity of listings and a tight credit market, even the most qualified buyers are being outbid, turned down for loans or simply can’t find what they’re looking for. As a result they are being forced to sit on the sidelines.

headline: A Young Star, Team Player
abstract: Jan Lisiecki proved he was a team player, literally, at his debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: When you are a young pianist appearing with a given orchestra for the first time, you don’t want to seem presumptuous. You want to be a team player, literally.

headline: The Language of Uptalk
abstract: Cooking with Emily Dickinson; Hot Pockets of hope.
lead_paragraph: THE BIG PROFILEBy Dave Itzkoff

headline: Pews Tirelessly Restored, and an Immigrant Redeemed
abstract: When, after seven months in jail, Fabian Cervantes walked into a church where he had worshiped and toiled, his best friend in the congregation considered it a miracle.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning last summer, Fabian Cervantes walked through the doors of Our Lady of Refuge, the Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn that he had lost hope of ever seeing again. His arms were pale from seven months in jail. His clothes hung limply because he had lost 25 pounds. His sallow eyes attested to scores of sleepless nights.

headline: Render That Duck Fat
abstract: Rendering is simply a matter of letting the fat simmer very slowly until it is completely liquid, then straining and cooling it a bit before pouring it into jars for future use.
lead_paragraph: For the braise featured in this week’s City Kitchen column, I bought four large, meaty Muscovy duck legs, weighing about a pound apiece. They were untrimmed, which meant they came with a generous coating of fat.

headline: The Gift Tax and Other Tax Worries
abstract: Bucks readers weigh in on their concerns about higher taxes in the new year.
lead_paragraph: With the tax talks in Washington seemingly at an impasse, no one knows for sure what will happen to the now-generous gift tax exemption. But the tax lawyers and advisers Paul Sullivan spoke to for his Wealth Matters column this week said the wealthy have been scrambling in recent weeks to make gifts before the exemption — now at $5.12 million a person — expires at the end of the year.

headline: A Contrarian Spin on the Next Big Climate Report
keywords: ['Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Earth', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Sun']
abstract: Extracting one sentence from a draft report, a climate skeptic asserts that an international body has decided that cosmic rays are a major cause of global warming. But he omits the report’s surrounding context, which discredits the cosmic ray theory.
lead_paragraph: Some Green readers have probably heard by now that a draft of the next big United Nations report on climate change has leaked.

headline: Judge Dismisses Case Against Harlem Wizards
abstract: The Harlem Ambassadors basketball team claimed that the Harlem Wizards stole one of their best players, but a judge has thrown out the case.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Ambassadors and Harlem Wizards, two of the best-known show basketball teams in the country, have at least one thing in common: They both claim to play a “Harlem” brand of basketball.

headline: Simpler Ways to Enjoy the Holidays
abstract: Kristin van Ogtrop, managing editor of Real Simple, answers reader questions about gift giving, family gatherings and other potentially stressful holiday events.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Booming and of Real Simple recently submitted questions to Kristin van Ogtrop, the managing editor of Real Simple, about ways to simplify life this holiday season. Ms. van Ogtrop, who has spent her career at magazines, also oversees Adventures in Chaos, a blog where she writes about life as a working mother. headline: The Case of Cinematic Déjà Vu

headline: Doha: Weirdly Tame and Dispirited
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: At the annual climate change negotiations there were no people in polar bear suits, and there was no solid agreement.
lead_paragraph: The annual United Nations climate change negotiations this year in Doha, which wrapped up on Dec. 8, seemed weirdly tame and dispirited. There was minimal press coverage and, as Jennifer Haverkamp of the Environmental Defense Fund observed, there were “no people in polar bear suits, no passionate youth doing skits, no melting ice sculptures—no real infusion of energy.”  There was also no solid agreement on how to confront the threat of global warming by slowing the seemingly inexorable rise of heat-trapping emissions or by helping poor nations mitigate the inevitable damage or, preferably, both. That was not weird. These conferences have not produced a binding document since the Kyoto Protocol of 1997, which was itself flawed because it asked nothing of big developing nations, and, partly for that reason, was never ratified by the United States Congress.

lead_paragraph: We could fit only three reader’s recipes into the pages of the Dining Section this week, but I needed to offer just one more here on Diner’s Journal because shortbread is, hands down, my favorite. Amy Casey, of Sparta, N.J., submitted an unusual recipe for one that calls for melted butter and a little bit of rice flour (which is now relatively easy to find since it’s a popular gluten-free flour). You can mix this recipe up in a bowl with a wooden spoon in about 3 minutes, and the rice flour gives the shortbread a sandy, singular texture that’s accentuated by the coating of granulated sugar on the top and bottom. Bonus, it keeps for weeks — but only if you hide it from me.

lead_paragraph: A Greek magistrate on Friday ordered that the oligarch Lavrentis Lavrentiadis, who was arrested Thursday on charges of embezzlement and fraud, be remanded to custody after visiting the 40-year-old businessman in an Athens hospital. Mr. Lavrentiadis, the former majority stakeholder in Proton Bank, which is alleged to have issued $900 million in bad loans to keep other businesses afloat, is the focus of an investigation that has highlighted concerns about deep-rooted corruption and crony capitalism in Greece. He was admitted to the hospital on Thursday night after citing health problems when the police visited his home in an affluent Athens suburb. Mr Lavrentiadis was expected to be transferred to the capital’s high-security Korydallos prison on Saturday after his request to be admitted to a psychiatric hospital was turned down and he spent Friday night in police custody.

abstract: Ambassador Eric Goosby, the Obama administration’s global AIDS czar, was named to lead a new Office of Global Health Diplomacy on Friday, the State Department said.
lead_paragraph: Ambassador Eric Goosby, the Obama administration’s global AIDS czar, was named to lead a new Office of Global Health Diplomacy on Friday, the State Department said. Dr. Goosby will continue to head Pepfar, the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, which pays for prevention and treatment. His new role was welcomed by some advocacy groups and U.N.AIDS, the United Nations agency. Chris Collins, policy chief for AmFAR, which promotes AIDS research, said high-level diplomacy was crucial to getting countries to spend more on their epidemics, and to asking them to stop ignoring politically unpopular victims like gay men, drug users and prostitutes. Also on Friday, Kathleen Sebelius, secretary of health and human services, created a post in her department, assistant secretary for global affairs, and appointed Dr. Nils Daulaire to it.

headline: Iran: Progress on Nuclear Talks
abstract: The leader of a United Nations nuclear inspection delegation reported progress on Friday in negotiations with Iran regarding its nuclear energy work and said another meeting was planned for Jan. 16.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a United Nations nuclear inspection delegation reported progress on Friday in negotiations with Iran regarding its nuclear energy work and said another meeting was planned for Jan. 16. But the leader, Herman Nackaerts, deputy director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said the Iranians still had not allowed the inspectors to visit Parchin, the military site where, inspectors suspect, nuclear weapons trigger testing work may have been conducted. Speaking to reporters upon his return in Vienna, home of the agency headquarters, Mr. Nackaerts described the negotiations held in Tehran on Thursday as “a good meeting” and expressed hope that the next round of talks would lead to a final agreement on an inspection plan, including a Parchin visit. Iran’s state-run media also reported progress had been achieved but made no mention of Parchin. Western diplomats who have long accused Iran of stalling tactics on the nuclear issue expressed skepticism. Some recalled that the nuclear agency’s director general, Yukiya Amano, had been optimistic about a breakthrough last May after talks, only to be disappointed later.

headline: Russia: Vodka Saves Animals’ Lives
abstract: A Russian circus trainer fed a cocktail of warm water and vodka to two elephants stranded in the blistering Siberian cold on Thursday and credited it with saving their lives.
lead_paragraph: A Russian circus trainer fed a cocktail of warm water and vodka to two elephants stranded in the blistering Siberian cold on Thursday and credited it with saving their lives. A trailer carrying the Indian elephants caught fire on a highway in the Novosibirsk region, sending emergency workers scrambling to get the animals out of the cold and into a nearby garage, state media reported. The animals’ trainer, Leonid Labo, diluted two cases of vodka and fed the mixture to the animals, he told Komsomolskaya Pravda, a popular tabloid. The animals suffered nothing more serious than frostbite to their ears, a veterinarian said. The director of the Novosibirsk regional zoo said if not for the vodka, the animals certainly would have died. “In cold temperatures we give vodka to the elephants and the monkeys even when they are inside,” said the director, Rostislav Shilo. “But only domestic vodka.”

headline: China Calls for ‘No Delay’ on Gun Controls in U.S.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Gun Control', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: China, which enforces a near-total ban on the private possession of firearms, has called for stricter gun controls in the United States. There were no fatalities in that attack, although some of the children reportedly had their ears and fingers cut off.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The state news agency in China, the official voice of the government, has called for the United States to quickly adopt stricter gun controls in the aftermath of the shooting rampage in Connecticut that left 28 people dead, including 20 schoolchildren.

headline: Buffeted by the Web, but Now Riding It
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Digital technology has overwhelmed many of those who sought to master it. Brian Lam was both a prince and casualty of it.
lead_paragraph: When the consumer Web exploded in the mid-1990s, part of the promise was that it would transform careers and the concept of work. Remember the signs on telephone poles and banners all over the Internet? “Work at home and turn your computer into a cash register! Ask me how.” The next generation of Americans would be able to work on their own terms.

headline: An Awkward, Articulate Pose by Way of Tel Aviv and Manhattan
abstract: “Devouring Devouring” is the choreographer Netta Yerushalmy’s bid to mix New York and Tel Aviv sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: In “Devouring Devouring,” an aptly named new work by the choreographer Netta Yerushalmy, the dancers practically ate the stage alive. At the start Joanna Kotze took firm steps along the perimeter of La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater, where the work was presented from Thursday through Sunday. While facing the back wall, she delivered a high kick and then, as if being sucked through a wind tunnel, ended up on the floor stretched on her side. Quickly she shot a leg up and remained still as a statue.

headline: ‘In the Crowds of New York, To Be Exclusive Is to Know that You Exist.’
abstract: “Despite widespread assumptions that the banks, the Jews or the Mafia run New York,” a marketing executive named James Lindheim wrote in 1975, “the true ruler of the city are its new social class: the hippoisie.”
lead_paragraph: One thing kept bugging me when I was reporting my article on Barneys: Sure, the store in the ’80s and ’90s was a paragon of cool, but so what? Lots of New York stores have been daring — for their fashion, design and windows. What made the difference at Barneys? An illuminating source was an essay by James B. Lindheim called “A New Class,” which ran in August 1975 in Harper’s. At the time, Lindheim was a vice president of the marketing and research firm Yankelovich, Skelly and White.

headline: One-Sided Defeat Leaves the Giants in a Three-Way Tie
abstract: The Falcons routed the Giants to further establish their dominance in the N.F.C. and virtually assure that the Giants will have to endure their same old story of a white-knuckle endgame.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — All week, Giants players said this year could be different. They had lived through the stress that came with spending the final month of last season with their tiptoes on the precipice and, after they walloped the New Orleans Saints a week ago, it seemed reasonable to think that this time, they really might make the finish a little less dramatic. Maybe, just maybe, they said, they could make it easier on their fans, their coaches and themselves.

headline: Aeolian Airs, 50 Years On
abstract: The Aeolian Chamber Players celebrated half a century of innovation with a concert at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: For any musical institution a 50th anniversary is cause for celebration. But there must be a special pride in the occasion if you happen to be a new-music group responsible for bringing into existence pieces that have attained lives of their own. So it was when the Aeolian Chamber Players, a mixed ensemble that made its New York debut at Town Hall in January 1962, celebrated a half-century with a concert in the Thalia at Symphony Space on Friday evening.

headline: You Are All Soft! Embrace Chaos!
abstract: “Antifragile,” Nassim Nicholas Taleb’s follow-up to his “Black Swan,” argues that top-down efforts to eliminate volatility in public and private lives end up making things more fragile, not less.
lead_paragraph: A reader could easily run out of adjectives to describe Nassim Nicholas Taleb’s new book “Antifragile: Things That Gain From Disorder.” The first ones that come to mind are: maddening, bold, repetitious, judgmental, intemperate, erudite, reductive, shrewd, self-indulgent, self-congratulatory, provocative, pompous, penetrating, perspicacious and pretentious.

headline: Stevie Wonder Songs, Refashioned and Repackaged
abstract: The jazz pianist Robert Glasper took on Stevie Wonder’s repertory in a program called “Songs in the Key of Life.”
lead_paragraph: Jazz musicians taking on Stevie Wonder’s repertory is an old story, but more recently it’s acquired a newer, more serious, and almost fashionable purpose. The pianist Robert Glasper was sure to get involved. His work, including this year’s album “Black Radio” (Blue Note), has shown how younger jazz musicians can merge naturally with hip-hop and soul without completely yielding to them.

abstract: Some media companies have adjusted their plans because of the school shootings in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Some media companies have adjusted their plans because of the school shootings in Connecticut. The Fox network and the Syfy cable channel both quietly changed episodes of series planned for the weekend. Syfy did not broadcast a scheduled episode Friday night of the show “Haven” because it contained scenes that involved violence in a school. Fox decided on Saturday that it would replace the planned episodes of two animated series, “Family Guy” and “American Dad,” that were to be broadcast Sunday night. The network made no official statement, but one executive confirmed that the decision was made because the content of the episodes could have been seen by some viewers as insensitive in light of these recent events. In both cases the networks scheduled repeats to fill those hours. Paramount Pictures has postponed the United States premiere of “Jack Reacher” in response to the shootings, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported. This action film, which stars Tom Cruise and contains a scene in which a sniper attack leaves several people dead, was originally set to be unveiled on Dec. 15 in Pittsburgh, where a large portion of the movie was filmed. The premiere was postponed “out of honor and respect for the families of the victims whose lives were senselessly taken,” according to a statement from the studio; the event has not been rescheduled. The film, featuring the Reacher character popularized in Lee Child’s series of novels, is still set for a nationwide release this Friday.

headline: For 200 Million Indians, a Life Steeped in Discrimination
abstract: Photographers explore lives of a Dalit community in Madhya Pradesh.
lead_paragraph: One in six Indians — approximately 200 million people in all — is born a Dalit. From the day a Dalit is born, life is predestined. Caste discrimination seeps through social symbols, practices and traditions, dooming Dalits to a lifetime of inequity and a position on the lowest rung of Indian society.

headline: A Photographic Vision in Lourdes
abstract: To secular sorts, the spectacle of pilgrims flocking to Lourdes in France can be puzzling. For Jeppe Boje Nielsen, photographing it was challenging — and humbling.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy enough to caricature the spectacle of the pilgrims who flock to Lourdes. On crutches, wheelchairs and gurneys, the broken in body — but not in spirit — pray and meditate in the very grotto where a 14-year-old Bernadette Soubirous said she saw the Virgin Mary in 1858.

The fair will continue until March 13. Angelica Mesiti, 36, who lives in Sydney, works with video and performance. Her video installation is about immigrant musicians.

headline: In the Middle: Why Elderly Couples Fight
abstract: Degenerative relationships are not uncommon among the elderly in even the happiest marriages. Both mental and physical changes feed the discord, marriage therapists and geriatricians say.
lead_paragraph: George and Gracie (let’s call them that because using their real names would make them even unhappier than they already appear to be) are in their 80s and have been married for more than 65 years. Until recently they seemed to ride the waves that are inevitable in any marriage that spans nearly seven decades; through good and bad, they were partners and best friends.

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful car bomb exploded near government offices in a town in the northwestern tribal belt on Monday, killing at least 17 people and wounding dozens, local officials said.

headline: Safety Agency Widens Inquiry on Ford Floor Mats

lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into whether 480,000 Ford, Lincoln and Mercury vehicles have floors designed so that floor mats – if not properly secured – are nudged forward to snag the gas pedal and possibly cause unintended acceleration.

headline: The Anxiety of the Long-Distance Meditator
abstract: On my 30-day retreat the goal was enlightenment. So why was I pacing, panicking and reviewing my microwave lunch options?
lead_paragraph: “You want to cultivate the crackling intensity of the ninja,” Daniel Ingram told me. Ingram made a living as an emergency doctor, but his real passion was teaching advanced meditation. It was day one of a 30-day solitary retreat, and this was my first meditation instruction. We were sitting in Ingram’s straw bale guesthouse, a squat round building next to the main house at the end of a long country road in rural Alabama. Behind the house a thick forest buzzed with insect life.

headline: Between the Dates in the History Books
abstract: A demonstration in Moscow on Saturday felt cold and scary and a little bit boring. Is that how we will remember this period between the beginning of the protest movement last year and Putin’s eventual fall?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — I was in my mid-20s the first time I reported from a war zone. Over the following decade, I would get almost used to — or, like many war correspondents, addicted to — the sudden sense of immersion, the immense vividness of sound, the slowing down of time and then the head-spinning intake of the air of peace on the way out. But that first time I was struck by the way people get used to living in war, sleeping through blasts, cooking on an open fire on the sidewalk and constantly bickering about things that don’t matter.

headline: Anything Goes in Bangalore’s ‘Wild West’ Real Estate Market

lead_paragraph: BANGALORE —On her annual summer visit to Bangalore this year, Vibha Pingle, founder of a nonprofit based in Cambridge, Mass., set out to help her aging parents sell their large suburban home and buy a centrally-located apartment. Ms. Pingle accomplished neither task, but she did get a crash course on the untamed ways of Bangalore’s real estate trade.

headline: Before Facebook Deal, Instagram’s Talks With Twitter
abstract: Instagram’s founders had talks with top Twitter executives as late as March, verbally agreeing to a price for the photo-sharing service, according to a New York Times report. | The American International Group is preparing to end its longtime association with the Asian insurer AIA Group. | Argentina is still fighting over defaulted bonds, but it’s at least getting a naval ship back. | Sidney Gilman, the Alzheimer’s researcher at the center of an insider trading case, lived a double life.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE FACEBOOK DEAL, INSTAGRAM’S TALKS WITH TWITTER  |  Facebook’s deal to buy Instagram for $1 billion stunned Wall Street and Silicon Valley when it was announced in April. But executives at Twitter had an additional reason to be surprised. Instagram’s founders “held several meetings as late as March with top Twitter executives,” The New York Times’s Nick Bilton reports. “The sides had verbally agreed weeks earlier on a price for Instagram of $525 million in cash and Twitter shares,” Mr. Bilton reports, citing people on both sides of the talks, who requested anonymity because the talks were private and because they were concerned about legal repercussions.

abstract: Brave thought: When all hope was lost for two educators in Newtown, Conn., they created hope for the rest of us and left it behind.

Like many of us, I found myself at holiday parties over the weekend, ambivalent and conflicted over conversation about this event, or about anything else.

headline: New Inquest to Be Held Into Death of Amy Winehouse
abstract: A coroner who recorded that the soul singer had died of accidental alcohol poisoning later resigned from her post amid questions about her qualifications.
lead_paragraph: More than a year since the death of Amy Winehouse, the sideshow surrounding her demise and the investigation into it has yet to subside. Officials in London said that a new inquest would be held into Ms. Winehouse’s death next month because the coroner who conducted the original examination lacked proper qualifications, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, the Grammy-winning soul singer who performed hit songs like “Rehab” and “Valerie,” was found dead in her apartment in the London borough of Camden on July 23, 2011.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Reporting From Newtown, and a Puppet Provocateur
abstract: The site of the senseless killing of schoolchildren is now a base of operations for TV news; in Puerto Rico, a free-speaking puppet with a TV show may have crossed a line; and an escapee from tech blogging returns on his own terms.
lead_paragraph: The senseless murders of 20 schoolchildren and six adults who cared for them at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., has shocked the nation, and the world, drawing round-the-clock news coverage to the town, Peter Applebome and Brian Stelter report. Nearly every newscast on CNN since Friday night has been broadcast from Newtown, for example, as has been true for nearly every network television morning and evening newscast. There has been tension, however, with some townsfolk lashing out at reporters, and others welcoming the chance to share their grief with the rest of the country. Big-name anchors can be spotted going door-to-door, seeking interviews. The anchors, Mr. Applebome and Mr. Stelter write, said they know when no means no.

headline: Dec. 17 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
abstract: Live coverage in the aftermath of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Two of the children killed in Friday’s shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., were buried Monday, as investigators continued to try to piece together the motive behind Adam Lanza’s rampage, which claimed the lives of 20 children and six adults at the school and Mr. Lanza’s mother before Mr. Lanza killed himself.

headline: Leading Off: After a Pause, Games Go On
abstract: Football is a world all too accustomed to wrestling the aftermath of violence recently. On Sunday, the sport gave way for a time when President Obama spoke at a vigil for 20 children murdered at a Connecticut elementary school.
lead_paragraph: Sports broadcasts get interrupted by real life all the time, setting off the kind of TV juggling that aims to skate through the uncomfortable moment before returning to the regularly scheduled distraction. But Sunday night brought something different altogether, and not just because the Patriots-49ers game was actually knocked off NBC for a presidential speech brought on by tragedy, nor because Patriots made the telling and painfully appropriate move of silencing their usual celebratory musket fire.

headline: ‘Amour’ on Top, Sort of
abstract: The chief film critics of The New York Times picked their Top 10 films of 2012 and “Amour” topped both lists. Then again, one was in alphabetical order.
lead_paragraph: Various critics groups on the East and West Coasts have shared their top film choices in the last month. There was the New York Film Critics Circle and the National Board of Review, both going with “Zero Dark Thirty,” while the Los Angeles Film Critics Association went with “Amour.” What say the New York Times chief film critics, who don’t vote in those polls?

headline: 25 Lessons About First Graders
abstract: In the aftermath of the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., the author, with help from a first-grade teacher, compiled a list of things he has learned about first graders.
lead_paragraph: Among the many horrors associated with the killing of 20 children at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., is that they were all first graders. On Sunday I spoke with Joanne Strongin, a longtime first-grade teacher at E.M. Baker Elementary School in Great Neck, N.Y. Together we put together a list of 25 things we have learned about first graders.

In the latest installment of his magisterial, multivolume biography, Mr. Caro uses his wondrous narrative gifts to tell the dramatic story of how Johnson was catapulted to the White House in the wake of the assassination of John F. Kennedy, and how he used his potent political skills to push his predecessor’s civil rights legislation through Congress and lay the groundwork for his own revolutionary war on poverty.

headline: Dwight Garner’s 10 Favorite Books of 2012
abstract: “Wild” by Cheryl Strayed, “Red Plenty” by Francis Spufford and more.
lead_paragraph: POEMS 1962-2012 by Louise Glück (Farrar, Straus & Giroux). An event. Ms. Glück’s collected poems have a great novel’s cohesiveness and raking moral intensity. This is a poet with a prosecutorial mind: in supple and exact language, she interrogates the world around us. She is fearsome. And fearless.

Both center on Ms. Mantel’s brilliant reimagining of Thomas Cromwell, a minor player in most tales of Henry VIII but the major schemer in this ingenious version. “Wolf Hall” was a superb but not essential prologue to the second book’s more fine-tuned war of nerves. Tightly focused on sparring between Cromwell and Anne Boleyn, it mixes 16th-century ambience with timeless bitchery.

headline: Feeling For | Heather Taylor Home’s Linens
abstract: Taylor, a multi-hyphenate known for hosting events in Los Angeles, has created a new collection of decorative linens inspired by memories of convivial, casually chic meals in Mexico and Greece.
lead_paragraph: “I like to try to create a sense of warmth in a world that can feel cold,” says the gallerist and budding lifestyle guru Heather Taylor. Taylor De Cordoba, the space she owns with her husband, Alex De Cordoba, in Los Angeles’s Culver City gallery district not only shows emerging artists in an atypically cozy environment, but also hosts food-and-flower-festooned events like trunk shows for fashion-designer friends and Eating Our Words, a series teaming literary readings with artisanal tastings. (The New Yorker writer Dana Goodyear recited poetry as guests sampled desserts by ChocoVivo; the “Wild” author Cheryl Strayed was paired with I Heart Pies and Carmela ice cream.) These multisensory goings-on — along with Taylor’s frequent dinner parties and crafting sessions with haute-bohemian pals like Kirsty Hume and Shiva Rose — are documented on Taylor’s popular blog, L.A. in Bloom. Taylor, also a skilled knitter and weaver, holds a special fondness for the tactile pleasures of tabletop textiles: “Even if I’m just throwing together a quick dinner for myself, I want it to look beautiful,” she says. “When I’m setting a table, I feel an endorphin rush of excitement.” Taylor intends to spread that feeling with Heather Taylor Home, her new collection of decorative linens inspired by memories of convivial, casually chic meals in Mexico and Greece. The festive cocktail and dinner napkins, place mats and table runners are made from unprocessed linen hand-embroidered in India with folkloric motifs for a look that’s at once rustic and refined. A last-minute holiday or hostess gift that will, no doubt, keep on giving.

After successfully seeking holistic treatment, she reassessed her life. “I came to the conclusion that all I wanted to do was spend time at the spa,” she says. “So I decided to open one.” Thanks to New York State law, which requires that at least one owner of a spa have a cosmetology license, Rubin enrolled in beauty school, which she attended with the same sort of dedication she had given to her Harvard M.B.A. “The teachers really liked me,” she says wryly. “I never missed a class and I was all about critical thinking and scientifically backed facts.”

headline: ‘A Christmas Story’ Climbs the Broadway Box Office Charts
abstract: The high gross for “Christmas Story” was partly the result of its producers adding a ninth performance last week; most other shows had only the usual eight.

Its $1,377,131 gross put “A Christmas Story” ahead of two shows that beat it the prior week — the Al Pacino-led “Glengarry Glen Ross” and the super-hero spectacle “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” The high gross for “Christmas Story” was partly the result of its producers adding a ninth performance last week; most other shows had only the usual eight.

At the end of the Pennsylvania Ballet production of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” the young hero and heroine leave the Kingdom of Sweets not in the flying sleigh seen in New York City Ballet’s staging of the same Balanchine classic, but in a flying sailboat, a tiny yacht just made for two, which lifts off into the air.

Mr. Pullman’s “Fairy Tales From the Brothers Grimm” transports us to the opposite pole of storytelling pleasure: the domain of the fixed, the communal and the familiar.

On the screen Barack Obama is speaking with a correspondent on “60 Minutes.” It’s Nov. 16, 2008. “I have said repeatedly,” Mr. Obama asserts, “that America doesn’t torture.” The three look at the screen without a word, and then Ms. Bigelow cuts to a close-up of one, Maya (Jessica Chastain). The analyst’s face is a blank. This is, Mr. Obama continues, part of “an effort to regain America’s moral stature in the world.”

headline: Fears That Lack of Money Will Weaken Malaria Battle
abstract: The world has made great progress against malaria, but the fight is stalling for lack of funds, the World Health Organization’s annual report on malaria concluded on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The world has made great progress against malaria in the last decade, but the fight is stalling for lack of funds, the World Health Organization’s annual report on malaria concluded on Monday. The amount spent on the disease by all countries rose to $1.8 billion last year, compared with $100 million in 2000, and, as a result, about one million children’s lives were probably spared over that time, the report said. But it would take $5 billion a year to get nets, insecticide spraying, diagnostic kits, effective drugs and hospital treatment to everyone needing them, and donor contributions, especially to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, have been nearly flat since 2010. Last year, the number of new nets purchased fell sharply, to 66 million from 145 million two years ago. Since nets wear out in three years and children are always being born, large numbers of infants and toddlers will soon be unprotected if more money does not come in, the report warned. The W.H.O. estimated that there were 219 million malaria cases in the world in 2010, with 660,00 deaths.

Mr. Peña Nieto proposed a six-point program, which involves alleviating addiction, establishing a new paramilitary police force with 10,000 recruits, folding the Federal Police into the Interior Department and reclaiming public spaces like parks. Mr. Peña Nieto did not say when the plan would go into effect. During a meeting of the National Security Council, Interior Secretary Miguel Ángel Osorio Chong criticized Mr. Calderón’s strategy, which focused on the arrest of drug cartel leaders and depended largely on heavily armed security forces. “Security resources more than doubled, but, unfortunately, crime has increased,” he said.

headline: Crowds Are Not People, My Friend
abstract: The serious flaws with our tendency to think of crowds as sentient beings rather than groups of individuals.
lead_paragraph: We have all been to a church or a concert without merging with the rest of the audience into some sort of hive mind. Likewise, we all know from experience that Internet message boards aren’t Borg-like mind-melding machines that multiply users’ brain power. So why, then, do we insist on treating crowds, real or virtual, like sentient beings? We’ve long believed that physical crowds are emotional, irrational and prone to violence. Over the last decade, we’ve come to think of virtual crowds as sources of wisdom that can’t be found in individuals. Both these ideas treat crowds as entities, rather than groups of people — an idea that has its origins in 19th-century sociology, which, according to scientists studying crowd behavior today, is deeply flawed.

lead_paragraph: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — In South Africa, a nation where the gap between the rich and poor yawns wider than just about anywhere in the world, Cyril Ramaphosa might seem an unlikely savior to a political party whose base is the poor. His fortune is estimated to top $500 million. He sits on the board of the mining company whose 34 workers were killed in a harsh police crackdown on an illegal strike protesting low pay and miserable living conditions.

headline: Feeling For | Sebastian Bergne’s Brussels Sprouts Wrap
abstract: The London designer finds a festive way to celebrate the once-lowly vegetable.
lead_paragraph: The once-lowly Brussels sprout has become the darling of many a restaurant side-dish menu, but who would have expected it to be the inspiration for wrapping paper? Just in time for the holidays, the London designer Sebastian Bergne offers us the very tasty Brussels Sprouts Wrap, his ode to a vegetable that he thinks many people in the U.K. still “love to hate.” Like many born-again Brussels sprout fans, Bergne understands that it’s all about the cooking, and has printed his favorite recipe — which includes bacon and chestnuts — on the paper itself.

headline: A Growing List of Gun Victims, and the Mayor’s Demand for a Plan

lead_paragraph: On the same day as the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., another madman attacked little children outside a primary school many thousands of miles away.

headline: Rape Suspects Captured in Record Time, Delhi Police Say

headline: No Monkey Business: Woman Behind Botched Fresco Restoration Sells Painting on eBay
abstract: An original oil painting by Celia Giménez, depicting only a rustic scene and no holy figures or primates, has been sold on eBay for about $1,400.
lead_paragraph: You may not appreciate the handiwork of Celia Giménez, the 80-year-old woman whose unauthorized restoration of a religious fresco turned the face of Jesus into something resembling, say, a monkey in a shearling coat. But like it or not, she is now a professional artist: The Associated Press reported that an original painting by Ms. Giménez, depicting only a rustic scene and no holy figures or primates, had been sold on eBay for about $1,400.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Nielsen Buys Arbitron, and Instagram’s New Ad-Friendly Rules
abstract: Known for its TV ratings, Nielsen buys a company known for its radio ratings; Richard Engel of NBC News is released after being held in Syria; independent bookstores report improved sales, despite the lack of a breakout hit; Instagram, now part of Facebook, issues new terms of service.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen Holdings announced Tuesday morning that it would be acquiring Arbitron, the radio ratings company, for $1.26 billion, Michael de la Merced reported. The acquisition price amounts to $48 a share in cash for each outstanding share of Arbitron, or a 26 percent premium to Arbitron’s closing price on Monday. The deal was described by Nielsen as part of its effort to track how people view and listen to media programs, which can be delivered in an increasing array of formats.

headline: The Deal Dilemma
abstract: Let me share my agonizing.
lead_paragraph: First things first: cutting Social Security benefits is a cruel, stupid policy — just not nearly as cruel and stupid as raising the Medicare eligibility age. But sometimes you have to accept bad things in pursuit of a larger goal: health reform should have included a public option — heck, it should have gone straight to single-payer — but a flawed route to universal coverage was better than none at all.

During the season, these fine managers must convincingly beg fans: please love our players, invest your emotions — and large chunks of your paychecks — in those wonderful humans wearing our uniform. Please forget that our franchise has not won a championship since, oh, we forget when. Please shell out large sums for tickets and jerseys and the privilege of being associated with us.

headline: Musical Moments, Part VI: ‘Clair de Lune’
abstract: A reader finds transcendence in Debussy’s popular piano piece “Clair de Lune.”
lead_paragraph: What constitutes a “moment” in music? Some readers cited fairly long passages, even whole movements of pieces, as favorite moments. But BAM (to use the name readers gave for their posts), from Farmington, Conn., pointed to a precise moment toward the end of Debussy’s popular piano piece “Clair de Lune” when a single note is introduced to a chord, resulting in a “subtle change of harmony,” like “the instant of recognizing first love on a moonlit night.” In this video I discuss that moment.

lead_paragraph: With few bankable stars in his new film, the director Ang Lee has been doing many of the press rounds himself for “Life of Pi,” traversing the globe to promote his 3-D story of a boy, a boat and a tiger. We caught up with Mr. Lee recently at the Apple store in SoHo, where he was due for a Q. & A. He had been traveling with the film since its premiere at the New York Film Festival in September, when he admitted to some fatigue. “I thought I was going to get sick,” he said, “but I didn’t have time.”

headline: Top 10 Movies for Grown-Ups, AARP Edition
abstract: For the generations that grew up watching movies in theaters instead of on their laptops, a list of 2012 releases that includes no vampires.
lead_paragraph: Call me a dinosaur, but I still watch movies in theaters. When I walk into the theater I feel like a kid — because even at the age of 60, I’m the youngest person there. Part of that is, younger people don’t have the emotional ties to movie theaters that my generation does. They’re at home watching on Netflix, or in the case of my kids, on their laptops. And part is selection — I have yet to see a movie with a vampire in a leading role.

lead_paragraph: Two prominent New York theaters, Manhattan Theater Club and Ars Nova, announced on Tuesday that they have chosen five playwrights as the first recipients of their new Writer’s Room commissions. The commissions are worth between $5,000 and $10,000 a piece and are geared to developing works for possible Off Broadway productions at the theaters. The inaugural commissions will go to Thomas Bradshaw (“Job”), Samuel D. Hunter (“The Whale”), and Sharyn Rothstein (“The Invested”); a fourth commission will be shared by Adam Bock (“A Small Fire”) and Justin Levine (“Bonfire Night”), who are developing a new musical.

Among the producers are Robert Watman, the chief executive of ’70s- and ’80s-themed nightclub chains Polly Esther’s and Culture Club, and Denise Fennell and Suzanna Melendez, two of the creators of “Birdy’s Bachelorette Party,” a pop-infused send-up in which real bachelorette parties blended with a fictional one. “Time Machine” will feature actors playing music idols like Madonna, Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and Britney Spears, with audience members encouraged to ask questions about their personal lives and become celebrity gossipmongers themselves. Ms. Melendez will direct the show.

But as performed with a gorgeous sorrowful twang by Marie-France Arcilla in “Working: A Musical,” at 59E59 Theaters, this evocative ballad belongs unequivocally to the woman standing before us, a mother of three who toils as an assembly-line steam-press operator in a luggage factory, reflecting on her “wasted” life.

lead_paragraph: Six months after the federal government added cancer to the list of sicknesses covered by the $4.3 billion World Trade Center fund, a New York City health department study has found no clear link between cancer and the dust, debris and fumes released by the burning wreckage of the twin towers.

lead_paragraph: Instagram, the popular photo-sharing service, was met with anger after changing its terms of service on Monday. The changes will let advertisers in Facebook’s ad network use data and information that users have shared on Instagram, and will also give Instagram and Facebook the right to use its users’ photographs and identity in advertisements. The changes are to go into effect Jan. 16.

abstract: The owners of the Indianapolis Colts and the Indiana Pacers pledge to donate $750,000 to the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Basketballs and bassoons, goalposts and Gustav Holst, brutal human collisions on grass and intertwining melodies on stage, twirling batons and time-beating batons – none of these things seem to go together. But they do for the sake of Indianapolis. The city’s orchestra said the owners of the local professional football and basketball teams had each promised to donate $750,000 to help the financially ailing orchestra survive.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The International Criminal Court in The Hague said Tuesday that it found testimony against a former rebel leader “too contradictory and too hazy” to convict him of a gruesome 2003 attack on a village in the Democratic Republic of Congo in which some 200 people were hacked to death and female survivors were raped and held in camps as sex slaves.

lead_paragraph: Seven weeks after Hurricane Sandy dumped an estimated 500 million gallons of water in Hoboken, crippling its transportation network and leaving tens of thousands of commuters casting about for alternative modes of travel, officials said Tuesday that PATH train service was at last set to resume.

Mr. Stettinius, who is also the president, helped to establish the company, which was created in 2008 through the merger of four former Colliers firms. The deal was a 47 percent increase in value from when the property at 72-76 Green Street, designed by Isaac F. Duckworth, last sold five years ago. It is also the latest in a torrent of building sales that have taken hold this year in SoHo.

headline: A Fond Last Look at  “Gossip Girl”
abstract: The CW series “Gossip Girl” said goodbye this week.
lead_paragraph: The CW series “Gossip Girl” was not great TV. Far from it. And as it said goodbye this week, this cult show deserved to be remembered not only for the previously unknown young actors it turned into stars, but for its knowing embrace of the fashion world over its six seasons. Where else but on “Gossip Girl” would designers like Suno, Zuhair Murad, and Rag & Bone be regularly name-checked, or teenage girls be found fretting over whether to wear Oscar de la Renta or Marchesa to a garden party? On Monday, the show’s last episode, in which “Gossip Girl” was revealed as Dan Humphrey (played by Penn Badgley), prompted its fans — and some of its stars — to take to Twitter, a few with theories about the significance of the finale’s date and many with their own alternate endings.

headline: The Will to Compromise
abstract: The surprising plausibility of a fiscal cliff deal.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I wrote a post expressing a certain pessimism about a major fiscal cliff deal, arguing that that because the baseline for negotiations includes a large tax increase no matter what, any deal beyond that all-but-guaranteed tax hike would give partisans on both sides a plausible reason to feel like losers: Republicans because the tax number required to make a deal would look so huge (upwards of $1 trillion and all that), and Democrats because any entitlement cuts at all would seem like a concession too far given the relative strength of their negotiating position.

Scans of Mummy Show Pharaoh’s Slit Throat

headline: The Unfolding Story of Maps: Dragon Warnings to Smartphone Screens
abstract: Simon Garfield’s new book, “On the Map,” delves into the history of cartography and some of its newer aspects.
lead_paragraph: Simon Garfield’s past work includes a whole book about the color mauve and last year’s delightful “Just My Type,” an ebullient survey of facts about fonts and typography. Now he turns his attention to a somewhat mustier subject: the history of cartography. He is most engaging on the most checkered parts of that history.

headline: The Gentleman Action-Hero From Hawaii
abstract: R.I.P. Senator Daniel Inouye, who blended the virtues of political courage, dedication and modesty.
lead_paragraph: It was odd but gratifying to see the way Senator Daniel Inouye, who died yesterday in Washington at age 88 after serving Hawaii in Congress for more than 50 years, was praised in multiple dimensions today.  The New York Times obituary stressed his “quiet,” “courtly,” “soft-spoken” nature, painting a portrait of a deferential man plucked from obscurity now and then for various important jobs (like the Watergate and Iran-Contra hearings). Awestruck bloggers and commenters at sites like Reddit, meanwhile, focused more on the senator as an action hero, someone out of a Quentin Tarantino movie.  Many of them had apparently just found out what Mr. Inouye did in World War II—an amazing story that was in all the obits and on his Medal of Honor citation, and is now in Badass Digest, under the headline “The Time Daniel Inouye Pried a Grenade From His Severed Arm.”

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreign Investments', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Vulture Funds']
