lead_paragraph: For years, the titans of finance have held out the promise that they could export their business model overseas and mint billions in the process. Yet, there are increasing signs that global deal-making was always a myth.

headline: U.N. Presents Grim Prognosis on the World Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Forecasts']
abstract: It could take until 2017 to recoup the jobs lost in the United States and Europe since the 2008-2009 global recession, according to a report released on Tuesday by the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: World economic growth has weakened substantially this year and faces the confluence of a triple threat — the so-called fiscal cliff in the United States, the European debt crisis and a sharp slowdown in China, the United Nations said in a report released on Tuesday. The worst case, the report said, could be a new global recession that mires many countries in a cycle of austerity and unemployment for years.

headline: Étude on Aging, Its Graces, Its Indignities
abstract: A masterpiece about life, death and everything in between, Michael Haneke’s “Amour” is about an elderly French couple — played by two titans of French cinema — in their final days.
lead_paragraph: A masterpiece about life, death and everything in between, Michael Haneke’s “Amour” takes a long, hard, tender look at an elderly French couple, Georges and Anne — played by two titans of French cinema, Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva — in their final days. Set in contemporary Paris, it begins with the couple’s front door being breached by a group of firemen. One moves through the rooms, delicately raising a hand to his nose before throwing open several large windows. He may be trying to erase the smell that probably brought the firemen there in the first place and which has transformed this light, graceful, enviable apartment into a crypt.

headline: Without Any Fanfare, Jennifer Egan Switches Publishers
abstract: In a move over the summer that was not publicly announced, the author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel “A Visit From the Goon Squad” joined Scribner, after publishing “Goon Squad” and one other novel with Alfred A. Knopf.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Jennifer Egan quietly switched publishers this summer, joining Scribner, a division of Simon & Schuster, from Alfred A. Knopf, a division of Random House.

headline: A Trio of Hot Chile Extracts
abstract: Henry Family Farm Chile Pepper Extracts, a David Rosengarten Selection, come in three varieties.
lead_paragraph: A stocking stuffer with a warning label? “Use one drop at a time” is what it says on the little bottles of fiery chile extracts made by the Henry Family Farm in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia. There are three varieties: yellow fatali African habañero delivers fruity notes with the heat; green Jamaican lime chile is tart; and the orange naga jolokia ghost chile of India is rich, and the hottest of the trio. They are easier to use in this liquid form (think cocktails) than as a ground spice.

headline: A Bakery Reaches to West Village
abstract: A bakery, Bien Cuit, introduced in Brooklyn a year and a half ago, now has a satellite store opening in the West Village in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Golper and Kate Wheatcroft, above, who opened their bakery, Bien Cuit, a year and a half ago in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, are already adding a Manhattan satellite. The new bakery in the West Village is more rustic than the original, and has space for cafe tables and chairs. Differences also emerge in the menu, for Mr. Golper, the baker, is featuring several items not sold in Brooklyn. A sleek bûche de Noël, lacquered in dark chocolate and buttoned up with tiny macarons, is filled with insanely rich chocolate mousse. Though scarcely eight inches long, it would satisfy six people. Potpies filled with artichokes, potatoes, olives and cheese, or, more typically, with chicken, sport flaky peek-a-boo lattice tops. The galette des rois, or kings’ cake for Epiphany, is classically done, with a lush almond filling. There are sandwiches on Bien Cuit breads and salads, too.

headline: Kenneth Chenault’s Crisis Years
abstract: The White House is said to be considering Mr. Chenault, the chief executive of American Express, for a post in President Obama’s cabinet. If an offer materializes, the actions of American Express during the 2008 financial crisis will no doubt be closely examined.
lead_paragraph: It is sure to come up: What did Kenneth I. Chenault do during the bailouts?

headline: Improvisation, With Prompting to Set the Mood
abstract: So Percussion, a Brooklyn ensemble, prepares its “Where (we) Live,” a work that includes mood cues from a prompter.
lead_paragraph: On a recent rainy afternoon, I was sitting at an old-fashioned desk in a bare concrete loft in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, listening intently to the members of So Percussion, joined by Grey McMurray on electric guitar, rehearse a composition called “Toothbrush.” The piece will form part of their show “Where (we) Live,” which opens on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater.

headline: At Grand Central, Produce by Eli Zabar
abstract: Eli Zabar takes over the produce stands at both ends of Grand Central Market with abundant displays.
lead_paragraph: The produce stands at both ends of the Grand Central Market are now in the hands of Eli Zabar, who has turned each one into a garden of delights. Lavish displays of vegetables, fruit and flowers practically overflow their open shelves. The produce is more abundant near the street entrance, while at the stand near the inner station door you’ll find olives, nuts and dried fruits; packaged precut vegetables to grab and go; and soups, juices, dips and dressings. The prices are lower than in all of his other stores, Mr. Zabar said. An example? Mangoes are $2.99 instead of $3.99 to $4.99, and peeled and sliced they are $6.99 a pound, compared with $8.99 uptown.

headline: A Do-Your-Own Quick Bite From Spain
abstract: San Sebastián Food in Spain has introduced a kit for preparing and serving pintxos or quick bites.
lead_paragraph: The pintxo, a quick bite (pronounced PEEN-cho), is the Basque country’s contribution to the tapas bar. Now San Sebastián Food, a company based in Spain that sells food products and arranges culinary tours of the Basque region, has introduced a kit for preparing and serving them. You get two slate serving boards, ceramic bowls and glasses; four ceramic spoons; and a bunch of wooden skewers, all designed for various tidbits like garlic shrimp, potato tortilla and anchovies skewered with olives and peppers. There is also a recipe booklet, an apron and a small skillet.

headline: After the Deluge, an Outpouring of Support From Afar

headline: China: A Rising Party Leader Is Elevated Yet Again
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A Communist Party star, Hu Chunhua, has been appointed party chief of Guangdong Province, which is central to China’s export economy.
lead_paragraph: A Communist Party star, Hu Chunhua, has been appointed party chief of Guangdong Province, which is central to China’s export economy and has been a laboratory for more open economic policies since 1979, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Tuesday. Mr. Hu, 49, was party chief of Inner Mongolia and was given one of 25 Politburo seats during the leadership transition in November. Party insiders had said Mr. Hu — a protégé of Hu Jintao, the former general secretary of the party, who is not related — would most likely be appointed to Guangdong to give him experience in a coastal economic powerhouse before he ascends further. He has a chance of being appointed to the Politburo’s elite Standing Committee in 2017. His closest rival, Sun Zhengcai, was posted in November to Chongqing, the booming southwest municipality once run by Bo Xilai, the disgraced party aristocrat.

headline: Congo: Two Rebel Leaders Hit With Financial Sanctions
abstract: The United States blacklisted two senior leaders of the M23 movement, a Congolese rebel military force, accusing them of recruiting child soldiers and obstructing peaceful resolutions of conflict.
lead_paragraph: The United States blacklisted two senior leaders of the M23 movement, a Congolese rebel military force, accusing them of recruiting child soldiers and obstructing peaceful resolution of the chronic conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Under sanctions imposed by the Treasury Department, any property held by the two, Col. Baudoin Ngaruye and Col. Innocent Kaina, that is within jurisdiction of the United States government is frozen, and no Americans can conduct transactions with them. The Treasury’s action reflects increased international pressure on the M23 group and its leadership, which has been implicated in widespread rights abuses by investigators at the United Nations. lead_paragraph: President Hugo Chávez has come down with a respiratory infection as he seeks to recover from a complicated procedure for cancer, a government official in Caracas said Tuesday. The official, Ernesto Villegas, the information minister, said doctors detected the infection on Monday and “proceeded immediately” to treat it. “It has been controlled,” he said. He added that Mr. Chávez was in stable condition. The president is in a hospital in Havana, where he had the operation last week. Kenyan security forces have blamed ethnic Somalis for a recent spate of fatal grenade attacks and attacks on churches. The attacks began after Kenya sent troops into Somalia last year in the most extensive military operation in Kenya’s history. Hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees live in Kenya, many of them concentrated in forlorn camps along the border, but thousands also live in the capital, Nairobi.

headline: Quentin’s World
abstract: From “Reservoir Dogs” to “Django Unchained,” the writer and director Quentin Tarantino has concocted a genre of his own.
lead_paragraph: THE road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom, Blake wrote, and for the last few decades no one in Hollywood has followed that road more assiduously than Quentin Tarantino. His movies are famous for their violence and bloodshed; their blaring soundtracks; their offbeat, Pinteresque dialogue; their startling performances from actors you had almost forgotten about; and their encyclopedic range of references to other movies, especially schlocky ones. He spent his formative years — the period when everyone else was in film school — working as a clerk in a video store, and it shows. His films are apt to allude to Godard in one frame and a movie like “Candy Stripe Nurses” or “Dead Women in Lingerie” in the next.

headline: Scientists See Big Impacts on U.S. Ecosystems from Global Warming
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: From fisheries to forests, American ecosystems are feeling the effect of human-driven climate change, with more to come.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis by dozens of scientists provides a useful update on measured and anticipated impacts of human-driven climate change on ecosystems from western forests to coastal waters. The report, “Impacts of Climate Change on Biodiversity, Ecosystems, and Ecosystem Services,” is one of a suite of studies feeding into what will be the third National Climate Assessment, an overarching analysis of impacts on everything from transportation systems to public health. (Periodic assessments were requested by Congress in 1990; the previous two are here.) The previous two reports were the subject of political and legal tussles.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Holiday Christmas Book?

lead_paragraph: Gretchen: Each year, my mother gives my daughters a Christmas picture book, so we have a large collection. A friend asked which book was my favorite, and I had a lot of trouble deciding.

headline: E-Commerce, With Bricks and Mortar, Too
abstract: As Bonobos and other online retail companies open bricks-and-mortar locations, they are turning retail maxims on their head.
lead_paragraph: After years of eschewing bricks-and-mortar locations as old-fashioned, suddenly e-commerce zealots are finding out something simple: customers really, really like to try on clothes.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood Meets Real Violence and Anger at Instagram
abstract: Penguin settles reluctantly with the Justice Department, and Time Inc. gets a new editor.
lead_paragraph: What was once unthinkable is now almost routine for studio and network executives as they prepare contingency plans for programming after tragedies like the massacre in Newtown, Conn., write Brooks Barnes and Bill Carter. At USA Network, executives used keywords to search for terms like “children” and “killing” to find and postpone sensitive episodes. The incident has also sparked a discussion about hypocrisy within the entertainment business, which is seen as largely liberal and supportive of gun control but makes its bread and butter on violent images.

lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted unanimously on Wednesday to raise the base fare on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.50, and to increase the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by $8, to $112.

headline: Dec. 19 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings']

lead_paragraph: Funerals and wakes were held on Wednesday for at least six victims of Friday’s school shooting in Newtown, Conn. Detectives continued to search for a possible motive. In Washington, President Obama  ordered  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to develop a multifaceted response. The president also said he would submit broad new gun control proposals to Congress no later than January.

headline: Musical Moments, Part VII: Brahms
abstract: The chief classical music critic for The Times analyzes a reader’s favorite moment in Brahms’s Intermezzo in E-flat.
lead_paragraph: Brahms prefaces his Intermezzo in E-flat (Op. 117, No. 1) with a quote from a short poem, a sad Scottish lullaby, sung by a mother who is comforting a weeping child. And this intermezzo begins like a gentle lullaby. But a reader from Beachwood, Calif., loves the moment in this piece, a short transitional phrase, when the music turns mysterious and troubling. I agree, and I discuss it in this video.

headline: 12-12-12 Producers Say Concert Brought In $50 Million
abstract: They say they expect more money to flow in over the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: The 12-12-12 benefit concert at Madison Square Garden last week has raised about $50 million for people affected by Hurricane Sandy, the producers announced on Tuesday night. They said that they expected more money to flow in over the coming weeks from the sales of albums, merchandise and more donations, and that the first $50 million in aid would be distributed immediately.

headline: From Selling T-Shirts to Collecting Awards
abstract: This time last year, Lucy Alibar, co-writer of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” was selling T-shirts at a downtown musical. Now she’s on the awards circuit.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Alibar, the co-writer of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” has explained how casting Quvenzhané Wallis, who was 6 at the time of filming even though the part of Hushpuppy initially called for an 11-year-old, changed the whole tenor of the script. As Ms. Alibar and her co-writer, the director Benh Zeitlin, discovered, it’s one thing to say, as Hushpuppy’s father does, “I’m worried about you because you’re so stupid,” to a preteen; quite another when she’s a tiny girl.

headline: Hundreds of Political Parties Are India’s Pressure Valve Against Unrest
abstract: The 2009 general elections were contested by 364 parties, many of them representing in very specific ways the concerns, biases and hopes of various communities.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It is hard to say something nice about any Indian political party, especially within 900 words, but in my latest “Letter From India” column I argue that an important factor in maintaining a largely peaceful India is that there are so many political parties. The 2009 general elections were contested by 364 parties, many of them representing in very specific ways the concerns, biases and hopes of various communities. As the power of older, larger parties erodes, the many smaller parties are gaining influence because the major parties need them in order to assemble a governing coalition.

headline: Ballet Opening Night at La Scala Is Canceled as Chorus Members Go on Strike
abstract: The strike forced the cancellation on Wednesday of opening night of Berlioz’s “Roméo et Juliette” with choreography by Sasha Waltz.
lead_paragraph: Chorus members at La Scala theater in Milan, protesting having to wear costumes and make gestures without extra pay during a dance performance, have gone on strike. The strike forced the cancellation on Wednesday of opening night of Berlioz’s “Roméo et Juliette,” with choreography by Sasha Waltz. The choristers said the extra duties violate their contract, but management argued they were no more than normally called for, according to Italian new reports. James Conlon, the American conductor and the music director of the Los Angeles Opera, was to have led the performance. Strikes or the threat of labor action at La Scala cause frequent disruptions, usually in opera productions.

headline: New Label Alert | Roomeur
abstract: Roomeur’s first collection for prefall imagines the feminist icon Frida Kahlo transplanted to modern-day Gotham.
lead_paragraph: Best friends since studying fashion design together in Israel, Hagit Kassif and Omer Pozner had always planned on starting a label together. Different paths brought them to New York — Diane von Furstenberg for Kassif, Elie Tahari for Pozner — then separated them again when Kassif headed to London to start a master’s degree at the Royal College of Art. But six months into her program, she called Pozner and told him it was time to stop dreaming and get to work. “I said, ‘Quit your job, this is it,'” she remembers. Reunited in New York and designing under the name Roomeur, the pair have just shown their first collection for prefall. Inspired by photographs of Frida Kahlo as well as by her artwork, it imagines the feminist icon transplanted to modern-day Gotham and in possession of, among other things, a brocade shorts suit and a draped black silk frock with a vibrant botanical print and a wrapped waist. “We were thinking of the two sides of Frida’s character,” Pozner says. “The hard and the soft.”

headline: Bork and Liberalism
abstract: Robert Bork’s defeat and the making of the post-Reagan Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: The death of Robert Bork at the age of 85 has naturally turned attention back to the famous hinge moment in his long career — the confirmation hearings that transformed him from “Robert Bork, illustrious conservative legal scholar” into “Robert Bork, icon of the culture wars,” and made his last name a synonym for the demagogic, by-any-means-necessary takedown of a judicial nominee. How much of a turning point the hearings really represented in our progress toward polarization can be debated, but they certainly changed the way law and politics intersect: Everything from the shape of confirmation hearings to the career choices of would-be jurists to the trajectory of the modern conservative legal movement has been stamped by Bork’s defeat at the hands of Ted Kennedy, Joe Biden, and a united front of liberal interest groups.

The couple spent six months renovating two commercial buildings on a corner lot they bought three years ago, across the street from their home. “We’d pull pieces out, and they’d be hot and dusty,” Ms. Holt-Garza said. “We decided we needed a nice clean space to show the furniture.” The 900-square-foot showroom is now filled with Mr. Garza’s saddle leather, wood and powder-coated steel furniture; Ms. Garza’s table linens and throw pillows; and works on paper by the local artists Leslie Wilkes and Meghan Gerety. headline: An Updated Chair for a Restored Masterwork
abstract: A wider, softer version of the Brno chair by Mies van der Rohe furnishes the renovated Villa Tugendhat.
lead_paragraph: Returning the Mies van der Rohe masterwork Villa Tugendhat, an outstanding example of early modernism, to its former glory was a huge undertaking. The house, built in 1930 in Brno, Czechoslovakia, with an innovative iron frame, had been neglected after the Tugendhat family fled the Nazis in 1938. Vladimir Ambroz, the head designer of A.M.O.S Design in what is now the Czech Republic, oversaw much of the recently completed two-year project, including the restoration of all the Mies-designed furniture. Mr. Ambroz thought that the original Brno chair, an endlessly copied classic, needed a companion piece that would be softer and more comfortable. This low lounge seat pays homage to the original — the tubular steel, for example, is the same — but the chair is wider and deeper for contemporary users. The chair, in Spinneybeck leather, is $1,365: 011-420-542-212-898 or amosdesign.cz.

She was sentenced to time served and returned by immigration authorities to Mexico on Tuesday. A law enforcement source said that officials were “pretty confident” that Mr. Guzmán is her father, but her lawyer said that played no role in her case.

In last month’s regional elections in Catalonia, separatist parties won 74 of the 135 seats in the Catalan Parliament. Yet the vote turned out to be a setback for Mr. Mas himself, because his party lost 12 seats.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Senators Criticize ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ and Filming Assange
abstract: The film’s depiction of torture is criticized by three senators; report finds BBC “completely incapable” of dealing with its sexual abuse crisis; and more.
lead_paragraph: Three prominent United States senators on Wednesday joined critics of the film “Zero Dark Thirty” over its depiction of C.I.A. interrogations in the ultimately successful hunt for Osama bin Laden, Scott Shane writes. In a letter to Michael Lynton, chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which is releasing the film, the senators called the film “grossly inaccurate and misleading in its suggestion that torture resulted in information that led to the location” of Bin Laden. The three — Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan; and John McCain, Republican of Arizona — called on Sony to “consider correcting the impression that the C.I.A.’s use of coercive interrogation techniques led to the operation” against Bin Laden, but they do not explain exactly how that could be done.

headline: On Not Seeing the Forest for the Equations
abstract: No, macro isn’t converging.
lead_paragraph: So, Noah Smith weighs in on the state of macro and argues that there really isn’t that much disagreement in the field, because both saltwater and freshwater macro use the same set of techniques. (For newbies: saltwater is the kind of macro practiced at MIT, some of Harvard, Princeton, etc., macro that still finds Keynesian ideas useful and argues that monetary and fiscal policy can be effective; freshwater is Chicago, Minnesota, etc. insisting that business cycles are optimal responses to real shocks).

Oh, they’ll take the day off and drink organic wine, but they won’t be buying presents, putting up a tree, baking cookies, lighting candles or decking any halls. There will be no taking of a family picture for their card and no sending of that card or any other.

headline: 36 Hours in Queens, N.Y.
abstract: If you want an alternative New York experience, something with grit and spice, consider Queens, where a splintered world collides in a jumble of diversity.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER old New York, where immigrants strived, cultures collided, grit outshined glamour and ethnic restaurants were filled with ethnic crowds, not Instagramming foodies? Before Manhattan commerce was diluted with H&M and Starbucks, and Brooklyn became half hipster playground, half suburb substitute? That city lives on in Queens, where the forces of gentrification have barely nipped at the edges of the city’s most expansive borough, home to 2.2 million people, from (it seems) 2.2 million backgrounds. Though its coastal areas have only just begun to recover from the destruction of Hurricane Sandy, most of the borough’s vast territory was untouched by the storm, and is full of sights and sounds unlike anything you’ll find a short subway ride away in “The City.”

headline: E-Reader Market Shrinks Faster Than Many Predicted
abstract: Nearly three years after the first iPad, the tablet has come a long way. Now there are plenty of smaller, cheaper tablets that are pretty powerful. So why buy an e-book reader? That appears to be what a lot of people are thinking this year.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after the first iPad was introduced, the tablet has come a long way. Now there are plenty of smaller, cheaper tablets that are pretty powerful. So why buy a more primitive e-book reader?

headline: Obama, Fan of ‘Lincoln’ (and ‘Beasts,’ Too)
abstract: President Obama tells Time magazine what he learned from “Lincoln,” one of a few films this season that get his thumbs-up.
lead_paragraph: When Time magazine announced Barack Obama as its person of the year, bet you didn’t think it would include a dive into his movie tastes. But granted an audience with the president, the magazine’s managing editor, Richard Stengel, asked him about watching “Lincoln.”

headline: ‘Newsies’ Recoups Initial Investment
abstract: The Broadway musical “Newsies” has recouped its $5 million capitalization, becoming the fastest of any Disney musical on Broadway to turn a profit, the show’s producers said.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “Newsies,” a David-vs.-Goliath story about the 1899 strike of New York City newsboys, has recouped its $5 million capitalization, becoming the fastest of any Disney musical on Broadway to turn a profit, the show’s producers said on Thursday.

headline: UBS Settlement Minimizes Impact of Guilty Plea
abstract: To settle a rate-rigging case, the Japanese securities subsidiary of UBS pleaded guilty to a charge of felony wire fraud as part of a settlement that was structured to keep the potential fallout from the plea to a minimum.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss banking giant UBS paid a fairly stiff price to settle the rate-rigging case. In addition to approximately $1.5 billion in penalties and disgorgement, the bank’s Japanese securities subsidiary pleaded guilty to a charge of felony wire fraud.

headline: Questions Remain About New Plan on ‘Too Big to Fail’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Bank of England recently put out a new paper on how they might work together to aid a major financial institution who gets into trouble.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Bank of England recently put out a new paper on how they might work together to aid a major financial institution that gets into trouble.

headline: Insurance Institute Announces Its New Top Safety Pick+ Award
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A Top Safety Pick+ must get either an Acceptable or Good rating in the new small overlap frontal crash test. And it must earn a Good rating in at least four of the five evaluations that the insurance institute conducts.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has added a new frontal crash test to its portfolio, it announced on Thursday that it will add a new safety award to recognize vehicles that do even better than those that receive its Top Safety Pick award.

headline: Asked & Answered | Pascal Barbot
abstract: T talks to the chef and writer of new tome based on his 12-year-old, 25-seat Michelin-starred Parisian restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of a new cookbook dedicated to a hotshot chef and his destination restaurant is usually met with the realization that the volume is more advanced than our brains can fathom, although it will look lovely on a coffee table or impressive on a shelf. You might expect more of the same from “Astrance: A Cook’s Book” (Éditions du Chêne, $95), the new tome from the 12-year-old, 25-seat Michelin-starred Parisian restaurant that was recently ranked 18th in the world. Astrance’s chef Pascal Barbot is a master, after all. But Astrance, which was written by Chihiro Masui and Barbot’s business partner Christophe Rohat, who is responsible for everything that goes on in the front of house, is an entirely unorthodox, or as Masui might say, “unnatural,” cookbook. In it, what Barbot calls “spoken recipes” reveal more about the chef’s process and approach than the traditional combination of head notes and directions do.

headline: Media Baubles: A Just-in-the-Click-of-Time Gift Guide
abstract: Miss the shipping deadline on Christmas? Media Decoder has a list of push-button gifts. And is seeking more.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, someone here, we won’t say who, came up with the bright idea of doing a media-centric gift guide. There was a fair amount of skepticism, but when the list was produced, it settled everything. Some of the best editorial minds in the hemisphere — well, actually, the dark overlords of the media kingdom at The New York Times — judged it to be ill-considered, dumb, awkwardly executed and full of log-rolling.

headline: Ackman Outlines Bet Against Herbalife
abstract: At an event held by the Sohn Conference Foundation in Manhattan, William Ackman of Pershing Square kicked off a three-hour presentation arguing that Herbalife’s retail sales were far less than it claimed.
lead_paragraph: From the perspective of Herbalife‘s executives, the company is built on a sound model that benefits its participants.

headline: Recommended Reading: Journo-Code Commit Messages
abstract: Recommended reading: New York Times interactive news developer Tyson Evans’s NiemanLab article on commit messages.
lead_paragraph: New York Times interactive news developer Tyson Evans wrote this fantastic article that’s sure to fill you with holiday cheer: “Updated horse parser”: The year in journo-code commit messages at NiemanLab.org.

headline: Boehner Cancels Tax Vote in Face of G.O.P. Revolt
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner abruptly halted efforts to pass fallback legislation to prevent a fiscal crisis after conservative Republicans refused to allow taxes to rise even on the most affluent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s effort to pass fallback legislation to avert a fiscal crisis in less than two weeks collapsed Thursday night in an embarrassing defeat after conservative Republicans refused to support legislation that would allow taxes to rise on the most affluent households in the country.

headline: Shorter Stairway to Heaven: Rock Stars Die Younger, Study Finds
abstract: Rock and pop musicians die prematurely more often than the general population, a British study found.
lead_paragraph: A new study confirms what music fans have long suspected: rock and pop musicians die prematurely more often than the general population.

headline: A Brief History of the New York Stock Exchange
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange, with its opening bell and floor traders, has been the public image of a stock market for two centuries
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange, with its opening bell and floor traders, has been the public image of a stock market for two centuries

headline: Why Renters Use More Electricity
abstract: Data indicate that a landlord is less likely to invest in Energy Star appliances than a homeowner is, because usually the landlord is not paying the electric bill.
lead_paragraph: Why do people buy inefficient refrigerators and clothes washers when spending a little more for an efficient one would save them money over time through lower electricity or water bills? There are a variety of reasons, but one that is persistently cited is that people are not necessarily buying these appliances for themselves. Often the buyer is a landlord, and the user is a tenant who does not make the choice but faces the consequences because he receives the energy bill.

headline: She’ll Be Thankful for the Memory
abstract: In a growing mainstream retail market, an erotic toy with built-in flash memory is the latest addition.
lead_paragraph: FLASH memory drives come in many odd forms — disguised as plastic sushi pieces, Swiss Army knives and Hello Kitty figures. Now, a contender for the oddest: a vibrator.

headline: Russian Ban on U.S. Adoptions Moves Forward
abstract: Russia’s proposed ban jeopardizes adoptive families that have already begun to form.
lead_paragraph: A law that would prohibit adoptions of Russian children by United States citizens passed Russia’s lower house of Parliament on Wednesday. The bill (in retaliation for a new United States law that seeks to punish Russian citizens who are accused of violating human rights) still faces two more legislative votes, and President Vladimir V. Putin has evaded the question of whether or not he would sign it.

headline: The View from Notre Dame: Russell’s Twist of Fate
abstract: KeiVarae Russell traded in his dream of playing for Southern Cal for one that has him playing for a national title in a new position at Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: In December 2011, KeiVarae Russell traded in his childhood dream of suiting up for Southern California for a new one of playing for Notre Dame. One year later,  Russell, a  freshman cornerback, can realize the biggest dream of all: a national championship.

headline: Bistro SK in City Island
abstract: At night, City Island is left to its residents, who have welcomed Bistro SK as if positively starved for coq au vin and bavette, hanger steak with red wine-shallot sauce.
lead_paragraph: At night, City Island is left to its residents, who have welcomed Bistro SK as if positively starved for coq au vin and bavette, hanger steak with red wine-shallot sauce.

abstract: A government watchdog’s report estimating Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac’s Libor losses lays out an easy-to-follow road map for others.
lead_paragraph: The potential victims of the Libor scandal are starting to estimate the costs to their bottom lines.

headline: A Bistro in the Bronx With a Warm Welcome
abstract: In a borough where day-trippers usually come for fried clams and garlic bread, Bistro SK offers a repository of authentic French cuisine.
lead_paragraph: FOR all the restaurants in New York City claiming the name “bistro,” it is rare to find one with the most crucial ingredient. It’s not duck confit; it’s a dining room where everyone is welcomed and waited on by the owner, who may also be (or be married to) the chef.

headline: Q&A: Easing the Pain of Computing
abstract: If too much time at the computer is making your body hurt, see a doctor and then explore other ways to work more comfortably.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Forget the East-West Divide; It’s Berlin vs. Munich
abstract: The filmmaker Christian Petzold talks about his upbringing in West Germany, summers in East Germany and what filmmakers in Berlin think of their counterparts in Munich.
lead_paragraph: For the German director Christian Petzold, the subject of his latest film, “Barbara” — a character study of an East German doctor torn between her sense of professional responsibility and a desire to escape to the West with her lover — is one that hits close to home. He was born in West Germany to parents who had fled together from East Germany, but as a child and adolescent, he would return with them to East Germany each summer, to enjoy the warmth and affection of the many relatives who had remained behind while also experiencing what he now describes as an “atmosphere that was very, very mistrustful” in the larger society.

headline: Nearly 30,000 Jobs Lost Because of Hurricane Sandy
abstract: The impact of the storm on small businesses and larger companies whose offices could not reopen for weeks afterward left New York City and the state with fewer jobs in November than in October.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy wiped out nearly 30,000 jobs in and around New York City last month, the New York State Labor Department said on Thursday.

headline: Hoping for a Silent Night
keywords: ['Gifts', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Friendship', 'Christmas']
abstract: Holiday questions about blowing Santa’s cover; meeting the parents; reaching out to a former friend, and other holiday-related issues.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I raised our boys (twins, 6, and their brother, 1) to believe in Santa. My sister decided against it with her little ones (6, 4, 2 and 1). We will be together for a day around Christmas, and she wrote that if Santa comes up, her oldest will spill the beans, causing confusion and possibly heartbreak. She suggested we tell our children not to mention Santa, and asked what I thought. What do you think?

headline: $1,200 a Pound, Truffles Suffer in the Heat
abstract: Black Périgords are becoming scarcer and more expensive, and some scientists say it is because of the effects of global warming on the fungus’s Mediterranean habitat.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just about everything in Eduardo Manzanares’s shop, Truffes Folies, is made with truffles. Sausage, cheese, spaghetti — even popcorn.

headline: NYSE Euronext’s Decent Deal for Its Suffering Shareholders
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: NYSE Euronext shareholders may wish they could still collect the extra $3 billion that rival suitors were offering last year. But the firm’s chief knew it was time to take ICE’s offer, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: At least Duncan Niederauer, the NYSE Euronext chief executive, isn’t blind to the inevitable. He has agreed to sell the Big Board to IntercontinentalExchange for $8.2 billion.

headline: Cash and Debit Prevail This Holiday Season
abstract: Consumers may be trying to avoid credit card debt.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is one time when my credit card gets a heavy workout, and this year is no different. But I’m apparently an outlier, according to a survey of holiday consumer spending.

headline: Cardinal Finds a Biblical Parallel in a School Aide’s Selfless Life and Death
abstract: Anne Marie Murphy, 52, a victim in the Newtown, Conn., school rampage, “laid down her life for her friends,” Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said at her funeral.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — To those who know what aides do for the disabled children in their care, it was no surprise that after a gunman invaded the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., the body of Anne Marie Murphy was found slumped protectively over at least one of her charges, a 6-year-old boy named Dylan Hockley.

headline: Who’s to Blame for the Fiscal Cliff Impasse?
abstract: Boehner and McConnell claim the Democrats have done nothing.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are trying to blame the apparent impasse in fiscal cliff negotiations on President Obama and the Democrats.

abstract: A house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in Phoenix was sold on Thursday, after it had been threatened for months with demolition.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright here for his son was sold on Thursday, guaranteeing its preservation after it had been threatened for months with demolition by its owners, who had planned to replace it with new homes.

lead_paragraph: In a telephone interview shown on Thursday by the Saudi news channel Al Arabiya, a man who identified himself as Ahmad Fakhouri, a prominent Syrian state television anchor, announced his defection.

headline: Should Felton Be Shooting So Much?
abstract: Knicks point guard Raymond Felton is converting fewer than 40 percent of his field goal attempts on a team that collectively shoots 45 percent from the field.
lead_paragraph: Because the Knicks’ offense has been so strong under the direction of Raymond Felton, there is a sense that his passing has led to the eye-popping production. After all, part of the thinking behind letting Jeremy Lin leave was that the Knicks, with Carmelo Anthony as the team’s centerpiece, needed a more traditional point guard at the controls.

headline: Snow Fall: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek
abstract: A group of world-class skiers and snowboarders set out to ski Tunnel Creek. Then the mountain moved.
lead_paragraph: The snow burst through the trees with no warning but a last-second whoosh of sound, a two-story wall of white and Chris Rudolph’s piercing cry: “Avalanche! Elyse!”

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Renzo Rosso, the Italian executive who has turned cool style into big bucks, is expanding his empire.

lead_paragraph: Fresh powder beckoned 16 expert skiers and snowboarders into the backcountry. Then a slab of snow cracked and swept violently down the mountain. No one knew how many were caught.

lead_paragraph: MADRID — Rodrigo Rato, a former top banking official in Spain and a former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, on Thursday became the most prominent banker to appear in a Spanish court since the start of the country’s financial crisis.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: The Touchfire iPad Keyboard
abstract: The Touchfire iPad keyboard is a transparent, flexible, squishable, silicone membrane, weighing less than an ounce. The Touchfire’s surface is molded into the shape of keys so you can type on the tablet screen with ease.
lead_paragraph: Thumpity thump-thump — that’s the sound your fingers make on an iPad screen when they try to type. It’s not an efficient process. You sort of have to keep looking down at the glass to see where your fingers are. In short, typing is not, ahem, the iPad’s shining moment.

headline: Brian McGrory Rises From Boston Globe Paperboy to Become the Paper’s Next Editor
abstract: In his 23 years working in the newspaper’s newsroom — as opposed to delivering its copies — Mr. McGrory has been a reporter, columnist and metro editor. He succeeds Martin Baron.
lead_paragraph: 8:44 p.m. | Updated The Boston Globe announced on Thursday that Brian McGrory, a columnist and former metro editor at the newspaper and a Boston native with deep roots in the area, would be its next editor. The appointment is effective immediately.

headline: Web Service Raises $7 Million to Automate Your Life
abstract: IFTTT, a Web service that lets people create automated tasks like preprogrammed wake-up calls and saving Facebook photos to Dropbox, has raised money from a roster of Silicon Valley investors. Linden Tibbets, chief executive, said his first order of business would be to hire more people.
lead_paragraph: IFTTT, the nifty Web service that offers a way to automate tasks online, just got a nice holiday present: a significant chunk of change from the venture capital firms Andreessen Horowitz, NEA and Lerer Ventures.

headline: ‘Inventing Abstraction’
abstract: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: For All His Flaws, an Influential Ceramist
abstract: Michael Cardew, the complex and charismatic British ceramist, is the subject of a new biography.
lead_paragraph: The British ceramist Michael Cardew carefully recorded his anxieties and failures. From his 1920s apprenticeships until his death in 1983, he traveled worldwide, proselytizing for traditional, handmade ceramics and writing confessional diary entries and letters to his family. He detailed his nightmares about misfortunes befalling his wife and three sons during his long absences, and his frustrating efforts to set up self-sufficient potteries in Ghana and Nigeria.

headline: When the Future Became Now
abstract: “Inventing Abstraction: 1910-1925,” a dizzying, magisterial cornucopia at the Museum of Modern Art, captures some of the original thrill and terror of the creation of abstract art.
lead_paragraph: In the second decade of the 20th century, abstraction became the holy grail of modern art. It was pursued with feverish intent by all kinds of creative types in Europe, Russia and elsewhere, responding to assorted spurs: Cubism and other deviations from old-fashioned realism, the beautiful whiteness of the blank page, communion with nature, spiritual aspirations, modern machines and everyday noise.

headline: Two Inaugural Balls to Honor Obama Guests and Military Families
abstract: By holding only two official inaugural balls this year, compared with 10 in 2009, President Obama has demonstrated that he prefers a scaled-down celebration.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will hold just two official inaugural balls – one for guests of his choosing, with some limited tickets for the public, and the other to honor military families – after he takes the oath of office to begin his second term, inaugural planners said Thursday.

headline: Egypt’s Chief Prosecutor Retracts His Resignation
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The move was the latest bizarre turn in a complicated three-way struggle among the new Islamist president, the institutions of the old government and the president’s opposition in the streets.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s chief prosecutor withdrew his resignation on Thursday, just days after submitting it. The move was the latest bizarre turn in a complicated three-way struggle among the new Islamist president, the institutions of the old government and the president’s opposition in the streets.

headline: Hollande Uses Softer Tone on Delicate Visit to Algeria
abstract: President François Hollande of France sought to strike a more nuanced and conciliatory tone with the former French colony but stopped short of issuing the apology Algiers has long called for.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a delicate and closely watched visit to Algeria, President François Hollande of France on Thursday acknowledged the “profoundly unjust and brutal” nature of France’s colonial rule, a statement seen in both countries as heralding a change of tone. But Mr. Hollande did not make an apology for France’s conduct, although Algeria has long pressed for one.

headline: The Giving Spree | Tiina Laakkonen

lead_paragraph: Who: The fashion stylist and new store owner Tiina Laakkonen, whose Amagansett home was featured in T’s Design and Living issue.

headline: Boomers and Millennials Feel a Need to Care for One Another
abstract: A new study by the Pew Research Center suggests that not only is there no Boomer-Millennial war, but rather the two generations feel a duty to care for one another.
lead_paragraph: Last summer there was a media frenzy about a supposed war between greedy baby boomers who are sucking up the nation’s resources, and young adults, the millennials, doomed to a bleak financial future. “Are Millennials the Screwed Generation?” asked the Daily Beast, which never lets itself get bogged down by nuances.

lead_paragraph: The Oscar winner Cuba Gooding Jr., and the Tony nominees Vanessa Williams and Condola Rashad will join Cicely Tyson in “The Trip To Bountiful” on Broadway, the producers said on Thursday.

headline: A Tokyo Ramen Innovator Eyes the Lower East Side
abstract: Ivan Orkin, the creator of rule-breaking restaurants in Japan, hopes to open his first New York branch.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of buzz about Ivan Orkin, the American chef who took the Frank Sinatra route — “his way” — with ramen in Tokyo. He is now in New York and plans to open a version of his popular ramen restaurants on the Lower East Side.

headline: ‘Iron Curtain’ Exhibition at Hebrew Home
abstract: Hebrew Home, a retirement community in Riverdale, the Bronx, has an impressive art collection that is on view to the public.
lead_paragraph: A perk of living in a city brimming with artists and art lovers is that there tends be a lot of stuff around. Having a surplus means that terrific work can end up in unexpected places. Many of those places are fun to seek out.

headline: Pushed and Pulled, a Doctor Wants a Way Out
abstract: The lead character in “Barbara,” a doctor in 1980s East Germany, tries to adjust after being transferred from Berlin to a more remote location as a punishment.
lead_paragraph: “Barbara” is a film about the old Germany from one of the best directors working in the new: Christian Petzold. For more than a decade Mr. Petzold has been making his mark on the international cinema scene with smart, tense films that resemble psychological thrillers, but are distinguished by their strange story turns, moral thorns, visual beauty and filmmaking intelligence. His latest to open in the United States, “Barbara,” begins in 1980 with an East German doctor from Berlin (Nina Hoss) who, after an unspecified offense, has been recently banished to the boonies. There, in between hospital rounds and harassment from the secret police, she waits and she burns.

headline: Applicants Continue to Flock to Early Admission Programs
abstract: One theme that emerges is that many binding early decision and nonbinding early action programs continue to record double-digit increases in applicants when compared with the previous year.

headline: The Caucus: Paying Final Respects
abstract: Sen. Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, who died Monday at 88, laid in state in the Capitol rotunda on Thursday.

headline: A Bronzino Portrait Heads to Auction
abstract: “Portrait of a Young Man With a Book,” by the 16th-century artist Agnolo Bronzino, is expected to bring $12 million to $18 million at auction next month.
lead_paragraph: Agnolo Bronzino was the go-to guy for power portraits in 16th-century Florence. “They were generally commissioned by wealthy people to convey a certain swagger and confidence,” said Nicholas Hall, head of Christie’s international department of old master paintings.

headline: In Japan, a Test of Inflation Targets
abstract: For two decades, Japan has provided stark evidence that chronic deflation is possible in a modern economy. Now, its central bank appears ready to do whatever it takes to get inflation.
lead_paragraph: “Under a paper-money system, a determined government can always generate higher spending and, hence, positive inflation.”

abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York said he would draw on his resources to push for change.
lead_paragraph: It is a moment when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s heart races and his breath gets caught in his throat: the ringing of a bedside telephone in the middle of the night.

headline: Fewer First-Time Buyers
abstract: At least two national surveys suggest a decline because of tight credit and cash-rich investors.
lead_paragraph: TWO recent national surveys of real estate agents suggest that first-time buyers are on the decline, their access to the housing market blocked by tight credit and eager investors.

headline: Memorials, Along With Some Mischief
abstract: The Berlin-based artist Hito Steyerl makes her New York solo debut at e-flux with three videos.
lead_paragraph: The New York solo debut of the Berlin-based artist and writer Hito Steyerl at e-flux is one of the best gallery shows of the season. Ms. Steyerl works primarily in video, but defines the medium broadly to include documentary, staged history, what look like found film images and the near-equivalent of home movies.

headline: The Nervous Leading the Blind to the End

lead_paragraph: Praising the virtues of the radio dramas from his childhood, Stephen King once noted that the perfect monster is the one you make in your mind.

headline: White House Asks Police for Help in Shaping Gun Control Policy
abstract: The administration hopes to defuse criticism from conservatives by enlisting law enforcement officials to help shape its response to the Connecticut shootings.
lead_paragraph: The White House recruited national law enforcement leaders on Thursday to help shape a response to last week’s school shootings in Connecticut, hoping to use the credibility of America’s police officers to build support for measures curbing the spread of assault weapons.

headline: Awaiting the End in a Small Turkish Town
abstract: A small Turkish town in the Aegean region is braced for thousands of visitors who hope to be among the few to survive the Dec. 21, 2012, doomsday supposedly predicted by the Mayan calendar.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Despite assurances from leading Islamic and Christian clerics and the global skepticism based on scientific facts, as many as 10,000 people are expected to descend on a small Turkish town in the Aegean region in hopes of being among the few to survive the Dec. 21, 2012, doomsday supposedly predicted by the Mayan calendar.

headline: ‘Why Does Everyone Have a Grandma and Grandpa Except Me?’
abstract: There is no road map for comforting a child who is grieving someone she has never met.
lead_paragraph: “Why does everyone have a grandma and grandpa except me?” my 4-year-old daughter asked me a couple of weeks ago as we snuggled on the couch. I answered her the way I have answered my 8-year-old son over the past five years: “Grandma and Grandpa are in heaven, so even though you can’t see them, they are watching you all the time.”

headline: Vain Glorious | Dr. Philippe Allouche on the Bio-Lift Facial
abstract: All things facials, from Dr. Philippe Allouche of the French skin care line Biologique Recherche.
lead_paragraph: A facial massage that feels more like an annual checkup — assessing hydration, elasticity and epidermal water loss — is an intriguing way to start a spa treatment. Dr. Philippe Allouche of the French skin care line Biologique Recherche has been practicing medical beauty since the early 1990s. His clinical, holistic “Bio-Lift” facial at the Peninsula Spa in New York professes to reshape the face. T spoke to Dr. Allouche about the virtues of electrical currents, the healing power of the hand and his golden rule: never, ever do steam extractions.

headline: Venison and Zinfandel Wines
abstract: The weather and the wine demanded a plate of robust food.
lead_paragraph: The weather and the wine demanded a plate of robust food. Our zinfandels had class, so I chose venison, sophisticated and festive. And when I discovered that D’Artagnan, the meat and luxury food purveyor, offered venison osso buco, I decided that was the ticket. Venison is leaner than veal, but braising made it rich and tender. (Boneless venison stew meat could be used instead.) Cranberries, red wine, sweet parsnips and a heady whiff of allspice rounded out the dish. Broad noodles or grits alongside would welcome a pool of the abundant sauce. And remember to provide small forks for the lagniappe, the bone marrow. FLORENCE FABRICANT

Among the most unusual lures are the super-handy parking spaces in the 19-story Sky Garage at 11th Avenue and 24th Street, where sales began in 2007 and ended this year. The architect Annabelle Selldorf gave 14 apartments there separate elevators so that residents could park their cars within 10 feet of their living rooms. This amenity is not without a precedent: the town-house garage of the early 1900s.

headline: Once Banished, Never Silenced
abstract: Judith Bernstein, in her first solo show in a museum, has seven works from 1966 to 2012 in the New Museum’s lobby gallery.
lead_paragraph: Outstanding artworks in the Vietnam-era department of my personal mental museum include: James Rosenquist’s “F-111”; Peter Saul’s hallucinatory paintings of rape and carnage in Vietnam; Claes Oldenburg’s monumental sculpture of a giant lipstick standing vertically on military tank tracks; and Judith Bernstein’s mural-scale, charcoal drawings of enormous phallic screws. All of these have in common a more or less explicit metaphorical conflation of war and sexual violence.

headline: A Continent’s Art on a Long American Journey
abstract: A small but highly compelling show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tells the story of African art’s early reception in the United States with unusual candor.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to take for granted just how quickly art travels today, whether by JPEG or shipping crate. For a sense of how slow things were just a century ago, and how much could get lost en route from one continent to another, visit “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde,” a small but highly compelling show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It’s one of several exhibitions timed to the centennial of the Armory Show of 1913, where many New Yorkers caught their first glimpse of Modern art from Europe (much of it influenced by African sculpture).

headline: Thrill-Seeking Beats Take the Scenic Route
abstract: The Brazilian director Walter Salles wrestles with Jack Kerouac’s 1957 novel, “On the Road,” which inspired countless stoned hippie odysseys to Haight-Ashbury and beyond.
lead_paragraph: First the good news: America the Beautiful has rarely looked more ripe for exploration than it does in “On the Road,” a noble attempt by the Brazilian director Walter Salles (“The Motorcycle Diaries,” “Central Station”) to capture literary lightning in a bottle. With spacious skies stretching endlessly over open, uncongested roads bordered by amber waves of grain, and purple mountains beckoning in the distance, the movie resurrects a perennial frontier dream and invites you to barrel into the unknown with its Beat Generation legends.

His Christmas Tree-O, which released a scrappy and endearing album on Palmetto two years ago, does more or less what you’d expect, batting around holiday standards with a mischievous but sentimental air.

lead_paragraph: If you have followed the exploits of So Percussion, you will probably recognize that “Where (we) Live,” the new show that the group has mounted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater, is a project its members have been working toward for some time now. headline: Playing With the Band When the Music Meant Everything
abstract: In “Not Fade Away,” David Chase has written and directed a portrait of what it meant to chase rock ’n’ roll dreams in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: There is plenty of hope but little glory in “Not Fade Away,” David Chase’s sympathetic, acutely drawn portrait of a young Italian-American musician in New Jersey chasing 1960s rock ’n’ roll dreams. That character, Douglas Damiano (the perfectly cast John Magaro), is not a baby Bruce Springsteen or Jon Bon Jovi surrogate ascending to the pantheon while the whole world cheers. Near the beginning of the movie, a voice-over narrator, Douglas’s younger sister Evelyn (Meg Guzulescu), remarks, “Like most bands, you’ve never heard of them.”

lead_paragraph: For me, Cirque du Soleil will always be associated with the movie “Knocked Up,” in which the characters played by Seth Rogen and Paul Rudd take in a performance of “Mystère” under the influence of hallucinogenic mushrooms. If such a trip is not to your taste, or if a trip to Las Vegas is not on your calendar, you might opt for the relatively inexpensive, mildly mind-blowing “Cirque du Soleil: Worlds Away,” a new 3-D movie directed by Andrew Adamson.

headline: Paranoia From Both Left and Right
abstract: Patrea Patrick’s “American Empire” posits that multinational corporations have created a “cartel economy” bent on world domination.
lead_paragraph: Like one of those optical illusions that can be viewed as two completely different things, Patrea Patrick’s “American Empire” will give you whiplash. At first glance this eye-rollingly melodramatic documentary seems to be a left-wing attack on unbounded corporate power. Just squint a little, however, and you’ll see a right-wing conspiracy rant whose attacks on the Federal Reserve would make Ron Paul thrill.

headline: France: Budget Proposal Approved
abstract: The French Parliament approved the Socialist government’s 2013 budget proposal, a rigorous and contested plan to drop the deficit and increase taxes on individuals and businesses.
lead_paragraph: The Parliament on Thursday approved the Socialist government’s 2013 budget proposal, a rigorous and contested plan to drop the deficit to 3 percent of the gross domestic product with $26 billion in increased taxes on individuals and businesses and savings of $13 billion through a freeze in public spending. Members of the opposition called the tax increases unfair, citing, for instance, a 75 percent rate applied to income over $1.3 million and $13 billion in additional taxes on corporations already worried about high labor costs. Some on the left said the spending cuts were out of step with President François Hollande’s promises to promote growth and avoid austerity measures. The budget was based on growth projections of 0.8 percent for 2013, a figure some economists said was too optimistic.

headline: Canada: Court Seeks a Balance on Veils
abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Thursday that witnesses could cover their faces for religious reasons while testifying in court under some circumstances.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Thursday that witnesses could cover their faces for religious reasons while testifying in court under some circumstances. A Muslim woman, who cannot be named under a court order, asked to wear a niqab, a full-face veil, for religious reasons when testifying in an Ontario court against two men whom she has accused of sexual assault. The Supreme Court did not specifically rule on her request. But it provided trial judges with a four-part process for analyzing such requests to maintain a balance between religious freedoms and the right to a fair trial. The defendants’ lawyers argued that the faces of witnesses provided clues about the truthfulness of their testimony. Canada’s immigration minister recently barred women from wearing a niqab when taking the citizenship oath.

headline: OSHA Says It Is Investigating Garage Employee’s Drowning

lead_paragraph: Federal agents have opened an investigation into the death of a man who drowned during Hurricane Sandy at the underground garage in Manhattan where he worked.

headline: Use of Death Sentences Continues to Fall in U.S.
abstract: Thirty-six years after the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty, its use is waning; new data show 80 death sentences were handed down in 2012, about a third of the total in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-six years after the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty, its use is waning, with prosecutors and juries preferring to sentence convicted murderers to life in prison without parole. New data for 2012 show that nine states executed inmates this year, the fewest in two decades, and the number of death sentences handed down this year — 80 — was about a third of the total in 2000.

headline: Georgia: A Stalinist Restoration
abstract: The decision to restore a monument of Joseph Stalin was a rebuke to President Mikheil Saakashvili, who has tried to clear Georgia of all vestiges of Soviet symbolism.
lead_paragraph: A municipal assembly in Gori on Thursday voted to restore a monument of Stalin, the Soviet leader who died in 1953. It was a rebuke to President Mikheil Saakashvili, who has tried to clear Georgia of all vestiges of Soviet symbolism. A monument of Stalin stood for 48 years in the central square in Gori, his birthplace, until June 2010, when the authorities removed it. Mr. Saakashvili’s party was defeated in October by an opposition coalition led by Bidzina Ivanishvili. Some members of Mr. Ivanishvili’s coalition promised to restore monuments to Stalin in Gori and other cities. Zviad Khmaladze, the leader of Gori’s district assembly, said that $15,000 would be allocated to set up the monument near the small house where Stalin was born.

headline: ‘Borking’ Before Bork
abstract: The verb “to Bork” may seem like a dig at an honored martyr of the right, but the campaign to defeat him was neither unprecedented nor illegitimate.
lead_paragraph: THE death on Wednesday of Robert H. Bork, the conservative judge whose Supreme Court nomination was rejected by the Senate in 1987, has prompted a flood of commentaries describing his confirmation battle as a historic turning point. By opposing Mr. Bork for his right-wing views, it is alleged, Senate Democrats engaged in an unprecedented act of brazen partisanship against Ronald Reagan’s nominee, politicizing a once deferential process.

headline: Labs, Washed Away
abstract: After a natural disaster like Hurricane Sandy, hospital patients will return long before the researchers are back on track.
lead_paragraph: BEDPAN ALLEY is the affectionate name given to a stretch of First Avenue in Manhattan that is packed with more hospitals than many cities possess. This stretch also happened to be right in the flood zone during Hurricane Sandy. Water damage and power failures closed down all three of the New York University teaching hospitals — Bellevue Hospital, Tisch Hospital and the Manhattan V.A. Two months later, they are still not admitting patients, though two are on schedule to begin doing so shortly.

headline: Is the Cure for Cancer Inside You?
abstract: How one scientist’s losing battle against his own cancer might save the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Steinman saw her husband’s BlackBerry blinking in the dark. It had gone untouched for several days, in a bowl beside his keys, the last thing on anybody’s mind. But about an hour before sunrise, she got up to get a glass of water and, while padding toward the kitchen, found an e-mail time-stamped early that morning — “Sent: Monday, Oct. 3, 2011, 5:23 a.m. Subject: Nobel Prize. Message: Dear Dr. Steinman, I have good news for you. The Nobel Assembly has today decided to award you the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2011.” Before she finished reading, Claudia was hollering at her daughter to wake up. “Dad got the Nobel!” she cried. Alexis, still half-asleep, told her she was crazy. Her father had been dead for three days.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Instagram in Retreat, and ‘Jersey Shore’ Signs Off
abstract: After its users rebelled, the photo-sharing app did a full retreat from its new proposed terms of service; The Boston Globe named a new editor, Brian McGrory; and the iconic MTV series ended on Thursday after six seasons — what, if anything, is its legacy.
lead_paragraph: The photo-sharing app Instagram on Thursday completed a full retreat from its proposed new terms of service that led to instant outcry from users, Nicole Perlroth and Jenna Wortham reported. The question, however, was whether the move came too late from Instagram, which was acquired this year by Facebook and is under the same pressure as its parent company to generate advertising revenue. The proposed changes included a clause that suggested Instagram would share users’ data — like their favorite places, bands, restaurants and hobbies — with Facebook and its advertisers to direct ads more precisely. In the interim, other services, including Flickr, which coincidentally has just introduced a new app, appeared to be gaining followers.

headline: Interpretive Freedom
abstract: The Constitution is more than its text, Akhil Reed Amar argues.
lead_paragraph: In “America’s Unwritten Constitution,” Akhil Reed Amar, a commendably unorthodox and, in some ways, iconoclastic constitutional scholar at Yale Law School, bucks dominant opinions on both sides of the political spectrum. He contends that the written Constitution points to an unwritten one, and he argues that we can interpret with both intellectual honesty and analytical rigor. Aware that the idea of an unwritten constitution has been abused by judges and scholars on both the left and right, Amar insists that the idea itself is sound — indeed indispensable to the cause of constitutional fidelity — and needs rescuing from its abusers.

headline: Who Made That Champagne Cork?
abstract: The mushroom top to “devil’s wine.”
lead_paragraph: According to legend, a French monk named Dom Pérignon realized that a cork could seal in the fizz and flavor of Champagne after he saw Spanish travelers using tree bark to plug their water gourds. But George Taber, author of “To Cork or Not to Cork,” and other historians dispute this story. Taber cites evidence of Champagne corks on the Duke of Bedford’s household inventory list from 1665 — several years before Dom Pérignon took charge of the vineyards at the abbey of Hautvillers. Still, Pérignon and his name remain indelibly associated with Champagne.

headline: Laptop Prop?
keywords: ['Jams and Jellies', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Pesticides', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In doubt, inorganic, incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: I’m alternately amused and annoyed by the proximity of laptop computers on anchors’ desks during televised news broadcasts and other public-affairs programming. While I’d like to believe it’s there for the news reader’s reference as she tracks breaking news, or to look up momentarily forgotten facts like the capital of Estonia, I am more disposed to believe they are just props situated to convey the impression of a (phony) “up to the minute” information capacity. Does a news program have an ethical responsibility to avoid misrepresenting how current its reporters’ information is likely to be? What’s more, isn’t positioning the laptop to continuously display its manufacturer’s logo a form of advertising inappropriate for a news organization? JACK KENNY, BUFFALO

headline: Our Family Christmas, Rescinded
abstract: When my mother stopped hosting Christmas, her (grown) children panicked.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, my mother announced that she was spending Christmas in Egypt with friends. I flew home anyway, alone, and spent two days making homemade pierogies and sauerkraut and bread for the traditional Carpatho-Rusyn meal we always have on Christmas Eve. At 10 p.m., my sister had an hour off from her rounds at the hospital. She came home and we ate. Then she left, and I did the dishes.
