headline: Andy Ricker to Open Whiskey Soda Lounge in Brooklyn
abstract: The chef plans to open a bar just a few doors down from his Pok Pok Ny.
lead_paragraph: If you were not convinced that Brooklyn was an East Coast version of Portland, Ore., the chef Andy Ricker, who owns Pok Pok Ny in Brooklyn, keeps adding to the case. In the spring, he plans to open a Whiskey Soda Lounge, like the one he has in Portland, just a few doors down from Pok Pok Ny. This branch, in a small space, will serve drinks and Thai-style “drinking food” snacks that Mr. Ricker described as “spicy-salty-sour.” He sees it as a holding pen for customers waiting for tables at the restaurant. And he plans to serve Ike’s Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings, a cult favorite.

headline: Laws of Physics Can’t Trump the Bonds of Love
abstract: Jeffrey Wright uses wacky experiments to teach children about the universe, but it is his own personal story that teaches them the true meaning of life.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Wright is well known around his high school in Louisville, Ky., for his antics as a physics teacher, which include exploding pumpkins, hovercraft and a scary experiment that involves a bed of nails, a cinder block and a sledgehammer.

headline: Game Theory: Shooter Games Get Easier, and That Makes Change Harder
abstract: Dialing back the violence in video games is difficult as designers get better at making the games and players get better at shooting.
lead_paragraph: Dear Stephen, Chris, assorted friends and frenemies,

headline: Ancient Marine Reptiles Swam in Rivers Too
abstract: A newly discovered species of mosasaur probably adapted to fresh water the same way as river dolphins in Asia and South America.
lead_paragraph: Mosasaurs were large, ancient relatives of monitor lizards. They were common during the Late Cretaceous period, 66 million to 100 million years ago, and were found near shallow marine areas in salt water.

headline: A Happy Ending, Sort of, Comes With No Closure
abstract: “West of Memphis” follows the successful but prolonged legal battle to free the so-called West Memphis Three, who were released from prison last year under a plea bargain.
lead_paragraph: “West of Memphis,” a work of fierce documentary advocacy directed by Amy Berg (“Deliver Us From Evil”), follows the successful crusade to free three men convicted of murder 18 years ago in a sloppy, hysterical rush to justice.

headline: An Oratorio Gets Its Day
abstract: Patrick Gardner led the Riverside Choral Society in the “Christmas Oratorio,” the third high-profile performance of the work this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: It has been a season of relief for those New York Bach fans perpetually disappointed that their master’s “Christmas Oratorio” is not a holiday perennial on the order of Handel’s “Messiah.”

headline: Thousands of Children Are at Risk in Central Africa, Aid Agency Warns
abstract: Measles, a highly contagious and sometimes deadly disease, is on the rise in Central Africa, the aid agency Doctors Without Borders warned.
lead_paragraph: A large measles epidemic is spreading in Central Africa, endangering the lives of thousands of children, the medical charity Doctors Without Borders warned last week.

headline: Big Money and Mischief in Reagan-Era Hollywood
abstract: William Stadiem’s latest book, “Moneywood,” is his take on the players and money in the film industry during the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: William Stadiem’s specialty has been collaborating on gossipy tell-alls with minor celebrities. Very minor celebrities, but well-positioned ones. Mr. Stadiem’s books include “Mr. S: My Life With Frank Sinatra,” with George Jacobs, Sinatra’s keenly observant valet, and “Marilyn Monroe Confidential: An Intimate Personal Account,” with Lena Pepitone, who worked for Monroe as a maid. According to reader feedback on the Goodreads site, the Monroe book is a better written treatment of National Enquirer-type material. If you read it by a pool and dropped it in the water, a reader says, you wouldn’t be all that sorry.

headline: Making a Sandwich by the Book
abstract: The Saltie cookbook features recipes from the compact shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Do you really need a cookbook to make a sandwich? Not for PB&J, perhaps, but what if you are tempted by soft scrambled eggs and ricotta on fresh focaccia, or sardines with pickled eggs and salsa verde? That’s when you should open the Saltie cookbook, based on the menu at this compact sandwich shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Besides recipes for sandwiches and their components, it has desserts, soups, eggs and salads. An easily assembled cock-a-leekie makes a delicious cold-weather supper. The method is unusual: bring a whole chicken to a boil, then let it cool in the liquid for an hour, after which the chicken is done and you have your broth. Prunes add color and a touch of sweet richness.

headline: Smoked Fish From Long Island
abstract: Under the name North Fork Smoked Fish, Phil Karlin, a fisherman, is bringing dips, pâtés and fillets to Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Phil Karlin, a commercial fisherman based in Cutchogue, N.Y., has started making and selling various smoked fish products under the name North Fork Smoked Fish. His line includes smoked blue fish fillets and a creamy smoked blue fish pâté, a slightly spicier Caribbean pâté made with smoked swordfish, a mixed smoked-fish dip, and hot-smoked Norwegian salmon pâté (below) and fillets, all tailor-made for easy entertaining. The pâtés and dips are appetite-whetters. The succulent fish fillets can be served alongside a salad, in a sandwich or broken up into a chowder.

headline: As Forests Disappear, Examining the Mechanisms of Their Death
abstract: Trees are disappearing across the world, in a way not fully understood, so a scientist in New Mexico has set up a kind of sylvan intensive care unit to get answers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ALAMOS, N.M. — Everywhere, trees are dying.

headline: Turkish Breads Seek a Niche in the Bagel Capital
abstract: The simit, which is like a large bagel and comes beaded with sesame seeds, is the star attraction at a new Turkish shop on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: In Eastern Mediterranean regions, Balkan countries and the Arab world there is a popular snack that looks like a large bagel and comes beaded with sesame seeds. It has various names, but in Turkey it’s called simit, and it is the star attraction at a new shop in Manhattan called Simit & Smith. The Smith is fictitious; the Turkish entrepreneurs behind the enterprise added it to make the name more American-sounding, said Burak Atay, the managing partner. They opened on the Upper West Side last week and already have a bakery and store in Cliffside Park, N.J. Two spots are planned for the financial district in early 2013.

headline: The Wretched Lift Their Voices
abstract: Amid the grime, power ballads and surging strings, there is a familiar, reassuring story of oppression, liberation and redemption.
lead_paragraph: In the first long act of “Les Misérables,” Anne Hathaway opens her mouth, and the agony, passion and violence that have decorously idled in the background of this all-singing, all-suffering pop opera pour out. It’s a gusher! She’s playing Fantine, the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping “I Dreamed a Dream,” her gaunt face splotched red and brown. The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera. Ms. Hathaway, though, holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion. She devours the song, the scene, the movie, and turns her astonishing, cavernous mouth into a vision of the void.

headline: For the Home Mixologist, One Tool for 10 Tasks
abstract: A new gadget combines everything you need, except the shaker and alcohol, to make a drink.
lead_paragraph: A Swiss Army knife for the bar? Why not, especially in a small apartment. This gadget, the Bar10der, combines everything you need, except the shaker and alcohol, to make a drink. The muddler at one end doubles as a reamer. A strainer, knife, zester, channel knife, stirrer, bottle opener and corkscrew all pull out of the handle for use. There is a double jigger, for an ounce and a half-ounce. The cushioned rubber-clad handle is easy to grip, and you have a choice of colors: azure, purple, lime or orange.

headline: 12 Restaurant Triumphs of 2012
abstract: The Times’s chief restaurant critic counts down his favorite new restaurants of the year.
lead_paragraph: AT the end of my first year in the restaurant critic’s chair, the New York dining landscape still looks like a wonderland to me.

abstract: The calf, a male who has not yet been named, is the first calf ever born at the Prospect Park Zoo, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Dec. 26 | Brooklyn’s bovine population has grown by one: a calf was born at the Prospect Park Zoo, officials announced Monday.

headline: Going to Sleep While We Wait for Santa
abstract: Wheels is taking a not-so-long winter’s nap.
lead_paragraph: We’re not sure if Santa Claus will leave a luxury car with a giant bow in the driveway, a motorcycle in the garage or a Matchbox car in the stocking, but we do know he won’t leave anything if we’re awake. So Wheels is taking a not-so-long winter’s nap tonight and tomorrow. But rest assured we’ll be back on Wednesday. Merry Christmas to all!

headline: In Performance: Alice Ripley of ‘A Civil War Christmas’
abstract: The actress sings a medley of “Yellow Rose of Texas” and “Ain’t That a Rockin’ All Night” from Paula Vogel’s show at New York Theater Workshop.
lead_paragraph: “A Civil War Christmas,” Paula Vogel’s play with music, is set during the grim holiday season of 1864. Alice Ripley, who plays Mary Todd Lincoln and other characters, sings a medley of “Yellow Rose of Texas” and “Ain’t That a Rockin’ All Night.” The show runs through Dec. 30 at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Buried Treasure That Is Filled With Mystery
abstract: When it comes to truffles, it pays to know a few facts about the weird biology and the often duplicitous nature of the truffle business.
lead_paragraph: IF you have never bought truffles because, frankly, you do not know how to begin and you are afraid you will get skunked, well, you are not alone. Serious home cooks and even food pros are bamboozled all the time. It’s actually pretty difficult and always expensive to attain good-quality truffles, especially for retail customers. In fact, acquiring truffles is so fraught with potential fraud that you might wonder whether the dining experience is worth the financial risk.

headline: The Chemistry Sets of Yesteryear
abstract: From “Chemcraft” to the “Midgetlab,”  chemistry sets flourished from the early through the mid-20th century, featuring everything from gender-specific kits to tabletop labs complete with “Atomic Energy.”
lead_paragraph: From “Chemcraft” to the “Midgetlab,”  chemistry sets flourished from the early through the mid-20th century, featuring everything from gender-specific kits to tabletop labs complete with “Atomic Energy.”

headline: Practical to Career-Oriented to Just Plain Fun
abstract: A brief history of chemistry sets: Utilitarian tools of the trade made way for skill-building sets and, later, zany approaches to “kitchen chemistry.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Potter fans will appreciate the origin of the chemistry set: In 18th century England, university students were given supply lists and sent to shops in London that assembled kits for each course of study, from geology to mineralogy and chemistry.

headline: A Haunting Tale, Perfect for Christmas
abstract: The Crossing, a 24-voice choir, performed David Lang’s “Little Match Girl Passion” on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: At holiday time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art draws countless visitors to its Medieval Sculpture Garden to see the splendid Christmas tree and 18th-century Neapolitan crèche. The garden has also been a special site for holiday concerts. The museum has put much thought over the years into choosing appropriate seasonal music, especially early music.

headline: Gifts That Keep Giving (if Not Exploding)
abstract: Today’s science kits lack the free-play style and sometimes dangerous materials of yore, but many argue that they can still spark a lifelong interest in inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Ask scientists of a certain age about their childhood memories, and odds are they’ll start yarning about the stink bombs and gunpowder they concocted with their chemistry sets. Dangerous? Yes, but fun.

headline: What’s Your Best Meal of 2012?
abstract: Share your best restaurant meals of the year by tweeting us at @nytdining, using the hashtag #bestmeal2012.
lead_paragraph: Pete Wells has listed his best new restaurants of the year, along with some of the best dishes he tasted. Now we look to you. Share your best restaurant meals of the year by tweeting us at @nytdining, using the hashtag #bestmeal2012. Your pick doesn’t have to be from a new restaurant, or even a place in New York City; it simply has to be something delicious, intriguing, stimulating or just so good you couldn’t stop thinking about it.

headline: Russian Prosecutor Seeks Acquittal in Lawyer’s Death
abstract: The prosecutor’s turnabout came as the Russian government was moving to retaliate against the United States for adopting a human rights law named for Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer who died in prison.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A prosecutor unexpectedly pressed Monday for the acquittal of the only official to be tried in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer whose death in prison three years ago generated an international furor over Russian human rights abuses.

headline: No Requiem for Earth, Only Celebration
abstract: Friday was predicted to be the apocalypse, and the Society for Universal Sacred Music presented the performance of “The Creation” as a gesture of renewal and reverence for life.
lead_paragraph: The world did not end on Friday as the ancient Maya calendar foretold. But if any apocalyptic forces were kicking around the planet that day, they were combated by a performance that evening at Carnegie Hall of “The Creation,” Haydn’s astonishing oratorio that depicts God’s making of the world, presented by the New York Virtuoso Singers, the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and a roster of vocal soloists, conducted by Harold Rosenbaum.

headline: Not Even the Russians Can Do This ‘Laurencia’
abstract: The artistic director of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo for years dreamed of bringing the ballet “Laurencia” to life; now he has, at the Joyce.
lead_paragraph: Tory Dobrin, the artistic director of the all-male drag company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, affectionately known as the Trocks, first saw a clip of the Soviet-era ballet  “Laurencia”  on television in the early ’80s, and it stayed with him. The ballet shows its choreographer, Vakhtang Chabukiani, dancing in a ripped shirt, with a bare midriff and torn pants, surrounded by women in peasant skirts and blouses.

headline: What He Does for Love
abstract: New albums from the Game, Eric Revis and Ryan Blotnick.
lead_paragraph: For the last couple of months, VH1 has been showing the reality show “Marrying the Game,” which chronicled the wedding preparations of the Game, the abrasive, derivative rapper, and his longtime girlfriend, Tiffney Cambridge. By the end of the season, though, the two were at loggerheads, and the wedding was off, at least partly because of the Game’s heavy focus on completing work on “Jesus Piece,” his fifth album.

headline: ‘No Means No,’ and More From Wise Grandparents
abstract: When the grandparents step in to baby-sit for a few days, generational child-rearing styles clash, and smiles and tears and a lot of sentimentality ensue.
lead_paragraph: “Parental Guidance,” a new comedy with Billy Crystal, is about a minor-league baseball announcer who, after he’s canned for being an old shtick in the mud (he doesn’t tweet), develops a new relationship with his daughter and grandkids. Actually, he teaches everyone a lot of lessons — it’s revenge of the geezer — allowing him to have his curmudgeonly cake and eat it too. Mostly, though, “Parental Guidance” is what families who are desperate to get out of the house over the holidays and need to bridge the generational divide will see after they’ve seen “Les Misérables.”

headline: Qatar 2022: Nine Years Can Go By Fast
abstract: Touching on the pluses and minuses of Qatar hosting the 2022 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, soccer fans around the world revel in what has been called the biggest sporting event on the planet — the World Cup.

headline: More on a Man Who Flew More Than a Million Miles
abstract: Last week’s column recounted the story of Tom Stuker, whom United Airlines called its top flier of the year. But some readers were skeptical.
lead_paragraph: AS the end of the year approaches, many business travelers anxiously do the mileage math. That is, how many miles did I fly this year on a given airline? Was it enough to hit the mark for whichever elite-status level I’m pursuing for next year?

headline: Harmonizing Two Holidays
abstract: Marc Kudisch and Jeffry Denman blend Hanukkah and Christmas in their musical stage show at the York Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Marc Kudisch and Jeffry Denman rely too much on well-worn themes to make “The Holiday Guys: Happy Merry Hanu-Mas!,” their new seasonal stage show, a must-see addition to the December crush. But it’s moderately diverting, nonthreatening and nontaxing, which seem to be the main theatrical criteria at this time of year. And when the two men put aside the predictable banter and just sing, it’s downright pleasant.

headline: That’s No Mouse King in the Trailer
abstract: “Chris March’s The Butt-Cracker Suite!” is a campy reinvention of Tchaikovsky’s “Nutcracker,” which Mr. March calls a “trailer park ballet.”

headline: Gaza: Rights Group Accuses Militants of Unlawful Rocket Attacks on Israel
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Human Rights Watch said that armed Palestinian groups had violated the laws of war by firing hundreds of rockets toward population centers in Israel during eight days of fighting in November.
lead_paragraph: Human Rights Watch said Monday that armed Palestinian groups in Gaza had violated the laws of war by firing hundreds of rockets toward population centers in Israel during eight days of fighting in November. Three Israeli civilians, a soldier and a civilian contractor at a military base were killed by the rocket fire. The group said that two Palestinians were killed, apparently by rockets that fell short, and that the militants endangered Gaza civilians by firing from densely populated areas. More than 150 Palestinians were killed by Israel airstrikes and shelling. A spokesman for Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, rejected the report as biased, telling Reuters that the Palestinians were defending themselves. Human Rights Watch, a nongovernmental group based in New York, has criticized Israel for what it called unlawful attacks on a house that killed 12 people, and on Palestinian journalists during the conflict. Israel has insisted that it fired on legitimate targets.

abstract: The police rescued the children while breaking up nine child trafficking rings and arresting 355 suspects, the Ministry of Public Security announced Monday.

According to the official Xinhua news service, the gangs abducted children in several provinces in the south and then sold them elsewhere in China. The raid was part of a nationwide crackdown on kidnappers, who often seize boys. Most of the stolen children are sold to families who want a male heir but face limitations imposed by China’s strict family-planning policies. The Chinese government says that 10,000 children are kidnapped each year, but some experts suggest the number may be as high as 70,000.

The federal Investigative Committee on Monday accused Mr. Navalny of stealing more than $3 million from the Union of Right Forces, a liberal party that is now defunct, in 2007. The authorities have also accused Mr. Navalny and his brother of conspiring to steal money in business deals. The second is as an anti-gun-violence activist, working the same streets he used to roam late into the night to prevent gunshots before they happen.

abstract: In a recent interview with Vibe, he said he would not watch Quentin Tarantino’s latest film, set in the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: He may not have seen it, but the film director Spike Lee already has an opinion about “Django Unchained.” In a recent interview with Vibe, he said he would not watch Quentin Tarantino’s latest film, set in the antebellum South, which opened in theaters on Tuesday. “I can’t speak on it ’cause I’m not gonna see it,” he said. “The only thing I can say is it’s disrespectful to my ancestors, to see that film.”

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The police said Tuesday that they had arrested a former official of a federal agency that manages state enterprises on charges of stealing $330 million in property, a theft noteworthy even by the standards of Russian public corruption.

headline: Ben Affleck Says No to a Senate Run
abstract: Speculation began after Mr. Affleck, a Democratic-leaning star who has been widely discussing Middle Eastern and national politics as he promotes his film “Argo,” did not rule it out during an appearance on “Face the Nation.”
lead_paragraph: Any Massachusetts residents dreaming of having an Oscar winner who publicly rubbed up J. Lo as their Washington envoy are due for disappointment. Ben Affleck declared that he would not compete for John Kerry’s Senate seat if Mr. Kerry is confirmed as secretary of state. “I love Massachusetts and our political process, but I am not running for office,” Mr. Affleck wrote on his Facebook page.

headline: Clout Diminished, Tea Party Turns to Narrower Issues
abstract: The November election significantly weakened the once-surging movement, and its activists have not been front and center in the fiscal debate consuming Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Tea Party might not be over, but it is increasingly clear that the election last month significantly weakened the once-surging movement, which nearly captured control of the Republican Party through a potent combination of populism and fury.

headline: Mine, All Mine: Ski Areas Rent Whole Mountains
abstract: A few ski areas in the United States offer the chance for skiers to rent the mountain for the day.
lead_paragraph: Having a private ski mountain seems the stuff of ski-bum fantasy. But for little more than the price of a daily lift ticket (if overall cost is divided equally), a few ski areas offer the chance for skiers to act like king (or queen) of the mountain for the day.

headline: What to Play on Boxing Day
abstract: The day after Christmas is for watching Premier League soccer matches, drinking and listening to Santa-free tunes.
lead_paragraph: It was fun putting together the Christmas Dozen Playlist that accompanied my eggnog column. And I couldn’t have done it without my friend Sean, an M.T.A. subway motorman, whose holiday gift to his friends is a painstakingly compiled, wonderfully idiosyncratic music mix; he introduced me to three of the numbers I included on my playlist: Toots and the Maytals’ “Christmas Feeling Ska”; BeauSoleil’s “Papa St. Nick”; and William Bell’s “Everyday Will Be Like a Holiday.” (I did not consult with Questlove, but he has some tips for holiday-party playlist-making, too.)

headline: Gunman Who Killed 2 Firefighters Left Chilling Note
abstract: The police in Webster, N.Y., found remains in the home of William Spengler, 62, believed to be those of his sister, as well as a note expressing his passion for killing.
lead_paragraph: WEBSTER, N.Y. — On Monday morning when darkness was still raw, William Spengler Jr. armed himself with a rifle, a revolver and a shotgun. He had killed before. Harboring a deep-seated hatred of his sister, who lived with him, and a desire to harm his neighbors on a beachfront strip off Lake Ontario, Mr. Spengler composed a rough, typewritten plan that foretold of the destruction to come.

headline: Now in 3-D, Christmas With the Queen
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II and the archbishops of Canterbury and York employed technological upgrades, using 3-D video and Twitter to spread their Christmas messages.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, Queen Elizabeth II marked Christmas in a third dimension. Speaking from London, the queen videotaped her traditional holiday address to the British public in 3-D, and even donned 3-D glasses to watch it from Buckingham Palace. In the annual remarks, which she writes herself, the queen paid tribute to servicemen and women whose “sense of duty takes them away from family and friends” over the holidays, and highlighted a year that included the 60th anniversary of her reign and the London Olympic Games, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Mass Holiday Homecoming Saddles a Rural Irish Town
abstract: Each year, cavalcades of Irish nomads return to a town they regard as their spiritual home, bringing with them ostentatious displays of wealth and a history of disorderly conduct.
lead_paragraph: RATHKEALE, Ireland — Christmas in Ireland is a time of homecomings, with joyous family reunions at airports and ferry piers. But the largest single gathering of all briefly turns this little town into the only place in Ireland where armed police officers patrol the streets 24 hours a day to deter internecine feuds and other disorderly conduct.

headline: In Hopes of Healthier Chickens, Farms Turn to Oregano
abstract: Chicken farms including Bell & Evans in Pennsylvania are using oregano-based products as substitutes for antibiotics, but research on their effectiveness is scant and many remain skeptical.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICKSBURG, Pa. — The smell of oregano wafting from Scott Sechler’s office is so strong that anyone visiting Bell & Evans these days could be forgiven for wondering whether Mr. Sechler has forsaken the production of chicken and gone into pizza.

headline: From the 17th Century, Gleeful Jinks Aplenty, More Low Than High
abstract: “Restoration Comedy,” by Amy Freed, reimagines and seriously glams up some classics at the Flea.
lead_paragraph: How do you hold an audience of the young and hip captive, let alone keep them laughing, wolf-whistling and hooting with delight through a three-and-a-half-hour evening fashioned from the dusty bones of 17th-century popular theater? Ed Sylvanus Iskander’s raucous production of Amy Freed’s anachronism-flaunting “Restoration Comedy” at the Flea Theater answers that question.

headline: It’s Not Just a Job; It’s a Musical
abstract: “Working: A Musical” has been updated to reflect the current unemployment picture as well as changes in the jobs people perform as some old fields dwindle and new ones are born.
lead_paragraph: The song “Millwork,” a haunting slice of blue-collar melancholia, has been recorded by its composer, James Taylor, and covered by artists from Emmylou Harris to Eddie Vedder, Bruce Springsteen to Bette Midler. But as performed with a gorgeous sorrowful twang by Marie-France Arcilla in “Working: A Musical,” at 59E59 Theaters, this evocative ballad belongs unequivocally to the woman standing before us: a mother of three who toils as an assembly-line steam-press operator in a luggage factory, reflecting on her “wasted” life.

Starting in early January checks from $1,000 to $5,000 will go out to companies, choreographers and theaters knocked back on their heels by the destruction and flooding.

lead_paragraph: The annual Kennedy Center Honors are always a heartening reminder that amid the din of day-to-day pop culture, real and enduring artistic achievement is taking place, even if we forget to notice. But the 35th installment of the awards, which will be broadcast Wednesday night on CBS, is particularly satisfying, a delicious mix of highbrow and not so highbrow, beginning with a man who memorably dressed as a woman and ending with a rock ’n’ roll symphony.

And yet, as easy as it might be to dismiss eating from harvests no more than 100 miles from home as a lark of the privileged, the movement is still gaining converts.

abstract: A day off would have been a merciful itinerary, but for roughly 450 of the world’s best basketball players, this is the life they have chosen, and many cherish: work on Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen grueling years as a professional basketball player and Jerry Stackhouse was slipping into uniform, color-coordinated sneakers included, for the first time on Christmas Day. A benefit of having never held down a roster spot on one of the chosen holiday elite has been quality family time at home, nestled comfortably in front of expanding television screens.

lead_paragraph: Bernard Moitessier of France surprised the sailing world by peeling away from the first solo, nonstop, around-the-world race when he was on the cusp of finishing in 1969. He said in his reports to passing ships that he had found enlightenment on the high seas. He continued to go two-thirds of the way around the globe before landing in the South Pacific because he could.

abstract: In “Tabu” the Portuguese filmmaker Miguel Gomes tells two tales, that of a three women of different classes in contemporary Lisbon, and of the eldest one’s adventures in Africa during her youth.
lead_paragraph: The word melancholy occurs several times in “Tabu,” Miguel Gomes’s odd and sometimes entrancing new film, memorably at the beginning, where it is used (in a voice-over) to describe a Portuguese explorer making his wistful way through the wilds of Africa, haunted by ghosts and threatened by crocodiles. This poor, intrepid soul is a character in a movie that is watched by Pilar (Teresa Madruga), a middle-aged single woman living in modern Lisbon. Her unadventurous, middle-class euro zone existence is melancholy in its own way. Like the explorer, Pilar is filmed in narrow-screen black-and-white, which casts a glow of nostalgic mystery over her everyday dealings with friends and neighbors.

I think he would make a fine secretary of defense — precisely because some of his views are not “mainstream.” I find the opposition to him falling into two baskets: the disgusting and the philosophical. It is vital to look at both to appreciate why Hagel would be a good fit for Defense at this time.

headline: Colonel Wilder’s Lightning Brigade

Rosecrans was getting ready to move his 44,000 men against the 38,000 soldiers under Gen. Braxton Bragg, based in Murfreesboro, just 26 miles from Nashville. The Federal general didn’t have enough cavalry to simultaneously support a movement on Bragg and a hunt for Morgan’s 3,000 raiders, but he could ill afford to let supply disruptions threaten his attack plans: President Lincoln was growing impatient for results.

headline: Is Growth Over?
abstract: Worth thinking about.
lead_paragraph: It’s taken me a while to get around to Bob Gordon’s stimulating essay suggesting that the great days of economic growth are behind us. It’s not that different from things he’s been saying before, and I have in the past had a lot of sympathy for that view. I now believe, however, that his technological pessimism is wrong — or if you prefer, it’s the wrong kind of pessimism. But this is definitely a discussion worth having.

headline: In the Company of Captain Cook
abstract: In “Sailing the Unknown,” the poet Michael J. Rosen imagines the journal of the real-life 11-year-old who was the youngest sailor aboard Captain Cook’s Endeavour.
lead_paragraph: A young boy conscripted aboard a ship of seasoned sailors. A journey to faraway lands in an uncharted world. A tale of cannibals and exotic creatures and devastating illness. This could be the makings of the latest young adult action thriller. Instead it’s a strikingly illustrated picture book for older readers, piquantly evocative of centuries-old historical events.

headline: An Early Tale of the Internet
abstract: An electrical engineer who worked on the forerunner to the Internet recalls a visitor from the government to the laboratory where he worked — a place that developed many personal computing and networking technologies.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday I interviewed Peter E. Hart, an electrical engineer who was an early artificial intelligence researcher, about one of the first robots, a machine named Shakey that was designed at SRI International beginning in 1966. SRI was one of the laboratories from which many personal computing and networking technologies were first developed.

headline: In Speaker Dock, a Minimalist Home for the iPhone 5
abstract: Harman has released the JBL OnBeat Micro speaker dock, which features the must-have Apple Lightning connector, but not much else.
lead_paragraph: Capitalizing on the sudden need for iPhone 5 docking stations, Harman has released the JBL OnBeat Micro speaker dock that features the must-have Apple Lightning connector.

headline: Consequences of a Political Deadlock
abstract: TimesCast: Fiscal impasse adds to economic anxiety. | At Jerusalem’s Western Wall, women fight against ultra-Orthodox beliefs. | Christmas after Hurricane Sandy in Red Hook, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast: Fiscal impasse adds to economic anxiety. | At Jerusalem’s Western Wall, women fight against ultra-Orthodox beliefs. | Christmas after Hurricane Sandy in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: These Worlds Take a Lot of Work
abstract: Dan Hennah and Joe Letteri discuss their production design and special effects work on “The Hobbit” films.
lead_paragraph: A CREW of hundreds came together to create the locations for Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit” trio of prequels to his “Lord of the Rings” movies. Some of the artists who brought their expertise to “Rings” are back. Dan Hennah, who won an Oscar for set decoration in “Return of the King,” served as the production designer on the new films. And Joe Letteri, whose work at Weta Digital gave form and texture to the character Gollum, has returned to Middle-earth, now with a more advanced set of technological tools at his disposal.

headline: The End of Spider-Man (at Least for Now)
abstract: A longtime nemesis, Doctor Octopus, takes over Spider-Man’s mind, body, costume and mission.
lead_paragraph: Comic book fans who pick up Issue No. 700 of “The Amazing Spider-Man,” which arrived in stores on Wednesday, will see what Marvel Comics is promising as the final fight between Spider-Man and his longtime nemesis Dr. Octopus. The end result has the villain taking over the hero’s mind, body, costume and mission. Dr. Octopus, who is convinced he can do a better job than Peter Parker’s alter ego, begins his adventures as the wall-crawling hero in “The Superior Spider-Man,” the first issue of which will be available Jan. 9.

headline: Reminder: Campaign Finance Donor Search Will Be Deprecated
abstract: A reminder that the presidential donor search in our Campaign Finance API will be deprecated this Friday, Dec. 28.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a regular user of the presidential donor information returned by our Campaign Finance API, don’t forget: that request type will be deprecated this Friday, Dec. 28. We won’t be creating a new version; we’re removing the data from our servers completely. Please update your code, and leave a comment if you have questions or concerns.

headline: Storm Weakened a Fragile System for Mental Care
abstract: The odds of securing mental health treatment in a crisis in New York City have worsened significantly since Hurricane Sandy knocked out hospitals and disrupted outpatient services.
lead_paragraph: When a young woman in the grip of paranoid delusions threatened a neighbor with a meat cleaver one Saturday last month, the police took her by ambulance to the nearest psychiatric emergency room. Or rather, they took her to Beth Israel Medical Center, the only comprehensive psychiatric E.R. functioning in Lower Manhattan since Hurricane Sandy shrank and strained New York’s mental health resources.

headline: Even in a Lockout Year, Rangers Raise a Banner
abstract: While Madison Square Garden was being refurbished this summer, workmen hoisted a banner that reads, “2011-12 Atlantic Division Champions.”
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. lockout has derailed a lot of plans, like teams celebrating last season’s accomplishments at their home openers.

headline: ‘Crowdfunding’ Rules Are Unlikely to Meet Deadline
abstract: A delay by the Securities and Exchange Commission has frustrated backers of a provision that exempts small companies from having to register before they can sell stock to the public.
lead_paragraph: When the Jobs Act became law in April, supporters proclaimed a new era for small businesses seeking to raise money.

abstract: Narendra Modi sworn in as Gujarat’s chief minister for the fourth time.

headline: RocketHub Ponders Its Future in Crowdfunding
abstract: Much depends on how the rules are written, but if the company needs to raise more capital, it probably won’t use its own platform.
lead_paragraph: We have published a story about why the Securities and Exchange Commission has struggled to write the rules that will carry out equity crowdfunding for small businesses. One company that has been at the forefront of the effort to influence those rules is RocketHub, a donation- and rewards-based crowdfunding site based in New York. Itself a small business, RocketHub debuted in 2010 and now has about 10 employees, including its four founders — but is still viewed as one of the largest American crowdfunding platforms.

headline: Your Best Meal of 2012, New York Edition
abstract: Readers shared their best meals in New York City this year.
lead_paragraph: We asked you to tweet your favorite meal of the year using the hashtag #bestmeal2012, and received so many responses that we’ve split the highlights into two categories to feature here on Diner’s Journal. First up are New York City places, some of which you’ll also find on Pete Wells’s list of the best new restaurants of the year. Restaurants that are further afield will be gathering in a post this afternoon. Tell us your #bestmeal2012 by tweeting us at @nytdining.

headline: Video: A Red Hook Church Rebounds After Hurricane
abstract: After being flooded by Hurricane Sandy, a Brooklyn parish experienced a flow of generosity and new faces at Christmas Mass.
lead_paragraph: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, people attended Christmas Mass at Visitation Church, which has experienced a resurgence since Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Exploring the Roots of an Emerging Planet-Spanning ‘Mind’
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Evolution', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Paleontology', 'Philosophy', 'Religion and Belief', 'Science and Technology', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: An exploration of the 21st-century relevance of a 20th-century theologian’s ideas about humanity’s global consciousness.
lead_paragraph: I’m grateful to Krista Tippett, the host of the captivating public radio program “On Being,” for including me in an exploration of the present-day resonance of “noosphere,” the concept of an emerging global intelligence shaped in the early 20th century by Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, a French Jesuit priest, philosopher and paleontologist (with others). You can read two of Teilhard’s most influential books touching on this concept — “The Phenomenon of Man” and “The Future of Man” — online.

headline: Every Bird Counts, but Some Make the Heart Beat Faster
abstract: Roaming with binoculars, a participant in the annual Christmas Bird Count longs to glimpse a certain sparrow.
lead_paragraph: Binoculars at the ready, a small group of birders fanned out through the field, searching for a brown-and-gray bird that was stubbornly refusing to show itself.

The account declared itself to be the handiwork of Tommasso Debenedetti, a journalist who has created fake Twitter pages for other well-known figures.

headline: Catching the Sights, Not the Bugs
keywords: ['Infections', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Medicine and Health', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: When traveling abroad, what steps should you follow to help prevent illness? A doctor dispenses advice.
lead_paragraph: Friends and family so often asked Dr. Charles E. Davis, a specialist in microbiology and infectious disease, how to avoid getting sick when they travel abroad, he decided to put all of his advice in one place. The result is “The International Traveler’s Guide to Avoiding Infections,” released this year by Johns Hopkins University Press. Below are edited excerpts with Dr. Davis in a discussion about precautions international travelers should take before and after trips to far-flung destinations.

headline: In Soccer as in Life, Will a Resurgent Germany Dominate a Weakened Europe?
abstract: Germany’s rise to dominate Europe on the economic front is clear, but the IHT’s Nick Kulish reports that German might extends to an even more important realm: soccer.
lead_paragraph: Our colleague Nicholas Kulish has written a year-end sports piece sure to get folks thinking. “The resurgence of German soccer began, like the country’s economic comeback, after a long slide toward stagnation amid dire prophecies of impending irrelevance,” Nick writes.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4 P.M. (AMC) CASINO (1995) Martin Scorsese directs this crime drama based on the nonfiction book by Nicholas Pileggi that follows Ace Rothstein (Robert De Niro), a gambling savant hired by the Mafia to run a casino in Las Vegas in the 1970s and to ensure that the bosses back home always receive a piece of the profits. His muscle is Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci), whose criminal activities and proclivity for violence spiral out of control. “Mr. Pileggi, Mr. De Niro and Mr. Pesci, all ‘Goodfellas’ alumni, are back in familiar capacities, joining Mr. Scorsese to do what they do best,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “But,” she added, “ ‘Casino’ also has a new ingredient in Sharon Stone,” above with Mr. De Niro, “who will be nobody’s idea of Hollywood fluff after this spectacular, emblematic performance. As Ginger McKenna, a gorgeous hustler who falls from the ranks of Vegas’s royalty to its lowest depths, she represents the full range of this film’s stark extremes.” Ms. Stone, above with Mr. De Niro, received an Oscar nomination.

lead_paragraph: On the eve of his retirement, Senator Joseph Lieberman reflects on his political career and the proper role of bipartisanship.

headline: Game Theory: Considering Video Games as Ballet
abstract: Playing games is as much about motion and gesture as it is about witnessing what occurs on a screen
lead_paragraph: Like Lucy, when I write and think about video games, I try to focus on what the medium can do that the canonical arts — books, movies, theater, dance, music, television, painting, sculpture, comics, whatever — cannot. But I think it’s also worth emphasizing how video games resemble the culturally accepted arts. They’re more alike than different.  In 2012, I started reading a couple of books — one new, the other newish — about the history of other art forms, and their infancies would be very familiar to gamers.

lead_paragraph: 8:45 p.m. | Updated In the days after the Connecticut school killings, a newspaper in nearby Westchester County, N.Y., decided to respond by publishing the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in its readership area. The newspaper, The Journal News, said that informing people about legal weapons in their neighborhoods was a public service.

headline: No Questions on N.R.A. Plan, but Plenty of Comments

lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association didn’t take any questions at its news conference last Friday, announcing its National School Shield program to have armed guards in every school. But there were plenty of harsh words on Twitter, many from celebrities — even those not included in the “Demand a Plan” video that has gotten millions of YouTube views.

headline: Senators to Return With 5 Days Left and No Clear Fiscal Path

headline: Quirks of the Game: N.B.A. Schedule Short-Circuits Rivalries
abstract: The N.B.A. plays fewer intra-division games than any other sport, which means rivalries like Knicks-Nets don’t get much time to grow.

headline: Potent Winter Storm Moves East After Pouncing on Wide Area of the Country
abstract: Severe weather that brought tornadoes to the South and snow from Texas to Ohio could bring 12 to 18 inches of snow to an area from western New York to central Maine.
lead_paragraph: A powerful winter storm that spawned tornadoes in the Deep South and brought Christmas Day snow to Dallas moved east on Wednesday, bringing blizzard conditions in Indiana and Ohio, severe thunderstorms to the Southeast and snow, driving rain, high winds and travel snarls to the Northeast.

headline: Car Buyers Lack Interest in Electric Cars, Study Says
abstract: Mainstream car buyers don’t understand that the higher upfront cost of an electric vehicle could be recouped, at least in part, by cost saving on fuel, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: Mainstream car shoppers are simultaneously ignorant and apathetic about plug-in electric vehicles. That’s the essential finding of a new study from the Indiana University School of Public and Environmental Affairs. The study, which is based on a survey of 2,300 adult drivers in 21 large American cities in fall 2011, is a snapshot of driver sentiment 18 months ago.

headline: NBC’s Display of a 30-Shot Gun Magazine Prompts a Police Inquiry
abstract: The Metropolitan Police Department in Washington said they were looking into whether David Gregory broke the law when he showed a high-capacity magazine on “Meet the Press.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Metropolitan Police Department said on Wednesday that it had opened an investigation into whether NBC and David Gregory, the host of “Meet the Press,” broke the law when Mr. Gregory displayed a high-capacity gun magazine during an interview on Sunday with the vice president of the National Rifle Association.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Moving to the cloud isn’t just changing the way businesses work by adding more collaboration. It changes the consulting businesses that actually sell most of the software used by business.

headline: Hidden Passions, Visible in Clothes
abstract: Jacqueline Durran’s costumes for the film “Anna Karenina” draw heavily on the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: THE shock of infidelity among the aristocracy of 19th-century Russia was the theme of Tolstoy’s “Anna Karenina.” So while audacious, it makes a certain kind of sense that the director Joe Wright’s film adaptation (written by Tom Stoppard) would be so willfully unfaithful to the book, let alone to the fashions of the day. Can you believe that Anna? Who does she think she is, flaunting about in all that Chanel jewelry before Coco was even born? Actually, what the lead characters wear in this telling has less to do with Cossack hats and astrakhan than with a style all its own — one based primarily in the extravagantly feminine lines of 1950s couture, reflecting a different period of promise. Think of Balenciaga, not Bolshoi

headline: Pasolini’s Legacy: A Sprawl of Brutality
abstract: The life and work of the Italian filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini is invariably seen through the prism of his gruesome death, but a MoMA retrospective reveals greater complexity.
lead_paragraph: “It is only at our moment of death that our life, to that point undecipherable, ambiguous, suspended, acquires a meaning.” So said the filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini in a 1967 interview. The idea that death defines a person has seldom been more vividly illustrated than in the case of Pasolini, whose extraordinary life and work are invariably seen through the prism of his gruesome end.

She wants to turn a couple into documentaries, a storytelling technique she picked up after recently auditing a film class. After a recent knee surgery, she looks forward to regularly climbing back into her favorite pair of black kitten-heeled Jimmy Choo’s.

headline: Coca Licensing Is a Weapon in Bolivia’s Drug War
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Coca (Plant)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The world’s third-largest cocaine producer has taken an unorthodox approach to controlling the growing of coca that veers markedly from the wider war on narcotics.
lead_paragraph: TODOS SANTOS, Bolivia — There is nothing clandestine about Julián Rojas’s coca plot, which is tucked deep within acres of banana groves. It has been mapped with satellite imagery, cataloged in a government database, cross-referenced with his personal information and checked and rechecked by the local coca growers’ union. The same goes for the plots worked by Mr. Rojas’s neighbors and thousands of other farmers in this torrid region east of the Andes who are licensed by the Bolivian government to grow coca, the plant used to make cocaine.

headline: Art Larsen, Quirky Tennis Champion, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Larsen, whose habit of tapping things earned him the nickname Tappy, won the precursor to the United States Open in 1950 and was inducted into the Tennis Hall of Fame in 1969.
lead_paragraph: Art Larsen, a national tennis champion whose career was marked by eccentricity and cut short by a motor scooter accident that nearly killed him, died on Dec. 7 in San Leandro, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Tapping Into Parisian Luxury
abstract: Originally designed for the Four Seasons Hotel Georges V in Paris, the Perle faucet is studded with crystal “droplets.”
lead_paragraph: Pierre-Yves Rochon originally designed the Perle faucet for the honeymoon suite at the Four Seasons Hotel Georges V in Paris (he was the interior designer who oversaw the property’s renovation). At a glance, it looks elegant but not particularly flashy. Then you notice the crystal “droplets” covering the faucet’s spout and handles. Rarely has so much bling been used without garish effect. “I was thinking about how, when it rains, drops of water attach to glass on a window,” Mr. Rochon said.

headline: George Nelson Pieces Once Again Meet Their Market
abstract: Miniature chests designed in 1954 are being sold by Herman Miller — for the third time.
lead_paragraph: By George, they’re back. So-called Miniature chests, designed for Herman Miller by George Nelson, were introduced in 1954. The dainty pieces, which rest on aluminum bases, stayed in production until 1963 — a time when the company was abandoning residential furniture to focus on its office business. Miller has twice tried to revive the Japanese-inspired goods: once in 1994, when it reintroduced its home collection (they failed to sell), and again in 2005 (the chests were made in Asia, and the poor quality of the craftsmanship ultimately doomed the project). Bringing the chests back “is one of my favorite examples of doing the right thing,” said Ben Watson, creative director of Herman Miller, who is resurrecting a number of forgotten items from the company’s archives. This time around, the chests are made in the United States and have the same hand-fitted drawers as the originals. They are available in a wide range of solid woods with white or black metal pulls. The six-drawer chest is $2,809, the nine-drawer chest, $3,192; the optional base, $418. Information: hermanmiller.com/collection or (616) 654-3000.

headline: An Architectural Model Maker Is Happy to Shrink Your Home
abstract: Michael DelPriore on translating mansions into miniature houses.
lead_paragraph: Michael DelPriore of Ryerson Studio makes free-standing, eerily lifelike models of houses, commercial spaces and city parks. With computer programs like AutoCAD available, you might assume that physical models, built shingle by shingle, are passé. But Mr. DelPriore, 56, still does a brisk business, usually for architects, who use his little buildings in client presentations. Recently he opened his practice to commissions from the general public. Now anyone willing to spend upward of $10,000 can have a doll-size version of a real or imagined dream home. From his workplace in Kingston, N.Y., he spoke to a reporter about translating mansions into minis.

headline: Why Isn’t This Man Smiling?

headline: A Shop That Frames a World of Embroidery
abstract: Coral & Tusk in South Williamsburg sells embroidered napkins, pillows and even gift cards.
lead_paragraph: Coral & Tusk is a fantastical world of embroidery, with creatures and feathers stitched on napkins, pillows and even gift cards. The force behind the thread is Stephanie Housley, 37, a textile designer who started the company five years ago. “I come from a long line of Appalachian women who did loads of hand work,” she said. “My grandma could make a doll or toy out of anything.” There are plenty of dolls in this 1,200-square-foot space in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn. All began as Ms. Housley’s hand drawings, which she scans, then redraws stitch by stitch in a computer file. The files are sent to India to be machine embroidered, but thanks to Ms. Housley’s method, the finished goods are quirky, with perfectly imperfect stitching that makes each piece look hand-made. Prices range from $10 for a felt charm to $230 for a floor cushion. 109 South Fifth Street (Bedford Avenue), Room 401, Brooklyn; coralandtusk.com or (718) 388-4188.

headline: South Africa: Mandela Is Released From the Hospital
abstract: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s former president, was released from the hospital late Wednesday, ending a 19-day hospital stay.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s former president, was released from the hospital late Wednesday, ending a 19-day hospital stay. Mr. Mandela, 94, has been in frail condition for several years. He retired from public life in 2004 and was last seen publicly in 2010, though he receives frequent visits from old friends. He was hospitalized on Dec. 8 and treated for a lung infection; he also had surgery to remove gallstones, government officials said. Mac Maharaj, a spokesman for South Africa’s current president, Jacob Zuma, said that Mr. Mandela would be staying at home in a suburb of Johannesburg and receiving high-level care there. Mr. Mandela was elected in South Africa’s first fully democratic elections in 1994.

headline: Futurism and Policy
abstract: The long-term matters, but what do we know?
lead_paragraph: As regular readers have noticed, I’ve been spending a fair bit of time recently thinking about issues of long-term growth. Why? Partly just as a break from fiscal cliffery and the endless battle against dumb short-run macro. But it’s also true that the long run matters for policy: given how much public debate focuses on things like the state of Social Security or Medicare in the year 2040, it’s definitely worth trying to figure out what we know or don’t know about what our economy might look like in the year 2040.

headline: As Swing Districts Dwindle, Can a Divided House Stand?
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Most members of the House of Representatives come from hyperpartisan districts where they face essentially no threat of losing their seat to the other party — and have little incentive to work across party lines.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, there were 103 members of the House of Representatives elected from what might be called swing districts: those in which the margin in the presidential race was within five percentage points of the national result. But based on an analysis of this year’s presidential returns, I estimate that there are only 35 such Congressional districts remaining, barely a third of the total 20 years ago.

headline: Capturing Climate Change Digitally
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Color', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Photography', 'Photosynthesis', 'Seasons and Months', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: Using two Webcams, scientists discover a high correlation between canopy hue and carbon dioxide uptake in an English forest. As the seasons shift with global warming, they will be able to chart changes in uptake.
lead_paragraph: The changing palette of colors in a forest signals more than the arrival of a new season. For those who know how to look, the colors also reveal how much carbon dioxide the trees are absorbing from the atmosphere during photosynthesis, a new study suggests. By analyzing thousands of photographs of a forest canopy less than 40 miles outside London, the researchers were able to estimate carbon uptake over a two-year period based on the leaves’ hues.

lead_paragraph: The Washington, D.C., police are investigating whether NBC and David Gregory, the anchor of “Meet the Press,” broke the district’s gun laws during an exclusive interview with Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association, Michael S. Schmidt reported. Mr. Gregory brandished an empty magazine that can hold up to 30 bullets while asking Mr. LaPierre what harm would come from banning such equipment. However, in Washington, possessing even an empty magazine is against the law, and, according to the police, NBC asked for permission to display the magazine and was told that it could not. NBC has declined to comment on the matter.

headline: The Music They Made
abstract: A sound collage featuring Whitney Houston, Etta James, Doc Watson and other musicians who died in the past year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fifth annual installment of The Music They Made, a sound collage featuring the musicians who died in the past year. As in past versions, a few (entirely coincidental and random) themes emerged in the mix for 2012. We find a statistically improbable number of divas (Whitney, Etta, Donna, Chavela), two of the greatest soul bassists ever to record — and more sitar than you would expect, all of it sounding as fresh as the day it was played. The artists were young and old, famous and belatedly famous. You can play the full versions of the songs sampled above on Spotify.

In journalism, the flipping of the calendar pages means only one thing: lists. And sports journalism is always right out there at the front of the pack of lists. Want the 12 surprising moments of the year in sports. Check. Breakout athletes of the year? How ‘bout 30 of them? A string of memories from the minds of a dozen or so of The Times’s writers? headline: Monitoring Mandela and the Soul of a Nation
abstract: After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africa’s triumph over apartheid, was discharged from hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians raised fresh questions.
lead_paragraph: PLETTENBERG BAY, South Africa – After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent lung infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africa’s triumph over apartheid, was discharged from a hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians saying he would not return immediately to his remote, rural home at Qunu in the Eastern Cape region raised questions that his family and associates sought to answer a day later.

headline: Steinway Decides to Keep the Keys of Its Kingdom
abstract: The owner of the piano maker Steinway & Sons says it is no longer up for sale.
lead_paragraph: The corporate owner of the piano maker Steinway & Sons says the company is no longer up for sale. In a news release issued Wednesday, the company – Steinway Musical Instruments Inc. – said that in July 2011 it began studying the possible sale of itself or its band instrument division. Several expressions of interest came in but the company decided against them. It also said it was shutting down a possible deal to sell the band unit to an investor group led by two board members.

headline: A ‘Sexual Musical,’ Now Middle-Aged

lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago The New York Times reported that the sexually frank 1974 musical revue “Let My People Come” will be revived this winter for eight Fridays at the Underground, a bar just south of Columbia University. According to the producer, John Forslund, the original lyrics and sketches will be revised and updated, and while the revival will feature “far less nudity than the original,” there will still be ample opportunity to see cast members, both male and female, in the buff.

In this scene, Boy Willie, played by Brandon J. Dirden, explains why he wants to sell the instrument, much against the wishes of his sister. Eating dinner at nearby tables were groups of uniformed workers who were catering an event that night. It was only a few years ago that Mr. Dirden wore the same ultramarine outfit, in the exact same building, dreaming of the stage instead of treading it.

headline: Ingrates and Clumsy Guests
abstract: What to do about grandchildren who never express thanks for gifts, and a guest who breaks vintage Champagne glasses.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have nine grandchildren ranging in age from 10 to 22. They are all wonderful. We live at a distance; so every year, we send each of them Christmas and birthday gifts. We love shopping for them and try to choose things they will enjoy. But we never hear a peep back. Not a single thank you. Ever. It’s as if the gifts disappear into a black hole. But isn’t commanding thanks awkward?

headline: South Asia Through Modernist Binoculars
abstract: “Radical Terrain” at the Rubin Museum of Art, the third and last in the Modernist Art From India series, looks at landscapes across the years and styles.
lead_paragraph: “Radical Terrain” is the last of three small, carefully judged, back-to-back exhibitions in the series Modernist Art From India at the Rubin Museum of Art. How lucky New York is to have a museum willing and able to do such shows, unfamiliar in content but large with history. If we relied on our big institutions, which so often spoon-feed us what we already know, we would be unaware that India even had a modern art, never mind one of variety and complexity.

abstract: The Scandinavian tradition of the smorrebrod, or open-face sandwich, has been rebooted.
lead_paragraph: When the original Aamanns opened in Copenhagen in 2006, locals embraced it as an invigorating reboot of an endangered food tradition: the smorrebrod, or open-face sandwich. As Mile End in Brooklyn has reinvented the Jewish deli, and Parm in NoLIta reworked the Italian-American sandwich shop, Aamanns took up an institution that had become neglected and synthetic, re-engineered it with traditional methods and good ingredients, then served it up proudly with a side of modern design.

headline: Unwrapped After Christmas, a Tenor
abstract: At the end of his Metropolitan Opera debut on Wednesday evening the tenor Bryan Hymel drew a prolonged ovation for his performance in “Les Troyens.”
lead_paragraph: When, close to midnight on Wednesday, the American tenor Bryan Hymel appeared for his curtain call at the end of the Metropolitan Opera’s performance of the Berlioz epic “Les Troyens,” the entire cast lined up onstage and applauded along with the audience during the prolonged ovation. This gesture from the singers seemed not just a welcoming tribute to a young colleague making his Met debut on short notice in the daunting role of Aeneas. The cast members, especially the beaming mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, who was again a vocally sumptuous and alluring Dido, seemed genuinely grateful to Mr. Hymel for saving the day by giving an impassioned and confident performance of a heroic role that dominates this formidable French opera.

headline: Underbelly of a Brotherhood

And though “Allegiance” dips a toe in that water, this well-acted debut feature from Michael Connors (a former Army captain) is too limited in ambition and scope to satisfy our expectations.

headline: Vying for Fluency in Many Languages
abstract: The work of Trisha Baga — her video projections, paintings, sculptures and scattered objects — is being showcased at two museums and a gallery in New York.
lead_paragraph: Trisha Baga must feel as if she had died and gone to heaven. Her poetically frowzy installations of video projections, paintings, sculptures and scattered objects can be seen now in two New York museums — in a lobby gallery solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art and in “New Pictures of Common Objects,” a group show at MoMA PS 1 — and she has a sprawling exhibition at Greene Naftali in Chelsea, a gallery admired by the art world cognoscenti. A New York resident, she also had solo shows in London and Munich in 2012. And she is only 27.

headline: Suburban Sprawl
abstract: Edie Middlestein, the larger-than-life protagonist of Jami Attenberg’s new novel, is killing herself by overeating, and her family can’t bear to watch.
lead_paragraph: There’s a touching paradox in the first chapter of Jami Attenberg’s caustic, entertaining and bighearted new novel, “The Middlesteins.” Edie, 5 years old and 62 pounds, is already too solid, in her mother’s estimation, too big for her age. But how can her mother not feed her, when she and her husband feel that food is “made of love, and love . . . made of food”? How can these parents deny Edie life-giving nourishment when Edie’s father, a Jewish immigrant from Ukraine, nearly starved on his journey to Chicago and has never been able to get enough to eat since? Even though it’s clear that young Edie suffers under her own weight — she huffs and puffs up the stairs “like someone’s gassy old uncle after a meal” — her mother can’t refuse her the liverwurst and rye bread she loves. This is a Jewish mother after all, and those of us who’ve had one know that the message, when it comes to food, is always have a little more. It’s an attitude that comes not just from love, but also from fear; a history fraught with disaster and hunger gives rise to the feeling that one must always be prepared. Therefore, bubbeleh, have another matzo ball.

headline: 36 Hours in El Paso, Tex.
abstract: Big views, a lively club scene, a revived theater and even local wineries await visitors to this border city.
lead_paragraph: SITUATED at the intersection of Texas, Mexico and New Mexico, El Paso is a city with a distinct flavor. It juxtaposes authentic Mexican culture with a growing hipster scene, and though it’s one of the largest cities in Texas, it still often ends up as a mere pit stop on I-10. Once the storied heart of the Old West (and playground of Billy the Kid), El Paso has recently gained much of the big-city feel of its neighbor across the border, Ciudad Juárez. It has come into its own with new theaters, restaurants and nightclubs, many of them transplants from its sister city, the epicenter of the Mexican drug war.

His breakout work, “Twenty-Six Gasoline Stations,” was a photo essay that looked more like a user’s manual; it set the tone for much Conceptual art and was followed by other, equally deadpan compendiums (“Every Building on the Sunset Strip,” “Nine Swimming Pools”).

headline: Jamming Ritually
abstract: The fans sing along and forget their cares and daily routines when the Disco Biscuits come to town.
lead_paragraph: “Cascade to the rhythms, open up your mind/Cut loose from the furious snakes, unwind,” the Disco Biscuits sang in “Digital Buddha,” a song that popped up as excerpts in both their sets on Wednesday night at the Best Buy Theater. That’s as good a mission statement as any for this long-running jam band. The Disco Biscuits were starting their regular year-end stint in New York City, including three more Best Buy shows and New Year’s Eve at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. It’s a familiar and welcome ritual, complete with lasers flashing grids and canopies over the dancing crowd and videos traversing sci-fi geography as the band stays busy with its instruments. The musicians have to be listening to one another intently; often, they stay in the shadows.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Schools Accused of Discrimination
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Organized Labor', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The lawsuit alleges that the district selects schools with a high percentage of African-American teachers for turnaround, while taking no action against other similarly performing schools.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Teachers Union filed a suit in federal court on Wednesday charging that the Chicago Public Schools discriminate against African-American teachers and staff members in selecting schools for “turnaround,” in which faculty and staff members are dismissed and replaced. The lawsuit alleges that the district selects schools with a high percentage of African-American teachers for turnaround, while taking no action against other similarly performing schools. More than half the 347 tenured teachers who were terminated by the district in recent turnarounds were African-American, the lawsuit said, although black teachers make up less than 30 percent of the district’s tenured teaching staff.

abstract: We’ve been hearing a lot about the short-run projections for our economy. But when it comes to the prospects for the long run, we know less than we think.
lead_paragraph: The great bulk of the economic commentary you read in the papers is focused on the short run: the effects of the “fiscal cliff” on U.S. recovery, the stresses on the euro, Japan’s latest attempt to break out of deflation. This focus is understandable, since one global depression can ruin your whole day. But our current travails will eventually end. What do we know about the prospects for long-run prosperity?

lead_paragraph: Representative Edward J. Markey will run for Senator John Kerry’s vacant seat, The Boston Globe reported Thursday. Mr. Markey, a Democrat, is one of the first to bid for the seat since President Obama nominated Mr. Kerry last week to be secretary of state. First elected to Congress in 1976, Mr. Markey, 66, has been particularly active on environmental issues. He co-sponsored the climate bill to reduce heat-trapping gases that passed the House in 2009 before stalling. Mr. Kerry is expected to be confirmed, opening up the seat he has held for 28 years. The special election is expected to take place in May or June.
