Revkin suggests that the film “may not satisfy many people,” not least because its main characters “too often border on caricature.” For those interested in learning more, check out this video of a Times Talks event in which the paper interviewed Mr. Van Sant and Matt Damon, who stars in the film. And this feature focuses on Mr. Damon’s screenwriting collaboration with John Krasinski. [The New York Times]

headline: The Wayward Essay
abstract: Three new collections examine literature, culture high and low, and modern living.
lead_paragraph: In its quality of attention and faith in the salvific power of the right words in the right order, the essay resembles nothing so much as a secular prayer. That, at least, was the original point. The essay has proved wayward, which has been the great secret to its longevity.

headline: Bouquet Garni
abstract: Does the term “bouquet garni” intimidate you? Don’t let it! Melissa Clark shows why.
lead_paragraph: Does the term “bouquet garni” intimidate you? Don’t let it! Melissa Clark shows why.

headline: Basic Cooking Starts With Stew
abstract: Throwing everything into a pot, adding water and letting it stew is one of the most basic ways to cook.
lead_paragraph: IF you read enough 19th-century novels, you’re likely to run into the description of the ever-bubbling stew pot. It’s the caldron at the ready to feed a famished family, a parade of visitors, the hungry vicar on his afternoon stroll or whatever other literary stereotype comes to call.

headline: The Music They Made, Spotified
abstract: A playlist of songs by musicians who died this year.
lead_paragraph: For the past five years, I’ve been putting together a video feature to accompany the magazine’s annual The Lives They Lived issue. The sound collage, called The Music They Made, features samplings of songs from musicians who died in the past year. If you want to play the full songs featured in this year’s video — and why wouldn’t you! — you can use the Spotify playlist below.

headline: Handled With Care
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: What becomes of the personal libraries scholars leave behind?
lead_paragraph: I have been here many times before. Not to this particular library but to others like it. Some have been on college campuses, others in private homes. Some have sprawled through many rooms, including the bathroom; others were confined to a single space. One had no windows; another overlooked a lake. Most were crowded. All were dusty.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ZONA: A Book About a Film About a Journey to a Room,  by Geoff Dyer. (Vintage, $15.) In Andrei Tarkovsky’s 1979 film “Stalker,” two Russian intellectuals are guided by a tormented fool to a post-apocalyptic government-­restricted area called the Zone. (Within the Zone lies the so-called Room, where innermost hopes are revealed and even realized.) In Dyer’s vivid analysis, he watches himself watching the film, contemplating his own desires and what he considers to be “the most distinctive feature of Tarkovsky’s art: the sense of beauty as force.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MARMEE & LOUISA: The Untold Story of Louisa May Alcott and Her Mother,  by Eve LaPlante. (Free Press, $26.) Alcott’s toiling, much put-upon mother was the complex core of “Little Women”; LaPlante’s dual biography attempts to save her from invisibility.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Siri Hustvedt has long explored the intersections and interplay of science and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Siri Hustvedt has long explored the intersections and interplay of science and storytelling. Her study of neuropsychoanalysis in “The Shaking Woman; Or, A History of My Nerves” was inspired by Montaigne, and her novels are peopled by deeply philosophical painters, poets and psychiatrists. At the moment, she’s just completed another novel and is preparing a lecture on hysteria to present to a neurophysiology conference.

headline: The Rope, the App and Van Gogh in Amsterdam
abstract: Consolation for disappointed art lovers who arrive in this city and realize that the Van Gogh museum is closed for renovation: Follow the red braided rope.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM—Consolation for disappointed art lovers who arrive in this city and realize that the Van Gogh Museum is closed for renovation: Follow the red braided rope.

headline: Shock to the Senses
abstract: Oliver Sacks explores the power of hallucinations through first-person accounts.
lead_paragraph: Since his first extraordinary work, “Migraine,” was published in 1970, the neurologist Oliver Sacks has been writing a particular kind of medical literature. His detailed explications of a single patient’s symptoms, his emphasis on the subjective experience of illness, his willingness to share stories from his own life and his references to medical texts from earlier centuries are not only atypical of how most neurologists work today, they defy the status quo. And yet, Sacks’ work is part of a long tradition of descriptive, narrative, case-oriented medical writing he has himself called “romantic.”

headline: This Week’s Movies: Dec. 28
abstract: Times critics look at “Les Misérables,” “Django Unchained” and “West of Memphis.”
lead_paragraph: This week, Times critics look at Tom Hooper’s “Les Misérables,” Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” and the documentary “West of Memphis.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Approaching the Fiscal Deadline
abstract: TimesCast: Amid a flurry of activity, time is running out for a deal on taxes. | Keeping Ireland green with carbon taxes. | How doping came to the equestrian world.
lead_paragraph: TimesCast: Amid a flurry of activity, time is running out for a deal on taxes. | Keeping Ireland green with carbon taxes. | How doping came to the equestrian world.

headline: Strays
abstract: Desperately searching for a missing cat, Peter Trachtenberg ponders the mysteries of relationships — both human and animal.
lead_paragraph: “Not many things are better than a kitten.”

headline: Crimes Without Punishment
abstract: José Saramago’s first major novel, about several generations of a Portuguese family, has finally been translated into English.
lead_paragraph: It might seem surprising that only now — 14 years after José Saramago won the Nobel Prize in Literature and two years after his death — is this major novel, first published in Portugal in 1980, appearing in English translation. Then again, politically radical fiction is often a tough sell in our market. While Saramago was an outspoken member of his country’s Communist Party (“Marx was never so right as now,” he remarked at the outset of the recent global financial crisis), in his best-known work his politics are embedded in allegory or fantasy, allowing readers to view them as loosely humanist or to overlook them entirely. Not so with “Raised From the Ground.” Still, what’s apt to strike readers of this book is not so much that it’s radical but that it’s topical. “What kind of world,” it asks, “divides into those who make a profession of idleness and those who want work but can’t get it”? The novel even ends with descriptions of a kind of Occupy movement — though one with higher stakes — as peasants take over farm estates whose owners have relocated rather than pay their workers a living wage.

headline: Must Win
abstract: In a town deep in the Florida Everglades, high school football is seen as the only means of escape.
lead_paragraph: The “season with a high school team” genre has proved particularly durable since Buzz (then H. G.) Bis­singer’s “Friday Night Lights” became the touchstone some two decades ago, generating its own branded feature film, television series and follow-up e-book. It set the standard for countless similar tales, most notably Michael Lewis’s “Blind Side” and the Academy Award-­winning documentary “Undefeated.”

headline: Coming of Age in Rochester
abstract: In this debut novel, a group of friends in the late 1990s roam their dying city.
lead_paragraph: In his first novel, “Maverick Jetpants in the City of Quality,” the Rochester native Bill Peters depicts his hometown as a city in decay, haunted by past glories and racked by vandalism. The narrator, Nate, is about to turn 21. He lives with his mother and her current squeeze, “Fake Dad No. 3.” Mostly, he drifts and looks for work in a somewhat desultory fashion. His ambition, such as it is, is to join his best friend, Necro (né Andrea: “Everyone in Rochester is Italians”), at Kodak, the firm that made Rochester famous. But it’s 1999, and the prospects are bleak for old-fashioned companies like Kodak and for Rust Belt cities like Rochester, whose nickname hasn’t been “City of Quality” since the 1960s.

headline: Stage Manager
abstract: A biography of Thornton Wilder, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and novelist.
lead_paragraph: Writing in his memoirs, Tennessee Williams remembers paying a visit to Thornton Wilder after the New Haven opening of “A Streetcar Named Desire” (1947). Wilder — then at the height of his eminence, having won Pulitzers for both “Our Town” (1938) and “The Skin of Our Teeth” (1942) — dismissed Williams’s latest effort with the air of one “delivering a papal bull,” as Williams put it. A “lady” like Stella, Wilder declared, would never marry a “vulgarian” like Stanley Kowalski. “This character,” Williams reflected of his colleague at the time, “has never had a good lay.” With the perspicacity that would lead him to become, arguably, our greatest postwar playwright, Williams had pretty much hit the nail on the head.

headline: They Get Around
abstract: A history of voyages around the world, starting in the 16th century.
lead_paragraph: Joyce E. Chaplin faces a challenge in “Round About the Earth.” She’s written a 535-page history of circumnavigation, from the voyages of Ferdinand Magellan (1519-22) to the Dutch teenager Laura Dekker (2011-12), which is to say the history of a highly conceptual and antiquated exploit. We all sense that encircling the planet is — or was — quite a feat. But a feat of what, exactly? Today it’s possible to book a round-the-world air ticket simply by tapping a smartphone. After Magellan’s expedition did it the first time, one wonders if there’s any sense in recording all those who came after.

headline: Soviet Dreams
abstract: An orphaned heroine is an emblem of 1930s Moscow.
lead_paragraph: A superstitious tradition, meant to protect children from vengeful spirits, persists in Spanish-­speaking countries — naming babies for the opposite qualities that benevolent parents might be expected to wish upon their offspring. Parents who want their daughters to lead joyful lives might name them Dolores (“sorrows,” “pain”) or Soledad (“loneliness”). A boy might be called Tristán (“the sad one”). But Andrey Platonov, the beleaguered Soviet writer who died in 1951 of tuberculosis (contracted from his son, who had been infected in Stalin’s gulag), seems to have pursued the reverse strategy when, in the mid-1930s, he began work on an allegorical novella entitled “Happy Moscow,” to see whether it was “objectively impossible” to write a bona fide “Soviet” work of fiction.

headline: Rogues’ Gallery
abstract: This novel’s heroine gets entangled in the world of art forgery.
lead_paragraph: Isabella Stewart Gardner was decidedly eccentric. She walked lions, not dogs; drank beer, not sherry; and bathed opposite improving maxims rather than wallpaper patterns. (Some were more ominous than others: “Secret of two, secret of God; secret of three, secret of all.”) Such behavior made her reputation, though it was her magnificent art collection, assembled with the help of the young Bernard Berenson, that won her lasting fame. In 1903, Gardner opened her Venetian-style gallery — then called Fenway Court — to the city of Boston, enriching generations to come.

headline: Secret Loves
abstract: Stories that shed light on expectation and disappointment.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the title story in “My Escapee,” Corinna Vallianatos’s taut and delicate collection, the resident cat at a rest home, the pet meant to comfort and slow “the hammering of an unhealthy heart,” dies in the lobby. White heads gather around Algebra’s corpse to sigh and accuse. One woman collapses and is denounced as a fake. “Don’t pretend you loved that cat,” Ginny, the main character, says. To which the woman’s husband replies: “She loved the thought of her. She truly did.”

headline: A World of Color
abstract: A biography looks at Titian against the backdrop of Venice’s mighty commercial empire.
lead_paragraph: If only Titian had left us the scathing letters and soul-baring sonnets of his contemporary Michelangelo, whose image as a tortured genius has enchanted biographers since the Renaissance. In their place we have just a smattering of Titian’s business correspondence and a few official statements. His friendship with the ferocious satirist and pornographer Pietro Aretino is the stuff of speculation. So too are his relations with the models and companions who appear in masterpieces like the “Venus of Urbino,” which transforms one of Venice’s highest-priced courtesans into a goddess of love, taunting us with her half-smile while resting her hand in a forbidden realm.

headline: Destination: Wellness
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Medicine and Health', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Spas']
abstract: Wellness retreats, wellness rooms, wellness resorts, wellness weekends. Answering the insistent call of wellness tourism and trying to figure out what it all is.
lead_paragraph: SO I’m sitting in a hotel in upstate New York with my feet in a bucket of warm water charged with electricity when it suddenly hits me that maybe “getting well” wasn’t going to be as much fun as I thought it was going to be.

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Medicine and Health', 'Spas', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine']

lead_paragraph: Not only is wellness a tough one to define, but its terminology can be equally impossible to interpret. Here is a helpful rundown of some of the terms, attractions and techniques in the land of the well.

abstract: The social wrasse is being hit from all directions: from the top by humans and from the bottom by the invasive lionfish.
lead_paragraph: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on the social wrasse, one of the world’s most endangered fish.

headline: For Some, the Slopes. For Her, the Cheese.
abstract: On a trip to the mountains in southeastern France, the author finds that soft powder can’t compete with silky cheese.
lead_paragraph: LET’S get this straight up front: I’m no skier. But when my French sister-in-law and her athletic husband, who hails from Grenoble (he basically grew up on skis), suggested we meet up for a slopeside family reunion in France last January, I was just as elated as my ski-obsessed husband and children.

headline: Sichuan’s Tibetan Corner, Outside of Time
abstract: Remote Tagong, one of the highest towns in the world, has a slow-paced existence that revolves around a Tibetan monastery.
lead_paragraph: HIGH on the Tibetan plateau, a few dozen red-robed monks of the Lhagang Monastery sat facing one another, rocking back and forth as they chanted with faces turned upward, to the heavens.

headline: Restaurant Report: Belcampo Meat Co. in Larkspur, Calif.
abstract: This new restaurant and butcher shop 30 minutes north of San Francisco sells and serves meat sourced exclusively from its 10,000-acre farm upstate.
lead_paragraph: Though rich in dining options, San Francisco is not quite as besotted with all things meat as other major American cities. New York has the Spotted Pig and Swine; Los Angeles has Animal and Lazy Ox. But the Bay Area, perhaps still under the thrall of flower children grown gray, has yet to welcome a meat temple of its own. Belcampo Meat Co., a restaurant and butcher shop that opened in November in Larkspur, 30 minutes north of San Francisco, aims to change that.

headline: Exit Lines
abstract: Last words have an almost mystical significance in both Eastern and Western cultures, in part because they hold out the possibility of revealing a deep insight or lifting a veil on life’s meaning.
lead_paragraph: MY father spoke to his college roommate every day for 50 years. Though the two lived in different states, 800 miles apart, they were business partners, sounding boards and friends. Then one day my father called and his friend wasn’t there. He had died the night before of a terminal illness, which he had never told my father about. The two never said goodbye.

lead_paragraph: This was the week we were supposed to get a grand bargain. Instead, we got an undignified stalemate.

headline: The Future of Your Taxes
abstract: Bucks readers weigh in on the long-term fiscal outlook in the United States and how (or if) they’re planning for a future of higher taxes or fewer benefits.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Your Money column, I tried to make the case that the current brinkmanship in Washington is a bit of a sideshow to a long-term problem that nobody much wants to discuss: we haven’t come close to charging ourselves enough money to pay for all of the things we’ve promised to one another.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Ayana Mathis, whose novel, “The Twelve Tribes of Hattie,” is at No. 10 on the hardcover fiction list, has become obsessed with a passage from “The Sound and the Fury.”
lead_paragraph: QUOTING QUENTIN:  Ayana Mathis’s first novel, “The Twelve Tribes of Hattie” — reviewed in next week’s issue, and already anointed by Oprah Winfrey — holds steady at No. 10 in its second week on the hardcover fiction list. Mathis told me recently that she’s become obsessed with Faulkner, especially with this passage from “The Sound and the Fury,” in which Quentin, considering suicide in Boston, sees a black man on the bus and has a moment of fleeting insight: “They come into white people’s lives like that in sudden sharp black trickles that isolate white facts for an instant in unarguable truth like under a microscope; the rest of the time just voices that laugh when you see nothing to laugh at, tears when no reason for tears. They will bet on the odd or even number of mourners at a funeral. A brothel full of them in Memphis went into a religious trance ran naked into the street. It took three policemen to subdue one of them. Yes Jesus O good man Jesus O that good man.”

headline: Chronicling Ballet’s Pain and Passion

headline: Giving History a Bel Canto Twist
abstract: Joyce DiDonato, an experienced purveyor of tortured bel canto and baroque heroines, prepares for the title role in “Maria Stuarda,” at the Met, directed by David McVicar.
lead_paragraph: WEARING a black dress and clutching a Bible, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato walked stiffly on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera during a recent rehearsal for Donizetti’s “Maria Stuarda,” which will open on New Year’s Eve and be broadcast Live in HD on Jan. 19. First kneeling, then standing, her aching movements in the final scenes reflected the title character’s physical demise after years of imprisonment.

To be introduced at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit and offered for sale in the spring, the car comes with the blessing of Berry Gordy Jr., Motown’s founder. Mr. Gordy also appears in a new television advertisement publicizing the Motown edition and promoting “Motown: The Musical,” a production based on Mr. Gordy’s life set to open on Broadway in April.

headline: Mad Science and Pop Hits
abstract: The critics Jon Pareles, Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the year’s biggest pop trends, and those that will be reshaping the genre for years to come.
lead_paragraph: FOR pop 2012 was a year of rewired consensus. A year in which Taylor Swift finally accepted her pop-star birthright, waved casually at country and then bravely entered dubstep. A year in which the critic-consensus R&B star was Frank Ocean, who spent most of the year spilling out feelings and then averting his eyes. A year in which Carly Rae Jepsen suffocated the mainstream and then evaporated. A year in which Psy, a B-list Korean pop star, unleashed a video (and song) that became the first to surpass one billion views on YouTube, redefining virality in pop along the way.

abstract: At a time when more Americans are without religious affiliation, the “nones,” as they are known, seem conspicuous in their absence from recent scenes of grief and mourning.
lead_paragraph: Since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, the tableau of grief and mourning has provided a vivid lesson in the religious variety of America. An interfaith service featuring President Obama, held two days after Adam Lanza killed 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut, included clergy members and representatives from Baha’i, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim and both mainline and evangelical Protestant congregations.

headline: Senate Leaders Set to Work on a Last-Minute Tax Agreement

abstract: After weeks of fruitless negotiations with the House speaker, John A. Boehner, President Obama turned to Senator Harry Reid and Senator Mitch McConnell to try to avert a fiscal crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the urging of President Obama, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate set to work Friday night to assemble a last-minute tax deal that could pass both chambers of Congress and avert large tax increases and budget cuts next year, or at least stop the worst of the economic punch from landing beginning Jan. 1.

headline: For a Great Salad, Pretend You Are French
abstract: The key to a great Gallic salad? A well-made vinaigrette dressing.
lead_paragraph: THERE must be something deep within the collective French psyche that intuitively grasps how to create a good salad. How else can you explain the fact that you can get an excellent one just about anywhere in France? A meal without salad, as a first course or to refresh the palate after the main course, is nearly unheard of there.

headline: Five Years Later, Some Countries Still Lag
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Five years ago, in the fourth quarter of 2007, the United States economy peaked before what became known as the Great Recession set in. Some countries, China and Australia among them, never saw their economies decline, but most did, and some of the largest economies remain smaller than they were in 2007. The world economy — measured by total gross domestic product in 56 countries for which data are available — is now about 6 percent larger. But share prices have yet to fully recover in most countries.

abstract: Mrs. Harris’s 1981 murder trial galvanized a nation mulling feminist perspectives with its story of vengeance by an aging woman scorned.

headline: Dealing With Uncertainty
abstract: Bucks readers discuss what they’re doing with their investments, given the continuing uncertainties about the economy.
lead_paragraph: As Paul Sullivan writes in this week’s Wealth Matters column, 2012 was a year of uncertainty, and it looks as if 2013 will at least begin that way. And with investors’ memories of the collapse in equity markets in 2008 still fresh, financial advisers say they have spent much of the last 12 months trying to get their clients to let go of their fears.

headline: Summing Up a Year in Pictures
abstract: A photographic presentation, online and in Sunday’s paper, of the stories of 2012.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, The New York Times brought its print and online readers comprehensive, immediate and intimate visual coverage of news around the world and in the New York region, including: brutal urban warfare in Syria, Hurricane Sandy’s destruction, a hard-fought election victory for President Obama and the mass murder of adults and children at a Connecticut elementary school.

The eight-day Jewish December holiday that ended recently is Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights. Passover and its Seder, the traditional meal and retelling of the exodus from Egypt? That’s in the spring.

lead_paragraph: Jack Kirby, who died in 1994, was one of the comic-book industry’s most famous creators. Much has been written about his contributions to Marvel Comics — he worked with Stan Lee in creating the Fantastic Four, the Incredible Hulk and the X-Men, among others — and the continuing legal battle in which Mr. Kirby’s family is trying to win the copyright to those figures.

lead_paragraph: All David Shuffler wanted to do when he was 14 years old was play basketball on the street and go to Starlight Park – which despite its name was a dimly lighted, dusty sliver tucked between the Bronx River and the Sheridan Expressway.

lead_paragraph: I appreciated Glamour’s latest cover story, “500 Ways to Just Be Yourself,” styled with verve by Anne Christensen on the adorable Anne Hathaway. But who’s counting?

headline: Dreams of ‘Open’ Everything
abstract: GitHub, a successful young company for open-source software projects, has $100 million in funding and a long-term dream of taking its approach outside engineering and into all business, even government. Other Silicon Valley companies share the attitude.
lead_paragraph: Software is not merely about automating every aspect of our lives anymore. Some of its makers want to change the way we all interact, spreading their supposed egalitarian excellence.

headline: Union and N.H.L. to Discuss New Offer
abstract: The latest proposal, which came after two weeks of silence between the N.H.L. and the players’ association, could reflect an effort to settle the lockout and save the season.
lead_paragraph: After owners made an extensive new proposal, the N.H.L. and the players union agreed Friday to resume bargaining this weekend in a bid to end the 104-day lockout and salvage the 2012-13 season.

headline: Bouquet Garni Basics
abstract: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make a bouquet garni, a bouquet of herbs that adds flavor to a soup, stew or pot of beans.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video shows how to make a bouquet garni, which basically means tying up a little bouquet of herbs with kitchen string and throwing them in bubbling liquid — a stew or soup (like Scotch broth), or a pot of beans or grains. The herbs give up their flavor to the pot, and tying them up makes them easy to dispose of so you don’t need to pick out thyme branches as you eat.

headline: Childhood, Uncensored
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Lauren Myracle’s novels take an uncensored look at the lives of children and teenagers that has won her plenty of young fans and lots of criticism from some older readers.
lead_paragraph: LAUREN MYRACLE has been called Satan, a pedophile, and a corrupter of youth, yet her series of books about a trio of Atlanta teenagers, written entirely in text messages, has sold a total of 1.5 million copies. She has been hailed as this generation’s Judy Blume for her candor, but outraged parents have lobbied to ban her books, which tackle topics like erections, that awkward first bra purchase, and clueless flirting that leads one sophomore to have a hot-tub encounter with a teacher. (Spoiler: her BFFs rescue her in the nick of time.)

headline: Frustrations With Robocalls, and the Joy of the Ordinary
abstract: The writer looks at the issues of 2012 that stirred reader passions, and found that she got the most responses to one column on robocalls and another on redefining success.
lead_paragraph: I LOVE going back over the year and looking at readers’ responses to my column. It provides a perspective I lack when I’m focusing on one column at a time and receiving comments piecemeal.

abstract: Combining growth of gross domestic product and recovery of national stock markets as a gauge, the United States has performed better than most nations since 2007.

headline: Art Insurance Losses from Hurricane Sandy May Reach $500 Million
abstract: Insurance industry estimates suggest that insurance losses for flooded galleries and ruined art after Hurricane Sandy may come to as much as $500 million – or the rough equivalent of what the art insurance business takes in each year, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Two months after Hurricane Sandy caused severe flooding in many Chelsea galleries, the bill for the art world’s recovery is shaping up to be hefty. By mid-November, AXA Art Insurance, one of the largest art insurers, estimated that it would be paying out $40 million, and a Reuters report last week quoted industry estimates suggesting that insurance losses for flooded galleries and ruined art may come to as much as $500 million – or the rough equivalent of what the art insurance business takes in each year. That would amount to the largest loss the art world and its insurers have ever sustained.

headline: Stretching Trucks’ Mileage
abstract: The TrailerTail developed by ATDynamics was designed to reduce the aerodynamic drag generated at the rear of trailers.
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS you’ve recently been surprised to drive up behind an 18-wheeler on the Interstate whose trailer doors appeared to be ajar. No need to be alarmed: what you saw was probably one of several attempts at improving the fuel economy of long-haul trucks.

The slight, gentle architect with a flair for rescuing decaying buildings was a fixture in this onetime center of the city’s art world. Even well into the 1980s, as SoHo began morphing into an outdoor shopping mall, his was a familiar face.

headline: Pakistan to Lift YouTube Ban, as a Viral Video Star Is Welcomed Home
abstract: Pakistan’s interior minister announced on Friday that the country plans to lift a ban on YouTube, one day after a Pakistani viral-video star was lauded by fans.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s interior minister announced on Friday that the country plans to lift a ban on YouTube that was imposed in September, following violent protests over a crude anti-Islam film uploaded to the site by an Egyptian-American. The government acted to rescind the ban just hours after the star of one of the year’s most popular YouTube videos, a singing Pakistani fishmonger, was given a hero’s welcome upon his return to the city of Lahore from Britain.

lead_paragraph: IT’S a good bet that when Michelle Obama accompanies her husband to his inaugural next month, and later the round of balls, she will not be thinking of her critics or those White House aides who once fretted about the political fallout from her designer fashion. That’s because she has turned the seemingly frivolous into political capital of her own.

The five-story brick and limestone house, which they bought for $12.85 million in 2010, sold for $21.45 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Watching Dancers Grow, as Cultivated by a Daredevil
abstract: A program this month at the Paris Opera Ballet brings to mind how William Forsythe’s “In the Middle, Somewhat Elevated” began a new era for ballet 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On May 22, 1987, two female dancers in green leotards and black tights stood on the empty stage of the Palais Garnier here, in a pool of light. The women, hands on hips, each swiveled a point-shoe tip on the floor idly and glanced up at two golden cherries inexplicably suspended over their heads. Then one gave an almost imperceptible shrug and walked off, and the other began to dance, suddenly galvanized by a rhythmic, electronic crash of sound.

abstract: Beyond its traditional merlot, Long Island’s wine industry has an expanding range of single-grape and blended reds and whites, rosés and sparkling wines.
lead_paragraph: As the Long Island wine industry enters its 40th year in 2013, the conventional notion that merlot is its defining specialty continues to be strongly challenged.

headline: TV Where Too Far Is Never Far Enough
abstract: Was 2012 a nadir for reality television? Can the offerings possibly get any worse? Has the genre become too ludicrous to parody?
lead_paragraph: “Our big dilemma going into the end of the season is whether we may actually be pushing the envelope too far,” says the protagonist of “The King of Pain,” one of 2012’s most enjoyable novels for anyone who is a fan of reality television or simply likes monitoring the continuing train wreck that its more tawdry regions have become.

headline: Full of Hospitality, and Exuberantly Greek
abstract: Pontos Taverna, in downtown Norwalk, is as warm, welcoming and homey as the food, which has an authentic flair, big portions and reasonable prices.
lead_paragraph: PONTOS TAVERNA, just half a block from the Garden Cinema in downtown Norwalk, is an old-fashioned Greek place, with a family atmosphere that comes straight from the owner. Nikolaos Kiriakidis opened Pontos in April of 2011 with his seven siblings; his father, Teddy (the chef); and his mother, Anna (the hostess). “We worked in other restaurants,” Nikolaos Kiriakidis explained, “and finally decided to open our own.”

headline: Main Facade Intact at Ladies’ Mile Landmark, but Damage Is Serious
abstract: The former O’Neill & Company dry-goods emporium building on the Avenue of the Americas looks much the same, though a load-bearing column collapsed and many zigzag cracks were evident.
lead_paragraph: News of a facade collapse on Tuesday at the former O’Neill & Company dry-goods emporium conjured images of significant architectural loss. This gleaming white facade on the Avenue of the Americas, from 20th to 21st Streets, is among the largest single expanses of ornamental cast-iron in the city. Its signature elements — gold-colored beehive domes at each corner turret and Hugh O’Neill’s name boldly inscribed in the pediment — make it especially memorable.

headline: For 12 Days of Christmas, 6 ‘Brandenburg’ Concertos
abstract: Three of the “Brandenburg” Concertos were included in a single program as part of the Twelfth Night Festival from Trinity Church.
lead_paragraph: Almost a year ago Trinity Church announced that it would cut back its remarkable music program. The offerings and their quality had blossomed since the 2010 arrival of Julian Wachner as director of music and arts, but they did not come cheap.

headline: A Taste of Americana, Off the Bone and on Tap
abstract: Holy Smoke has over 30 craft beers on tap and slow cooks its meats in the basement — many patrons take the smell of barbecue smoke home in their clothing.
lead_paragraph: When I heard about Holy Smoke, a barbecue spot in Mahopac, from three people — all food connoisseurs — in four days, I knew I needed to check it out. Though it has been around since 2004, it is on a sleepy residential strip of Route 6N, and so has remained somewhat of a secret. Not among local residents, however. And not among the craft beer and barbecue lovers who visit from around the New York City area. Holy Smoke was rocking the first time I went. Diners enter through the no-fuss bar, where, on that visit, people were lined up and crowding around the room’s high-top tables. The proprietor, Chris Casino, was pouring the brews — Holy Smoke has 30 taps devoted to such delicious and artfully named drafts as Tröegs Mad Elf and Southern Tier Old Man Winter, and an impressive lineup of bourbons as well. If you are a Budweiser or wine drinker, however, you are pretty much out of luck (they do offer Sutter Home by the glass).

headline: Whitman in Washington
abstract: What the American bard saw in the capital.
lead_paragraph: Among the countless Northerners shocked by the Union defeat at Fredericksburg, Va., in December 1862 was the Brooklyn poet and journalist Walt Whitman. In Whitman’s case the shock was personal: his brother George was among the wounded. He quickly packed his bags and rushed south to the Union position. When Whitman arrived at the field hospital set up in a mansion, he found a scene from hell, watched over by an imposing angel: Clara Barton moved amid screams of surgery, ministering to youths, bandaging the bleeding and soothing the dying with low-spoken words and water.

headline: Iran: Navy Begins War Games Near Vital Waterway
abstract: Iran, which periodically conducts naval maneuvers, began the war games Friday in the Gulf of Oman near the Strait of Hormuz, a waterway considered vital to oil tanker traffic.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s naval forces began six days of war games on Friday in the Gulf of Oman near the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway considered vital to international oil tanker traffic. Accounts in the state-run news media said the war games, covering a 400,000-square-mile area, were devised to test combat ships, submarines, reconnaissance methods and a new version of the Thunder surface-to-air midrange missile. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted a commander, Rear Adm. Habibollah Sayyari, as saying the exercises were meant to transmit a message of friendship to neighbors and display “the armed forces’ military capabilities.” Iran, which periodically conducts such naval maneuvers, has said it could close the Strait of Hormuz as retaliation for Western sanctions imposed over Iran’s disputed nuclear energy program.

headline: Italy: Departing Leader Backs a New Centrist Coalition
abstract: Mario Monti, the departing caretaker prime minister, said he would back a centrist grouping in national elections that are expected to place in February.
lead_paragraph: Mario Monti, the departing caretaker prime minister, said Friday that he would back a centrist grouping in national elections expected in February. Mr. Monti, left, governed for 13 months before resigning this month. Although he said that he would not be a candidate — as a senator for life, he does not need to run in elections — his statement solidifies him as a de facto third-party leader. Traditionally, political groups have named a candidate for prime minister before elections. The grouping led by Mr. Monti, who in recent days has been endorsed by the powerful Roman Catholic Church, will challenge the center-right leader, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has adopted a populist stance critical of the euro; and the center-left leader, Pierluigi Bersani, whose Democratic Party is leading in polls.

headline: Papers Show Rare Friction for Thatcher and Reagan
abstract: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan agreed on many issues, but newly published documents show how the two strong allies butted heads over Britain’s 1982 Falklands war with Argentina.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The bond between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan, both in office in the 1980s, has become a kind of gold standard, showing what the “special relationship” between Britain and the United States can be when their leaders share a political creed.

headline: Standing on Tradition While Stretching the Boundaries of Bluegrass
abstract: The Infamous Stringdusters stretched the bounds of bluegrass in their show on Thursday at the Bowery Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: The Infamous Stringdusters, who headlined the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, have the lineup of a traditional bluegrass band: fiddle, banjo, Dobro, guitar and bass. They played and sang like one, too, with flying fingers and close harmonies, when they took up bluegrass standards like “Orange Blossom Special” or “Deep Ellum Blues.” But in the years since the group emerged from Nashville in 2007, the Stringdusters, like a lot of other young string bands, have ignored purism, applied their virtuosity to untraditional tunes and structures and found a wider audience along the jam-band circuit.

headline: Glimpses of France Through the Centuries
abstract: “Medieval to Monet: French Paintings in the Wadsworth Atheneum” provides a fascinating survey of how a culture’s essential themes endure as styles and tastes evolve.
lead_paragraph: “Have you seen a Monet yet?” a visitor in the third gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum’s cleverly named “Medieval to Monet” show murmured to her friend. She was afraid she’d missed something among the paintings of religious subjects, mythological scenes and extravagantly decked-out aristocrats.

headline: Versions of Sugar Plums
abstract: The “Nutcracker” roles offer an opportunity to assess the delights and failings of New York City Ballet’s women, and wonder who will stand out in the future.
lead_paragraph: How can anyone foresee the career developments of individual ballet dancers? Stand back, and they seem determined by the whims of fate. Close up, fate seems scarcely involved. We all know that intensely human matters contribute: directorial taste, personal talent, discipline, health and character.

headline: A Place Comfortable With Boeing, Anarchists and ‘Frasier’
abstract: A revamped History & Industry Museum has a new home on Lake Union in Seattle, with some 50,000 square feet of exhibits about that city’s past and future.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Everything connects. The first commercial aircraft made by Boeing, in 1919, hangs from the ceiling. It has no wheels because it regularly landed on Lake Union here after airmail runs to Canada. You can see that lake through a hole in the floor of this building, a former Naval Reserve Armory that was built out over the water in 1942. And above that hole now rises a commissioned 65-foot-high sculpture made by John Grade from the planks of a century-old schooner that also plied Lake Union.

abstract: When a storm hits, lawmakers should provide immediate relief instead of letting ideology trump common sense.
lead_paragraph: Republicans haven’t made it easy for the Northeast to get the $60.4 billion in aid it needs to recover from Hurricane Sandy. They have objected to the amount — which is considerably less than the $82 billion requested by the region’s governors — and tried to slash it. They have demanded that $3.4 billion of the aid for flood control be offset by spending cuts in other programs. And in the Senate, as on virtually all bills, they filibustered the aid package proposed by President Obama.

headline: A Trainer Keeps Up With His Toddler
abstract: Court Wing, the head trainer and co-founder of CrossFit NYC, gets in some exercise by chasing his 20-month-old son and exploring new neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Sunday is the one day of the week when Court Wing, the head trainer and a founder of CrossFit NYC, doesn’t train clients in the high-intensity, boot-camp-style conditioning routine that he describes as a mix of powerlifting, track and field, and gymnastics. That is not to say that Mr. Wing, 44 and a Seattle native, doesn’t work out. His Sundays are usually devoted to “recovery work” — fitness-fan-speak for flexibility and range-of-motion training. He also exercises by chasing his 20-month-old son, Asher, around his apartment in Astoria, Queens, while his wife, Morgan, 36, a social worker, takes a bit of well-deserved rest.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:15 A.M. (Showtime) STARDUST (2007) Charlie Cox is Tristan, a young man desperate to prove that he would do anything to win the love of his lady fair (Sienna Miller), which includes bringing her a falling star that recently crashed near their village. But to reach the star he must travel to the magical realm of Stormhold, where the star takes the form of a human (Claire Danes, above with Mr. Cox). He also encounters a rapidly aging witch, Lamia (Michelle Pfeiffer), and the cross-dressing captain (Robert De Niro) of a flying pirate ship. Directed by Matthew Vaughn and adapted from the graphic novel written by Neil Gaiman and illustrated by Charles Vess, this fantasy tale “barrels forward with a fearless audacity,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Holden found Ms. Pfeiffer’s Lamia to be “as deliciously evil a witch as the movies have ever invented.” He added, “As the embodiment of every vain, wicked stepmother in fairy tale literature mixed with the cauldron-tending crones of ‘Macbeth’ (Lamia is one of three cackling sisters), Ms. Pfeiffer goes for broke with the relish of a star who figures she has nothing to lose.”

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Lights and Crowds
abstract: Revelers may be ushering in the future here, but Times Square is built on the past, like electric lights, the subway and the Shuberts.
lead_paragraph: Times Square is so crowded, so bright with distractions, that visitors may feel they have walked into an overpopulated and hypercommercial future. But the square’s identity is rooted in the early 1900s, when earlier technologies — the subway and the electric light bulb — made possible its development, from a shabby center for the horse and livery businesses to a hub for news media, entertainment and, increasingly, shopping.

headline: Once Upon a Time, 200 Years Later, in Pictures
abstract: A selection of photographs inspired by the macabre, fantastical and downright creepy Grimms’ Fairy Tales, on the occasion of the collection’s bicentennial.
lead_paragraph: This month marks the bicentennial of the publication of Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm’s “Kinder-und Hausmärchen” — “Children’s and Household Tales,” in English, but more commonly known as Grimms’ Fairy Tales. The collection of stories — “Sleeping Beauty,” “Little Red Riding Hood” and “Rumpelstiltskin” are just a few of the most well known — have been revised, retold, reinterpreted and even Disneyfied so many times over the past two centuries that it’s easy to forget the original tales were a potent mix of the macabre, fantastical and downright creepy.

I pay $14 for a vodka/soda. It has been seven years since I moved to Manhattan from a mountain hiking town of 7,537 people in California. I can’t remember the last time I dug a hole to poop in. I’ve gone city soft.

Lavrov, said Saturday that there was “no possibility” of persuading President Bashar al-Assad to leave Syria, leaving little hope for a breakthrough in the standoff. He also said that the opposition leaders’ insistence on Mr. Assad’s departure as a precondition for peace talks would come at the cost of “more and more lives of Syrian citizens” in a conflict that has already killed tens of thousands.

headline: Personal Finance Advice, Taken to the Woodshed
keywords: ['Financial Planners', 'Books and Literature', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: In a new book, Helaine Olen says that much of the available advice on personal finance doesn’t consider the costly realities of many investors’ lives.
lead_paragraph: IT’S rare to come across a realistic and readable book about personal finance. Most are laden with rosy promises, followed by acronyms and turgid advice. Helaine Olen, a freelance journalist, offers an exception with “Pound Foolish: Exposing the Dark Side of the Personal Finance Industry” (Portfolio, $27.95). It’s a take-no-prisoners examination of the ways she says we have been scared, misled or bamboozled by those purporting to help us achieve financial security.

headline: Don’t Just Talk About Change. Show It.
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Dyslexia', 'Small Business', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: When the writer’s family business wanted to change its factory layout, he used a Lego display to walk employees through the idea — and received many helpful suggestions as a result.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born in 1956. I should have been reading in grade school, but I’m dyslexic — I have trouble reading, writing and spelling — and few people knew much about the condition in those days. My mother realized that something was wrong, but she didn’t know what. She advocated for me at school and told my teachers not to give up on me. I attended five grammar schools because my mother was constantly looking for something to help me. It was a lonely childhood, and I hate to think how I might have ended up if she hadn’t been so supportive.

headline: Progress Where They Make iPhones

Now, however, there are signs that all the negative attention, including reports in this newspaper, has caused the companies to make changes, like raising wages, limiting work hours and providing chairs with backs instead of stools at workstations.

headline: Why the Economy Needs Tax Reform
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials']
abstract: Fixing the tax code could be a defining legacy for President Obama’s second term.
lead_paragraph: Over the next four years, tax reform, done right, could be a cure for much of what ails the economy. Higher taxes, raised progressively, could encourage growth by helping to pay for long-neglected public investment in education, infrastructure and basic research. More revenue would also reduce budget deficits, helping to put the nation’s finances on a stable path. Greater progressivity would reduce rising income inequality, and with it, inequality of opportunity that is both an economic and social scourge.

headline: How to Read in 2013
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Magazines']
abstract: This is the moment to get out of your rut and visit the rest of the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: COME what may in the next 12 months, 2013 has this much going for it: It’s a year without a midterm election, and a year that’s as far removed as possible from the next presidential race. This means that for a blessed 365 days you can be a well-informed and responsible American citizen without reading every single article on Politico, without hitting refresh every 30 seconds on your polling-average site of choice, without channel-hopping between Chris Matthews’s hyperventilating and Dick Morris’s promises of an inevitable Republican landslide.

headline: The Power of a Hot Body
abstract: A wonderful solution for energy shortages: human heaters.
lead_paragraph: As I waited with a throng of Parisians in the Rambuteau Metro station on a blustery day, my frozen toes finally began to thaw. Alone we may have shivered, but together we brewed so much body heat that people began unbuttoning their coats. We might have been penguins crowding for warmth in Antarctica’s icy torment of winds. Idly mingling, a human body radiates about 100 watts of excess heat, which can add up fast in confined spaces.
