Here is a sampling of illustrations from the past year.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 30
abstract: President Obama joins NBC’s “Meet the Press” Sunday to talk about the looming deadline for a deal to avert the so-called fiscal cliff.
lead_paragraph: As the deadline to avert the automatic tax increases and spending cuts of the so-called fiscal cliff draws near, the Sunday shows feature members of Congress and, most notably, President Obama, who will join NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Ai Weiwei and the Communist Party, Tormenting Each Other
abstract: Readers weigh in on my column about the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about the great Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and the challenge he and people like him present to the Chinese leadership. I do think it’s a sign of progress that Ai is today free from prison and able to needle the Party. One of the ways to measure the new leader, Xi Jinping, will be whether Ai is left alone — and whether Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning writer, is released from jail.

headline: Pakistan Lifts, Then Reinstates, YouTube Ban
abstract: Online rejoicing at the end of Pakistan’s three-month ban on YouTube was short-lived on Saturday, as the government reimposed the ban shortly after it was lifted.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Salman Masood reported on Twitter, online rejoicing at the end of Pakistan’s three-month ban on YouTube was short-lived on Saturday, as the government reimposed the ban shortly after it was lifted following reports that copies of a low-budget film mocking the Prophet Muhammad appeared in searches of the site.

headline: Plus Ten
abstract: Hanging ten with Steve Savoy.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — How do you decide whether you’ve enjoyed solving a crossword puzzle? I realize that enjoyment is more of a visceral experience than an intellectual one, but I think it’s worth taking a closer look at this thing we do and figuring it out.

headline: Mystery Powder Leads to Evacuations in Greenwich Village
abstract: The police cordoned off a block of Ninth Street near Fifth Avenue, after a narcotics squad discovered explosive powder during a search warrant of an apartment building.
lead_paragraph: A search for narcotics in a Greenwich Village apartment on Saturday morning led to a call to the bomb squad and evacuations after detectives discovered explosive powder, the police said.

headline: A Spending-Limits Bill Serves as a Great Excuse
abstract: Lawmakers may be looking for a way to say no to their constituents, even when the money for their needs is available, and make it look like a political accomplishment.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Medicaid Waiver Presents Structuring Challenges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Hospitals', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: A Medicaid transformation waiver could transform aspects of Texas’ health care, if hospitals and providers can figure out how to create a system that will reap the benefits.
lead_paragraph: By year’s end, health care providers across Texas will have submitted proposals to state leaders to transform the way they care for the poor and the uninsured. They have been spurred by a Medicaid waiver Texas officials sought and received in 2011 from the federal government, one that ties financing to cooperation, cost efficiency and better patient outcomes.

headline: Dancing the Apocalypse Away, Extravagantly
abstract: Richard Garriott de Cayeux, the video game mogul and space voyager, is known for turning his virtual worlds into lavish parties at his 65-acre ranch in the Hill Country.
lead_paragraph: Elvira Butz, a septuagenarian adventurer who has dived to the Titanic aboard a Russian submersible, trekked solo through the rain forests of Papua New Guinea and searched for meteorites in Antarctica, spent the final minutes of Dec. 21, 2012, the day the Mayans supposedly predicted the world would end, dancing to “Gangnam Style” at the base of a 30-foot replica of a Mayan pyramid built on the shore of Lake Austin.

headline: In Mexico, a New Approach to Stanching Drug Violence
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Under policies announced by Enrique Peña Nieto, Mexico’s new president, the focus will be on street gangs and criminals employed by cartels rather than eliminating drug trafficking bosses.
lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — The military tank that had stood at the entrance to this Mexican border city since 2008 was not here on Christmas Eve. Neither was the machine gun turret that pointed down this gritty town’s main street.

headline: Building Congregations Around Art Galleries and Cafes as Spirituality Wanes
abstract: As more Americans identify as “spiritual but not religious,” evangelicals are changing their focus to building inviting community spaces.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The mural painted on the side of a building in the Deep Ellum warehouse district here is intentionally vague, simply showing a faceless man in a suit holding an umbrella over the words “Life in Deep Ellum.” Inside there are the trappings of a revitalization project, including an art gallery, a yoga studio and a business incubator, sharing the building with a coffee shop and a performance space.

headline: Smoke but Little Fire After Manhole Blasts in SoHo
abstract: The Fire Department said that there had been a manhole explosion near Prince and Mercer Streets and evacuated a building to monitor its air quality.
lead_paragraph: The explosion echoed in the streets of SoHo on Saturday afternoon as tourists walked along dampened sidewalks and a crowd gathered inside the Fanelli Cafe, one of New York City’s older restaurants.

headline: Pakistan Lifts YouTube Ban, for 3 Minutes
abstract: A ban imposed after an anti-Islam video caused riots was reinstated when it was discovered that blasphemous material was still available on the site.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A ban on YouTube, which Pakistan imposed after an anti-Islam video caused riots in much of the Muslim world, was lifted Saturday, only to be reinstated — after three minutes — when it was discovered that blasphemous material was still available on the site.

headline: Biden Is Back for a 2nd Run at Gun Limits
keywords: ['Constitutional Amendments', 'Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The current debate offers Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. a chance to craft a legislative response that would reinstate his assault weapons ban, while also making it more effective.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Never much known for restraint, Joseph R. Biden Jr. did not hold back during a presidential primary debate in 2007 when a voter asking about gun rights in a recorded video displayed a fearsome-looking semiautomatic rifle and declared, “This is my baby.”

headline: Drone Spy Wars
abstract: Al Qaeda and Taliban-supported death squads accuse tribesmen of collaborating with the United States, and often force them to confess on video before executing them.
lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda and Taliban-supported death squads accuse tribesmen of collaborating with the United States, and often force them to confess on video before executing them.

headline: Drone War Spurs Militants to Deadly Reprisals
abstract: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal belt tape confessions and executions of men accused of aiding drone attacks, deepening an atmosphere of paranoia and mistrust.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — They are dead men talking, and they know it. Gulping nervously, the prisoners stare into the video camera, spilling tales of intrigue, betrayal and paid espionage on behalf of the United States. Some speak in trembling voices, a glint of fear in their eyes. Others look resigned. All plead for their lives.

headline: A Soul Surfer, in Winter
abstract: Freezing temperatures cannot keep Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a meditation student and lifelong surfer from Queens, from finding his bliss in winter waves.
lead_paragraph: Freezing temperatures cannot keep Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a meditation student and lifelong surfer from Queens, from finding his bliss in winter waves.

headline: Stunned and Battered, Knicks Need Break
abstract: Coming off a last-second loss in Sacramento, the depleted Knicks hope to have at least Amar’e Stoudemire back after three days off.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks returned to New York on Saturday physically beaten up and coming off one of their most agonizing losses of the season, a 106-105 defeat to the Kings in Sacramento.

headline: UConn Repays Stanford by Ending Long Streak
abstract: No. 2 Connecticut outplayed No. 1 Stanford on both ends of the floor and the visiting Huskies snapped the Cardinal’s 82-game unbeaten streak at home in a 61-35 rout.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — For the viewing public, this was a matchup between the nation’s top-ranked teams. For Connecticut, there was also the small matter of revenge.

headline: Sloshing and Churning, Syracuse Routs West Virginia in Pinstripe Bowl
abstract: With 378 yards on the ground, the Orange manhandled the Mountaineers, 38-14, amid snow and sleet to earn their second bowl win in four years under Coach Doug Marrone.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a matchup between Syracuse and West Virginia would have constituted a typical Saturday afternoon Big East game, maybe on a crisp day in October. For 56 years, from 1955 to 2011, they battled that way, always in the regular season.

headline: Coming Soon to Belgian Village, a French Film Idol Fleeing Taxes
abstract: Néchin, a rural settlement in Belgium, has become a tax haven for scores of wealthy French citizens, including, most recently, the actor Gérard Depardieu.
lead_paragraph: NÉCHIN, Belgium — The last time a big star lit up this sleepy village of potato fields and rain-drenched pastures was in 1667, when the Sun King, Louis XIV of France, stopped by for the day. But even he may not have created quite the commotion caused by Gérard Depardieu, the celebrated actor, turbulent bon vivant and, since a visit to the mayor’s office here on Dec. 7 to register as a resident, France’s most reviled tax exile.

headline: Halfway Houses Prove Lucrative to Those at Top
abstract: The second-largest operator of halfway houses in New Jersey, a nonprofit, has paid its founder roughly $7 million over the past decade, and has hired several of the founder’s relatives.
lead_paragraph: The Kintock Group, the second-largest operator of halfway houses in New Jersey, is a nonprofit agency that is financed almost entirely by government contracts. But it is run like a well-heeled family business.

headline: Jeffrey Potter, Biographer of Pollock, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Potter’s work “To a Violent Grave” was based on his own recollections as well as interviews with many who knew Jackson Pollock.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Potter was an aspiring writer working as a building contractor in the Hamptons in 1949 when he developed a friendship with a gruff, taciturn neighbor who shared his passion for oversized machines like backhoes, bulldozers, dredgers and jacks big enough to lift a house from its foundations.

headline: A Veteran Hangs on to His Title, but a Young Champion Is Dethroned
abstract: Viswanathan Anand, now 43, successfully defended the men’s championship in May, but on the women’s side, Hou Yifan, 18, failed to repeat as titleholder.
lead_paragraph: A changing of the guard was anticipated in the top ranks this year. It was the men’s champion, now 43, whom many thought to be vulnerable. But it was the teenage women’s champion who was dethroned.

headline: Nets Talk Over Lunch and Win After Dinner
abstract: P. J. Carlesimo, the Nets’ interim coach, said the best way to persuade owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov to keep him is to do what he did Saturday: win.
lead_paragraph: A Russian billionaire and a coaching lifer from Scranton, Pa., walked into a Greek restaurant, providing the setup for a corny punch line or perhaps an agenda for the future of the Nets. Or maybe it was just a lunch.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 30
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 30
lead_paragraph: We just can’t afford a politically self-inflicted wound to our economy.

headline: Corrections: December 30, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on December 30, 2012.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Megan Healey, JC Leston
abstract: A pediatric nurse practitioner marries an insurance underwriter.
lead_paragraph: Megan Marie Healey and J Christian Leston were married Saturday in Hicksville, N.Y. Frank Crivello, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

headline: Seth Thayer Jr. and Gregory Tinder
abstract: The wedding took place in Northport, Me.
lead_paragraph: Seth Alexander Thayer Jr. and Gregory Nelson Tinder were married Saturday at their home in Northport, Me. R. Declan O’Connor, a notary public and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Ryan Murphy, Courtney Jeske
abstract: The couple is married in New York.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Chandra Murphy and Courtney Aaron Jeske are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, the pastor of the church, officiated.

headline: Sara Chidester and Stephen Gould
abstract: The couple, both doctors who met as students at Johns Hopkins, are to be married in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sara Janine Chidester and Dr. Stephen Alexander Gould are to be married Sunday at Catlin Gardens, an inn in Slate Hill, N.Y. Cantor Judith K. Steel is to officiate with the Rev. Harold Steindam, a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

headline: Dolores Swirin, Paul Yao
abstract: The couple is married in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Dolores Anne Swirin and Paul Lin Yao were married Monday at the couple’s apartment in Brooklyn. Cantor Lisa B. Segal officiated.

headline: Matthew Sobaski, David Marchi
abstract: The couple is married in New York.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Christopher Sobaski and David John Marchi were married Thursday in New York. The Rev. Alma Daniel, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts.

headline: Allison Rothman, Paul Strachman
abstract: The bride is an account executive at a marketing firm, and the groom should have no problem writing the thank-you notes.
lead_paragraph: Allison Elizabeth Rothman and Paul Pinkhas Strachman were married Saturday evening at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur D. Weiner officiated.

headline: Beth DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi
abstract: The couple is married in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Beth Rudin DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi were married Wednesday afternoon by Patricia Alexander, a Florida notary, at the bride’s house in West Palm Beach, Fla. That evening, Koginka Kamaru Xue, a shaman, led a spiritual ceremony in the same location.

headline: Grace Clawater and Mark Doramus Jr.
abstract: The couple, who met at Princeton, are married in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Grace Clawater, a daughter of Hollee Hedge Clawater and D. Wayne Clawater of Houston, was married Saturday in Houston to Mark Christopher Doramus Jr., a son of Laura Laker Doramus and Mr. Doramus Sr. of Little Rock, Ark. The Very Rev. Dr. J. Pittman McGehee performed the ceremony at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral, of which he is a former dean.

headline: Sasha Rutizer and Jenifer Markowitz
abstract: The couple is married in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Army Capt. Sasha Noel Rutizer and Jenifer Robin Markowitz were married Saturday at the Hillyer Art Space in Washington. Judge Douglas Miles of the El Paso County Court in Colorado received permission from Superior Court of the District of Columbia to officiate. Rabbi Kenneth Block took part in the ceremony.

headline: Trending in Asia in 2012: Our Top 10
abstract: From the best — and worst — countries to be a woman, to human and animal rights, to China, China, China, our most read and commented posts on Asia.
lead_paragraph: Our most popular Asia posts of 2012, by the number of readers and/or the number of comments:

headline: How to Blog Asia for the MSM
abstract: A look back at the work of Mark McDonald, our main Asia blogger since we launched. Mark is leaving his blog duties but he is not going far. Then again, when you cover the world like Mark and Rendezvous do, there is no “far.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re a close reader of IHT Rendezvous, you’re jonesing for a fix of Mark McDonald right about now. Our peripatetic Asia blogger’s last day writing was Wednesday. He’s moving on to other assignments. We’ll miss him.

headline: Elegy in Neon
abstract: James and Karla Murray’s “New York Nights,” is a neon-soaked celebration of the nocturnal institutions that keep the city that never sleeps awake, satiated and comfortably numb.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK CITY exists in a perpetual state of reinvention. That is its nature. What was here yesterday is something else today and will be something new again tomorrow. That change sustains the city, imparts it with a vital energy that keeps it from becoming a frozen museum of itself, like Paris or Rome.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: The end of the year is always a time of reflection for journalists, who look back on the changes and transformations that occurred in the year gone by. In Open Magazine, Manu Joseph describes the rise of the “New Rebel,” the young, educated and affluent person who is angered by the state of the nation.He writes: “Till not so long ago, they were never a crowd except in happy times — a college festival or a rock concert. But now they walk in giant furious swarms, having done their apprenticeship in rebellion under Team Anna last year, holding English placards, abusing the few politicians whose names they know. Nobody’s votebank, orphaned by their own republic, they march to some monument or other to become news.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: The longest rail tunnel in India, which cuts through the foothills of the Pir Panjal mountain range, opened for a trial run on Thursday, the Hindustan Times reported. The 11-kilometer, or 6.8-mile, railway track cost the government 13 billion rupees, or $236 million. It will connect Kashmir to the rest of the country via rail for the first time. The track is expected to be functional next year.

headline: Giants’ Probabilities for Playoffs
abstract: The Giants’ chances of advancing to the playoffs range from 8.5 percent to 17.9 percent, depending on which statistical analyst you consult.
lead_paragraph: Under the headline “The Indescribable Collapse of the Incomprehensible 2012 Giants,” Greg Hanlon of CapitalNewYork.com summed up what Giants fans know well:

headline: At Delhi Protest Ground, Talk of Causes Behind Violence Against Women
keywords: ['Cremation', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Men spoke of frustration and economic disparity, while women said mothers should teach children better.
lead_paragraph: The body of the 23-year-old victim of a fatal gang rape in New Delhi this month was returned to India from Singapore early Sunday, as calls for government action and protests in response to the attack continued to rouse people across India.

headline: Game Theory: The Year of Antisocial Gaming
abstract: They say 2012 was the year of the social game. Don’t believe them. This was actually the year of the antisocial game.
lead_paragraph: It had been a while since any of my friends had spent significant time together online in Call of Duty or Madden or World of Warcraft or any of the big-budget experiences we knew as multiplayer gaming. Things like deadlines, dinner parties and changing diapers were taking up all of our time. But suddenly, here we were, playing and competing with one another just like the old days.

headline: Day of Seesaw Talks Produces No Accord on Fiscal Crisis
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Senate was set to reconvene Monday after failing to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders on Sunday failed to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect on New Year’s Day, despite a round of volatile negotiations over the weekend and an attempt by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to intervene.

headline: 2012: The Year in Graphics
abstract: A selection of graphics and interactives from 2012 with information on how they were produced.
lead_paragraph: A selection of graphics and interactives from 2012 with information on how they were produced.

headline: Fisher Island: Paradise Built
abstract: Three miles off the coast of Miami lies a 216-acre man-made island that has long been home to the rich and powerful. But legal troubles may intrude upon the seclusion residents covet.
lead_paragraph: Three miles off the coast of Miami lies a 216-acre man-made island that has long been home to the rich and powerful. But legal troubles may intrude upon the seclusion residents covet.

headline: Disruptions: The Real Hazards of E-Devices on Planes
abstract: If the Federal Aviation Administration does not re-evaluate its ban on device use during takeoff and landing, someone will be hurt, but not because of interference with the plane’s avionics.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, flying with phones and other devices has become increasingly dangerous.

headline: Several Eras End at One Lower East Side Building
abstract: After more than four decades, two married artists are being evicted from a 19th-century synagogue on the Lower East Side where they had found an affordable home even as gentrification crept into the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The collapse and demolition in 2006 of the First Roumanian-American Congregation synagogue at 89 Rivington Street — the “cantors’ Carnegie Hall” — seemed to have eradicated almost every trace of what was once a large and vibrant Jewish community.

headline: 19 Shiite Pilgrims Bound for Iran Are Killed in Pakistan
abstract: The remotely detonated bomb, which struck buses bearing passengers on a religious pilgrimage, also wounded at least 25 people in southwestern Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 19 Shiite pilgrims, including four women, were killed Sunday when their convoy of three buses in southwestern Pakistan was struck by a remotely detonated bomb, officials said. At least 25 other people were wounded in the attack in the Mastung district of Baluchistan Province.

headline: In Europe, Focus Begins to Shift to the Speed of a Nascent Recovery
abstract: The probability of catastrophe in the euro zone has fallen substantially because of a fundamental change in the way European leaders are dealing with the debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: SAY what you will about the euro zone’s quarreling policy makers. They can claim at least one achievement during 2012: their common currency still has a heartbeat.

headline: The Hostage Drama Begins
abstract: Here comes very big trouble.
lead_paragraph: It sure looks as if we’re going over the fiscal cliff, but that may be the least of our problems. The debt ceiling is a much bigger and more dangerous issue, and it looks very much as if Republicans are set to destroy the full faith and credit of the United States if they can’t get their way.

headline: ‘The Hobbit’ Holds Lead at Busy Movie Theaters
abstract: “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” distributed by Warner Brothers, took in $32.9 million, for a new three-week domestic total of $222.7 million.
lead_paragraph: Bloody violence (“Django Unchained”) and dirty actors singing (“Les Misérables”) both intrigued North American movie audiences over the weekend, but it was a furry-footed holdover that claimed the No. 1 spot: “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” distributed by Warner Brothers, took in a robust $32.9 million, for a new three-week domestic total of $222.7 million.

headline: Afghan Camps Receive Winter Aid, but Officials Say It Isn’t Enough
abstract: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Sunday distributed emergency cold weather supplies to families in a refugee camp where two days earlier a 3-year-old child died of exposure to the cold.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Sunday distributed emergency cold-weather supplies to families in a refugee camp where two days earlier a 3-year-old died of exposure to the freezing temperatures.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) DICK CLARK’S NEW YEAR’S ROCKIN’ EVE WITH RYAN SEACREST 2013 Taylor Swift, Carly Rae Jepsen and Neon Trees join Mr. Seacrest, above, in New York to help ring in the new year during this celebration from Times Square. Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas hosts segments from Los Angeles with appearances by Brandy, Flo Rida, Karmin, OneRepublic and Pitbull. “New Year’s Rockin’ Eve Celebrates Dick Clark,” recalling the TV host, who died in April at 82, leads in at 8.

headline: Newtown Shooting the Worst Day of His Presidency, Obama Says
abstract: The president says he will wait for a report from a task force chaired by the vice president before proposing specific gun-control legislation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said Sunday that the day of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was the worst of his presidency and that he wanted new legislation limiting access to some types of firearms passed within the first year of his second term.

headline: Is Our Austerians Learning?
abstract: Not a chance.
lead_paragraph: Paul Solman has a post on Greg Mankiw’s attempt at a gotcha over my views circa 2003 on the consequences of deficits. As Solman notes, not only are the situations very different, I’ve also long since acknowledged that I was wrong, and have explained how and why I modified my views as a result. Extra bonus: notice how Mankiw, faced with the failure of his gotcha, immediately tries to claim that he wasn’t actually saying what he was, in fact, saying.

headline: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, Nobel Winner, Dies at 103
abstract: By studying chicken embryos in the bedroom of her house in Turin, Italy, Dr. Levi-Montalcini discovered how embryo cells built a latticework of intricate connections.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, a Nobel Prize-winning neurologist who discovered critical chemical tools that the body uses to direct cell growth and build nerve networks, opening the way for the study of how those processes can go wrong in diseases like dementia and cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Rome. She was 103.

headline: Republicans Consider Changing Electoral Vote Counting to Improve Presidential Odds
abstract: As more states fall reliably in the Democrat or Republican column, some swing states controlled by Republicans are considering changing how they apportion their Electoral College votes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not too long ago, political analysts assumed the Republicans had a clear advantage in the Electoral College, the system according to which each state, based on population, is given electors that in almost all cases are awarded on a winner-take-all basis, determining who will be the president of the United States. Today, it’s the Democrats who have the edge.

headline: Big Depositors Seek a New Safety Net
abstract: With $1.5 trillion of bank deposits losing an unlimited government guarantee granted in the financial crisis, services are parceling cash into F.D.I.C.-insurable bundles at multiple banks.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of the New Year, $1.5 trillion of bank deposits will lose an unlimited government guarantee that was granted during the financial crisis to assure skittish customers that their cash was safe. For a handful of boutique firms that service banks, it’s a boon for business.

headline: Heavens to Betsy
abstract: Keep it clean.
lead_paragraph: Given this blog’s growing readership, I find it necessary every once in a while to remind people of the rules on commenting. In particular, the Grey Lady is very Victorian; comments containing obscenities will not be posted except through oversight. For what it’s worth, by the way, when I do the moderation myself — which is some of the time — the obscene language seems more common in supportive than critical comments. Hey, I often feel like cursing too. No matter, it’s still forbidden

headline: How to Help
abstract: The aid organization with the most permanent presence in Kabul’s refugee camps is a respected Afghan group, Aschiana.
lead_paragraph: The aid organization with the most permanent presence in Kabul’s refugee camps is a respected Afghan group, Aschiana, which also runs schools that provide students with hot lunches. Aschiana’s United States fund-raising branch can be reached at www.aschiana-foundation.org, and their Afghan office is at www.aschiana.com.

headline: Afghan Troop Deaths Rise as Army Expands Its Role
abstract: The Afghan government hit a grim record in its quest to take over the country’s security: more than 1,000 soldiers died in 2012, a 20 percent increase from 2011.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government has hit a grim record in its quest to take over the country’s security from coalition forces: more than 1,000 soldiers died in 2012, a roughly 20 percent increase from 2011.

headline: Mellower? Maybe, but the Barbs Still Sting
abstract: The comedian Sandra Bernhard flung out some choice words for the past year in a performance of outspoken talk and musical numbers at Joe’s Pub.
lead_paragraph: To describe Sandra Bernhard nowadays as a mellower version of the comic sniper she used to be is not to say that she has lost her edge. In her monologues on Friday evening at Joe’s Pub, where she is performing a series of end-of-the-year shows, this comedian and singer, now 57 (but looking two decades younger), seemed on top of current trends in music and fashion as ever. And she flung out some choice but unprintable words for the year we are leaving behind.

headline: For Day Laborers, Used to Scraping By, Hurricane Creates a Wealth of Work
abstract: For workers in New York and New Jersey, Hurricane Sandy yielded demolition and construction jobs that had been scarce since the  housing market collapsed.
lead_paragraph: The day after the storm, Manuel Sinchi, like some other New Yorkers, gathered a few friends, hopped on his bicycle and headed down to badly stricken Coney Island to volunteer his services.

headline: When the Costume Isn’t Enough
abstract: The soprano Elza van den Heever said she was moved to shave her head to play Elizabeth I in “Maria Stuarda” as a way of contributing to the professionalism she saw at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: The title character in “The Bald Soprano,” the absurdist Ionesco play, never shows up, but watch for her at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: New Year’s Honors From the Queen
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Music', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: The fashion designer Stella McCartney and the actor Ewan McGregor were among those named to receive New Year’s Honors from Queen Elizabeth II, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Stella McCartney (below), the actor Ewan McGregor, the singer Kate Bush and the cartoonist Quentin Blake were among those named to receive New Year’s Honors from Queen Elizabeth II, The Associated Press reported. Ms. McCartney will be recognized for her efforts in creating the Olympic uniforms for the British athletes in the 2012 London Summer Games; Mr. McGregor for his overall work in film; Ms. Bush for her music; and Mr. Blake, perhaps best known for his work on books by Roald Dahl, for his art.

headline: A 17th-Century Genius, a Quack, or Perhaps Both
abstract: “A Man of Misconceptions,” by John Glassie, profiles the 17th-century German polymath Athanasius Kircher,  whose sprawling résumé was said to include hieroglyphics translation and a “cat piano.”
lead_paragraph: In 2002 the New York Institute for the Humanities organized a symposium under the title “Was Athanasius Kircher the Coolest Guy Ever, or What?“ The highlights of this 17th-century German Jesuit polymath’s sprawling résumé, summed up in John Glassie’s brisk new biography, suggest the question wasn’t completely absurd.

headline: Giants Do Their Part but Miss Out on Playoffs
abstract: The Giants, hopeful for a playoff spot, pummeled the Eagles, but the result was rendered meaningless when the Bears beat the Lions.

headline: In Images: A History of Premier Automobiles
abstract: As the Padmini taxi rolls into the sunset, a look back at its Mumbai manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: The black and yellow Padmini taxi is as identifiable with Mumbai as the Volkswagen Beetle taxi in Mexico City or the once ubiquitous Checker cab in New York. Alternately loathed and romanticized, the Padmini — or some version of it — was produced in Mumbai from 1964 to 2000 by Premier Automobiles. It became a favorite of taxi drivers in the 1970s because it was cheaper, easier to drive and more maneuverable than the tank-like Hindustan Ambassador, its main competition in Bombay, as the city was known then. For the individual motorist, it was attainable and passed for sporty in a tightly controlled automotive industry.

They had reason to be hopeful: the album not only was an original pressing, on the black-and-gold Parlophone label that was discontinued (and replaced with a sleeker, black-and-yellow update) a few months after the album was released, but it is also autographed. But when bidding reached only £12,000 ($19,500), they withdrew the disc. Now the BBC reports that they have sold it privately for the price they had turned down at the auction.

I used cayenne for heat and a chiffonade of romaine lettuce was a good stand-in for the bean sprouts, crunchy and fresh. Lots of chives stood in for scallions. I did without cilantro or Thai basil but had plenty of Italian basil and mint from my garden.

lead_paragraph: As I explained last year on this date, I took this photo in Paris in 1980, at the sleepy peak of the August vacances, when most shops, including this watch store, were shuttered. The elderly gentleman, to my eye, seemed particularly uncomfortable on his walk as he passed the hand of time.

headline: Tribulations in Spain
abstract: With a huge deficit, Spain has introduced one austerity measure after another.
lead_paragraph: With a huge deficit, Spain has introduced one austerity measure after another.

headline: Looking Ahead to Civil and Criminal Cases to Come
abstract: If recent cases serve as a guide, too many loopholes in the system allow white-collar fraud to go undetected.
lead_paragraph: It is not really of question of whether there will be a major white-collar crime that captures the public’s attention in 2013; it’s a question of when and how costly it will be.

headline: Poets Who Look Death in the Eye
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Two new poetry collections, “Writers Writing Dying” by C. K. Williams and “The Glimmering Room” by Cynthia Cruz, address mortality.
lead_paragraph: The poets C. K. Williams and Cynthia Cruz, at first glance, couldn’t seem more different. Mr. Williams owns a Pulitzer and has published more than 20 books; her latest book is just Ms. Cruz’s second. He casts long, serpentine lines upon the page; she savors the cryptic burst. And Mr. Williams was born into the same 1930s Newark that shaped Philip Roth, while Ms. Cruz came of age in Santa Cruz, Calif., skateboarding and listening to punk.

headline: Latvia’s Growth Is Cited as Austerity Success Story
abstract: With Latvia experiencing economic growth after deep budget cuts, many have suggested the results could be replicated elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: With Latvia experiencing economic growth after deep budget cuts, many have suggested the results could be replicated elsewhere.

headline: In Ireland, Recession and Austerity
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Recession and Depression', 'Taxation', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Unemployment', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The effects of slashed budgets have pummeled the country’s fragile economy, leaving scars that are likely to take years to heal.
lead_paragraph: The effects of slashed budgets have pummeled the country’s fragile economy, leaving scars that are likely to take years to heal.

headline: President Obama on the Fiscal Talks
abstract: President Obama says a deal is “within sight,” less than 24 hours before the so-called fiscal cliff.
lead_paragraph: President Obama says a deal is “within sight,” less than 24 hours before the so-called fiscal cliff.

headline: Inflammation Byproduct Linked to Stress
abstract: Danish researchers found that the C-reactive protein, a byproduct of inflammation in the body, was associated with a greater risk of psychological stress and clinical depression.
lead_paragraph: Using data from two large studies, Danish researchers have found that higher blood levels of C-reactive protein, or CRP, are associated with a greater risk of psychological stress and clinical depression.

headline: Ford Fusion Energi MPGe Hits Triple Digits, E.P.A. Says
abstract: The E.P.A. says the Fusion Energi can get the equivalent of 108 miles per gallon in city driving.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Ford Fusion Energi plug-in hybrid has received an E.P.A. certification of being able to achieve the equivalent of 108 miles per gallon in city driving, the automaker has announced.

headline: Conceder In Chief?
abstract: Not as bad a deal as some reports, but setting up the next crisis.
lead_paragraph: OK, I’ve had my own sorta-kinda briefing on the apparent fiscal cliff deal, and I’m pretty much with Noam Scheiber. Viewed on its own, it’s a bad and upsetting deal but not as terrible as initial rumors had it. But the strategic consequences are likely to be very bad indeed, and in very short order too.

headline: Promoter Who Revamped Capitol Theater Buys It
abstract: Peter Shapiro buys the landmark building in Port Chester, N.Y., for $11.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The concert promoter who revitalized the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, N.Y., this year as a rock music hall has bought that landmark building from its previous owner. The promoter, Peter Shapiro, who is also a partner in the Brooklyn Bowl, said he paid $11.5 million for the 1,800-seat theater, closing a deal on Friday with the previous owner, Marvin Ravikoff.

headline: Worms Produce Another Kind of Gold for Growers
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Worms', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: New research suggests that vermicompost, a worm-created soil additive, helps plants grow with more vigor, and makes them more resistant to disease and insects, than those grown with other types of composts and fertilizers.
lead_paragraph: SONOMA, Calif. — Under rows of old chicken sheds, Jack Chambers has built an empire of huge metal boxes filled with cattle manure and millions of wriggling red worms.

headline: Where the Melvillean Things Are
abstract: Why I’m a big fan of Maurice Sendak: he loved Herman Melville. Here, some of Sendak’s provocative pictures for Melville’s novel, “Pierre or The Ambiguities.”
lead_paragraph: In last weekend’s Lives They Lived issue, the longtime contributor to the magazine Christoph Niemann sketched a clever, touching tribute to Maurice Sendak. Niemann (self-rendered in a way that recalls Calvin’s father in “Calvin & Hobbes”) recreates an afternoon in 2011 when he listened to the children’s book author being interviewed on the car radio. His drive was taken over by images from Sendak’s work the way Max’s bedroom is overrun by jungle in “Where the Wild Things Are,” with glimpses of Max, wild things, Jennie the dog, Mickey, a couple of bakers.

headline: A Ride in a 1954 Bentley R-Type Sedan
abstract: The car made a brief appearance in the television movie “Liz & Dick.”
lead_paragraph: In their criticism of Lindsay Lohan for her portrayal of Elizabeth Taylor in Lifetime’s recent “Liz & Dick,” reviewers missed an assured, if brief, appearance by 59-year-old Madame, who came out of semiseclusion to take on the role as conveyance to a cuckold.

headline: Silencing the Smartphone
abstract: Citing better productivity, some companies are trying to wean employees from constant contact with their electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: Resolutions to change behavior are common at this time of year, but they usually involve exercising more or smoking less. Now, some companies are adopting policies aimed at weaning employees from their electronic devices.

headline: Knowing You Carry a Cancer Gene
abstract: If you carry a gene mutation that greatly increases your risk of cancer, when does knowing about it become too much to handle?
lead_paragraph: I jogged into the Stanford Cancer Clinic with my boyfriend, the youngest people there by two decades. We stood there sweating and holding hands, a jarring sight in the sickly light.

headline: Sound vs. Noise, and the Elusive Quest for Quiet
abstract: In his new book, “Discord,” Mike Goldsmith offers surprising facts about sound and traces our relationship with noise through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: Mike Goldsmith has assembled a lot of facts about noise, some familiar (trucks are noisy), some worth noting (the Big Bang was silent) and some nearly lost to history: The ill-fated Concorde was so loud that in 1976 Congress banned its landing in the United States (a decision quickly overturned by the secretary of transportation). A fatal crash in 2000 led to the doom of the Concorde entirely.

headline: City Room’s Top Animal Posts of 2012
abstract: New York City is a jungle, and we have the stories to prove it.
lead_paragraph: 2012 was a big year for news in New York, and City Room was there for Hurricane Sandy, developments in the Etan Patz case, the brazen daytime shooting in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Health Care Hackers and Guns for Christmas
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include people showing off their Christmas guns on Instagram, Electronic Arts receiving more than $9 million in tax credits from Florida and Zynga retiring 11 of its games.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis: No Relief on the Horizon
abstract: European Union officials have struggled to turn things around — debating new treaties, shoring up banks, securing more funding.  The people of Greece, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Latvia have dealt with economic troubles in various ways.
lead_paragraph: European Union officials have struggled to turn things around — debating new treaties, shoring up banks, securing more funding.  The people of Greece, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Latvia have dealt with economic troubles in various ways.

headline: Birds Found to Have Emotional Reactions to Song
abstract: Female white-throated sparrows were found to respond to the songs of male sparrows in the same way as humans listening to pleasant music.
lead_paragraph: The human brain responds to music in different ways, depending on the listener’s emotional reaction, among other things. Now researchers report that the same holds true for birds listening to birdsong.

headline: Grapes Can Be Different by Location in Vineyard
abstract: The surfaces of grapes may harbor different species of yeast microbes, which could be related to variances in sun exposure and temperature.
lead_paragraph: Wine enthusiasts, consider this: The same grapes from different parts of a vineyard can be quite different.

headline: Big Data: Rise of the Machines
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Business experts and recent research predict that machine-generated sensor data will become a larger and larger portion of all data produced. That is opening up a huge opportunity for Big Data technology beyond the consumer Internet.
lead_paragraph: For a column that laid out some second thoughts on Big Data, one of the people I talked to was Thomas H. Davenport, who has worked in the fields of knowledge management and analytics for 15 years. Data analytics is the predecessor to Big Data. He knows the context — what’s new and what’s not with Big Data — as well as anyone.

headline: Pill Could Join Arsenal Against Bedbugs
abstract: A deworming pill kills the bugs after a few bites with a technique known as xenointoxication, Greek for “poisoning the guest.”
lead_paragraph: THE HYPOTHESIS

headline: Youthful Orchestra Abets the Voice of a Clarinet
abstract: The New York String Orchestra concert on Friday at Carnegie Hall, conducted by Jaime Laredo, concluded an intensive 10-day training seminar for young players.
lead_paragraph: Mozart wrote several remarkable works for the Austrian clarinetist Anton Stadler, his friend and fellow Mason, including the great Quintet for Clarinet and Strings, and the Clarinet Concerto, the last major score Mozart completed, shortly before dying. He was clearly inspired by his colleague’s virtuosity and artistry. From all reports, Stadler could bend a gentle phrase with uncommon delicacy. Johann Schink, a Viennese critic, wrote that he would not have thought it possible for a clarinet to “imitate the human voice so deceptively,” as Stadler did.

headline: Outmaneuvered at Their Own Game, Antivirus Makers Struggle to Adapt
abstract: Consumers and businesses spend billions of dollars a year on antivirus software, but these programs rarely block freshly minted strains, because the malware creators move too fast.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The antivirus industry has a dirty little secret: its products are often not very good at stopping viruses.

headline: Mourning for Rape Victim Recasts New Year’s Eve in India
abstract: Thousands of protesters marched on Monday in New Delhi, pledging to “take back the night,” as India remained in mourning for the 23-year-old victim of a gang rape who died on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Sruthi Gottipati reports, thousands of protesters marched on Monday in New Delhi, pledging to “take back the night,” as India remained in mourning for the 23-year-old victim of a gang rape who died on Saturday.

headline: The Human Toll of Europe’s Economic Statistics
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Photography', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Europe’s sovereign debt crisis has largely been a story told through numbers. Telling that story photographically, however, has required looking beyond common depictions of demonstrations or evictions — at how Europeans actually live the crisis.
lead_paragraph: An interactive presentation of how the debt crisis has affected five European countries accompanies this post. We urge you to view it.

headline: ‘We Lost Things and We Can Replace Those Things’
abstract: Hurricane Sandy took a tremendous toll in Ortley Beach, N.J., but for some, the pain was tempered by the loss of life at Sandy Hook Elementary in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: ORTLEY BEACH, N.J. — Stefanie Pyper’s last prehurricane memory of her house on Fourth Avenue is one of bliss: the bike ride up to the Lavallette Boardwalk, seeing a school of dolphins in the ocean, the oasis of calm amid the turmoil of raising five children ranging in age from 8 to 18.

headline: Motor Skills May Predict Success in School
abstract: Researchers in Finland say that poor motor skills may be a factor in predicting poor academic performance in adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Poor motor function in childhood may be an important factor in predicting poor academic achievement in adolescence.

headline: The Confusion of Pill Coloring
abstract: Researchers tracking prescriptions for anti-epileptic drugs found that compared with patients whose pills remained the same, those whose pills’ color was changed were 53 percent more likely to stop buying them.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests that changing the color of a person’s pills — by switching to a generic from a brand name drug, for example — sharply reduces the chances that the patient will continue to take it.

headline: The Life of Pi, and Other Infinities
abstract: In the ever-evolving view of scientists, philosophers and other scholars, there really is no single, implacable entity called infinity.
lead_paragraph: On this day that fetishizes finitude, that reminds us how rapidly our own earthly time share is shrinking, allow me to offer the modest comfort of infinities.

headline: An Environmentalist Weighs the Fallout of Flying
abstract: M. Sanjayan, lead scientist for the Nature Conservancy, doesn’t fly if his presence is not crucial at the destination.
lead_paragraph: I FLY a lot. And honestly, flying now is a means to an end, although I used to enjoy it. It’s not that I hate it or am paranoid. It’s just that it’s a chore.

headline: Mortality: H.I.V.-Positive Smokers Lose More Years to Tobacco Than to the Virus, a Study Says
abstract: A Danish study of almost 3,000 H.I.V. patients also found that the risk of early death from cancer or heart disease was much higher among infected smokers than among noninfected ones.
lead_paragraph: H.I.V. patients who obtain good treatment but who smoke lose more years of life to tobacco than to the virus, a new Danish study has found.

headline: Juggling Diabetes and Cancer
abstract: Cancer and diabetes are two leading killers in America, and while each can be a devastating diagnosis, researchers are finding that the two often occur together.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Brenda Gray, a former schoolteacher in North Carolina, discovered she had Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Yankees at Payroll Threshold, at Least for Now
abstract: The Yankees’ payroll was close to their targeted $189 million on Monday, but it did include a number of unsigned players, including Phil Hughes.
lead_paragraph: On the final day of 2012 the Yankees will coincidentally close out the year at a landmark position in baseball’s payroll standings, the sport’s own fiscal cliff, which will arrive before the 2014 season. It is a spot they expect to revisit again in one year, but for now they are only passing it by.

headline: Coldplay Delivers in the Usual Way
abstract: Coldplay’s concert on Sunday night in Brooklyn, dominated by Chris Martin and visual effects, preceded a scheduled New Year’s Eve double bill with Jay-Z.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of its allotted time at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sunday night, Coldplay offered up “Fix You,” a vow of encouragement about as earnest and ingenuous as its title suggests. The song opens like a processional hymn and stays in that realm awhile before tipping decisively toward rock grandeur: a cue for Chris Martin, the voice and face and soul of the band, to shrug off any lingering scrap of pensiveness or decorum.

headline: Why Elliott Carter Wasn’t in ‘The Music They Made’
abstract: The Music They Made, an annual “sound collage” of the musicians who died in the previous year, generally doesn’t include classical musicans. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Alex Ross, the New Yorker music critic and author of the excellent books ‘‘The Rest Is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century’’ and ‘‘Listen to This,’’ called for a protest against the Times Magazine. He had his reasons: The annual mix I make honoring the musicians who died the previous year did not — once again — include any classical musicians.

headline: Remarks by the President on Fiscal Cliff Negotiations
abstract: The president appeared with middle-class families to deliver a statement on the fiscal-cliff talks on Monday in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The following is the full text of President Obama’s statement from the White House on the fiscal talks on Monday.

headline: Light Absorption Speeding Arctic Ice Melt
abstract: A new study in Geophysical Research Letters, based on a first-of-its-kind survey, reports that the ocean beneath Arctic ice is absorbing increasing amounts of solar energy.
lead_paragraph: The record-setting disappearance of Arctic sea ice this fall was an indication to many climate scientists and ice experts that the pace of climate change was outstripping predictions.

headline: Building a Better Goal Post
abstract: A look at the manufacturing of a football goal post that, with the push of a button, sinks to the ground in less than a minute.
lead_paragraph: A look at the manufacturing of a football goal post that, with the push of a button, sinks to the ground in less than a minute.

headline: Irving Azoff to Leave Live Nation
abstract: As part of his exit, Liberty Media, already one of Live Nation’s largest shareholders, will buy 1.7 million of Mr. Azoff’s shares in the company, giving Liberty a 26.4 percent stake in Live Nation.
lead_paragraph: Irving Azoff, the executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant, is leaving the company, Live Nation announced on Monday.

headline: Fearing Fighting, Residents Flee Capital of Central African Republic
abstract: Rebels rejected an offer from President François Bozizé that proposed forming a government of national unity, saying that previous agreements with him had been quickly broken.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — As efforts to broker a deal to stop a rebel advance failed, residents of the capital of the Central African Republic were packing up their belongings and fleeing into the country’s vast hinterlands, fearing a major battle between government troops and guerrilla fighters.

headline: Albums from Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale, and the Max Johnson Trio
abstract: “Buddy and Jim” by Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale, and “Elevated Vegetation” by the Max Johnson Trio.
lead_paragraph: BUDDY MILLER AND JIM LAUDERDALE

headline: Revisiting a Beatles Archive
abstract: Henry Grossman took more than 7,000 photos of the Beatles in the mid-1960s. A new book includes about 1,000 of them.
lead_paragraph: Henry Grossman took more than 7,000 photos of the Beatles in the mid-1960s. A new book includes about 1,000 of them.

headline: Big Innovations in Football Are Just Past the End Zone
abstract: Fans may not give football goal posts a second thought, but manufacturers continually tweak products like them to adapt to facilities’ changing needs, budgets and safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: In its home opener in 2005, the Central Florida football team ended a 17-game losing streak with an upset of Marshall. Fans swarmed the field and, in a time-honored tradition, tore down one of the goal posts at the Florida Citrus Bowl in Orlando.

headline: New Frontier for Topics in Science: Social Media
keywords: ['Mars (Planet)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: In surprising numbers, people posted, viewed and searched for science-related topics in 2012, embracing the ability to communicate with others about global subjects in real time.
lead_paragraph: The largest and most sophisticated rover landed safely on Mars and the world’s most famous Moon visitor died, but the space event that most captured the public’s imagination in 2012 involved a journey to Earth.

headline: The Kardashian Family Grows on Twitter
abstract: Kim Kardashian is pregnant with Kanye West’s baby, and the well-wishers and jokers start typing.
lead_paragraph: When Kanye West announced on stage last Sunday that his girlfriend, Kim Kardashian, is pregnant, it came as a surprise, not only to the audience, but reportedly also to Ms. Kardashian as well. So how did the Kardashian clan respond? On Twitter, of course, where they offered their congratulations. And sure enough, #kimye was again a trending hashtag. An E! special must be in this baby’s future.

headline: Obama Won New York City, in Case Anyone Was Wondering
abstract: Official results from the New York City Board of Elections show Mr. Obama won 81 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: However this fiscal cliff thing turns out, President Obama can take heart in one piece of news that broke on Monday: he won the election in New York City.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, Gaza Strip, West Bank and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, Gaza Strip, West Bank and India.

headline: Academy Members Get an Extra Day to Vote
abstract: In another hiccup in the Academy’s revamped calendar, the deadline to submit Oscar nomination ballots was extended a day.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has been having a tough time with deadlines: After extending the time limit for the documentary branch to compile its shortlist in the fall, the Academy is now giving all members an extra day to cast their entire Oscar nominating ballots.

headline: The More Things Change, the More a Band Can Do
abstract: The Golden Palominos backed up the folky singer-songwriters Lianne Smith and Lori Carson at Le Poisson Rouge on Saturday, after a superb opening set by the band Ida.
lead_paragraph: More an apparition than a band, the Golden Palominos have materialized, vanished and reconfigured over the past 30 years, according to the impulses of the drummer Anton Fier, the band’s only constant. The Golden Palominos have been a noise-funk band, a globally tinged pop band, a rock band and a folk-pop band, while their studio albums have featured guest lead vocalists like Michael Stipe of R.E.M. and John Lydon of Public Image Ltd.

headline: Prospecting for Treasure Behind Urban Padlocks
abstract: Many of the archetypes of the reality series “Storage Wars,” a marvel of casting, spill over to the New York spinoff, “Storage Wars: New York,” which has its premiere on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: I moved into my current apartment in November 2001, on the heels of the Sept. 11 attacks, boxing everything up for a move away from downtown Manhattan to an equally spacious but less forgivingly laid out place uptown. As part of the move I exiled some things to a storage outfit in Nassau County, N.Y., and there the pile rested, a ghost whose existence was proved only by the monthly checks I’ve written ever since.

headline: The Return of the Natives
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Children and Childhood', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The first vacation from college is a time for learning and readjustment.
lead_paragraph: STEVEN and Loraine Summer adore their sons Jason, 20, a junior at the University of Maryland, and Ari, 22, a graduate student at the University of Colorado. When the boys returned home in suburban Denver to visit at Thanksgiving, their parents enjoyed the adult conversation and learning about their sons’ career ambitions and new interests.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 31
abstract: A view of the year’s final day in sports, including basketball in the pros, football in the bowls and bike racing in the snow.
lead_paragraph: A view of the year’s final day in sports, including basketball in the pros, football in the bowls and bike racing in the snow.

headline: Revis Focuses on Return, One He Hopes Is With the Jets
abstract: Darrelle Revis, out since Week 3 with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, said he would like to stay with the Jets for the long term.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Darrelle Revis was a helpless spectator as the Jets’ season careened out of control.

headline: A Year of Market Gains, Despite Turmoil
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: Stock markets in Europe and the United States turned out to be good investments in 2012, even as governments battled economic problems that threatened disaster.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, some thought 2012 was destined to be the year that the euro zone — and maybe even the entire European Union — broke up. The banks that supported their governments, and that in turn depended on those same governments for bailouts if they went broke, were deemed to be particularly vulnerable to disaster.

headline: Live From Times Square: New Year’s Eve
abstract: A live broadcast of the New Year’s Eve celebration in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Thinking about spending the last few moments of 2012 in Times Square? Yes, it’s a New York tradition, the first gathering having taken place in 1904. But for the 2012-13 party, it’s probably already too late.

headline: Chief Justice Prods Congress to Resolve Budget Talks and Control National Debt
abstract: Lawmakers could look to the federal judiciary as an example of doing a lot with only a tiny fraction of the country’s total budget, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his annual report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. used his year-end report on the federal judiciary to give Congressional budget negotiators a little nudge.

headline: The Beatles, Seen From Unusual Angles
abstract: The photographer Henry Grossman is releasing “Places I Remember,” a new book of photographs of the Beatles.
lead_paragraph: When Time magazine first asked Henry Grossman to photograph the Beatles, at their American television debut on “The Ed Sullivan Show” in February 1964, he thought of it as just another assignment — a journey into the realm of teenage fads, and less exciting than the sessions he had done with world leaders, actors and opera singers. Mr. Grossman, who was 27 at the time, preferred classical music; at 76, he still shoots production photos for the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Actors, Offstage and Off Guard
abstract: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald describes his candid photographs taken during the shows “Ivanov” and “The Realistic Joneses.”
lead_paragraph: For many actors rehearsal is a place to make mistakes. For Glenn Fitzgerald it’s a place to make art. Starting in 1998, when he took portraits of Nathan Lane and other cast members in Jon Robin Baitz’s “Mizlansky/Zilinsky, or ‘Schmucks,’ ” Mr. Fitzgerald has captured scenes of productions in which he’s appeared.

lead_paragraph: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald talks about photos he’s taken of two shows in which he’s appeared.

headline: Spiritual Landscapes of the Gilded Age
abstract: The new exhibition on Louis C. Tiffany samples the Tiffany Studios’ enormous production of stained-glass windows as well as all kinds of other church-related objects.
lead_paragraph: In 1880, according to a frequently cited report, 4,000 churches were under construction in the United States. This Gilded Age frenzy of ecclesiastical building created a terrific demand for designers who could make houses of worship that were also theaters of spiritually inspiring beauty. And every church seemed to require at least one spectacular stained-glass window to transport the faithful into imaginary realms of transcendental bliss. The man who most famously fulfilled that need was Louis Comfort Tiffany (1848-1933).

headline: Humpback Whales Seek Pairings Based on Size
keywords: ['Research', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Reproduction (Biological)']
abstract: Female humpbacks on the prowl prefer the largest males on the breeding ground, while smaller males gravitate toward smaller females, scientists found.
lead_paragraph: Going underwater with video cameras and sonar, scientists have gained new insights into the mating behavior of humpback whales.

headline: Playing by Heart, With or Without a Score
abstract: The rigid protocol in classical music whereby solo performers are expected to play from memory seems finally to be loosening its hold.
lead_paragraph: It would seem that the filmmaker Michael Haneke, who wrote and directed the wrenching and poignantly acted new French movie “Amour,” is swept away by the mystique of a pianist, alone onstage, conveying mastery and utter oneness with music by playing a great piece from memory. The drama of playing from memory is at the crux of a scene involving the elegant French pianist Alexandre Tharaud, who, portraying himself, has a small but crucial role.

headline: Seasoned With Invention and Irreverence
abstract: At Thirty Acres in Jersey City, innovation surrounds seemingly familiar foods, taken apart and rebuilt in fresh partnerships.
lead_paragraph: ONE school of criticism holds that chefs should faithfully honor any cuisine they pilfer. But there’s an equally valid case for bold, fearless theft. A good pickpocket does not waste time with introductions.

headline: Thirty Acres
abstract: This restaurant challenges your sense of geography, starting with its location.
lead_paragraph: This restaurant challenges your sense of geography, starting with its location.

headline: Added In or Left Out, Fees Remain the Focus
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Business Travel', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: While American Airlines recently incorporated separate fees into base fares, Southwest Airlines seemed to be going in the other direction.
lead_paragraph: IN a move being watched by competitors, American Airlines is experimenting with a new pricing option that eliminates the potential penalty fee for changing flights for customers who pay a little extra for a basic coach ticket.

headline: A Podcast That Has Old-School Smarts
abstract: Julie Klausner’s podcast “How Was Your Week?” is a mix of riffing and interviews that has a literate sensibility.
lead_paragraph: In 2012 I spent more time with comedy podcasts than I did with sitcoms and talk shows combined. It’s not something I would recommend to everyone.

headline: Found Moments
abstract: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald takes photos of shows in which he appears.
lead_paragraph: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald takes photos of shows in which he appears.

headline: Piazza, the Marlin, And a Shared Fixation
abstract: Mike Piazza played five games for the Marlins, in 1998, but his Marlins baseball cards remain objects of desire for a lawyer in California and a student in Miami.
lead_paragraph: One is a corporate lawyer from Southern California with few hobbies and only the mildest interest in sports. The other is a college student from Miami who is less than half his age and has amassed a stash of memorabilia that matches his love of baseball.

headline: A Luminous Kingdom, Awaiting on a Blustery Night
abstract: In “Mikko Nissinen’s Nutcracker,” Mr. Nissinen, Boston Ballet’s artistic director, draws on diverse “Nutcracker” precedents.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — What’s new about Boston Ballet’s new “Nutcracker” is the expensive part: scenery and costumes, both by Robert Perdziola. The dances and the story appear largely the same. This is a shrewd way for any company to proceed: take a production and keep building it. On the day I arrived here, The Boston Globe reported that the production’s attendance and revenues were up.

headline: Enjoying the New Year’s Holiday
abstract: Please remember to celebrate responsibly.
lead_paragraph: Dresden, Germany, the home of Volkswagen’s Transparent Factory, is also the site of a spectacular New Year’s Eve fireworks display. So we’ll take this opportunity to wish everyone a Happy New Year and to remind you that drinking and driving don’t mix. We’ll be off on Tuesday but back with you on Wednesday. If you’re behind the wheel, stay safe and sober.

headline: 12 Foreign Stories From 2012 Worth Revisiting
abstract: There were hundreds of memorable stories from Times foreign correspondents in 2012. Here is a sampling of 12 from across the world.
lead_paragraph: There were hundreds of memorable foreign stories from Times correspondents in 2012. Here is a sampling of 12 from across the world in chronological order.

headline: Announcing the Latest Big Thing
abstract: Don’t be a retrograde loser. This is the newest new normal.
lead_paragraph: These past few weeks, every media outlet on the Internet, from Vogue to CNN, has been commemorating the hottest trends of 2012: donating to Kony 2012, taking placenta pills, wearing peplums, compulsively watching the Weather Channel. The lists go on and on.

headline: The Emancipation of Abe Lincoln
abstract: The Emancipation Proclamation evolved during the Civil War years, as did the thinking of its author.
lead_paragraph: ONE hundred and fifty years ago, on Jan. 1, 1863, Abraham Lincoln presided over the annual White House New Year’s reception. Late that afternoon, he retired to his study to sign the Emancipation Proclamation. When he took up his pen, his hand was shaking from exhaustion. Briefly, he paused — “I do not want it to appear as if I hesitated,” he remarked. Then Lincoln affixed a firm signature to the document.

headline: How Many Slaves Work for You?
abstract: We need a new Emancipation Proclamation to free the millions still held in servitude worldwide.

headline: After Crispy Pig Ears, 10 Trends for 2013
abstract: From long-aged meat to artisanal soft-serve, here are 10 food trends to look for in the new year.
lead_paragraph: IN our newly omnivorous nation, restaurant trends often have the same viral spread and short life span as boy bands — witness 2011’s crispy pig ears and sea buckthorn berries. Eating around the country on reporting trips in 2012, I saw food lovers everywhere embracing new interpretations of farm-to-table and nose-to-tail as fast as they came along.

headline: Hurting Knicks Uncertain of Tuesday’s Lineup
abstract: Carmelo Anthony and Amar’e Stoudemire both practiced Monday, although neither is a lock to start on Tuesday against the Trail Blazers.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks are stepping carefully into the new year, not quite sure just who will be on the court and who will be sitting and watching, when they take on the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.

headline: Pursuing a First Win in the Bowls Since 1949
abstract: If Northwestern beats Mississippi State in the Gator Bowl, it will have ended a nine-game skid in bowls, and Coach Pat Fitzgerald will have more wins than any of his predecessors.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — From the sidelines at a recent practice, Northwestern Coach Pat Fitzgerald looked as if he could have been a player. Fitzgerald, a baby-faced 38-year-old, wore a black, long-sleeved T-shirt and black shorts that revealed muscular calves. He was a bundle of energy, sprinting from player to player during drills, bumping chests and shouting encouragement. Only his clipboard and whistle gave him away.
